"_May_ it be right then," I said, as I rose, deeming it useless to continue a discourse which was all darkness to me; and, besides, sensible that the character of my interlocutor was beyond my penetration; at least, beyond its present reach; and feeling the uncertainty, the vague sense of insecurity, which accompanies a conviction of ignorance.
Me levanté, comprendiendo lo vano de continuar una conversación de la que no comprendía nada, e intuyendo, además, que el carácter de mi interlocutor era superior a mi penetración.
Me sentía indecisa y vacilante, como siempre que se trata de un tema que se ignora.
"Where are you going?"
-¿Adónde va? -A acostar a Adèle.
"To put Adele to bed: it is past her bedtime."
Ya es hora.
"You are afraid of me, because I talk like a Sphynx."
-Me teme usted, porque hablo como la Esfinge.
"Your language is enigmatical, sir: but though I am bewildered, I am certainly not afraid."
-Su lenguaje, señor, es enigmático, en efecto, pero no temo nada.
"You _are_ afraid--your self-love dreads a blunder."
-¡Sí!
Su amor propio le hace temer el llegar a decir desatinos.
"In that sense I do feel apprehensive--I have no wish to talk nonsense."
-Desde luego, reconozco que no deseo hablar de cosas sin sentido común.
"If you did, it would be in such a grave, quiet manner, I should mistake it for sense.
-Aunque sea eso lo que diga, lo expresa de un modo tan sereno y doctoral, que parece que dice cosas con sentido.
Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre?
¿No se ríe usted nunca?
No hace falta que conteste.
Don't trouble yourself to answer--I see you laugh rarely; but you can laugh very merrily: believe me, you are not naturally austere, any more than I am naturally vicious.
Ya he visto que ríe usted muy poco.
Pero puede usted llegar a reír con plena alegría, porque tan austera es usted por naturaleza como yo, por naturaleza, vicioso.
Lowood pesa todavía sobre usted, haciéndole dominar sus sentimientos, sus impresiones y hasta sus modales y sus gestos.

The Lowood constraint still clings to you somewhat; controlling your features, muffling your voice, and restricting your limbs; and you fear in the presence of a man and a brother--or father, or master, or what you will--to smile too gaily, speak too freely, or move too quickly: but, in time, I think you will learn to be natural with me, as I find it impossible to be conventional with you; and then your looks and movements will have more vivacity and variety than they dare offer now.
Teme usted, en presencia de un hombre -padre, persona mayor o lo que sea-, sonreír con excesiva alegría, hablar con demasiada libertad, moverse demasiado vivamente.
Pero confío en que usted, conmigo, aprenderá a ser más natural, ya que a mí me resulta imposible ser convencional con usted.
I see at intervals the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close-set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive is there; were it but free, it would soar cloud-high.
Cuando sea más natural, sus ademanes y sus miradas serán más vivos y más espontáneos.
Su mirada es la de un pájaro enjaulado.
You are still bent on going?"
Cuándo se halle libre, volará sobre las nubes...
¿Qué?
¿Insiste en irse?
"It has struck nine, sir."
-Son más de las nueve, señor.
"Never mind,--wait a minute: Adele is not ready to go to bed yet.
No importa; espere un minuto.
Adèle no tiene ganas de acostarse todavía.
My position, Miss Eyre, with my back to the fire, and my face to the room, favours observation.
La posición en que estoy, de espalda al fuego, me permite observar con facilidad.
While talking to you, I have also occasionally watched Adele (I have my own reasons for thinking her a curious study,--reasons that I may, nay, that I shall, impart to you some day).
He mirado de vez en cuando a Adèle, mientras hablábamos, ya que tengo motivos para creer que es un ser digno de estudio, por razones que algún día le explicaré, señorita...

She pulled out of her box, about ten minutes ago, a little pink silk frock; rapture lit her face as she unfolded it; coquetry runs in her blood, blends with her brains, and seasons the marrow of her bones.
Pues bien, mirándola, la he visto sacar del fondo de su cajita, hace diez minutos, un vestidito de seda rosa, que la ha entusiasmado y despertado sus instintos de coquetería.
'Il faut que je l'essaie!' cried she, 'et a l'instant meme!' and she rushed out of the room.
Enseguida ha dicho: «Il faut que je l'essaie et à Nnstant méme!», y ha salido del cuarto.

She is now with Sophie, undergoing a robing process: in a few minutes she will re-enter; and I know what I shall see,--a miniature of Celine Varens, as she used to appear on the boards at the rising of--But never mind that.
Ahora debe de estar con Sophie, entregada a la operación de probarse el vestido, y de aquí a poco la veremos entrar convertida en una miniatura de Céline Varens, que..., pero esto no interesa.
However, my tenderest feelings are about to receive a shock: such is my presentiment; stay now, to see whether it will be realised."
De todos modos, mis tiernos sentimientos están a punto de experimentar una conmoción.
Aguarde, pues, un momento y veremos si mis palabras se confirman.
Ere long, Adele's little foot was heard tripping across the hall.
A poco sentimos el pisar de los piececitos de Adèle en el vestíbulo.
She entered, transformed as her guardian had predicted.
Entró transformada como su protector había predicho.

A dress of rose-coloured satin, very short, and as full in the skirt as it could be gathered, replaced the brown frock she had previously worn; a wreath of rosebuds circled her forehead; her feet were dressed in silk stockings and small white satin sandals.

Un vestido de color de rosa, muy corto y con mucho vuelo, sustituía al vestido oscuro que llevaba antes; una guirnalda de capullos de rosa ceñía su frente, y calzaba calcetines de seda y unas pequeñas sandalias de raso blanco.
"Est-ce que ma robe va bien?" cried she, bounding forwards; "et mes souliers? et mes bas?
-¿Me sienta bien el vestido?
¿Y los zapatos?
Tenez, je crois que je vais danser!"
¿Y las medias?
¡Voy a bailar un poco!
And spreading out her dress, she chasseed across the room till, having reached Mr. Rochester, she wheeled lightly round before him on tip-toe, then dropped on one knee at his feet, exclaiming--
Y sujetando con las manos el vuelo de su vestido, cruzó la habitación hasta llegar ante Mr.
Rochester, e inclinándose ante él, a imitación de las artistas, hasta arrodillarse, le dijo:
-Muchas gracias por su bondad, Mr.
"Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte;" then rising, she added, "C'est comme cela que maman faisait, n'est-ce pas, monsieur?"
Rochester.
E incorporándose de nuevo, añadió: -Mamá haría lo mismo, ¿verdad?
"Pre-cise-ly!" was the answer; "and, 'comme cela,' she charmed my English gold out of my British breeches' pocket.
-¡Exactamente! -gruñó él-.
¡Y con qué gracia sacaba mi dinero inglés de mi británico bolsillo!
I have been green, too, Miss Eyre,--ay, grass green: not a more vernal tint freshens you now than once freshened me.
Yo también tuve mi primavera, Miss Eyre, y al disiparse me dejó como recuerdo esta florecilla francesa...
My Spring is gone, however, but it has left me that French floweret on my hands, which, in some moods, I would fain be rid of.

Not valuing now the root whence it sprang; having found that it was of a sort which nothing but gold dust could manure, I have but half a liking to the blossom, especially when it looks so artificial as just now.
I keep it and rear it rather on the Roman Catholic principle of expiating numerous sins, great or small, by one good work.
Un poco artificial, pero a la que me siento obligado, acaso en virtud de ese principio de los católicos que procuran expiar sus pecados haciendo alguna buena obra.
I'll explain all this some day.
Algún día me explicaré mejor...
Good-night."
¡Buenas noches!
CHAPTER XV
XV
Mr. Rochester did, on a future occasion, explain it.
Mr.
Rochester se explicó, en efecto.

It was one afternoon, when he chanced to meet me and Adele in the grounds: and while she played with Pilot and her shuttlecock, he asked me to walk up and down a long beech avenue within sight of her.
He then said that she was the daughter of a French opera-dancer, Celine Varens, towards whom he had once cherished what he called a "_grande passion_."
Una tarde nos mandó llamar a Adèle y a mí y, mientras ella jugaba con Piloto, él me llevó a pasear y me explicó que aquella Céline Varens había sido una bailarina francesa que fue su gran pasión.
This passion Celine had professed to return with even superior ardour.
Céline le había asegurado corresponderle con más ardor aún.
He thought himself her idol, ugly as he was: he believed, as he said, that she preferred his "_taille d'athlete_" to the elegance of the Apollo Belvidere.
Él creía ser el ídolo de aquella mujer, pensando que, feo y todo, Céline prefería su taille d'athléte a la elegancia del Apolo de Belvedere.

"And, Miss Eyre, so much was I flattered by this preference of the Gallic sylph for her British gnome, that I installed her in an hotel; gave her a complete establishment of servants, a carriage, cashmeres, diamonds, dentelles, &c.

-De modo, Miss Eyre, que, halagado por aquella preferencia de la sílfide gala hacia el gnomo inglés, la instalé en un hotel, la proporcioné criados, un carruaje y, en resumen, comencé a arruinarme por ella según la costumbre establecida...
In short, I began the process of ruining myself in the received style, like any other spoony.
I had not, it seems, the originality to chalk out a new road to shame and destruction, but trode the old track with stupid exactness not to deviate an inch from the beaten centre.
Ni siquiera tuve la inteligencia de elegir un nuevo modo de arruinarme.
Seguí el habitual, sin desviarme de él ni una pulgada.
I had--as I deserved to have--the fate of all other spoonies.
Y también me ocurrió, como era justo, lo que ocurre a todos en esos casos.

Happening to call one evening when Celine did not expect me, I found her out; but it was a warm night, and I was tired with strolling through Paris, so I sat down in her boudoir; happy to breathe the air consecrated so lately by her presence.
Una noche que Céline no me esperaba, se me ocurrió visitarla, pero había salido.
Me senté a aguardarla en su gabinete, feliz al respirar el aire de su aposento, embalsamado por su aliento...
No,--I exaggerate; I never thought there was any consecrating virtue about her: it was rather a sort of pastille perfume she had left; a scent of musk and amber, than an odour of sanctity.
Pero no, exagero...
Nunca se me ocurrió pensar que el aire estuviera embalsamado por su aliento, sino por una pastilla aromática que ella solía colocar en la habitación y que expandía perfumes de ámbar y almizcle...
Aquel fuerte aroma llegó a sofocarme.
I was just beginning to stifle with the fumes of conservatory flowers and sprinkled essences, when I bethought myself to open the window and step out on to the balcony.
Abrí el balcón.
La noche, iluminada por la luna y por los faroles de gas, era clara, serena...
It was moonlight and gaslight besides, and very still and serene.
En el balcón había una silla o dos.
The balcony was furnished with a chair or two; I sat down, and took out a cigar,--I will take one now, if you will excuse me."
Me senté, encendí un cigarro...
Por cierto que, con su permiso, voy a encender uno ahora...
Here ensued a pause, filled up by the producing and lighting of a cigar; having placed it to his lips and breathed a trail of Havannah incense on the freezing and sunless air, he went on--
Se lo llevó a sus labios y el humo del fragante habano se elevó en el aire frío de aquel día sin sol.

"I liked bonbons too in those days, Miss Eyre, and I was _croquant_--(overlook the barbarism)--_croquant_ chocolate comfits, and smoking alternately, watching meantime the equipages that rolled along the fashionable streets towards the neighbouring opera-house, when in an elegant close carriage drawn by a beautiful pair of English horses, and distinctly seen in the brilliant city-night, I recognised the 'voiture' I had given Celine.
-Entonces, señorita, me gustaban mucho los bombones.

Y he aquí que, mientras, alternándolos con chupadas al cigarro, estaba croquant -¡perdón por el barbarismo!- unos bombones de chocolate y contemplando los elegantes carruajes que se dirigían por la calle hacia la cercana ópera, vi llegar uno, tirado por dos caballos ingleses, en el que reconocí el que regalara a Céline.
She was returning: of course my heart thumped with impatience against the iron rails I leant upon.
Mi bella volvía.
El corazón me latió con impaciencia.

The carriage stopped, as I had expected, at the hotel door; my flame (that is the very word for an opera inamorata) alighted: though muffed in a cloak--an unnecessary encumbrance, by-the-bye, on so warm a June evening--I knew her instantly by her little foot, seen peeping from the skirt of her dress, as she skipped from the carriage-step.

La puerta del hotel se abrió y mi hermosa bajó del coche: la reconocí, a pesar de ir cubierta por un abrigo, innecesario en aquella cálida noche de junio, por sus piececitos que aparecían bajo el vestido.

Bending over the balcony, I was about to murmur 'Mon ange'--in a tone, of course, which should be audible to the ear of love alone--when a figure jumped from the carriage after her; cloaked also; but that was a spurred heel which had rung on the pavement, and that was a hatted head which now passed under the arched _porte cochere_ of the hotel.

Me incliné sobre la barandilla y ya iba a exclamar: «¡Ángel mío!», cuando me detuve al ver otra figura, también envuelta en un gabán, que descendía del coche después de Céline y que pasaba, con ella, bajo la puerta cochera del hotel.
"You never felt jealousy, did you, Miss Eyre?
»¿Nunca ha sentido usted celos, Miss Eyre?
Of course not: I need not ask you; because you never felt love.
Es superfluo preguntarlo.
No los ha sentido, puesto que no ha amado aún.
You have both sentiments yet to experience: your soul sleeps; the shock is yet to be given which shall waken it.
Hay sentimientos que no ha experimentado usted todavía...
You think all existence lapses in as quiet a flow as that in which your youth has hitherto slid away.
Usted imagina que toda la vida fluirá para usted mansamente como hasta ahora.
Floating on with closed eyes and muffled ears, you neither see the rocks bristling not far off in the bed of the flood, nor hear the breakers boil at their base.
Flota usted en la corriente de la vida con los ojos cerrados y los oídos obstruidos, y no ve las rocas que se encuentran al paso.

But I tell you--and you may mark my words--you will come some day to a craggy pass in the channel, where the whole of life's stream will be broken up into whirl and tumult, foam and noise: either you will be dashed to atoms on crag points, or lifted up and borne on by some master-wave into a calmer current--as I am now.

Pero -no lo olvide- le aseguro que vendrá un día en que llegue usted a un lugar del río en que los remolinos de la corriente la arrastren, la golpeen contra los peñascos, en medio de tumultos y peligros, hasta que una gran ola la impulse hacia una nueva corriente más calmada, como me pasa a mí ahora...
"I like this day; I like that sky of steel; I like the sternness and stillness of the world under this frost.
»Me complace este día, me complace este cielo plomizo, me gusta este paisaje helado.

I like Thornfield, its antiquity, its retirement, its old crow-trees and thorn-trees, its grey facade, and lines of dark windows reflecting that metal welkin: and yet how long have I abhorred the very thought of it, shunned it like a great plague-house?
Me gusta Thornfield, por su antigüedad, por su soledad, por sus árboles y sus espinos, por su fachada parda y sus hileras de oscuras ventanas en cuyos cristales se refleja el cielo plomizo...
¡Y a la vez aborrezco hasta el pensamiento de pensar en Thornfield, huyo de él como de una casa apestada!
How I do still abhor--"
¡Cuánto lo aborrezco!
He ground his teeth and was silent: he arrested his step and struck his boot against the hard ground.
Rechinó los dientes y calló.
Some hated thought seemed to have him in its grip, and to hold him so tightly that he could not advance.
Se detuvo un momento y golpeó violentamente con el pie el suelo endurecido por la escarcha.
We were ascending the avenue when he thus paused; the hall was before us.
Íbamos subiendo por una avenida dominada por el edificio.
Lifting his eye to its battlements, he cast over them a glare such as I never saw before or since.
Pain, shame, ire, impatience, disgust, detestation, seemed momentarily to hold a quivering conflict in the large pupil dilating under his ebon eyebrow.

Rochester contemplaba el almenar con una mirada como no le viera hasta entonces, y en la que se reflejaban el dolor, la vergüenza, la ira, la impaciencia, el disgusto y el odio, todo ello brotando simultáneamente.

Wild was the wrestle which should be paramount; but another feeling rose and triumphed: something hard and cynical: self-willed and resolute: it settled his passion and petrified his countenance: he went on--

La ferocidad predominaba en aquella expresión de sus sentimientos, pero al fin otro sentimiento, algo que podría calificarse de duro y cínico, triunfó sobre sus demás pasiones, dominándolas y petrificando su mirada.
"During the moment I was silent, Miss Eyre, I was arranging a point with my destiny.
She stood there, by that beech-trunk--a hag like one of those who appeared to Macbeth on the heath of Forres.
-Durante este rato en que he permanecido silencioso, señorita -continuó-, discutía cierto extremo con mi hado, que se me apareció como una de las brujas de Macbeth.

'You like Thornfield?' she said, lifting her finger; and then she wrote in the air a memento, which ran in lurid hieroglyphics all along the house-front, between the upper and lower row of windows, 'Like it if you can!
«¿Te gusta Thornfield?», me preguntó, mientras trazaba, con sus dedos, jeroglíficas figuras a lo largo de la fachada, desde las ventanas más altas a las más bajas.
Like it if you dare!'
«¿Te atreves a decir que te gusta?»
"'I will like it,' said I; 'I dare like it;' and" (he subjoined moodily) "I will keep my word; I will break obstacles to happiness, to goodness--yes, goodness.
«Me atrevo», contesté...
Y mantendré lo dicho, romperé los obstáculos que se opongan a la felicidad y a la bondad..., sí, a la bondad...

I wish to be a better man than I have been, than I am; as Job's leviathan broke the spear, the dart, and the habergeon, hindrances which others count as iron and brass, I will esteem but straw and rotten wood."
Quiero ser un hombre mejor de lo que he sido...
Adele here ran before him with her shuttlecock.
Adèle apareció en aquel momento.
"Away!" he cried harshly; "keep at a distance, child; or go in to Sophie!"
Rochester gritó con rudeza: -¡No te acerques, niña; vete con Sophie!
Continuing then to pursue his walk in silence, I ventured to recall him to the point whence he had abruptly diverged-- "Did you leave the balcony, sir," I asked, "when Mdlle.
Varens entered?"
Yo traté de conducirle al punto en que había interrumpido su relato. -¿Se quitó usted del balcón cuando entró aquella señorita?

I almost expected a rebuff for this hardly well-timed question, but, on the contrary, waking out of his scowling abstraction, he turned his eyes towards me, and the shade seemed to clear off his brow.

Esperaba una contestación violenta a una manera tan inoportuna de reanudar la conversación, pero, por el contrario, salió de su abstracción y me miró sin aquella expresión sombría que antes tuvieran sus ojos.
"Oh, I had forgotten Celine!
Well, to resume.
-¡Me había olvidado de Céline!

When I saw my charmer thus come in accompanied by a cavalier, I seemed to hear a hiss, and the green snake of jealousy, rising on undulating coils from the moonlit balcony, glided within my waistcoat, and ate its way in two minutes to my heart's core.
Pues bien, cuando la vi acompañada de un caballero, me pareció escuchar el silbido de un reptil, y la serpiente de los celos, a través de mis carnes, penetró hasta el fondo de mi corazón.
Strange!" he exclaimed, suddenly starting again from the point.
¡Qué raro es -exclamó Mr.

"Strange that I should choose you for the confidant of all this, young lady; passing strange that you should listen to me quietly, as if it were the most usual thing in the world for a man like me to tell stories of his opera-mistresses to a quaint, inexperienced girl like you!
Rochester de pronto- que yo la haya elegido a usted por confidente, jovencita!
Y más raro aún que usted me escuche con esa serenidad, como si fuera lo más corriente del mundo que un hombre cuente cosas de su querida a una muchacha inexperta.
But the last singularity explains the first, as I intimated once before: you, with your gravity, considerateness, and caution were made to be the recipient of secrets.
Pero la última singularidad explica la primera, como ya le dije una vez: usted, con su seriedad, su prudencia y su buen juicio, está hecha como a la medida para ser depositaria de confidencias.
Besides, I know what sort of a mind I have placed in communication with my own: I know it is one not liable to take infection: it is a peculiar mind: it is a unique one.
Además, conozco la clase de espíritu con el que comunico, y estoy seguro de que no le contagiaré ninguna maldad.
Happily I do not mean to harm it: but, if I did, it would not take harm from me.
Es un espíritu especial, acaso único.
The more you and I converse, the better; for while I cannot blight you, you may refresh me."
Las maldades que le cuente no la infestarán y, en cambio, el confesárselas me alivia...
After this digression he proceeded--
Después de aquella disgregación continuó:
"I remained in the balcony.
'They will come to her boudoir, no doubt,' thought I: 'let me prepare an ambush.'
-Continué en el balcón, suponiendo que subirían al gabinete y que desde mi puesto podría verles y oírles.

So putting my hand in through the open window, I drew the curtain over it, leaving only an opening through which I could take observations; then I closed the casement, all but a chink just wide enough to furnish an outlet to lovers' whispered vows: then I stole back to my chair; and as I resumed it the pair came in.
Corrí las cortinas del balcón, dejando el resquicio suficiente para ver, y entorné las puertas, a fin de poderles oír.
My eye was quickly at the aperture.
Entonces volví a sentarme.
Como esperaba, la pareja subió al gabinete.
Celine's chamber-maid entered, lit a lamp, left it on the table, and withdrew.
La doncella de Céline llevó una lámpara, la dejó sobre una mesa y se retiró.

The couple were thus revealed to me clearly: both removed their cloaks, and there was 'the Varens,' shining in satin and jewels,--my gifts of course,--and there was her companion in an officer's uniform; and I knew him for a young roue of a vicomte--a brainless and vicious youth whom I had sometimes met in society, and had never thought of hating because I despised him so absolutely.
Ambos se quitaron los abrigos y Céline apareció deslumbrante de sedas y joyas -regalos míos, por supuesto-...
Él era un oficial vestido de uniforme, un bellaco de vizconde, un joven disoluto y vacío de mollera, a quien yo conociera en sociedad y en el que nunca pensara sino para despreciarle.
On recognising him, the fang of the snake Jealousy was instantly broken; because at the same moment my love for Celine sank under an extinguisher.
Al reconocerle, la serpiente de los celos dejó de morder mi corazón, porque mi amor por Céline se había disipado instantáneamente.
A woman who could betray me for such a rival was not worth contending for; she deserved only scorn; less, however, than I, who had been her dupe.
Una mujer que me traicionaba con un rival como aquél, no era digna de afecto.
"They began to talk; their conversation eased me completely: frivolous, mercenary, heartless, and senseless, it was rather calculated to weary than enrage a listener.
»Comenzaron a hablar: su conversación era tan vulgar, insípida y estúpida que más bien aburría que animaba a escuchar.
A card of mine lay on the table; this being perceived, brought my name under discussion.
En la mesa había una tarjeta mía y ello me convirtió en tema de su charla.

Neither of them possessed energy or wit to belabour me soundly, but they insulted me as coarsely as they could in their little way: especially Celine, who even waxed rather brilliant on my personal defects--deformities she termed them.
Ninguno de ellos poseía bastante capacidad para ofenderme de un modo profundo, pero me insultaron cuanto pudieron a su mezquina manera, sobre todo Céline, que hizo hincapié en mis defectos físicos.

Now it had been her custom to launch out into fervent admiration of what she called my '_beaute male_:' wherein she differed diametrically from you, who told me point-blank, at the second interview, that you did not think me handsome.
¡Y ante mí se mostraba ferviente admiradora de lo que calificaba mi belleza varonil!...
En eso difería diametralmente de usted, que en nuestra segunda entrevista me dijo francamente que le parecía feo.
The contrast struck me at the time and--"
El contraste me chocó tanto que...
Adele here came running up again.
Adèle llegó corriendo otra vez.
"Monsieur, John has just been to say that your agent has called and wishes to see you."
-John dice que ha llegado el administrador y que desea verle.
"Ah! in that case I must abridge.
-Bien: hay que abreviar.

Opening the window, I walked in upon them; liberated Celine from my protection; gave her notice to vacate her hotel; offered her a purse for immediate exigencies; disregarded screams, hysterics, prayers, protestations, convulsions; made an appointment with the vicomte for a meeting at the Bois de Boulogne.
Abrí el balcón, entré en el gabinete, notifiqué a Céline que le retiraba mi protección, y la conminé a abandonar el hotel, ofreciéndola una cantidad para sus necesidades inmediatas.
No hice caso alguno de sus histerismos, súplicas, protestas y ademanes trágicos.
Next morning I had the pleasure of encountering him; left a bullet in one of his poor etiolated arms, feeble as the wing of a chicken in the pip, and then thought I had done with the whole crew.
Me cité con el vizconde para el día siguiente, en el bosque de Boulogne, y tuve el placer de alojarle una bala en uno de sus brazos, más débiles que las alas de un pollito.

But unluckily the Varens, six months before, had given me this filette Adele, who, she affirmed, was my daughter; and perhaps she may be, though I see no proofs of such grim paternity written in her countenance: Pilot is more like me than she.
Pero desgraciadamente, la Varens, a los seis meses, dio a luz esa muchachita, Adèle, asegurando que era hija mía.
Acaso sea cierto, aunque no veo en sus rasgos semejanza alguna conmigo.
Piloto se me parece más.
Some years after I had broken with the mother, she abandoned her child, and ran away to Italy with a musician or singer.
Años después de haber roto yo con su madre, ésta abandonó a la niña y se fue a Italia con un músico o cantante, no sé qué...

I acknowledged no natural claim on Adele's part to be supported by me, nor do I now acknowledge any, for I am not her father; but hearing that she was quite destitute, I e'en took the poor thing out of the slime and mud of Paris, and transplanted it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden.

Adèle no tiene derecho alguno a que yo la proteja, porque no creo ser su padre, pero al saber que la pobrecita estaba abandonada, la recogí del fango de París y la traje aquí, para que creciera en el limpio ambiente del campo inglés.

Mrs. Fairfax found you to train it; but now you know that it is the illegitimate offspring of a French opera-girl, you will perhaps think differently of your post and protegee: you will be coming to me some day with notice that you have found another place--that you beg me to look out for a new governess, &c.--Eh?"

Y ahora que sabe usted que es la hija ilegítima de una bailarina francesa, acaso no le agrade tanto el cargo que ejerce con ella y venga cualquier día a notificarne que ha encontrado usted otro empleo, que me busque otra institutriz, etcétera.
-No.

"No: Adele is not answerable for either her mother's faults or yours: I have a regard for her; and now that I know she is, in a sense, parentless--forsaken by her mother and disowned by you, sir--I shall cling closer to her than before.
Adèle no es responsable de las faltas de su madre ni de las de usted.
Yo tengo un deber respecto a ella y ahora que sé que es, hasta cierto punto, huérfana -ya que su madre la olvida y usted no la reconoce-, me siento más dispuesta a seguir cumpliéndolo.
How could I possibly prefer the spoilt pet of a wealthy family, who would hate her governess as a nuisance, to a lonely little orphan, who leans towards her as a friend?"
¿Cómo he de preferir ser institutriz en alguna familia donde constituya un enojo más que otra cosa, que ser la amiga de una huerfanita?
"Oh, that is the light in which you view it!
-Si lo ve usted así...
Well, I must go in now; and you too: it darkens."
Vaya, regresemos.
Está oscureciendo ya.
But I stayed out a few minutes longer with Adele and Pilot--ran a race with her, and played a game of battledore and shuttlecock.
Yo me entretuve algunos minutos más con la niña y el perro, y corrí y jugué con ellos.

When we went in, and I had removed her bonnet and coat, I took her on my knee; kept her there an hour, allowing her to prattle as she liked: not rebuking even some little freedoms and trivialities into which she was apt to stray when much noticed, and which betrayed in her a superficiality of character, inherited probably from her mother, hardly congenial to an English mind.

Cuando volvimos a casa y la quité el sombrero y el abrigo, la hice sentar en mis rodillas y durante una hora charlé con ella de las cosas que le complacían y que eran, principalmente, frivolidades sin sustancia, probable herencia de su madre y difíciles de concebir para una mentalidad inglesa.
Still she had her merits; and I was disposed to appreciate all that was good in her to the utmost.
Con todo, la niña tenía algunos méritos y yo estaba dispuesta a reconocerlos.
I sought in her countenance and features a likeness to Mr. Rochester, but found none: no trait, no turn of expression announced relationship.
Busqué en sus facciones alguna semejanza con Mr.
Rochester, pero no hallé ninguna.
It was a pity: if she could but have been proved to resemble him, he would have thought more of her.
Era lamentable, porque de haber podido probarle cierto parecido, él se hubiera preocupado más de la pequeña.
It was not till after I had withdrawn to my own chamber for the night, that I steadily reviewed the tale Mr. Rochester had told me.
Cuando me retiré a mi habitación, por la noche, pensé en la narración que Mr.
Rochester me había hecho.

As he had said, there was probably nothing at all extraordinary in the substance of the narrative itself: a wealthy Englishman's passion for a French dancer, and her treachery to him, were every-day matters enough, no doubt, in society; but there was something decidedly strange in the paroxysm of emotion which had suddenly seized him when he was in the act of expressing the present contentment of his mood, and his newly revived pleasure in the old hall and its environs.
Como él dijera, nada había de extraordinario en tal historia: los amores de un inglés con una bailarina francesa y la traición de ella eran cosa muy corriente.
Pero había algo extraño en la emoción que él experimentara cuando se refirió al viejo palacio.
I meditated wonderingly on this incident; but gradually quitting it, as I found it for the present inexplicable, I turned to the consideration of my master's manner to myself.
Gradualmente pasé, de meditar en aquel incidente, a pensar en la confianza que el dueño de la casa me manifestaba.
The confidence he had thought fit to repose in me seemed a tribute to my discretion: I regarded and accepted it as such.
Considerándola como un tributo a mi discreción, la acepté en tal sentido.
His deportment had now for some weeks been more uniform towards me than at the first.
Su comportamiento conmigo durante las últimas semanas era menos desigual que al principio.
No mostraba altanería y cuando nos veíamos parecía alegrarse.

I never seemed in his way; he did not take fits of chilling hauteur: when he met me unexpectedly, the encounter seemed welcome; he had always a word and sometimes a smile for me: when summoned by formal invitation to his presence, I was honoured by a cordiality of reception that made me feel I really possessed the power to amuse him, and that these evening conferences were sought as much for his pleasure as for my benefit.
Siempre reservaba para mí una palabra amable y una sonrisa.

Cuando me invitaba a reunirme con él, me acogía con una cordialidad que me llevaba a pensar que realmente debía de poseer la facultad de divertirle y que aquellas conversaciones durante las veladas debían de agradarle a él tanto como a mí.
I, indeed, talked comparatively little, but I heard him talk with relish.
Aunque yo solía hablar muy poco, le escuchaba con agrado.
Él, por naturaleza, era comunicativo y le gustaba abrir ante mi espíritu ignorante del mundo muchos horizontes sobre sus costumbres y escenas.

It was his nature to be communicative; he liked to open to a mind unacquainted with the world glimpses of its scenes and ways (I do not mean its corrupt scenes and wicked ways, but such as derived their interest from the great scale on which they were acted, the strange novelty by which they were characterised); and I had a keen delight in receiving the new ideas he offered, in imagining the new pictures he portrayed, and following him in thought through the new regions he disclosed, never startled or troubled by one noxious allusion.
No precisamente escenas de corrupción y costumbres viciosas, sino cosas cuyo interés residía en la novedad que para mí presentaban.
Yo experimentaba placer escuchando las ideas que él me sugería, imaginando los cuadros que él me pintaba, y siguiéndole con la imaginación a las nuevas regiones que extendía ante mi mente.
The ease of his manner freed me from painful restraint: the friendly frankness, as correct as cordial, with which he treated me, drew me to him.
La espontaneidad de sus maneras me libró de la molestia de sentirme cohibida, y la amistosa franqueza, tan correcta como cordial, con que me trataba, me impresionó.
I felt at times as if he were my relation rather than my master: yet he was imperious sometimes still; but I did not mind that; I saw it was his way.
Al poco tiempo experimentaba la impresión de que Rochester era más bien un amigo que un amo, aunque a veces me tratara con imperio.
Pero no me molestaba, porque comprendía que tal era su costumbre.

So happy, so gratified did I become with this new interest added to life, that I ceased to pine after kindred: my thin crescent-destiny seemed to enlarge; the blanks of existence were filled up; my bodily health improved; I gathered flesh and strength.
Sintiéndome más feliz, más interesada en la vida, mejor tratada, me encontraba más a gusto de lo habitual.
Los vacíos de mi vida se llenaban y, físicamente, también mejoré: estaba más gruesa y más fuerte.
And was Mr. Rochester now ugly in my eyes?
¿Me parecía feo ahora Mr.
Rochester?
No, reader: gratitude, and many associations, all pleasurable and genial, made his face the object I best liked to see; his presence in a room was more cheering than the brightest fire.
No, lector, la gratitud, unida a cuanto veía en él, todo bueno y genial, hacían que su rostro se me figurara lo más agradable del mundo.
Su presencia en una habitación parecía alegrar y caldear la atmósfera mejor que el más brillante fuego.
Yet I had not forgotten his faults; indeed, I could not, for he brought them frequently before me.
Ello no significaba que yo olvidase sus defectos, tanto más cuanto que los mostraba con frecuencia.
He was proud, sardonic, harsh to inferiority of every description: in my secret soul I knew that his great kindness to me was balanced by unjust severity to many others.
Era orgulloso y sarcástico y, en mi interior, yo reconocía que su mucha amabilidad hacia mí estaba compensada por su mucha severidad hacia los demás.

He was moody, too; unaccountably so; I more than once, when sent for to read to him, found him sitting in his library alone, with his head bent on his folded arms; and, when he looked up, a morose, almost a malignant, scowl blackened his features.
Estaba generalmente malhumorado.
Con frecuencia, cuando me enviaba a buscar, le encontraba en la biblioteca, solo, con la cabeza apoyada sobre sus brazos cruzados.
But I believed that his moodiness, his harshness, and his former faults of morality (I say _former_, for now he seemed corrected of them) had their source in some cruel cross of fate.
Y cuando la levantaba, un gesto melancólico, casi maligno, ensombrecía sus facciones.
Pero yo creía que su mal humor, su aspereza y sus anteriores vicios -anteriores, porque ahora parecía haberlos corregido- eran el resultado de alguna injusticia con que el destino le abrumara.
I believed he was naturally a man of better tendencies, higher principles, and purer tastes than such as circumstances had developed, education instilled, or destiny encouraged.
Yo entendía que, por naturaleza, Rochester era un hombre de buenas inclinaciones, elevados principios y delicados gestos, que las circunstancias, la educación y el destino habían desviado.
I thought there were excellent materials in him; though for the present they hung together somewhat spoiled and tangled.
I cannot deny that I grieved for his grief, whatever that was, and would have given much to assuage it.
Su pena, cualquiera que fuese, me apenaba a mí y hubiera dado cualquier cosa por poder mitigarla.

Though I had now extinguished my candle and was laid down in bed, I could not sleep for thinking of his look when he paused in the avenue, and told how his destiny had risen up before him, and dared him to be happy at Thornfield.
Aquella noche, en mi lecho, con la luz ya apagada, no conseguía dormir pensando en la mirada que Rochester dirigiera a la casa, y me preguntaba si él no podría llegar a ser feliz en Thornfield.
"Why not?"
I asked myself.
«¿Por qué no? -me preguntaba-.
"What alienates him from the house?
¿Qué le separa de este lugar?
Will he leave it again soon?
¿Por qué lo abandona siempre tan pronto?
Mrs.
Mrs. Fairfax said he seldom stayed here longer than a fortnight at a time; and he has now been resident eight weeks.
Fairfax dice que nunca pasa aquí más de quince días y ahora lleva, sin embargo, ocho semanas.
Sería lamentable que se marchase.
If he does go, the change will be doleful.
Suppose he should be absent spring, summer, and autumn: how joyless sunshine and fine days will seem!"
¡Qué tristes días, a pesar del sol radiante y el cielo despejado, me esperan en la primavera, en el verano y el otoño venideros, si él no está!»
I hardly know whether I had slept or not after this musing; at any rate, I started wide awake on hearing a vague murmur, peculiar and lugubrious, which sounded, I thought, just above me.
Después de este pensamiento, no sé si me dormí o no.
Lo cierto es que desperté oyendo un vago murmullo, extraño y lúgubre, que me pareció sonar precisamente encima de mí.
I wished I had kept my candle burning: the night was drearily dark; my spirits were depressed.
Hubiese querido tener encendida la vela, porque la noche era terriblemente oscura.
Me sentí deprimida y asustada.
I rose and sat up in bed, listening.
Me senté en el lecho y escuché.
The sound was hushed.
El murmullo se había apagado.
I tried again to sleep; but my heart beat anxiously: my inward tranquillity was broken.
Traté otra vez de dormirme, pero mi corazón latía tumultuosamente y mi serenidad había desaparecido.
The clock, far down in the hall, struck two.
El lejano reloj del vestíbulo dio las dos.
Just then it seemed my chamber-door was touched; as if fingers had swept the panels in groping a way along the dark gallery outside.
Creí percibir que unos dedos arañaban la puerta de mi dormitorio, como si buscasen a tientas una salida en la galería.
I said, "Who is there?"
Exclamé: -¿Quién es?
Nothing answered.
Nadie contestó.
I was chilled with fear.
Sentí un escalofrío de temor.

All at once I remembered that it might be Pilot, who, when the kitchen- door chanced to be left open, not unfrequently found his way up to the threshold of Mr. Rochester's chamber: I had seen him lying there myself in the mornings.
Recordé de pronto que, a veces, Piloto, cuando la puerta de la cocina quedaba abierta, salía y buscaba en la oscuridad el cuarto de su amor, en cuyo umbral le había visto durmiendo algunas mañanas.
The idea calmed me somewhat: I lay down.
Tal pensamiento me tranquilizó.
Silence composes the nerves; and as an unbroken hush now reigned again through the whole house, I began to feel the return of slumber.
But it was not fated that I should sleep that night.
Me tendí en el lecho y ya comenzaba a dormirme otra vez cuando un nuevo incidente vino a desvelarme.
A dream had scarcely approached my ear, when it fled affrighted, scared by a marrow-freezing incident enough.
This was a demoniac laugh--low, suppressed, and deep--uttered, as it seemed, at the very keyhole of my chamber door.
Esta vez era una risa casi demoníaca: baja, reprimida y que sonaba, según me pareció, a través del agujero de la cerradura de mi puerta.

The head of my bed was near the door, and I thought at first the goblin-laugher stood at my bedside--or rather, crouched by my pillow: but I rose, looked round, and could see nothing; while, as I still gazed, the unnatural sound was reiterated: and I knew it came from behind the panels.
La cabecera de mi cama estaba próxima a la puerta.
Al principio pensé que algún duendecillo burlón estaba al lado de mi lecho, o quizá en mi misma almohada.
Me levanté y no vi nada.
Aún estaba mirando, cuando el sonido se repitió, viniendo del otro lado de la puerta.
My first impulse was to rise and fasten the bolt; my next, again to cry out,
Mi primer impulso fue echar el cerrojo.
El segundo preguntar otra vez:
"Who is there?"
-¿Quién es?
Something gurgled and moaned.
Sentí una especie de gruñido.
Ere long, steps retreated up the gallery towards the third-storey staircase: a door had lately been made to shut in that staircase; I heard it open and close, and all was still.
Luego oí pasos en la escalera del tercer piso y el abrir y cerrar de una puerta que recientemente se había colocado al final de aquella escalera.
"Was that Grace Poole? and is she possessed with a devil?" thought I. Impossible now to remain longer by myself: I must go to Mrs. Fairfax.
«¿Será Grace Poole y estará poseída del diablo?», pensé.
Imposible seguir más tiempo sola.
Resolví reunirme con Mrs.
Fairfax.
I hurried on my frock and a shawl; I withdrew the bolt and opened the door with a trembling hand.
Me puse un vestido y un chal y con temblorosa mano abrí la puerta.
There was a candle burning just outside, and on the matting in the gallery.
En la estera de la galería alguien había dejado una bujía encendida.

I was surprised at this circumstance: but still more was I amazed to perceive the air quite dim, as if filled with smoke; and, while looking to the right hand and left, to find whence these blue wreaths issued, I became further aware of a strong smell of burning.
Me sorprendió aquella circunstancia, y mi extrañeza creció cuando noté que había un humo sofocante.
Mientras miraba a derecha e izquierda buscando el origen de aquella humareda, percibí también un fuerte olor a quemado.
Something creaked: it was a door ajar; and that door was Mr. Rochester's, and the smoke rushed in a cloud from thence.
De la puerta entornada del cuarto de Mr.
Rochester salían espesas nubes de humo.
I thought no more of Mrs. Fairfax; I thought no more of Grace Poole, or the laugh: in an instant, I was within the chamber.
Ya no pensé más en el ama de llaves, ni en Grace Poole, ni en las extrañas risas.
Tongues of flame darted round the bed: the curtains were on fire.
En un instante me hallé dentro de la alcoba.
In the midst of blaze and vapour, Mr. Rochester lay stretched motionless, in deep sleep.
El lecho estaba envuelto en llamas, sus cortinas ardían y bajo ellas, profundamente dormido e inmóvil, reposaba Mr.
Rochester.
"Wake! wake!"
-¡Despierte! -grité.
I cried.
I shook him, but he only murmured and turned: the smoke had stupefied him.
Apenas se volvió y sólo murmuró algo ininteligible.
El humo le había hecho desvanecerse.
Not a moment could be lost: the very sheets were kindling, I rushed to his basin and ewer; fortunately, one was wide and the other deep, and both were filled with water.
No se podía perder ni un segundo.
Corrí hacia el lavabo: el jarro y la palangana estaban llenos de agua.

I heaved them up, deluged the bed and its occupant, flew back to my own room, brought my own water-jug, baptized the couch afresh, and, by God's aid, succeeded in extinguishing the flames which were devouring it.
Los vacié sobre el lecho y sobre su ocupante, corrí a mi alcoba, cogí mi jarro y mi jofaina, los vertí sobre el lecho y, con la ayuda de Dios, logré extinguir las llamas que lo devoraban.

The hiss of the quenched element, the breakage of a pitcher which I flung from my hand when I had emptied it, and, above all, the splash of the shower-bath I had liberally bestowed, roused Mr. Rochester at last.
El baño con que había obsequiado pródigamente a Mr.
Rochester le hizo volver en sí.
Though it was now dark, I knew he was awake; because I heard him fulminating strange anathemas at finding himself lying in a pool of water.
Aunque, al apagarse el fuego la habitación estaba a oscuras, comprendí que se había despertado al oírle fulminar extraordinarias maldiciones contra quien le hiciera nadar en agua.
"Is there a flood?" he cried.
-¿Qué es esto, una inundación? -rugió.
"No, sir," I answered; "but there has been a fire: get up, do; you are quenched now; I will fetch you a candle."
-No, señor -repuse-, había estallado un incendio.
Espere: voy a traer una vela.
"In the name of all the elves in Christendom, is that Jane Eyre?" he demanded.
-¡Por todos los diablos del infierno, que esa es Jane Eyre!
"What have you done with me, witch, sorceress?
¿Qué ha hecho usted conmigo, bruja?
Who is in the room besides you?
¿Quién está con usted en la habitación?
Have you plotted to drown me?"
¿Se proponían ahogarme?
"I will fetch you a candle, sir; and, in Heaven's name, get up.
-Voy por una luz, señor -insistí-.
Somebody has plotted something: you cannot too soon find out who and what it is."
No sé lo que ha pasado.
"There!
I am up now; but at your peril you fetch a candle yet: wait two minutes till I get into some dry garments, if any dry there be--yes, here is my dressing-gown.
-Espere un minuto, a ver si encuentro alguna ropa seca si es que queda.
¡Sí!
Now run!"
Ya puede usted traer la vela.
I did run; I brought the candle which still remained in the gallery.
Cogí la luz que estaba en el suelo de la galería.
He took it from my hand, held it up, and surveyed the bed, all blackened and scorched, the sheets drenched, the carpet round swimming in water.
Él la tomó de mis manos, examinó el lecho quemado, las sábanas empapadas, la alfombra llena de agua.
"What is it? and who did it?" he asked.
-¿Qué ha ocurrido? -preguntó.

I briefly related to him what had transpired: the strange laugh I had heard in the gallery: the step ascending to the third storey; the smoke,--the smell of fire which had conducted me to his room; in what state I had found matters there, and how I had deluged him with all the water I could lay hands on.

Le relaté brevemente lo que sabía: la extraña risa en la galería, los pasos en la escalera del tercer piso, el olor a quemado que me condujo hasta su cuarto, el estado en que le había encontrado y cómo le anegara con cuanta agua pude hallar a mano.
He listened very gravely; his face, as I went on, expressed more concern than astonishment; he did not immediately speak when I had concluded.
Me atendió con más interés que sorpresa y cuando concluí permaneció callado.
"Shall I call Mrs. Fairfax?"
-¿Llamo a Mrs.
I asked.
Fairfax? -pregunté.
"Mrs. Fairfax?
No; what the deuce would you call her for?
-¿Para qué diablo va usted a llamarla?
What can she do?
Let her sleep unmolested."
No la moleste.
"Then I will fetch Leah, and wake John and his wife."
-¿Voy a buscar a Leah, o a John y a su mujer?
"Not at all: just be still.
You have a shawl on.
-No hace falta.
Siéntese en esa butaca y póngase mi abrigo si tiene frío con ese chal que lleva.
If you are not warm enough, you may take my cloak yonder; wrap it about you, and sit down in the arm-chair: there,--I will put it on.
Ahora coloque los pies en este taburete para no mojárselos.
Now place your feet on the stool, to keep them out of the wet.
I am going to leave you a few minutes.
Me voy; vuelvo dentro de unos minutos.
I shall take the candle.
Me llevaré la luz.
Remain where you are till I return; be as still as a mouse.
Estese aquí, quietecita como una muerta, hasta que yo vuelva.
I must pay a visit to the second storey.
Tengo que hacer una visita al piso de arriba.
Don't move, remember, or call any one."
No se mueva ni llame a nadie.
He went: I watched the light withdraw.
Salió.
He passed up the gallery very softly, unclosed the staircase door with as little noise as possible, shut it after him, and the last ray vanished.
Se deslizó por la galería sin hacer ruido, abrió con sigilo la puerta de la escalera, la cerró tras sí y la luz que llevaba se desvaneció.
I was left in total darkness.
Quedé en absoluta oscuridad.
I listened for some noise, but heard nothing.
Puse oído atento, pero no percibí rumor alguno.
A very long time elapsed.
Pasó mucho tiempo.
I grew weary: it was cold, in spite of the cloak; and then I did not see the use of staying, as I was not to rouse the house.
Yo sentía frío a pesar del abrigo, y ya estaba a punto de desobedecer las órdenes de Mr.
I was on the point of risking Mr. Rochester's displeasure by disobeying his orders, when the light once more gleamed dimly on the gallery wall, and I heard his unshod feet tread the matting.
Rochester e irme, a riesgo de incurrir en su desagrado, cuando vi reaparecer la luz proyectándose en los muros de la galería y sentí pasos sobre la estera.
"I hope it is he," thought I, "and not something worse."
«Confiemos en que sea él y no algo peor», pensé.
He re-entered, pale and very gloomy.
Rochester entró, pálido y sombrío.
"I have found it all out," said he, setting his candle down on the washstand; "it is as I thought."
Puso la luz sobre el lavabo. -Ya sé de lo que se trata -murmuró-.
Es lo que yo me había figurado.
"How, sir?"
-¿Qué era, señor?
He made no reply, but stood with his arms folded, looking on the ground.
No contestó.
Permaneció con los brazos cruzados, mirando al suelo.
At the end of a few minutes he inquired in rather a peculiar tone--
Al cabo de algunos instantes me dijo:
"I forget whether you said you saw anything when you opened your chamber door."
-¿Vio usted algo de particular cuando abrió la puerta de su cuarto?
"No, sir, only the candlestick on the ground."
-No, señor.
Sólo la bujía en el suelo.
"But you heard an odd laugh?
-¿Pero no oyó usted una risa rara?
You have heard that laugh before, I should think, or something like it?"
¿No la había oído antes de ahora?
"Yes, sir: there is a woman who sews here, called Grace Poole,--she laughs in that way.
She is a singular person."
-Sí, señor, y quien se ríe así es Grace Poole, una mujer muy extraña.
"Just so.
Grace Poole--you have guessed it.
She is, as you say, singular--very.
-Exacto, Grace Poole es, como usted dice, muy extraña.
Well, I shall reflect on the subject.
Pensaré en el asunto.
Meantime, I am glad that you are the only person, besides myself, acquainted with the precise details of to-night's incident.
Me alegro mucho de que sólo usted y yo sepamos los detalles de este incidente.
You are no talking fool: say nothing about it.
No diga nada de ello a nadie.
I will account for this state of affairs" (pointing to the bed): "and now return to your own room.
Yo explicaré esto -añadió señalando el lecho quemado-.
Ahora vuélvase a su cuarto.
I shall do very well on the sofa in the library for the rest of the night.
Yo puedo pasar muy bien la noche en el sofá de la biblioteca.
It is near four:--in two hours the servants will be up."
Son casi las cuatro y de aquí a dos horas los criados se levantarán.
"Good-night, then, sir," said I, departing.
-Entonces, buenas noches, señor-dije, saliendo.
He seemed surprised--very inconsistently so, as he had just told me to go.
Pareció sorprenderse, cosa asombrosa, porque él mismo me había dicho que me fuera.
"What!" he exclaimed, "are you quitting me already, and in that way?"
-¿Me deja usted de este modo? -exclamó.
"You said I might go, sir."
-Usted me lo ha mandado, señor.
"But not without taking leave; not without a word or two of acknowledgment and good-will: not, in short, in that brief, dry fashion.
-Pero no así; no sin una palabra de agradecimiento hacia usted, que me ha salvado de una muerte horrible...
Why, you have saved my life!--snatched me from a horrible and excruciating death! and you walk past me as if we were mutual strangers!
At least shake hands."
Al menos, permítame estrecharle la mano.
He held out his hand; I gave him mine: he took it first in one, them in both his own.
Le tendí la mano y él la estrechó primero con una de las suyas y luego con ambas.
"You have saved my life: I have a pleasure in owing you so immense a debt.
-Me ha salvado usted la vida y me satisface tener con usted una deuda tan grande.
I cannot say more.
No puedo decir más.
Nothing else that has being would have been tolerable to me in the character of creditor for such an obligation: but you: it is different;--I feel your benefits no burden, Jane."
Con cualquier otra persona, semejante deuda representaría para mí una carga intolerable, pero con usted es distinto, Jane.
Sus beneficios no se hacen abrumadores.
He paused; gazed at me: words almost visible trembled on his lips,--but his voice was checked.
Calló y me miró.
Se notaba que sus labios querían proferir alguna palabra más, pero se contuvo.
"Good-night again, sir.
-Buenas noches, señor.
There is no debt, benefit, burden, obligation, in the case."
Y conste que no hay caso de deuda, beneficio, obligación ni peso alguno.

"I knew," he continued, "you would do me good in some way, at some time;--I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you: their expression and smile did not"--(again he stopped)--"did not" (he proceeded hastily) "strike delight to my very inmost heart so for nothing.
-Experimento la sensación -continuó él- de que usted ejerce algún buen influjo sobre mí.
Lo adiviné cuando la vi por vez primera...
People talk of natural sympathies; I have heard of good genii: there are grains of truth in the wildest fable.
La gente dice que hay simpatías espontáneas; también he oído hablar de buenos genios...
En esa leyenda hay algunos puntos de verdad.
My cherished preserver, goodnight!"
Querida bienhechora mía: buenas noches.
Strange energy was in his voice, strange fire in his look.
En su voz vibraba una inusitada energía y en sus ojos ardía un insólito fuego.
"I am glad I happened to be awake," I said: and then I was going.
-Me alegro de haber estado despierta, señor -dije.
Y traté de irme.
"What! you _will_ go?"
-¿Ya se va?
"I am cold, sir."
-Tengo frío, señor. -¿Frío?
"Cold?
Yes,--and standing in a pool!
¡Claro: estamos en un charco!
Go, then, Jane; go!"
Bueno, váyase.. .
But he still retained my hand, and I could not free it.
Pero no soltaba mi mano.
I bethought myself of an expedient.
"I think I hear Mrs. Fairfax move, sir," said I.
Tuve que imaginar un pretexto. -Me parece haber sentido moverse a Mrs.
Fairfax -dije.
"Well, leave me:" he relaxed his fingers, and I was gone.
-Bien; váyase.
Aflojó sus dedos y me dejó marchar.
I regained my couch, but never thought of sleep.
Volví a mi alcoba, pero no pude dormir.
Till morning dawned I was tossed on a buoyant but unquiet sea, where billows of trouble rolled under surges of joy.
Mi imaginación flotó hasta la mañana en un mar alegre, pero turbulento, en el que olas de turbación sucedían a otras de grato optimismo.

I thought sometimes I saw beyond its wild waters a shore, sweet as the hills of Beulah; and now and then a freshening gale, wakened by hope, bore my spirit triumphantly towards the bourne: but I could not reach it, even in fancy--a counteracting breeze blew off land, and continually drove me back.
A trechos, más allá de las hirvientes aguas, parecíame divisar una plácida orilla, hacia la que de vez en cuando me impulsaba una fresca brisa.
Pero otro viento que soplaba desde tierra me hacía retroceder.
Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion.
La sensatez trataba de oponerse al delirio, el criterio a la pasión.
Too feverish to rest, I rose as soon as day dawned.
Incapaz de seguir acostada, me levanté en cuanto alboreó el día.
CHAPTER XVI
XVI
Al día siguiente yo temía, y a la vez deseaba, ver a Mr.
I both wished and feared to see Mr. Rochester on the day which followed this sleepless night: I wanted to hear his voice again, yet feared to meet his eye.
Rochester.
Ansiaba oír su voz de nuevo y me asustaba, sin embargo, presentarme ante él.

During the early part of the morning, I momentarily expected his coming; he was not in the frequent habit of entering the schoolroom, but he did step in for a few minutes sometimes, and I had the impression that he was sure to visit it that day.
Rochester, algunas veces, aunque pocas, solía entrar en el cuarto de estudio y permanecer en él, y yo estaba segura de que aquella mañana se presentaría.

But the morning passed just as usual: nothing happened to interrupt the quiet course of Adele's studies; only soon after breakfast, I heard some bustle in the neighbourhood of Mr. Rochester's chamber, Mrs. Fairfax's voice, and Leah's, and the cook's--that is, John's wife--and even John's own gruff tones.
Pero la mañana transcurrió sin que nada interrumpiese los estudios de Adèle.
Únicamente oí, antes de desayunar, algunas voces cerca del cuarto de Rochester: las del ama de llaves, de Leah, de la cocinera -que era la mujer de John- y el áspero acento del propio John.
There were exclamations of "What a mercy master was not burnt in his bed!"
"It is always dangerous to keep a candle lit at night."
Se percibían exclamaciones tales como: «¡Por poco se abrasa el señor en su cama!»
"How providential that he had presence of mind to think of the water-jug!"
«Es peligroso dejar la luz encendida por la noche.»
"I wonder he waked nobody!"
"It is to be hoped he will not take cold with sleeping on the library sofa," &c.
«¿No se habrá enfriado durmiendo en el sofá?», etcétera.

To much confabulation succeeded a sound of scrubbing and setting to rights; and when I passed the room, in going downstairs to dinner, I saw through the open door that all was again restored to complete order; only the bed was stripped of its hangings.
A aquella conversación siguió algún movimiento en el cuarto y cuando pasé ante él para ir a comer, vi a través de la puerta abierta que todo había sido puesto en orden.
Unicamente la cama carecía aún de cortinas.
Leah stood up in the window-seat, rubbing the panes of glass dimmed with smoke.
Leah estaba limpiando los cristales, empañados por el humo.

I was about to address her, for I wished to know what account had been given of the affair: but, on advancing, I saw a second person in the chamber--a woman sitting on a chair by the bedside, and sewing rings to new curtains.
That woman was no other than Grace Poole.
Iba a hablarla para saber qué explicación se había dado del caso, cuando divisé, sentada en una silla y colocando las anillas de las nuevas cortinas del lecho, a Grace Poole.
There she sat, staid and taciturn-looking, as usual, in her brown stuff gown, her check apron, white handkerchief, and cap.
Permanecía taciturna como de costumbre, con su vestido oscuro, su delantal ceñido y su cofia.

She was intent on her work, in which her whole thoughts seemed absorbed: on her hard forehead, and in her commonplace features, was nothing either of the paleness or desperation one would have expected to see marking the countenance of a woman who had attempted murder, and whose intended victim had followed her last night to her lair, and (as I believed), charged her with the crime she wished to perpetrate.
Estaba absorta en su trabajo, al que parecía dedicar todas las energías de su mente.

En sus vulgares rasgos no se percibía la palidez ni la desesperación que debían esperarse en una mujer que hacía poco intentara cometer un asesinato y cuya víctima debía, según mis suposiciones, haberle reprochado el crimen que tratara de perpetrar.
I was amazed--confounded.
Quedé perpleja.
She looked up, while I still gazed at her: no start, no increase or failure of colour betrayed emotion, consciousness of guilt, or fear of detection.
Ella me miró sin que su expresión se alterase y me dijo:
She said "Good morning, Miss," in her usual phlegmatic and brief manner; and taking up another ring and more tape, went on with her sewing.
«Buenos días, señorita», con tanta calma y flema como de costumbre.
Luego continuó su labor.
"I will put her to some test," thought I: "such absolute impenetrability is past comprehension."
«Es preciso poner a prueba esa indiferencia», pensé.
"Good morning, Grace," I said.
-Buenos días, Grace -repuse en voz alta-.
"Has anything happened here?
¿Ha ocurrido algo?
I thought I heard the servants all talking together a while ago."
Me ha parecido oír hablar aquí hace un rato...

"Only master had been reading in his bed last night; he fell asleep with his candle lit, and the curtains got on fire; but, fortunately, he awoke before the bed-clothes or the wood-work caught, and contrived to quench the flames with the water in the ewer."
-El señor estuvo leyendo esta noche en la cama, se durmió con la luz encendida y las cortinas se incendiaron.
Afortunadamente despertó a tiempo de apagar el fuego con el agua del jarro.
"A strange affair!"
I said, in a low voice: then, looking at her fixedly
-¡Qué raro! -dije, en voz baja, mirándola fijamente-.
--"Did Mr. Rochester wake nobody?
¿No despertó Mr.
Rochester a nadie?
Did no one hear him move?"
¿Ninguno le oyó moverse?
She again raised her eyes to me, and this time there was something of consciousness in their expression.
Me contempló de nuevo y ahora su expresión reflejaba un sentimiento distinto.
She seemed to examine me warily; then she answered--
Después de haberme examinado con recelo, contestó:
"The servants sleep so far off, you know, Miss, they would not be likely to hear.
-Ya sabe usted, señorita, que los criados duermen lejos.
Las alcobas más próximas son la de usted y la de Mrs.
Fairfax.
Mrs. Fairfax's room and yours are the nearest to master's; but Mrs. Fairfax said she heard nothing: when people get elderly, they often sleep heavy."
Ella no ha oído nada.
Las personas de cierta edad duermen muy pesadamente.

She paused, and then added, with a sort of assumed indifference, but still in a marked and significant tone--"But you are young, Miss; and I should say a light sleeper: perhaps you may have heard a noise?"
Se interrumpió, y luego agregó con afectada indiferencia, pero con significativo acento: -Usted es joven, señorita, y debe tener el sueño ligero.
¿No oyó nada?

"I did," said I, dropping my voice, so that Leah, who was still polishing the panes, could not hear me, "and at first I thought it was Pilot: but Pilot cannot laugh; and I am certain I heard a laugh, and a strange one."
-Sí -dije en voz baja, para que Leah no me oyese al principio creí que era Piloto.
Pero es imposible que un perro ría, y estoy segura de haber oído una risa muy extraña.
She took a new needleful of thread, waxed it carefully, threaded her needle with a steady hand, and then observed, with perfect composure--
Ella reanudó su labor con perfecta calma y me dijo:
"It is hardly likely master would laugh, I should think, Miss, when he was in such danger: You must have been dreaming."
-Debía usted de estar soñando, señorita, porque es muy raro que el amo, en un caso así, se riera.
"I was not dreaming," I said, with some warmth, for her brazen coolness provoked me.
-No soñaba -repuse acaloradamente-.
Su fingida frialdad me ofendía.
Me miró otra vez, escudriñadora.
Again she looked at me; and with the same scrutinising and conscious eye.
"Have you told master that you heard a laugh?" she inquired.
"I have not had the opportunity of speaking to him this morning."
"You did not think of opening your door and looking out into the gallery?" she further asked.
-¿Cómo no abrió usted la puerta y miró? -repuso sin perder la calma-.
Y ¿cómo no ha hablado al amo de esa risa extraña?
She appeared to be cross-questioning me, attempting to draw from me information unawares.
-No he tenido ocasión de verle esta mañana.
Y en vez de abrir, lo que hice fue echar el cerrojo.
The idea struck me that if she discovered I knew or suspected her guilt, she would be playing of some of her malignant pranks on me; I thought it advisable to be on my guard.
Me pareció que tenía interés en interrogarme.
Y como, si notaba que yo desconfiaba de ella, podía volver contra mí sus malignos propósitos, me pareció conveniente precaverme.
Por eso le di aquella respuesta.
"On the contrary," said I, "I bolted my door."
"Then you are not in the habit of bolting your door every night before you get into bed?"
-¿Así -continuó ella- que no tiene usted la costumbre de cerrar la puerta con cerrojo cuando se acuesta?
"Fiend! she wants to know my habits, that she may lay her plans accordingly!"
«¡La muy bruja quiere conocer mis costumbres para fraguar sus planes!», pensé.
Y la indignación, superando mi prudencia, me hizo contestar:
Indignation again prevailed over prudence: I replied sharply, "Hitherto I have often omitted to fasten the bolt: I did not think it necessary.
-Con frecuencia he omitido esa precaución, por no creerla necesaria.

I was not aware any danger or annoyance was to be dreaded at Thornfield Hall: but in future" (and I laid marked stress on the words) "I shall take good care to make all secure before I venture to lie down."
No pensaba que en Thornfield Hall hubiera peligro de muerte violenta.
Pero de aquí en adelante -y recalqué las palabras- tomaré mis precauciones antes de acostarme.

"It will be wise so to do," was her answer: "this neighbourhood is as quiet as any I know, and I never heard of the hall being attempted by robbers since it was a house; though there are hundreds of pounds' worth of plate in the plate-closet, as is well known.
-Será conveniente que lo haga -respondió Grace, aunque esta región es muy pacífica y yo no he oído nunca hablar de intentos de robo en esta casa.

And you see, for such a large house, there are very few servants, because master has never lived here much; and when he does come, being a bachelor, he needs little waiting on: but I always think it best to err on the safe side; a door is soon fastened, and it is as well to have a drawn bolt between one and any mischief that may be about.

Y eso que se sabe que aquí hay vajilla de plata por valor de varios cientos de libras y que, como el amo es soltero y está muy poco aquí, hay menos criados de los que corresponde a un edificio de esta importancia.
De todos modos, me parece que la prudencia no sobra y que siempre es mejor tener echado el cerrojo de la puerta entre uno y cualquier peligro que pueda sobrevenir.
A deal of people, Miss, are for trusting all to Providence; but I say Providence will not dispense with the means, though He often blesses them when they are used discreetly."
Mucha gente confía en Dios, pero yo digo que debe uno ayudarse para que Dios le ayude.
And here she closed her harangue: a long one for her, and uttered with the demureness of a Quakeress.
Así concluyó su párrafo, muy largo para lo que ella acostumbraba, y pronunciado con el gazmoño acento de una cuáquera.
I still stood absolutely dumfoundered at what appeared to me her miraculous self-possession and most inscrutable hypocrisy, when the cook entered.
Quedé estupefacta ante lo que me parecía un increíble dominio de sí misma y una hipocresía refinada.
"Mrs. Poole," said she, addressing Grace, "the servants' dinner will soon be ready: will you come down?"
La cocinera entró en aquel momento. -Grace -dijo-: ¿baja usted a comer?
"No; just put my pint of porter and bit of pudding on a tray, and I'll carry it upstairs."
-No -repuso ella-; póngame mi jarro de cerveza y un trozo de pudding en una bandeja y me lo llevaré arriba.
"You'll have some meat?"
-¿No quiere carne?
"Just a morsel, and a taste of cheese, that's all."
-Un poco.
Y también un trozo de queso.
"And the sago?"
"Never mind it at present: I shall be coming down before teatime: I'll make it myself."
La cocinera se dirigió a mí para decirme que Mrs.
Fairfax me esperaba, y salió.
The cook here turned to me, saying that Mrs. Fairfax was waiting for me: so I departed.
Apenas presté atención al relato que me hizo del incendio, mientras comíamos, el ama de llaves.

I hardly heard Mrs. Fairfax's account of the curtain conflagration during dinner, so much was I occupied in puzzling my brains over the enigmatical character of Grace Poole, and still more in pondering the problem of her position at Thornfield and questioning why she had not been given into custody that morning, or, at the very least, dismissed from her master's service.
No pensaba sino en el enigma del carácter y la posición de Grace Poole en la casa, ya que era raro que no la hubieran entregado a las autoridades o, al menos, la hubiesen despedido.
He had almost as much as declared his conviction of her criminality last night: what mysterious cause withheld him from accusing her?
Mr.
Rochester me había declarado casi abiertamente que ella era la culpable: ¿Cómo, pues, no la acusaba?
Why had he enjoined me, too, to secrecy?
¿Por qué me había recomendado el secreto?

It was strange: a bold, vindictive, and haughty gentleman seemed somehow in the power of one of the meanest of his dependants; so much in her power, that even when she lifted her hand against his life, he dared not openly charge her with the attempt, much less punish her for it.

Era extraño que un propietario, hombre de mal carácter y bastante rencoroso, estuviese en cierto modo a merced de la más insignificante de sus sirvientas, hasta el punto de que pudiera atentar contra su vida sin que la castigase ni la culpase siquiera.

Had Grace been young and handsome, I should have been tempted to think that tenderer feelings than prudence or fear influenced Mr. Rochester in her behalf; but, hard-favoured and matronly as she was, the idea could not be admitted.

Si Grace hubiese sido joven y hermosa, yo me habría inclinado a pensar que algún dulce sentimiento influía en Rochester más que la prudencia y el temor, pero con una mujer de su edad y aspecto no cabía tal idea.
"Yet," I reflected, "she has been young once; her youth would be contemporary with her master's: Mrs. Fairfax told me once, she had lived here many years.
«Sin embargo -reflexioné-, por su edad ella debe ser contemporánea de su señor, y tal vez en su juventud...
Mrs.
I don't think she can ever have been pretty; but, for aught I know, she may possess originality and strength of character to compensate for the want of personal advantages.
Fairfax me ha dicho que lleva aquí muchos años.
No creo que haya sido bonita nunca, pero podría compensar con su carácter y otras cualidades sus defectos físicos.
Mr. Rochester is an amateur of the decided and eccentric: Grace is eccentric at least.
Mr.
Rochester ama lo excéntrico, y Grace lo es.

What if a former caprice (a freak very possible to a nature so sudden and headstrong as his) has delivered him into her power, and she now exercises over his actions a secret influence, the result of his own indiscretion, which he cannot shake off, and dare not disregard?"
¿Quién sabe si algún antiguo capricho, muy posible en un carácter tan impetuoso y terco como el de Rochester, le tiene a merced de ella y hace que esa mujer influya en su vida?»

But, having reached this point of conjecture, Mrs. Poole's square, flat figure, and uncomely, dry, even coarse face, recurred so distinctly to my mind's eye, that I thought, "No; impossible! my supposition cannot be correct.
Pero en este punto de mis conjeturas, la maciza figura de la Poole acudió a mi mente con tal viveza que no pude por menos de pensar: «Es imposible.
Mi suposición no tiene base.»

Yet," suggested the secret voice which talks to us in our own hearts, "you are not beautiful either, and perhaps Mr. Rochester approves you: at any rate, you have often felt as if he did; and last night--remember his words; remember his look; remember his voice!"
Mas esa secreta voz que a veces suena en el fondo de nuestras almas, me sugería: «Sin embargo, tú no eres hermosa tampoco y parece que no desagradas a Mr.
Rochester.
Ya otras veces lo has notado, y sobre todo anoche...
¡Recuerda sus palabras, su mirada, su voz!»
I well remembered all; language, glance, and tone seemed at the moment vividly renewed.
Yo lo recordaba todo muy bien.
I was now in the schoolroom; Adele was drawing; I bent over her and directed her pencil.
En aquel momento estábamos en el cuarto de estudio.
Adèle dibujaba.
Me incliné sobre ella para guiarle la mano.
She looked up with a sort of start.
"Qu' avez-vous, mademoiselle?" said she.
Me miró con sobresalto. -¿Qué tiene usted, señorita? -dijo-.
"Vos doigts tremblent comme la feuille, et vos joues sont rouges: mais, rouges comme des cerises!"
Sus dedos tiemblan y sus mejillas están encarnadas como las cerezas...
"I am hot, Adele, with stooping!"
-Es que al inclinarme estoy en una posición incómoda, Adèle.
She went on sketching; I went on thinking.
Ella continuó dibujando y yo me sumí otra vez en mis pensamientos.
I hastened to drive from my mind the hateful notion I had been conceiving respecting Grace Poole; it disgusted me.
Me apresuré a eliminar de mi mente la desagradable idea que había formado a propósito de Grace Poole.
I compared myself with her, and found we were different.
Comparándome con ella, concluí que éramos muy diferentes.
Bessie Leaven had said I was quite a lady; and she spoke truth--I was a lady.
Bessie Leaven decía que yo era una señora, y tenía razón: lo era.
And now I looked much better than I did when Bessie saw me; I had more colour and more flesh, more life, more vivacity, because I had brighter hopes and keener enjoyments.
Y ahora yo estaba mucho mejor que cuando me viera Bessie: más gruesa, con mejor color, más viva, más animada, porque tenía más esperanzas y más satisfacciones.
"Evening approaches," said I, as I looked towards the window.
«Ya está oscureciendo -medité, acercándome a la ventana-, y en todo el día no he visto ni oído a Mr.
Rochester.

"I have never heard Mr. Rochester's voice or step in the house to-day; but surely I shall see him before night: I feared the meeting in the morning; now I desire it, because expectation has been so long baffled that it is grown impatient."
Seguramente le veré antes de la noche.
Por la mañana lo temía, pero ahora estoy impaciente por reunirme con él.»
When dusk actually closed, and when Adele left me to go and play in the nursery with Sophie, I did most keenly desire it.
Mi impaciencia se acrecentó cuando se hizo noche cerrada y Adèle se marchó a jugar con Sophie.

I listened for the bell to ring below; I listened for Leah coming up with a message; I fancied sometimes I heard Mr. Rochester's own tread, and I turned to the door, expecting it to open and admit him.
Yo esperaba oír sonar la campanilla, esperaba que Leah me avisase para que bajara, hasta esperaba que el propio Mr.
Rochester llamase a mi puerta...
The door remained shut; darkness only came in through the window.
Pero la puerta seguía cerrada y nadie entraba, sino la oscuridad de la noche a través de la ventana.
Still it was not late; he often sent for me at seven and eight o'clock, and it was yet but six.
Aún no era muy tarde: sólo las seis, y él a veces no enviaba por mí hasta las siete o las ocho.
Surely I should not be wholly disappointed to-night, when I had so many things to say to him!
¡Era imposible que no me mandara a llamar una noche en que tenía tanto de que hablarle!

I wanted again to introduce the subject of Grace Poole, and to hear what he would answer; I wanted to ask him plainly if he really believed it was she who had made last night's hideous attempt; and if so, why he kept her wickedness a secret.

Era preciso preguntarle sobre Grace para ver lo que respondía; era preciso preguntarle francamente si creía que era la culpable del odioso atentado de la noche anterior y, en tal caso, por qué deseaba guardar el secreto.

It little mattered whether my curiosity irritated him; I knew the pleasure of vexing and soothing him by turns; it was one I chiefly delighted in, and a sure instinct always prevented me from going too far; beyond the verge of provocation I never ventured; on the extreme brink I liked well to try my skill.
Retaining every minute form of respect, every propriety of my station, I could still meet him in argument without fear or uneasy restraint; this suited both him and me.
A tread creaked on the stairs at last.
Leah made her appearance; but it was only to intimate that tea was ready in Mrs. Fairfax's room.
Al fin se sintió un paso en las escaleras y Leah se presentó, pero sólo para anunciarme que el té estaba servido en el gabinete de Mrs.
Fairfax.
Thither I repaired, glad at least to go downstairs; for that brought me, I imagined, nearer to Mr. Rochester's presence.
De todos modos, me alegré de bajar, pensando que ello me acercaba a la presencia de Mr.
Rochester.
"You must want your tea," said the good lady, as I joined her; "you ate so little at dinner.
-Vaya, tome su té -dijo la buena señora cuando me vio-.
Hoy ha comido usted muy poco.
I am afraid," she continued, "you are not well to- day: you look flushed and feverish."
Temo que no se encuentre usted bien.
Parece un poco agitada.
"Oh, quite well!
I never felt better."
-¡Oh, nunca me he sentido mejor! -Demuéstremelo con su buen apetito.
"Then you must prove it by evincing a good appetite; will you fill the teapot while I knit off this needle?"
¿Quiere servir el té mientras yo arreglo la labor?
Having completed her task, she rose to draw down the blind, which she had hitherto kept up, by way, I suppose, of making the most of daylight, though dusk was now fast deepening into total obscurity.
Cuando lo hubo hecho, corrió las cortinillas de la ventana, lo que sin duda no había efectuado antes para aprovechar lo más posible la luz del día.
"It is fair to-night," said she, as she looked through the panes, "though not starlight; Mr. Rochester has, on the whole, had a favourable day for his journey."
-La noche es clara, aunque no hay estrellas -dijo, mirando a través de los cristales-.
Mr.
"Journey!--Is Mr. Rochester gone anywhere?
Rochester ha tenido buen tiempo para su viaje. -Pero ¿se ha marchado Mr.
I did not know he was out."
Rochester?
No lo sabía.
"Oh, he set off the moment he had breakfasted!
-Se fue en seguida de desayunar.
