En cambio, aquí -y señalaba el lugar en que habíamos entrado- todo es real, bello y puro.
Avanzó por un sendero circundado de boj.

He strayed down a walk edged with box, with apple trees, pear trees, and cherry trees on one side, and a border on the other full of all sorts of old-fashioned flowers, stocks, sweet-williams, primroses, pansies, mingled with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various fragrant herbs.
De un lado, lo sombreaban manzanos, perales y cerezos.
Al otro había un pénsil de flores: belloritas, trinitarias, escaramujos de olor, abrótano y hierbas aromáticas, todo ello fresco y lozano en la radiante mañana de primavera.

They were fresh now as a succession of April showers and gleams, followed by a lovely spring morning, could make them: the sun was just entering the dappled east, and his light illumined the wreathed and dewy orchard trees and shone down the quiet walks under them.
El sol apuntaba por Oriente y sus rayos besaban los árboles frutales y brillaban en los quietos muros.
"Jane, will you have a flower?"
-¿Quiere una flor, Jane?
He gathered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush, and offered it to me.
"Thank you, sir."
Cortó una rosa y me la ofreció. -Gracias, señor.
"Do you like this sunrise, Jane?
-¿Le gusta ver nacer el sol, Jane?
That sky with its high and light clouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm--this placid and balmly atmosphere?"
¿Este cielo donde flotan lejanas y brillantes nubes que se disiparán a medida que avance el día, esta atmósfera plácida y perfumada?
"I do, very much."
-Sí, me gusta mucho.
"You have passed a strange night, Jane."
-Ha pasado usted una noche muy mala, ¿no?
"Yes, sir."
-Sí, señor.
"And it has made you look pale--were you afraid when I left you alone with Mason?"
-Está usted muy pálida.
¿Tuvo miedo cuando la dejé sola con Mason?
"I was afraid of some one coming out of the inner room."
-Temía que saliese alguien del cuarto interior.
"But I had fastened the door--I had the key in my pocket: I should have been a careless shepherd if I had left a lamb--my pet lamb--so near a wolf's den, unguarded: you were safe."
-Ya había cerrado yo la puerta con llave.
¿Iba a dejar a mi oveja -a mi oveja favorita- al alcance del lobo?
Estaba usted bien segura.
"Will Grace Poole live here still, sir?"
-¿Cree que lo estaré mientras Grace Poole viva en la casa?
"Oh yes! don't trouble your head about her--put the thing out of your thoughts."
-No se asuste de Grace.
No piense en ella siquiera, por favor.
"Yet it seems to me your life is hardly secure while she stays."
-Me parece que ni la vida de usted está segura mientras ella continúe aquí.
"Never fear--I will take care of myself."
-No tema.
Ya me preocupo de mí también.
"Is the danger you apprehended last night gone by now, sir?"
-¿Se ha alejado el peligro que temía anoche, señor?
"I cannot vouch for that till Mason is out of England: nor even then.
-No respondo de ello mientras Mason no esté fuera de Inglaterra... y entonces tampoco.
To live, for me, Jane, is to stand on a crater-crust which may crack and spue fire any day."
"But Mr. Mason seems a man easily led.
La vida para mí, Jane, consiste en permanecer sobre el cráter de un volcán dormido que puede cualquier día entrar en erupción. -Pero Mason me parece una persona dócil.
Your influence, sir, is evidently potent with him: he will never set you at defiance or wilfully injure you."
Usted influye mucho sobre él y no creo que le dañe o le perjudique en nada.
"Oh, no!
-¡Oh, no desconfío de Mason!
Mason will not defy me; nor, knowing it, will he hurt me--but, unintentionally, he might in a moment, by one careless word, deprive me, if not of life, yet for ever of happiness."
El peligro está en que, sin querer, pronuncie alguna palabra que me costara, si no la vida, al menos la felicidad.
"Tell him to be cautious, sir: let him know what you fear, and show him how to avert the danger."
-Dígale que sea precavido, hágale comprender los temores que usted siente y adviértale del peligro.
He laughed sardonically, hastily took my hand, and as hastily threw it from him.
Él rió sarcásticamente, tomó mi mano y la apretó contra su pecho.
"If I could do that, simpleton, where would the danger be?
Annihilated in a moment.
-Si eso fuera posible, bobita, ¿dónde estaría el peligro?
Ever since I have known Mason, I have only had to say to him 'Do that,' and the thing has been done.
Desaparecería instantáneamente.
But I cannot give him orders in this case: I cannot say 'Beware of harming me, Richard;' for it is imperative that I should keep him ignorant that harm to me is possible.
A Mason, desde que le conozco, me basta decirle «Haz esto», para que lo haga en el acto.
Pero en este caso, no cabe hacer nada.
Now you look puzzled; and I will puzzle you further.
Parece usted confundida y se confundirá más aún si...
You are my little friend, are you not?"
Usted es amiga mía, ¿no?
"I like to serve you, sir, and to obey you in all that is right."
"Precisely: I see you do.
-Deseo serle útil y servirle en todo lo que sea razonable, señor. -Ya lo he visto.

I see genuine contentment in your gait and mien, your eye and face, when you are helping me and pleasing me--working for me, and with me, in, as you characteristically say, '_all that is right_:' for if I bid you do what you thought wrong, there would be no light-footed running, no neat-handed alacrity, no lively glance and animated complexion.
Me parece apreciar verdadera satisfacción en todo su aspecto cuando usted me ayuda en algo, trabaja para mí y me complace en cuanto, como usted dice, «es razonable».
Estoy seguro de que si la pidiera algo que no fuese razonable, mi amiga no huiría de mí, ni sentiría alegría, ni se pondría encarnada y le brillarían los ojos.
My friend would then turn to me, quiet and pale, and would say, 'No, sir; that is impossible: I cannot do it, because it is wrong;' and would become immutable as a fixed star.
No; mi amiga, en un caso así, se volvería hacia mí, serena y pálida, y me diría: «No, señor, porque no es razonable».
Well, you too have power over me, and may injure me: yet I dare not show you where I am vulnerable, lest, faithful and friendly as you are, you should transfix me at once."
Y permanecería tan inmutable como una estrella fija...
En fin: usted puede influir en mí y hasta herirme aunque no la mostrara mi lado vulnerable.
"If you have no more to fear from Mr. Mason than you have from me, sir, you are very safe."
-Si no tuviese usted que temer a Mr.
Mason más que a mí, bien seguro estaría usted, señor.
"God grant it may be so!
-¡Ojalá fuera así!
Here, Jane, is an arbour; sit down."
Vamos a sentarnos en ese banco, Jane.
The arbour was an arch in the wall, lined with ivy; it contained a rustic seat.
Adosado a la tapia había un banco bajo un dosel de hiedra.
Mr. Rochester took it, leaving room, however, for me: but I stood before him.
Se sentó y me hizo sitio.
Pero yo permanecí en pie.
"Sit," he said; "the bench is long enough for two.
-Siéntese -dijo-.
El banco es suficiente para los dos.
You don't hesitate to take a place at my side, do you?
¿Acaso teme sentarse a mi lado?
Is that wrong, Jane?"
¿Se trata de una cosa irrazonable?
I answered him by assuming it: to refuse would, I felt, have been unwise.
Mi contestación fue sentarme.
Comprendí que no había motivo para la negativa.

"Now, my little friend, while the sun drinks the dew--while all the flowers in this old garden awake and expand, and the birds fetch their young ones' breakfast out of the Thornfield, and the early bees do their first spell of work--I'll put a case to you, which you must endeavour to suppose your own: but first, look at me, and tell me you are at ease, and not fearing that I err in detaining you, or that you err in staying."

-Ahora, amiguita mía, mientras el sol bebe el rocío, mientras se abren las flores de este viejo jardín, mientras los pájaros levantan el vuelo a fin de buscar comida para sus crías, voy a exponer a usted un caso que..., pero antes míreme y dígame si encuentra mal que la retenga o no le agrada permanecer aquí. -No, señor.
"No, sir; I am content."
Estoy satisfecha.

"Well then, Jane, call to aid your fancy:--suppose you were no longer a girl well reared and disciplined, but a wild boy indulged from childhood upwards; imagine yourself in a remote foreign land; conceive that you there commit a capital error, no matter of what nature or from what motives, but one whose consequences must follow you through life and taint all your existence.
-Entonces, Jane, llame en su ayuda a su imaginación y suponga que no es usted una muchacha bien educada y disciplinada, sino una niña caprichosa y mimada desde la niñez.

Imagínese viviendo en un lejano país extranjero y dé por hecho que hubiera cometido un gravísimo error, no importa de qué clase o por qué motivos, pero cuyas consecuencias la persiguen a lo largo de toda su vida y amargan toda su existencia.
Mind, I don't say a _crime_; I am not speaking of shedding of blood or any other guilty act, which might make the perpetrator amenable to the law: my word is _error_.
Note que no hablo de un crimen, esto es, de verter sangre u otra cosa análoga que pongan al que lo comete bajo la acción de la ley.
No; me refiero a un error.
The results of what you have done become in time to you utterly insupportable; you take measures to obtain relief: unusual measures, but neither unlawful nor culpable.
Los resultados de lo que usted ha hecho acaban convirtiéndose en insoportables y usted adopta medidas para aliviarlos, medidas inusitadas, pero no ilegales.
Still you are miserable; for hope has quitted you on the very confines of life: your sun at noon darkens in an eclipse, which you feel will not leave it till the time of setting.
Usted sigue sintiéndose desgraciada; la esperanza la abandona, el sol y la luna de su vida se eclipsan.

Bitter and base associations have become the sole food of your memory: you wander here and there, seeking rest in exile: happiness in pleasure--I mean in heartless, sensual pleasure--such as dulls intellect and blights feeling.

Amargos y humillantes recuerdos son el único alimento de su memoria, y usted vagabundea de un sitio a otro buscando olvido en el destierro y felicidad en el placer, significando con esto el mero placer sensual.

Heart-weary and soul-withered, you come home after years of voluntary banishment: you make a new acquaintance--how or where no matter: you find in this stranger much of the good and bright qualities which you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered; and they are all fresh, healthy, without soil and without taint.

Con el corazón cansado y el alma marchita, vuelve usted a su casa tras años de voluntario destierro y halla usted a alguien -quién y cómo no hace al caso- en quien halla las cualidades que en vano ha buscado usted durante veinte años; cualidades en plena lozanía, no acompasadas por corrupción de clase alguna.

Such society revives, regenerates: you feel better days come back--higher wishes, purer feelings; you desire to recommence your life, and to spend what remains to you of days in a way more worthy of an immortal being.
Su trato le hace revivir, le regenera, experimenta mejores sentimientos y deseos más puros.
Desea usted volver a empezar su vida y terminarla de un modo más digno de un ser humano.
To attain this end, are you justified in overleaping an obstacle of custom--a mere conventional impediment which neither your conscience sanctifies nor your judgment approves?"
Para alcanzar este fin, ¿encontraría usted justificado saltar sobre un obstáculo, un impedimento meramente convencional, que ni la conciencia santifica ni la razón aprueba?
He paused for an answer:
Calló, esperando mi contestación.
and what was I to say?
¿Qué podía yo decir?
Oh, for some good spirit to suggest a judicious and satisfactory response!
En vano deseé que algún genio amigo me sugiriese una respuesta satisfactoria y sensata.
Vain aspiration!
The west wind whispered in the ivy round me; but no gentle Ariel borrowed its breath as a medium of speech: the birds sang in the tree-tops; but their song, however sweet, was inarticulate.
El viento Oeste agitaba la hiedra, pero ningún amable Ariel le hacía servir de vehículo de sus consejos.
Los pájaros cantaban en las ramas, pero su canto, aunque dulce, no me decía nada.
Again Mr. Rochester propounded his query:
Mr.
Rochester insistió:

"Is the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man justified in daring the world's opinion, in order to attach to him for ever this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing his own peace of mind and regeneration of life?"

-Si el vagabundo pecador, ahora quieto y arrepentido, desafiando la opinión del mundo, uniese a su vida la de la amable, bondadosa y gentil mujer a quien ama, ¿aseguraría la paz de su alma y la regeneración de su vida?
"Sir," I answered, "a wanderer's repose or a sinner's reformation should never depend on a fellow-creature.
-Señor -repuse-: creo que el reposo de un vagabundo y la reforma de un pecador no dependen de otro ser humano.

Men and women die; philosophers falter in wisdom, and Christians in goodness: if any one you know has suffered and erred, let him look higher than his equals for strength to amend and solace to heal."
El hombre puede corregirse por sí mismo, si reconoce que yerra. -Pero se necesita un instrumento.
"But the instrument--the instrument!
Dios, que impone el trabajo, da la herramienta.
God, who does the work, ordains the instrument.
Yo, se lo digo sin ambages, he sido un hombre disoluto, un vagabundo, un...
I have myself--I tell it you without parable--been a worldly, dissipated, restless man; and I believe I have found the instrument for my cure in--"
Creo haber hallado ahora el instrumento para mi salvación y...
He paused: the birds went on carolling, the leaves lightly rustling.
Se detuvo.
Los pájaros cantaban y las hojas de los árboles se balanceaban impulsadas por el viento.
I almost wondered they did not check their songs and whispers to catch the suspended revelation; but they would have had to wait many minutes--so long was the silence protracted.
Me sorprendió que unos y otras no suspendieran sus cantos y sus movimientos para escuchar la interrumpida revelación.
Pero hubieran tenido que esperar mucho, tanto como aquel silencio se prolongó...
At last I looked up at the tardy speaker: he was looking eagerly at me.
Cuando, al fin, osé mirar a mi interlocutor, él a su vez estaba mirándome a mí.

"Little friend," said he, in quite a changed tone--while his face changed too, losing all its softness and gravity, and becoming harsh and sarcastic--"you have noticed my tender penchant for Miss Ingram: don't you think if I married her she would regenerate me with a vengeance?"
-Amiguita mía -dijo, con tono totalmente distinto, ya sin dulzura ni gravedad algunas, sino con sarcasmo y dureza-: ¿ha notado usted la tierna inclinación que experimento hacia Blanche Ingram?
¿Cree que si me caso con ella me regenerará?
He got up instantly, went quite to the other end of the walk, and when he came back he was humming a tune.
Se levantó de pronto, se alejó hasta el extremo del sendero y volvió tarareando un cantar.
"Jane, Jane," said he, stopping before me, "you are quite pale with your vigils: don't you curse me for disturbing your rest?"
-Jane -dijo-: está usted palidísima.
¿No abomina de mí, que la he hecho pasar la noche en vela?
"Curse you?
No, sir."
-No, señor.
"Shake hands in confirmation of the word.
-Confírmelo con un apretón de manos.
What cold fingers!
¡Qué frías las tiene!
They were warmer last night when I touched them at the door of the mysterious chamber.
Estaban mucho más cálidas esta noche, a la puerta de la habitación misteriosa.
Jane, when will you watch with me again?"
¿Cuándo volverá a velar conmigo otra vez?
"Whenever I can be useful, sir."
-Cuando pueda serle útil, señor.
"For instance, the night before I am married!
-Por ejemplo, la noche antes de mi boda.
I am sure I shall not be able to sleep.
Estoy seguro de que esa noche no podré dormir.
Will you promise to sit up with me to bear me company?
¿Me promete usted sentarse entonces a mi lado haciéndome compañía?
To you I can talk of my lovely one: for now you have seen her and know her."
A usted puedo hablarle de mi amada, puesto que la conoce.
"Yes, sir."
-Sí, señor.
"She's a rare one, is she not, Jane?"
-Blanche es admirable, ¿verdad?
"Yes, sir."
-Sí, señor.
"A strapper--a real strapper, Jane: big, brown, and buxom; with hair just such as the ladies of Carthage must have had.
-Robusta, alta, morena, con un cabello como debían tenerlo las mujeres de Cartago...
¡Caramba!
Bless me! there's Dent and Lynn in the stables!
Dent y Lynn están ya en las cuadras.
Go in by the shrubbery, through that wicket."
As I went one way, he went another, and I heard him in the yard, saying cheerfully--
Se fue por un lado, yo me fui por otro y a poco le oí hablar diciendo tranquilamente:
"Mason got the start of you all this morning; he was gone before sunrise: I rose at four to see him off."
-Mason se ha ido hoy antes de salir el sol.
Me levanté a las cuatro para despedirle.
CHAPTER XXI
XXI
Presentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are signs; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has not yet found the key.
¡Qué cosa tan extraña son los presentimientos!
Ellos, como las simpatías espontáneas y los signos que se hallan en todas las cosas, constituyen un misterio del que la humanidad no ha encontrado la clave.
I never laughed at presentiments in my life, because I have had strange ones of my own.
Nunca me burlaré de los presentimientos, porque yo misma los he experimentado muchas veces.

Sympathies, I believe, exist (for instance, between far-distant, long-absent, wholly estranged relatives asserting, notwithstanding their alienation, the unity of the source to which each traces his origin) whose workings baffle mortal comprehension.
La simpatía espontánea existe también, como ocurre entre parientes que no se han visto jamás, y que simpatizan, no obstante, como demostración de su origen común.
And signs, for aught we know, may be but the sympathies of Nature with man.
En cuanto a los signos reveladores, quizá sean muestra de la simpatía de la naturaleza hacia el hombre.

When I was a little girl, only six years old, I one night heard Bessie Leaven say to Martha Abbot that she had been dreaming about a little child; and that to dream of children was a sure sign of trouble, either to one's self or one's kin.
The saying might have worn out of my memory, had not a circumstance immediately followed which served indelibly to fix it there.

Teniendo apenas seis años, oí una noche comentar a Bessie Leaven y Martha Abbot que la primera había soñado con un niño pequeño y que soñar con niños es signo seguro de desgracia, o para uno mismo o para otros.
The next day Bessie was sent for home to the deathbed of her little sister.
A la mañana siguiente Bessie tuvo que ir a su casa, porque su hermana menor había muerto.

Of late I had often recalled this saying and this incident; for during the past week scarcely a night had gone over my couch that had not brought with it a dream of an infant, which I sometimes hushed in my arms, sometimes dandled on my knee, sometimes watched playing with daisies on a lawn, or again, dabbling its hands in running water.
Ahora yo llevaba una semana soñando constantemente con un niño a quien tenía en brazos o sobre las rodillas, o cuyos juegos vigilaba en un prado.
Unas veces era un niño triste y otras riente; ora se refugiaba en mi regazo; ora huía de mi lado.
De un modo u otro, la aparición se me repitió durante siete noches.

It was a wailing child this night, and a laughing one the next: now it nestled close to me, and now it ran from me; but whatever mood the apparition evinced, whatever aspect it wore, it failed not for seven successive nights to meet me the moment I entered the land of slumber.
I did not like this iteration of one idea--this strange recurrence of one image, and I grew nervous as bedtime approached and the hour of the vision drew near.
El pensar en la reiteración de este sueño me ponía nerviosa en cuanto llegaba la hora de acostarme.

It was from companionship with this baby-phantom I had been roused on that moonlight night when I heard the cry; and it was on the afternoon of the day following I was summoned downstairs by a message that some one wanted me in Mrs. Fairfax's room.
Cuando el grito de aquella noche me despertó, soñaba estar en la fantástica compañía de aquel niño.
La tarde del día siguiente me dijeron que en el gabinete de Mrs.
Fairfax había una persona que deseaba verme.
On repairing thither, I found a man waiting for me, having the appearance of a gentleman's servant: he was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat he held in his hand was surrounded with a crape band.
Me dirigí hacia allí y encontré a un hombre de aspecto de criado.
Vestía de negro, con un crespón en el sombrero que tenía en la mano.
-Me parece que no me conoce usted, señorita -dijo-.
Pero yo a usted, sí.

"I daresay you hardly remember me, Miss," he said, rising as I entered; "but my name is Leaven: I lived coachman with Mrs. Reed when you were at Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and I live there still."
Me llamo Leaven y era cochero en casa de Mrs.
Reed cuando usted vivía allí hace ocho o nueve años.
"Oh, Robert! how do you do?
-¡Oh, Robert!
¿Cómo está usted?
I remember you very well: you used to give me a ride sometimes on Miss Georgiana's bay pony.
Le recuerdo muy bien.
Solía usted montarme en la jaquita de Georgiana.
And how is Bessie?
¿Y Bessie?
You are married to Bessie?"
Porque es usted marido de Bessie, ¿verdad?
-Sí, señorita.
"Yes, Miss: my wife is very hearty, thank you; she brought me another little one about two months since--we have three now--and both mother and child are thriving."
Bessie está bien, gracias a Dios.
Hace dos meses ha tenido otro pequeño.
Ya son tres con éste.
"And are the family well at the house, Robert?"
Todos están bien. -¿Y mis parientes, Robert?
"I am sorry I can't give you better news of them, Miss: they are very badly at present--in great trouble."
¿Cómo se encuentran? -Siento decirle que mal.
Sufren una gran desgracia.
"I hope no one is dead," I said, glancing at his black dress.
-Confío que no haya muerto ninguno -dije, dirigiendo una mirada al vestido negro del cochero.
He too looked down at the crape round his hat and replied-- "Mr. John died yesterday was a week, at his chambers in London."
-Mr.
John ha muerto en Londres hace una semana.
"Mr. John?"
-¡John!
"Yes."
-Sí.
"And how does his mother bear it?"
-¿Y cómo está su madre?
-¡Figúrese!
"Why, you see, Miss Eyre, it is not a common mishap: his life has been very wild: these last three years he gave himself up to strange ways, and his death was shocking."
Mr.
John hacía una vida muy extraña y su muerte lo ha sido más aún.
"I heard from Bessie he was not doing well."
-Bessie me dijo que no se comportaba bien. -¡Quia!
"Doing well!
He could not do worse: he ruined his health and his estate amongst the worst men and the worst women.
Hacía una vida pésima, derrochando su dinero y su salud entre las peores gentes que podía encontrar.
He got into debt and into jail: his mother helped him out twice, but as soon as he was free he returned to his old companions and habits.
Dos veces ha estado preso por deudas.
Su madre le ayudó a salir, pero en cuanto se halló libre volvió a sus vicios y a sus malas compañías.
His head was not strong: the knaves he lived amongst fooled him beyond anything I ever heard.
Creo que no estaba bien de la cabeza y las gentes con quienes trataba le acabaron de echar a perder.
He came down to Gateshead about three weeks ago and wanted missis to give up all to him.
Hace tres meses fue a casa y pidió a la señora que le diera todo cuanto poseía.
Missis refused: her means have long been much reduced by his extravagance; so he went back again, and the next news was that he was dead.
La señora se negó, porque sus bienes han mermado mucho como consecuencia de las locuras de su hijo.
How he died, God knows!--they say he killed himself."
Él se fue y ahora hemos sabido su muerte.
¡Y qué muerte!
Dicen que se ha suicidado...
I was silent: the things were frightful.
Yo estaba anonadada.

Robert Leaven resumed-- "Missis had been out of health herself for some time: she had got very stout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of poverty were quite breaking her down.
Robert Leaven continuó. -La señora, a pesar de ser robusta, hace tiempo que no está bien de salud.
The information about Mr. John's death and the manner of it came too suddenly: it brought on a stroke.
Las pérdidas de dinero y el temor a la pobreza la han empeorado.
Y la brusca noticia del suicidio del señorito le produjo un ataque.
She was three days without speaking; but last Tuesday she seemed rather better: she appeared as if she wanted to say something, and kept making signs to my wife and mumbling.
Durante tres días estuvo sin habla.
El martes pasado parecía encontrarse mejor.
It was only yesterday morning, however, that Bessie understood she was pronouncing your name; and at last she made out the words, 'Bring Jane--fetch Jane Eyre: I want to speak to her.'
Hacía señas a mi mujer, como si quisiera decirle algo.
Pero sólo ayer por la mañana pudo Bessie entender lo que le decía: «Tráigame a Jane, tengo que hablarla.»
Bessie is not sure whether she is in her right mind, or means anything by the words; but she told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana, and advised them to send for you.
Aunque Bessie no tenía certeza de que la señora supiese lo que decía, habló a las señoritas, aconsejándolas que enviasen a buscarle a usted.
The young ladies put it off at first; but their mother grew so restless, and said, 'Jane, Jane,' so many times, that at last they consented.
Las jóvenes se indignaron, pero su madre repitió: «Jane, Jane», tantas veces, que acabaron consintiendo.
I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can get ready, Miss, I should like to take you back with me early to-morrow morning."
Salí de Gateshead ayer y quisiera llevarla mañana por la mañana.
"Yes, Robert, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go."
-Iré, Robert.
Creo que debo hacerlo.
"I think so too, Miss.
-También yo lo creo, señorita.
Bessie said she was sure you would not refuse: but I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?"
Bessie decía que estaba segura de que usted no se negaría a ir.
Tendrá que pedir permiso, ¿no?
"Yes; and I will do it now;" and having directed him to the servants' hall, and recommended him to the care of John's wife, and the attentions of John himself, I went in search of Mr. Rochester.
-Sí; ahora mismo voy a solicitarlo.
Y dejando a Leaven al cuidado de John y de su mujer, fui en busca de Mr.
Rochester.
He was not in any of the lower rooms; he was not in the yard, the stables, or the grounds.
No le hallé ni en el salón, ni en el patio, ni en las cuadras.
Pregunté por él a Mrs.
I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had seen him;--yes: she believed he was playing billiards with Miss Ingram.
Fairfax y me dijo que debía de estar jugando al billar con Blanche Ingram.
To the billiard- room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices resounded thence; Mr. Rochester, Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton, and their admirers, were all busied in the game.
Llegué al cuarto de billar.
Oí las voces de Rochester, Blanche, las Eshton y sus admiradores, que estaban jugando.
It required some courage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one I could not defer, so I approached the master where he stood at Miss Ingram's side.
Aunque me disgustaba interrumpirles, no tuve más remedio que abordar al dueño de la casa, porque mi viaje no se podía diferir.

She turned as I drew near, and looked at me haughtily: her eyes seemed to demand, "What can the creeping creature want now?" and when I said, in a low voice, "Mr. Rochester," she made a movement as if tempted to order me away.
Blanche me miró como preguntándose: «¿Qué querrá esta sabandija?», y cuando me acerqué a él y le dije en voz baja: «Mr.
Rochester...», ella inició un movimiento como para mandarme salir.
I remember her appearance at the moment--it was very graceful and very striking: she wore a morning robe of sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in her hair.
She had been all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the expression of her haughty lineaments.
Recuerdo muy bien su aspecto de entonces.
Vestía un vestido de crespón azul celeste y ceñía el cabello con una cinta de seda del mismo color.
"Does that person want you?" she inquired of Mr. Rochester; and Mr. Rochester turned to see who the "person" was.
-¿Qué quiere esta mujer? -preguntó a Mr.
Rochester mientras éste se volvía para ver lo que yo deseaba.
He made a curious grimace--one of his strange and equivocal demonstrations--threw down his cue and followed me from the room.
Él hizo una de sus muecas características y me siguió fuera del cuarto.
"Well, Jane?" he said, as he rested his back against the schoolroom door, which he had shut.
-Y bien, Jane, ¿qué desea?
"If you please, sir, I want leave of absence for a week or two."
-Si no tiene inconveniente, señor, un permiso de una o dos semanas.
"What to do?--where to go?"
-¿Para que?
¿Adónde va?
"To see a sick lady who has sent for me."
-A visitar a una señora enferma, que ha enviado a buscarme.
"What sick lady?--where does she live?"
-¿Quién es?
¿Dónde vive?
"At Gateshead; in ---shire."
-En Gateshead, en el condado de...
"-shire?
That is a hundred miles off!
-¿A cien millas de aquí?
Who may she be that sends for people to see her that distance?"
¿Para qué pueden querer que las visite gentes que viven a tanta distancia?
"Her name is Reed, sir--Mrs.
-Se llama Mrs.
Reed."
Reed y...
"Reed of Gateshead?
-¿Reed de Gasteshead?
There was a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate."
Recuerdo un tal Reed de Gasteshead, un magistrado.
"It is his widow, sir."
-Es su viuda, señor.
"And what have you to do with her?
-¿Y qué tiene usted que ver con ella?
How do you know her?"
¿De qué la conoce? -Es tía mía.
"Mr. Reed was my uncle--my mother's brother."
Mr.
Reed era hermano de mi madre. -¡Demonio!
"The deuce he was!
¿Por qué no me lo ha dicho antes?
You never told me that before: you always said you had no relations."
Siempre me ha manifestado usted que no tenía parientes.
"None that would own me, sir.
-Realmente no los tengo.
Mi verdadero tío era Mr.
Mr. Reed is dead, and his wife cast me off."
Reed y, después de morir él, mi tía me envió fuera de su casa.
"Why?"
-¿Por qué?
"Because I was poor, and burdensome, and she disliked me."
-Porque yo era pobre y la desagradaba.
"But Reed left children?--you must have cousins?
-Pero Reed creo que dejó hijos, primos de usted, por tanto...

Sir George Lynn was talking of a Reed of Gateshead yesterday, who, he said, was one of the veriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgiana Reed of the same place, who was much admired for her beauty a season or two ago in London."

Sir Jorge Lynn me habló ayer de un Reed de Gateshead que es, por lo visto, uno de los mayores bribones de Londres, y de una Georgina Reed que causó mucha sensación en la capital hace una o dos temporadas.
"John Reed is dead, too, sir: he ruined himself and half-ruined his family, and is supposed to have committed suicide.
-John Reed ha muerto después de arruinarse y arruinar a su familia, y se supone que se ha suicidado.
The news so shocked his mother that it brought on an apoplectic attack."
La noticia ha producido a su madre un ataque de apoplejía.
"And what good can you do her?
Nonsense, Jane!
-¿Y de qué va usted a servirla?
I would never think of running a hundred miles to see an old lady who will, perhaps, be dead before you reach her: besides, you say she cast you off."
Me parece un absurdo, Jane, que haga usted un viaje de cien millas para ver a una mujer que quizá haya muerto cuando usted llegue y que, para colmo, la echó a usted de su casa.
"Yes, sir, but that is long ago; and when her circumstances were very different: I could not be easy to neglect her wishes now."
-Sí, señor, pero eso ocurrió hace mucho y las circunstancias han variado.
Mi deber ahora es complacerla.
"How long will you stay?"
-¿Cuánto tiempo estará fuera?
"As short a time as possible, sir."
-Lo menos posible, señor.
"Promise me only to stay a week--"
-¿Me promete no estar más de una semana?
"I had better not pass my word: I might be obliged to break it."
-Preferiría no darle palabra para no tener que incumplirla quizá.
"At all events you _will_ come back: you will not be induced under any pretext to take up a permanent residence with her?"
-En todo caso, ¿volverá usted y no se dejará inducir para quedarse allí?
"Oh, no!
-No.
I shall certainly return if all be well."
Volveré de todos modos. -Y ¿cómo nos arreglamos?
"And who goes with you?
You don't travel a hundred miles alone."
¡No va usted a hacer sola un viaje de cien millas!
"No, sir, she has sent her coachman."
-Ha venido el cochero de mi tía para llevarme con él, señor.
"A person to be trusted?"
-¿Es persona de confianza?
"Yes, sir, he has lived ten years in the family."
-Sí.
Lleva diez años en la casa.
Mr. Rochester meditated.
-¿Cuándo quiere irse? -dijo Mr.
"When do you wish to go?"
Rochester, después de meditar un momento.
"Early to-morrow morning, sir."
-Mañana por la mañana.
"Well, you must have some money; you can't travel without money, and I daresay you have not much: I have given you no salary yet.
-Supongo que necesitará usted dinero, porque presumo que no tendrá mucho y yo no le he pagado aún su salario.
How much have you in the world, Jane?" he asked, smiling.
¿Cuánto tiene para toda la vida, Jane? -me preguntó, sonriendo.
I drew out my purse; a meagre thing it was.
"Five shillings, sir."
-Cinco chelines, señor -repuse, mostrándole mi flaca bolsa.
He took the purse, poured the hoard into his palm, and chuckled over it as if its scantiness amused him.
Vació el contenido en la palma de la mano y lo agitó, alegremente, como si fuera cosa que le agradase.
Soon he produced his pocket-book: "Here," said he, offering me a note; it was fifty pounds, and he owed me but fifteen.
Luego sacó su billetero y me ofreció un billete.
Eran cincuenta libras y no me debía más que quince.
I told him I had no change.
Le dije que no tenía cambio.
"I don't want change; you know that.
-No necesito cambio.
Ya lo sabe usted.
Take your wages."
Es su sueldo.
I declined accepting more than was my due.
Rehusé, manifestando que aquello era más de lo que me debía.
He scowled at first; then, as if recollecting something, he said-- "Right, right!
Pareció pensar de pronto en algo, y dijo: -Bueno, bueno.
Better not give you all now: you would, perhaps, stay away three months if you had fifty pounds.
Quizá sea mejor.
De lo contrario, tal vez esté usted tres meses allí.
There are ten; is it not plenty?"
Tome entonces diez libras.
¿Basta?
"Yes, sir, but now you owe me five."
-Sí.
Ahora me debe usted cinco.
-Así volverá por ellas.
"Come back for it, then; I am your banker for forty pounds."
Soy su banquero.
Tiene usted conmigo cuenta corriente por cuarenta libras.
"Mr. Rochester, I may as well mention another matter of business to you while I have the opportunity."
-Mr.
Rochester, quisiera de paso hablarle de negocios.
"Matter of business?
-¿De negocios?
I am curious to hear it."
Me muero de curiosidad.
"You have as good as informed me, sir, that you are going shortly to be married?"
Hable. -Usted ha tenido la amabilidad de informarme de que piensa casarse en breve.
"Yes; what then?"
-Sí; ¿y qué?
"In that case, sir, Adele ought to go to school: I am sure you will perceive the necessity of it."
-En tal caso, Adèle debe ir a un colegio.
Estoy segura de que usted lo considerará necesario.
"To get her out of my bride's way, who might otherwise walk over her rather too emphatically?
-Desde luego, tendré que ponerla fuera del alcance de mi esposa que, si no, quizá se comportase demasiado altivamente con ella.
There's sense in the suggestion; not a doubt of it.
La sugerencia es razonable, sin duda.
Adele, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must march straight to--the devil?"
Como usted dice bien, Adèle tendrá que ir a un colegio.
Y usted, ¿adónde irá?
¿Al diablo?
"I hope not, sir; but I must seek another situation somewhere."
-Espero que no, señor, pero tendré que pensar en buscar otro empleo.
"In course!" he exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of features equally fantastic and ludicrous.
He looked at me some minutes.
-Por supuesto -exclamó, contrayendo las facciones y con un extraño tono de chanza.
"And old Madam Reed, or the Misses, her daughters, will be solicited by you to seek a place, I suppose?"
Luego, agregó-: Supongo que pedirá usted a la vieja Reed y a sus primos que le busquen un puesto, ¿no?
"No, sir; I am not on such terms with my relatives as would justify me in asking favours of them--but I shall advertise."
-No, señor.
No estoy con mis parientes en tan buenas relaciones como para pedirles que me proporcionen empleo.
"You shall walk up the pyramids of Egypt!" he growled.
-¡Veo que va usted a irse a parar lo menos a las pirámides de Egipto!
"At your peril you advertise!
Ha hecho usted mal en advertirme.
I wish I had only offered you a sovereign instead of ten pounds.
En vista de eso, sólo le doy un soberano.
Give me back nine pounds, Jane; I've a use for it."
Devuélvame nueve libras, Jane.
Las tengo destinadas a...
"And so have I, sir," I returned, putting my hands and my purse behind me.
-También yo, señor -dije poniendo las manos sobre mi bolsillo-.
"I could not spare the money on any account."
No puedo ceder dinero en concepto alguno.
"Little niggard!" said he, "refusing me a pecuniary request!
-¡Qué avarienta!
¡Negarme una petición de dinero!
Give me five pounds, Jane."
Deme cinco libras siquiera, Jane.
"Not five shillings, sir; nor five pence."
-Ni cinco chelines, señor.
Ni cinco peniques.
"Just let me look at the cash."
"No, sir; you are not to be trusted."
"Jane!"
-¡Jane!
"Sir?"
-¿Señor?
"Promise me one thing."
-Prométame una cosa.
"I'll promise you anything, sir, that I think I am likely to perform."
"Not to advertise: and to trust this quest of a situation to me.
Que cuando necesite esa nueva colocación me la pida.
I'll find you one in time."
Yo se la encontraré.
"I shall be glad so to do, sir, if you, in your turn, will promise that I and Adele shall be both safe out of the house before your bride enters it."
-Lo haré con gusto, si a su vez me promete que Adèle y yo saldremos de esta casa antes de que entre en ella su esposa.
"Very well! very well!
-Bueno, bueno.
I'll pledge my word on it.
Le doy palabra...
You go to-morrow, then?"
¿Se va mañana, pues?
"Yes, sir; early."
-Sí; muy temprano.
"Shall you come down to the drawing-room after dinner?"
-¿Bajará hoy al comedor después de cenar?
"No, sir, I must prepare for the journey."
-No, señor.
Tengo que preparar mi equipaje.
"Then you and I must bid good-bye for a little while?"
-Entonces, ¿debemos despedirnos por algún tiempo?
"I suppose so, sir."
-Supongo que sí, señor.
"And how do people perform that ceremony of parting, Jane?
-Y ¿cómo se verifica esa ceremonia de la despedida, Jane?
Teach me; I'm not quite up to it."
No estoy muy al corriente.
Infórmeme.
"They say, Farewell, or any other form they prefer."
-Pues diciéndose adiós, u otra fórmula semejante, a elección.
"Then say it."
-¿Por ejemplo?
"Farewell, Mr. Rochester, for the present."
-Hasta la vista...
"What must I say?"
-Y yo, por mi parte, ¿qué debo decir?
"The same, if you like, sir."
-Lo mismo, si usted gusta.
-Bien.
"Farewell, Miss Eyre, for the present; is that all?"
Adiós, Miss Eyre, hasta la vista.
¿Nada más?
"Yes?"
-Nada mas.
"It seems stingy, to my notions, and dry, and unfriendly.
-A mí me parece esto muy frío y poco afectuoso.
I should like something else: a little addition to the rite.
Convendría añadir algún detalle a ese ritual.
If one shook hands, for instance; but no--that would not content me either.
Un apretón de manos, por ejemplo...
Pero eso sería lo mismo.
So you'll do no more than say Farewell, Jane?"
¿Así que se limita usted a decirme adiós?
"It is enough, sir: as much good-will may be conveyed in one hearty word as in many."
-Es suficiente, señor.
Tanto se puede decir con una palabra como con muchas.
"Very likely; but it is blank and cool--'Farewell.'"
-Pero esto es tan seco, tan glacial...
«Adiós...»
"How long is he going to stand with his back against that door?"
I asked myself; "I want to commence my packing."
-Tengo que hacer mi equipaje... -empecé a decir.
The dinner-bell rang, and suddenly away he bolted, without another syllable: I saw him no more during the day, and was off before he had risen in the morning.
Pero en aquel momento sonó la campana de la cena y él, sin añadir una sola sílaba más, se alejó.
No le vi en todo el día y partí al día siguiente antes de que se levantara.
I reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o'clock in the afternoon of the first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall.
Llegué a Gateshead a las cinco de aquella tarde de principios de mayo.
Me detuve en la portería antes de seguir a la casa.
Todo estaba aseadísimo y cuidado.
It was very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little white curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were burnished bright, and the fire burnt clear.
Las ventanas ostentaban blancas cortinillas.
El suelo se hallaba escrupulosamente limpio.
Bessie sat on the hearth, nursing her last-born, and Robert and his sister played quietly in a corner.
Los dorados brillaban y en la chimenea ardía un excelente fuego.
Bessie estaba junto a la lumbre amamantando a su pequeño y Robert y su hermana jugaban tranquilamente en un rincón.
"Bless you!--I knew you would come!" exclaimed Mrs. Leaven, as I entered.
-¡Bendito sea Dios!
Ya sabía yo que vendría -dijo Bessie al verme entrar.
"Yes, Bessie," said I, after I had kissed her; "and I trust I am not too late.
-Sí, Bessie -dije, besándola-.
He venido en cuanto me ha sido posible.
How is Mrs. Reed?--Alive still, I hope."
¿Y mi tía?
Confío en que vivirá aún.
"Yes, she is alive; and more sensible and collected than she was.
-Vive, y hasta está más lúcida.
The doctor says she may linger a week or two yet; but he hardly thinks she will finally recover."
El doctor cree que resistirá aún una o dos semanas, pero dudo mucho que se restablezca.
"Has she mentioned me lately?"
-¿Ha vuelto a mencionarme?
"She was talking of you only this morning, and wishing you would come, but she is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the house.
-Esta mañana.
Ahora -por lo menos hace diez minutos- está durmiendo.
She generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and wakes up about six or seven.
Suele pasar aletargada toda la tarde y despertar a las seis o las siete.
Will you rest yourself here an hour, Miss, and then I will go up with you?"
¿Quiere quedarse aquí una hora?
Luego subiría yo con usted...

Robert here entered, and Bessie laid her sleeping child in the cradle and went to welcome him: afterwards she insisted on my taking off my bonnet and having some tea; for she said I looked pale and tired.
Entró Robert, y Bessie, dejando al niño en la cuna, fue a recibirle.
Después insistió en que yo me quitase el sombrero y tomase el té, porque le parecía verme pálida y fatigada.
I was glad to accept her hospitality; and I submitted to be relieved of my travelling garb just as passively as I used to let her undress me when a child.
Acepté con satisfacción su hospitalidad y dejé que me quitase la ropa de viaje como cuando era niña y ella me desvestía.

Old times crowded fast back on me as I watched her bustling about--setting out the tea-tray with her best china, cutting bread and butter, toasting a tea-cake, and, between whiles, giving little Robert or Jane an occasional tap or push, just as she used to give me in former days.
Recordé los viejos tiempos al verla preparar el té, cortar pan con manteca, tostar los bollos y, entretanto, dar algún empujón o un cachete a Robert y Jane, como a mí cuando era niña.
Bessie had retained her quick temper as well as her light foot and good looks.
Bessie había conservado su genio vivo como conservaba su agilidad y su buen aspecto.
Tea ready, I was going to approach the table; but she desired me to sit still, quite in her old peremptory tones.

I must be served at the fireside, she said; and she placed before me a little round stand with my cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as she used to accommodate me with some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and I smiled and obeyed her as in bygone days.

Una vez preparado el té, me dispuse a sentarme a la mesa, pero ella, con el tono autoritario de los años antiguos, me conminó a instalarme junto a la lumbre y colocó ante mí una mesita redonda en la que puso el servicio, exactamente como en mi infancia.
Y, como en mi infancia también, la obedecí, sonriendo.
She wanted to know if I was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of a person the mistress was; and when I told her there was only a master, whether he was a nice gentleman, and if I liked him.
Me preguntó si estaba contenta en Thornfield Hall y cómo era la señora.
I told her he was rather an ugly man, but quite a gentleman; and that he treated me kindly, and I was content.
Contesté que no era señora, sino señor, y por cierto todo un caballero, que me trataba amablemente, y que estaba muy satisfecha.
Then I went on to describe to her the gay company that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details Bessie listened with interest: they were precisely of the kind she relished.
Luego le describí la clase de visitantes que había en la casa y Bessie me atendió con interés, porque tales detalles eran los que le encantaban.
In such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me my bonnet, &c., and, accompanied by her, I quitted the lodge for the hall.
Hablando, se nos fue una hora.
Bessie volvió a ponerme el sombrero y demás adminículos y nos dirigimos a la casa.
It was also accompanied by her that I had, nearly nine years ago, walked down the path I was now ascending.

On a dark, misty, raw morning in January, I had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered heart--a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation--to seek the chilly harbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored.

También fui acompañada por ella como bajara yo, nueve años atrás, la escalera que ahora subía, en aquella oscura y brumosa mañana de enero en que abandoné una mansión hostil con el corazón amargado y desesperado, para buscar el frío refugio de Lowood, entonces lugar desconocido e inexplorado para mí.
The same hostile roof now again rose before me: my prospects were doubtful yet; and I had yet an aching heart.
I still felt as a wanderer on the face of the earth; but I experienced firmer trust in myself and my own powers, and less withering dread of oppression.

El mismo techo hostil me acogía de nuevo y también ahora me parecía ser una peregrina errante a través de la tierra, pero me sentía más segura de mí misma y me asustaban menos las injusticias que pudieran cometer conmigo los demás.
The gaping wound of my wrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment extinguished.
La herida de los agravios recibidos hacía tiempo estaba curada y la llama de los rencores, extinguida.
"You shall go into the breakfast-room first," said Bessie, as she preceded me through the hall; "the young ladies will be there."
-Entre primero en el cuarto de desayunar -dijo Bessie-.
Están allí las señoritas.
In another moment I was within that apartment.
Entré.
There was every article of furniture looking just as it did on the morning I was first introduced to Mr. Brocklehurst: the very rug he had stood upon still covered the hearth.
Todo estaba igual que la mañana en que me presentaran a Mr.
Brock1ehurst.

Glancing at the bookcases, I thought I could distinguish the two volumes of Bewick's British Birds occupying their old place on the third shelf, and Gulliver's Travels and the Arabian Nights ranged just above.
La alfombra era la misma, idéntica la biblioteca y hasta en su tercer estante pude distinguir Los viajes de Gulliver, Las mil y una noches y los demás libros que leía en mi niñez.
The inanimate objects were not changed; but the living things had altered past recognition.
Los objetos inanimados no habían cambiado, pero los vivientes habían experimentado variación.
Two young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as Miss Ingram--very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien.
Ante mí se hallaban dos jóvenes: una muy alta, casi tanto como Blanche Ingram, muy delgada, de faz severa y cetrina.

There was something ascetic in her look, which was augmented by the extreme plainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen collar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of a string of ebony beads and a crucifix.
Todo en su aspecto era ascético.
Aumentaba esta impresión la extrema sencillez de su vestido negro con un cuello blanco almidonado, su cabello liso y el monjil adorno de un rosario y un crucifijo.
This I felt sure was Eliza, though I could trace little resemblance to her former self in that elongated and colourless visage.
Tuve la certeza de que era Eliza aunque se parecía muy poco a la Eliza de mis recuerdos.
The other was as certainly Georgiana: but not the Georgiana I remembered--the slim and fairy-like girl of eleven.
La otra era Georgiana pero no la Georgiana de once años, la linda y delgada muchachita que yo evocaba.
This was a full-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and regular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair.
La actual era una opulenta joven, de amplias líneas, blanca como la cera, de hermosas y correctas facciones, lánguidos ojos azules y dorados rizos.
The hue of her dress was black too; but its fashion was so different from her sister's--so much more flowing and becoming--it looked as stylish as the other's looked puritanical.
Su vestido era negro también, pero absolutamente distinto del de su hermana.

In each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother--and only one; the thin and pallid elder daughter had her parent's Cairngorm eye: the blooming and luxuriant younger girl had her contour of jaw and chin--perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable hardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.
Una especie de luto estilizado.
Both ladies, as I advanced, rose to welcome me, and both addressed me by the name of "Miss Eyre."
Ambas se levantaron al entrar yo y me saludaron llamándome «Miss Eyre».
Eliza's greeting was delivered in a short, abrupt voice, without a smile; and then she sat down again, fixed her eyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me.
Eliza me dio la bienvenida con brusca, breve y cortada voz y sin una sonrisa, y luego dirigió la mirada al fuego y pareció olvidarse de mí.

Georgiana added to her "How d'ye do?" several commonplaces about my journey, the weather, and so on, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry side-glances that measured me from head to foot--now traversing the folds of my drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain trimming of my cottage bonnet.

Georgiana añadió un «¿cómo está usted?», varios tópicos acerca de mi viaje y el tiempo que hacía y una mirada con la que me examinó de pies a cabeza, deteniéndose en mi pelliza, de merino de color pardo.
Young ladies have a remarkable way of letting you know that they think you a "quiz" without actually saying the words.
A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner, nonchalance of tone, express fully their sentiments on the point, without committing them by any positive rudeness in word or deed.
Ambas muchachas tenían una curiosa manera de hacerle comprender a una que era una infeliz sin que una sola de sus palabras o actos lo exteriorizasen.
Pero el desprecio, encubierto o no, ejercía poca influencia entonces sobre mí.

A sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power over me it once possessed: as I sat between my cousins, I was surprised to find how easy I felt under the total neglect of the one and the semi- sarcastic attentions of the other--Eliza did not mortify, nor Georgiana ruffle me.
Hasta a mí me maravilló la naturalidad con que me senté entre mis dos primas, con absoluta indiferencia hacia el desprecio de la una y las irónicas amabilidades de la otra.

The fact was, I had other things to think about; within the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more potent than any they could raise--pains and pleasures so much more acute and exquisite had been excited than any it was in their power to inflict or bestow--that their airs gave me no concern either for good or bad.

Yo tenía otras cosas en qué pensar, placeres y dolores mucho mayores que experimentar y sufrir -sobre todo desde los últimos meses- y ellas no podían producirme ninguna impresión semejante, cualesquiera que fuesen sus propósitos en bien o en mal.
"How is Mrs. Reed?"
-¿Cómo está Mrs.
I asked soon, looking calmly at Georgiana, who thought fit to bridle at the direct address, as if it were an unexpected liberty.
Reed? -pregunté a Georgiana.
"Mrs. Reed?
¡Ah, quiere usted decir mamá!
Ah! mama, you mean; she is extremely poorly: I doubt if you can see her to-night."
Muy mal.
Dudo mucho de que pueda usted verla esta noche.
"If," said I, "you would just step upstairs and tell her I am come, I should be much obliged to you."
-Si tiene usted la atención de manifestarla que he venido, se lo agradeceré mucho -dije.
Georgiana almost started, and she opened her blue eyes wild and wide.
Georgiana me miró con asombro.
"I know she had a particular wish to see me," I added, "and I would not defer attending to her desire longer than is absolutely necessary."
-Sé -proseguí- que tenía un particular interés en verme y no quiero aplazar el cumplimiento de su deseo más del tiempo imprescindible.
"Mama dislikes being disturbed in an evening," remarked Eliza.
-A mamá no le agradará que la molesten por la noche -intervino Eliza.

I soon rose, quietly took off my bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I would just step out to Bessie--who was, I dared say, in the kitchen--and ask her to ascertain whether Mrs. Reed was disposed to receive me or not to- night.
Me levanté, cogí el sombrero y los guantes y dije que iba a preguntar a Bessie si Mrs.
Reed estaba dispuesta o no a recibirme aquella noche.
I went, and having found Bessie and despatched her on my errand, I proceeded to take further measures.
La despaché, pues, a averiguarlo y me preparé a adoptar ulteriores medidas.

It had heretofore been my habit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been to-day, I should, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next morning; now, it was disclosed to me all at once that that would be a foolish plan.
Si un año antes me hubiesen hecho una recepción de aquella clase en Gateshead, hubiera partido a la mañana siguiente.
Pero ahora comprendía que ello, en esta ocasión, hubiese sido desacertado.

I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see my aunt, and I must stay with her till she was better--or dead: as to her daughters' pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make myself independent of it.
Había hecho un viaje de cien millas para ver a mi tía y no debía separarme de su lado hasta que mejorase o muriera, sin preocuparme del orgullo y la insensatez de sus hijas.

So I addressed the housekeeper; asked her to show me a room, told her I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two, had my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I met Bessie on the landing.
Me dirigí, pues, al ama de llaves y le pedí que me preparase un cuarto, advirtiéndola que quizá permaneciese allí una semana o dos.
Llevaron mi equipaje a mi cuarto.
Bessie apareció. -La señora está despierta -dijo-.
"Missis is awake," said she; "I have told her you are here: come and let us see if she will know you."
La he dicho que ha venido usted.
Venga y veremos si la reconoce.
I did not need to be guided to the well-known room, to which I had so often been summoned for chastisement or reprimand in former days.
I hastened before Bessie; I softly opened the door: a shaded light stood on the table, for it was now getting dark.
No me era necesario guía para llegar al bien conocido cuarto a que tantas veces me llamaran en los viejos tiempos para propinarme castigos o reprimendas.
Precedí a Bessie y abrí la puerta con suavidad.

There was the great four-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet-table, the armchair, and the footstool, at which I had a hundred times been sentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted.

Sobre la mesa había una bujía y a su luz vi el gran lecho con las mismas cortinas de antes, el tocador, la butaca y el taburete en que cien veces fui condenada a arrodillarme para pedir perdón de faltas que no había cometido.

I looked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim outline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to leap out imp-like and lace my quivering palm or shrinking neck.
Incluso miré a cierto rincón esperando ver la varilla con que solían golpearme la palma de la mano.
I approached the bed; I opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled pillows.
Luego me acerqué al lecho y corrí las cortinillas que colgaban entre sus columnas.
Well did I remember Mrs. Reed's face, and I eagerly sought the familiar image.
Recordando muy bien el rostro de mi tía.
It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance and hushes the promptings of rage and aversion.
El tiempo tiene la virtud de disipar los afanes de venganza y extinguir los impulsos de aversión.

I had left this woman in bitterness and hate, and I came back to her now with no other emotion than a sort of ruth for her great sufferings, and a strong yearning to forget and forgive all injuries--to be reconciled and clasp hands in amity.

Yo me había separado de aquella mujer odiándola y ahora no experimentaba, sin embargo, más que conmiseración hacia sus grandes sufrimientos y un vivo deseo de perdonar y olvidar sus injurias y reconciliarme con ella.
The well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever--there was that peculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised, imperious, despotic eyebrow.
Distinguí su rostro duro e inflexible, su entrecejo imperioso, despótico, sus inconfundibles ojos...
How often had it lowered on me menace and hate! and how the recollection of childhood's terrors and sorrows revived as I traced its harsh line now!
¡Cuántas veces me habían contemplado con odio y amenazadores, y cuántas tristezas y terrores de la niñez me recordaban!
And yet I stooped down and kissed her: she looked at me.
No obstante, me incliné y besé aquel rostro.
"Is this Jane Eyre?" she said.
Ella me miró. -¿Eres Jane Eyre? -dijo.
"Yes, Aunt Reed.
-Sí, lo soy.
How are you, dear aunt?"
¿Cómo está usted, querida tía?
I had once vowed that I would never call her aunt again: I thought it no sin to forget and break that vow now.
Aunque yo jurara una vez no volver a llamarla tía jamás, no consideré pecado quebrantar ahora este juramento.
My fingers had fastened on her hand which lay outside the sheet: had she pressed mine kindly, I should at that moment have experienced true pleasure.
Mis dedos buscaron su mano.
Si ella la hubiese oprimido amistosamente, yo habría encontrado en ello verdadero placer.
But unimpressionable natures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so readily eradicated.
Pero las naturalezas insensibles no se ablandan con facilidad y las antipatías espontáneas no se desarraigan en un momento.
Mrs. Reed took her hand away, and, turning her face rather from me, she remarked that the night was warm.
Ella separó su mano y, volviendo la cara, comentó que la noche era calurosa.
Again she regarded me so icily, I felt at once that her opinion of me--her feeling towards me--was unchanged and unchangeable.
Cuando volvió a mirarme, con igual frialdad que siempre, comprendí que sus sentimientos respecto a mí no habían cambiado ni podían cambiar.

I knew by her stony eye--opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears--that she was resolved to consider me bad to the last; because to believe me good would give her no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.

Adiviné por sus duros ojos, impenetrables a la ternura, incapaces de lágrimas, que ella había resuelto considerarme mala hasta el fin, ya que creerme buena, en vez de producirla un generoso placer, le habría originado una mortificación.
I felt pain, and then I felt ire; and then I felt a determination to subdue her--to be her mistress in spite both of her nature and her will.
My tears had risen, just as in childhood: I ordered them back to their source.
I brought a chair to the bed-head: I sat down and leaned over the pillow.
Sentí pena y enojo, contuve mis lágrimas, a punto ya de brotar, como en la infancia, tomé una silla y me senté a la cabecera del lecho.
"You sent for me," I said, "and I am here; and it is my intention to stay till I see how you get on."
-Me ha enviado usted a buscar -dije- y he venido.
No pienso irme antes de que me diga lo que deseaba.
"Oh, of course!
-Por supuesto.
You have seen my daughters?"
¿Has visto a mis hijas?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"Well, you may tell them I wish you to stay till I can talk some things over with you I have on my mind: to-night it is too late, and I have a difficulty in recalling them.
-Pues puedes decirlas que quiero que estés aquí hasta que pueda explicarte ciertas cosas que tengo en la cabeza.
Ahora es demasiado tarde y no me es fácil recordar...
But there was something I wished to say--let me see--" The wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken place in her once vigorous frame.
Pero deseaba decirte... espera.
Su errante mirada y su alterado rostro demostraban que su antigua energía había desaparecido.
Turning restlessly, she drew the bedclothes round her; my elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed it down: she was at once irritated.
Trató de envolverse en las ropas de la cama.
Mi codo, apoyado en la colcha, se lo dificultaba y se irritó.
"Sit up!" said she; "don't annoy me with holding the clothes fast.
-No me molestes sujetando las ropas -dijo-.
Are you Jane Eyre?"
¿Eres Jane Eyre?
"I am Jane Eyre."
-Sí.
"I have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe.
-Esa niña me ha dado más disgustos que lo que nadie puede imaginar.

Such a burden to be left on my hands--and so much annoyance as she caused me, daily and hourly, with her incomprehensible disposition, and her sudden starts of temper, and her continual, unnatural watchings of one's movements!
¡Cuántas complicaciones me produjo, cada día y cada hora, con su incomprensible carácter y con su brusquedad!
¡Y qué modo tenía de contemplarle a una!
I declare she talked to me once like something mad, or like a fiend--no child ever spoke or looked as she did; I was glad to get her away from the house.
Una vez me habló como lo hubiera hecho un demonio.
Ningún niño habría dicho lo que ella.
Me alegré cuando salió de casa.
What did they do with her at Lowood?
The fever broke out there, and many of the pupils died.
She, however, did not die: but I said she did--I wish she had died!"
¡Y luego, cuando se declaró la epidemia en Lowood y murieron tantas discípulas, ella no murió, a pesar de lo mucho que yo deseaba que muriese!
"A strange wish, Mrs. Reed; why do you hate her so?"
-¡Extraño deseo!
¿Por qué la odiaba así?
-Su madre me era muy antipática.

"I had a dislike to her mother always; for she was my husband's only sister, and a great favourite with him: he opposed the family's disowning her when she made her low marriage; and when news came of her death, he wept like a simpleton.
Era la única hermana de mi marido y él la quería mucho.
Cuando se casó y murió al poco tiempo, mi esposo lloró como un tonto.
He would send for the baby; though I entreated him rather to put it out to nurse and pay for its maintenance.
Se empeñó en recoger a su hija, aunque yo le aconsejaba enviarla con una nodriza y pagar los gastos.
I hated it the first time I set my eyes on it--a sickly, whining, pining thing!
Odié a aquella pequeña desde que la vi, tan enfermiza, tan llorona...
It would wail in its cradle all night long--not screaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning.
No se durmió en su cuna como los demás niños, sino que pasó la noche lloriqueando.
Reed pitied it; and he used to nurse it and notice it as if it had been his own: more, indeed, than he ever noticed his own at that age.
Reed se compadecía de ella y no hacía más que informarse de su salud, como si fuera hija suya, o más aún, porque de sus hijos, a esa edad, casi no se preocupaba.
He would try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: the darlings could not bear it, and he was angry with them when they showed their dislike.
Se empeñaba en que mis niños tratasen bien a aquella mendiga y les reprendía si se negaban.
In his last illness, he had it brought continually to his bedside; and but an hour before he died, he bound me by vow to keep the creature.
Cuando enfermó mortalmente, no hacía más que llamar a la pequeña a su lado y me encargó antes de morir que la conservase bajo mi custodia.
I would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out of a workhouse: but he was weak, naturally weak.
¡Encargarme de una hospiciana!
Reed era débil, muy débil.
John does not at all resemble his father, and I am glad of it: John is like me and like my brothers--he is quite a Gibson.
John no se parece a su padre, gracias a Dios: es como mis hermanas y como yo.
Oh, I wish he would cease tormenting me with letters for money?
¡El vivo retrato de mi hermana Gibson!
I have no more money to give him: we are getting poor.
¡Sólo quisiera que dejase de atormentarme pidiéndome dinero!
I must send away half the servants and shut up part of the house; or let it off.
Ya no tengo nada que darle; estamos casi arruinados.
I can never submit to do that--yet how are we to get on?
Voy a tener que despedir a la mitad de la servidumbre y cerrar parte de la casa.
Two-thirds of my income goes in paying the interest of mortgages.
Dos tercios de las rentas se gastan en pagar los intereses de las hipotecas.
John gambles dreadfully, and always loses--poor boy!
John juega mucho y siempre pierde, el pobre...
Vive rodeado de fulleros.
He is beset by sharpers: John is sunk and degraded--his look is frightful--I feel ashamed for him when I see him."
Y tiene un aspecto horroroso.
Me avergüenza verle como le veo...
She was getting much excited.
"I think I had better leave her now," said I to Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed.
-Será mejor que salgamos -murmuré viendo tan excitada a mi tía.
-Puede ser...
"Perhaps you had, Miss: but she often talks in this way towards night--in the morning she is calmer."
Suele hablar así durante las noches.
Por las mañanas está más tranquila -dijo Bessie, que estaba sentada al otro lado del lecho.
I rose.
Me levanté.
"Stop!" exclaimed Mrs. Reed, "there is another thing I wished to say.
-Esperad -exclamó la Reed-; tengo algo más que decir.
He threatens me--he continually threatens me with his own death, or mine: and I dream sometimes that I see him laid out with a great wound in his throat, or with a swollen and blackened face.
John me amenaza siempre con matarse o matarme.
Muchas veces sueño que le veo tendido, con una enorme herida en la garganta o con el rostro negro, como los ahogados...
I am come to a strange pass: I have heavy troubles.
¡Oh, qué situación la mía!
What is to be done?
¿Qué haré?
How is the money to be had?"
¿De dónde sacaré dinero?
Bessie now endeavoured to persuade her to take a sedative draught: she succeeded with difficulty.
Bessie comenzó a persuadirla de que tomase un sedante y lo logró sin gran trabajo.
Soon after, Mrs. Reed grew more composed, and sank into a dozing state.
A poco, mi tía se tranquilizó y cayó en una especie de letargo.
I then left her.
Entonces me fui.
More than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with her.
Pasaron más de diez días antes de que pudiese reanudar mi conversación con ella.
She continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor forbade everything which could painfully excite her.
Estaba continuamente o delirando o amodorrada, y el médico prohibió hacer nada que pudiese impresionarla.
Meantime, I got on as well as I could with Georgiana and Eliza.
Entretanto me entendí lo mejor que pude con Georgiana y Eliza.
They were very cold, indeed, at first.
Ellas continuaban tan frías como al principio.
Eliza would sit half the day sewing, reading, or writing, and scarcely utter a word either to me or her sister.
Eliza estaba sentada casi todo el día, cosiendo, escribiendo o leyendo, y no nos dirigía la palabra ni a su hermana ni a mí.
Georgiana would chatter nonsense to her canary bird by the hour, and take no notice of me.
Georgiana pasaba horas y horas diciendo tonterías a su canario y no me hacía caso alguno.
But I was determined not to seem at a loss for occupation or amusement: I had brought my drawing materials with me, and they served me for both.
Pero yo no perdía mi tiempo.
Había traído mis útiles de trabajo y los utilizaba.

Provided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to take a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy myself in sketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened momentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of imagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks; the rising moon, and a ship crossing its disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad's head, crowned with lotus- flowers, rising out of them; an elf sitting in a hedge-sparrow's nest, under a wreath of hawthorn-bloom.

Con mi caja de lápices y unas hojas de papel, me sentaba aparte de ellas, junto a la ventana, y me divertía en hacer los dibujos que se me ocurrían, las escenas que desfilaban por el quimérico calidoscopio de mi imaginación.

Un trozo de mar entre las rocas, la luna elevándose sobre el mar y un navío cruzando ante su disco, la cabeza de una náyade coronada de flores de loto surgiendo entre olas, un enano sentado en un nido...
One morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face it was to be, I did not care or know.
Una mañana comencé a dibujar un rostro, sin preocuparme de lo que pudiera resultar.
I took a soft black pencil, gave it a broad point, and worked away.
Tomé un lápiz blando, de punta ancha, y comencé a trabajar.
Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and prominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: that contour gave me pleasure; my fingers proceeded actively to fill it with features.
A poco, había trazado una frente amplia y saliente, y el contorno de una cara cuadrada.
El principio me agradó y comencé a completar las facciones.

Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under that brow; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight ridge and full nostrils; then a flexible-looking mouth, by no means narrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it: of course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted on the temples, and waved above the forehead.

Bajo aquella frente se imponían unas cejas horizontales reciamente marcadas, a las que habían de seguir, naturalmente, una nariz enérgica, de amplias ventanas, una boca flexible y una firme barbilla con un bien definido hoyo en el centro.
El conjunto necesitaba, evidentemente, patillas negras y cabello negro, formando dos tufos en las sienes y ondeado por arriba.
Now for the eyes: I had left them to the last, because they required the most careful working.
Los ojos habían quedado para lo último, por requerir un trabajo más esmerado.
I drew them large; I shaped them well: the eyelashes I traced long and sombre; the irids lustrous and large.
Los hice grandes, muy sombreados, con largas pestañas y pupila ancha y brillante.
Mirándolo, pensé: «Está bien, pero no produce un efecto completo.

"Good! but not quite the thing," I thought, as I surveyed the effect: "they want more force and spirit;" and I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more brilliantly--a happy touch or two secured success.
Necesita más fuerza, más alma.»
Un par de toques, que dieron a las sombras más oscuridad y a las luces más brillo, completaron felizmente el trabajo.
There, I had a friend's face under my gaze; and what did it signify that those young ladies turned their backs on me?
Tenía el rostro de un amigo ante mis ojos.
Por tanto, ¿qué importaba que aquellas dos jóvenes me volviesen la espalda?
I looked at it; I smiled at the speaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.
Me sentí absorta y contenta y sonreí contemplando el dibujo.
"Is that a portrait of some one you know?" asked Eliza, who had approached me unnoticed.
-¿Es el retrato de algún conocido suyo? -preguntó Eliza que se había acercado a mí sin que yo me diera cuenta.
I responded that it was merely a fancy head, and hurried it beneath the other sheets.
Respondí que era un dibujo caprichoso y lo coloqué entre los demás que tenía.
Of course, I lied: it was, in fact, a very faithful representation of Mr. Rochester.
Yo sabía, desde luego, que era una representación muy exacta de Mr.
But what was that to her, or to any one but myself?
Rochester, mas ¿qué le interesaba eso a nadie, sino a mí misma?
Georgiana also advanced to look.
Georgiana se acercó también para mirar.
The other drawings pleased her much, but she called that "an ugly man."
Los demás dibujos le gustaron mucho, pero aquél, según ella, era «un hombre muy feo».
They both seemed surprised at my skill.
Las dos parecieron sorprendidas de mi habilidad.
I offered to sketch their portraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline.
Entonces les ofrecí hacer sus retratos.
Ambas se sentaron, ante mí, una después de otra, y obtuve de cada una un apunte de lápiz.
Then Georgiana produced her album.
Georgiana entonces sacó su álbum y le ofrecí contribuir a enriquecerlo con un dibujo a la aguada.
I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing: this put her at once into good humour.
Esto acabó por ponerla de buen humor.
She proposed a walk in the grounds.

Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a confidential conversation: she had favoured me with a description of the brilliant winter she had spent in London two seasons ago--of the admiration she had there excited--the attention she had received; and I even got hints of the titled conquest she had made.
Propuso dar un paseo por los alrededores y antes de dos horas estábamos entregadas a una conversación confidencial.

Me describió la brillante temporada que había pasado en Londres dos años antes, la admiración que le produjera, las atenciones de que la hicieron objeto y aun la conquista que había realizado de un joven aristócrata.

In the course of the afternoon and evening these hints were enlarged on: various soft conversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and, in short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day improvised by her for my benefit.
En el curso de la tarde y de la noche, las confidencias se profundizaron, me fueron relatados varios dulces coloquios y algunas escenas sentimentales.
En resumen, Georgiana improvisó en obsequio mío una verdadera novela sentimental.
The communications were renewed from day to day: they always ran on the same theme--herself, her loves, and woes.
Sus expansiones aumentaron de día en día, versando todas sobre el mismo tema: su amor y sus pesares.
It was strange she never once adverted either to her mother's illness, or her brother's death, or the present gloomy state of the family prospects.
Her mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of past gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come.

Era curioso que, en aquel sombrío momento de la vida de su familia, con su hermano muerto y su madre enferma, no pensara nunca en ello, limitándose a recrearse en el recuerdo de las pasadas alegrías y en imaginar las venturas que podría reservarle el porvenir.
She passed about five minutes each day in her mother's sick-room, and no more.
Pasaba diariamente cinco minutos en el cuarto de su madre, y no aparecía más por allí.
Eliza still spoke little: she had evidently no time to talk.
Eliza hablaba poco, sin duda por falta de tiempo.
I never saw a busier person than she seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say what she did: or rather, to discover any result of her diligence.
Jamás he visto persona más atareada de lo que ella parecía estar.
Lo difícil era descubrir los resultados prácticos de su actividad.
She had an alarm to call her up early.
I know not how she occupied herself before breakfast, but after that meal she divided her time into regular portions, and each hour had its allotted task.
No sé lo que hacía antes de desayunar, pero desde ese momento, todas sus horas estaban reguladas y dedicadas a una tarea diferente.
Three times a day she studied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common Prayer Book.
Tres veces al día estudiaba un pequeño libro que, según averigüé mediante la oportuna inspección, era un devocionario corriente.
I asked her once what was the great attraction of that volume, and she said, "the Rubric."
Three hours she gave to stitching, with gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large enough for a carpet.
Tres horas al día trabajaba bordando en oro una tela cuadrada que, por su tamaño, parecía una alfombra.
In answer to my inquiries after the use of this article, she informed me it was a covering for the altar of a new church lately erected near Gateshead.
Preguntándole sobre su objeto, me dijo que estaba destinada a cubrir el altar de una iglesia recientemente erigida en las cercanías de Gateshead.
Two hours she devoted to her diary; two to working by herself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the regulation of her accounts.
Dedicaba otras dos horas a escribir su diario, una a trabajar en el huerto y otra a hacer sus cuentas.
She seemed to want no company; no conversation.
Al parecer, no necesitaba compañía ni conversación.
I believe she was happy in her way: this routine sufficed for her; and nothing annoyed her so much as the occurrence of any incident which forced her to vary its clockwork regularity.
Creo que era feliz a su modo y que aquella rutina la bastaba.
Nada le disgustaba tanto como cualquier incidente que rompiese la monotonía de su vida regulada por el reloj.

She told me one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than usual, that John's conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had been a source of profound affliction to her: but she had now, she said, settled her mind, and formed her resolution.

Una noche en que se sentía más comunicativa que de costumbre, me dijo que la conducta de John y la ruina que amenazaba a su familia la habían afligido mucho, pero que al fin se había tranquilizado y adoptado su resolución.
