Her own fortune she had taken care to secure; and when her mother died--and it was wholly improbable, she tranquilly remarked, that she should either recover or linger long--she would execute a long-cherished project: seek a retirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from disturbance, and place safe barriers between herself and a frivolous world.

Habiendo tenido la precaución de salvar de la ruina sus propios bienes, cuando su madre muriera, ya que -según decía con toda tranquilidad- no era probable que curase ni que resistiese mucho, se proponía ejecutar un proyecto largo tiempo acariciado: retirarse a un lugar donde las costumbres rutinarias pudiesen asegurarse contra toda turbación exterior, y donde le fuese fácil establecer barreras entre ella y el frívolo mundo.
I asked if Georgiana would accompany her.
Le pregunté si Georgiana pensaba acompañarla.
"Of course not.
-Desde luego, no.
Georgiana and she had nothing in common: they never had had.
She would not be burdened with her society for any consideration.
Georgiana y yo no nos parecemos en nada ni nos hemos parecido nunca.
Georgiana should take her own course; and she, Eliza, would take hers."
Georgiana seguirá su camino y yo el mío.

Georgiana, when not unburdening her heart to me, spent most of her time in lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and wishing over and over again that her aunt Gibson would send her an invitation up to town.

Georgiana, cuando no empleaba el tiempo en abrirme su corazón, pasaba el día tumbada en el sofá, esperando con ansia el momento en que su tía Gibson le enviase una invitación para ir una temporada a la ciudad.
"It would be so much better," she said, "if she could only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over."
-Sería mejor -solía decir- que me marchara durante uno o dos meses, hasta que todo pasara.
I did not ask what she meant by "all being over," but I suppose she referred to the expected decease of her mother and the gloomy sequel of funeral rites.
Aquel «todo pasara» supongo, aunque nunca se lo pregunté, que quería decir hasta que su madre hubiera muerto y se efectuaran los funerales y demás solemnidades lúgubres.
Eliza generally took no more notice of her sister's indolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had been before her.
One day, however, as she put away her account-book and unfolded her embroidery, she suddenly took her up thus--
Eliza, generalmente, no solía hacer caso alguno de su hermana ni de sus quejas, pero un día, después de apartar su libro de cuentas y sus bordados, le habló de este modo:
"Georgiana, a more vain and absurd animal than you was certainly never allowed to cumber the earth.
-Georgiana; nunca ha existido en el mundo un ser más inútil y absurdo que tú.
You had no right to be born, for you make no use of life.
No tienes derecho a la vida, porque no sabes vivir.

Instead of living for, in, and with yourself, as a reasonable being ought, you seek only to fasten your feebleness on some other person's strength: if no one can be found willing to burden her or himself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, you cry out that you are ill-treated, neglected, miserable.
En vez de existir por ti y para ti, como debe hacer toda persona sensata, te es imposible prescindir de transmitir tus debilidades a otras personas de más energía que tú.
Si no las encuentras, comienzas a lamentarte de que eres desgraciada, de que te tratan mal, de que no te hacen caso.

Then, too, existence for you must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the world is a dungeon: you must be admired, you must be courted, you must be flattered--you must have music, dancing, and society--or you languish, you die away.
Para ti, el mundo es una prisión si no hay en él continuos cambios y novedades, si no te admiran, te adulan y te cortejan.
No sabes pasar sin el baile, la música, la compañía y por eso te aburres mortalmente.
Have you no sense to devise a system which will make you independent of all efforts, and all wills, but your own?
¿Quieres que te diga cómo puedes existir de un modo independiente, por ti misma, sin ayuda ajena?

Take one day; share it into sections; to each section apportion its task: leave no stray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes--include all; do each piece of business in its turn with method, with rigid regularity.
Divide tu día en partes y a cada una asígnale una tarea, sin dejar un cuarto de hora, diez minutos, ni cinco siquiera, sin algo que hacer.

The day will close almost before you are aware it has begun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one vacant moment: you have had to seek no one's company, conversation, sympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent being ought to do.
Cuando sea así, observarás que no necesitas compañía, conversación ni simpatía de nadie.
Y lograrás vivir con la independencia a que todo ser humano debe aspirar.
Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer you; then you will not want me or any one else, happen what may.
Sigue mi consejo, primero y último que te doy, y verás cómo no necesitas de mí ni de nadie, suceda lo que quiera.
Neglect it--go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling--and suffer the results of your idiocy, however bad and insuperable they may be.
Si no lo atiendes, sufrirás los resultados de tu sandez, por malos que sean.
Te lo digo francamente.
I tell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat what I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on it.
Escúchame bien, porque no volveré a hablarte así, sino que me limitaré a obrar.
After my mother's death, I wash my hands of you: from the day her coffin is carried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate as if we had never known each other.
En cuanto mamá muera, yo me lavo las manos respecto a ti.
El mismo día que la saquen de Gateshead, tú y yo nos separaremos para no volvernos a ver.

You need not think that because we chanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten me down by even the feeblest claim: I can tell you this--if the whole human race, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on the earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake myself to the new."
No imagines que porque hayamos nacido de los mismos padres voy a estar tolerando siempre tus quejas y tus lamentaciones.
Te digo más: si toda la raza humana fuera borrada del mapa y quedásemos tú y yo solas, te abandonaría en el Viejo Mundo y me marcharía al Nuevo.
She closed her lips.
"You might have spared yourself the trouble of delivering that tirade," answered Georgiana.
-Podías haberte ahorrado el sermón-dijo Georgiana cuando su hermana dejó de hablar-.
Nadie ignora que eres el ser más egoísta y de menos corazón que existe en el mundo, y a mí me constan tu odio y tu envidia hacia mí.

"Everybody knows you are the most selfish, heartless creature in existence: and _I_ know your spiteful hatred towards me: I have had a specimen of it before in the trick you played me about Lord Edwin Vere: you could not bear me to be raised above you, to have a title, to be received into circles where you dare not show your face, and so you acted the spy and informer, and ruined my prospects for ever."
Ya me lo demostraste lo suficiente con el papel que te diste prisa a desempeñar en mis relaciones con Lord Edwin Vere.
Te era insoportable que me elevase sobre ti, que obtuviera un título, que me recibiera en ambiente donde tú no te atreverías ni a asomar la cara.
Por eso actuaste como espía y destruiste para siempre mis esperanzas.
Georgiana took out her handkerchief and blew her nose for an hour afterwards; Eliza sat cold, impassable, and assiduously industrious.
Y Georgiana sacando su pañuelo, lo aplicó a su rostro y así permaneció más de una hora.
Eliza se sentó, fría y hermética, y se dedicó a su labor.
True, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were two natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably savourless for the want of it.
Feeling without judgment is a washy draught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and husky a morsel for human deglutition.
El día era lluvioso y soplaba un fuerte viento.
Georgiana se durmió sobre el sofá, con una novela entre las manos.
Eliza había ido a la iglesia.

It was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgiana had fallen asleep on the sofa over the perusal of a novel; Eliza was gone to attend a saint's-day service at the new church--for in matters of religion she was a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge of what she considered her devotional duties; fair or foul, she went to church thrice every Sunday, and as often on week-days as there were prayers.
Practicaba con rigidez sus deberes religiosos, acudiendo a la iglesia tres veces cada domingo y los demás días de entre semana, si se celebraban plegarias, hiciera el tiempo que hiciese.
Subí a la alcoba de la moribunda, sospechando que acaso se hallase desatendida, lo que ocurría con frecuencia, ya que los criados sólo le dedicaban una relativa atención.

I bethought myself to go upstairs and see how the dying woman sped, who lay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid her but a remittent attention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out of the room whenever she could.
Bessie was faithful; but she had her own family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall.
La enfermera se marchaba del cuarto en cuanto podía, y Bessie, aunque muy fiel, tenía bastante quehacer con su propia familia y rara vez podía dirigirse a la casa.
I found the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there; the patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; her livid face sunk in the pillows: the fire was dying in the grate.
Como esperaba, hallé solitario el dormitorio de la enferma.
La paciente parecía estar amodorrada, con la lívida faz sobre el almohadón; el fuego de la chimenea se estaba apagando.
I renewed the fuel, re-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on her who could not now gaze on me, and then I moved away to the window.
Eché más leña, arreglé las ropas del lecho, contemplé a mi tía y me acerqué a la ventana.
The rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously: "One lies there," I thought, "who will soon be beyond the war of earthly elements.
La lluvia batía violentamente los cristales y el viento aullaba con rabia.
Whither will that spirit--now struggling to quit its material tenement--flit when at length released?"
«¿Dónde irá -pensaba yo- el alma de esta mujer cuando abandone su cuerpo moribundo?»
In pondering the great mystery, I thought of Helen Burns, recalled her dying words--her faith--her doctrine of the equality of disembodied souls.
Mientras meditaba en tan gran misterio, recordaba a Helen Burns, sus últimas palabras, su fe, su creencia en la vida del más allá.

I was still listening in thought to her well-remembered tones--still picturing her pale and spiritual aspect, her wasted face and sublime gaze, as she lay on her placid deathbed, and whispered her longing to be restored to her divine Father's bosom--when a feeble voice murmured from the couch behind: "Who is that?"
Y me parecía escuchar su plácido tono, contemplar su rostro pálido y espiritual y su mirada sublime, verla luego tendida en su tranquilo lecho mortuorio...
I knew Mrs. Reed had not spoken for days: was she reviving?
De pronto, una débil voz murmuró: -¿Quién está ahí?
I went up to her.
"It is I, Aunt Reed."
-Soy yo, tía.
"Who--I?" was her answer.
"Who are you?" looking at me with surprise and a sort of alarm, but still not wildly.
-¿Quién -repuso con sorpresa y alarma-.
"You are quite a stranger to me--where is Bessie?"
No la conozco.
¿Dónde está Bessie?
"She is at the lodge, aunt."
-Está en la portería, tía.
"Aunt," she repeated.
-¡Tía!
"Who calls me aunt?
¿Por qué me llama tía?
You are not one of the Gibsons; and yet I know you--that face, and the eyes and forehead, are quiet familiar to me: you are like--why, you are like Jane Eyre!"
Usted no es ninguna de las Gibson, y aunque la creo reconocer...
Sí; esa cara, esos ojos y esa frente me recuerdan algo.
Es usted como... como Jane Eyre. .
I said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring my identity.
No dije nada, temiendo producirla una impresión muy fuerte si la descubría mi identidad.
"Yet," said she, "I am afraid it is a mistake: my thoughts deceive me.
-Sin embargo -siguió-, debo de estar equivocada.
Me engaña el corazón.
I wished to see Jane Eyre, and I fancy a likeness where none exists: besides, in eight years she must be so changed."
Quisiera ver a Jane Eyre y la imaginación me hace ver lo que no existe.
En ocho años debe de haber cambiado mucho.

I now gently assured her that I was the person she supposed and desired me to be: and seeing that I was understood, and that her senses were quite collected, I explained how Bessie had sent her husband to fetch me from Thornfield.
Entonces le aseguré con amabilidad que yo era la persona que ella suponía y a quien deseaba ver.
Notando que me comprendía y que estaba en sus cabales sentidos, le expliqué que el marido de Bessie había ido a buscarme a Thornfield.
"I am very ill, I know," she said ere long.
-Estoy muy enferma, lo sé-dijo ella-.
"I was trying to turn myself a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb.
Hace poco he querido volverme y he notado que no puedo ni mover los músculos.
It is as well I should ease my mind before I die: what we think little of in health, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to me.
Menos mal que recobro mi sentido antes de morir, porque cuando uno está sano piensa poco en lo que sucede en estos momentos...
Is the nurse here? or is there no one in the room but you?"
¿Está la enfermera ahí o estás tú sola?
I assured her we were alone.
Afirmé que estaba sola.
"Well, I have twice done you a wrong which I regret now.
-Bueno...
En dos ocasiones me he portado mal contigo.
One was in breaking the promise which I gave my husband to bring you up as my own child; the other--" she stopped.
La primera, quebrantando la promesa que hice a mi marido de que te trataría como a mis propios hijos...
"After all, it is of no great importance, perhaps," she murmured to herself: "and then I may get better; and to humble myself so to her is painful."
La otra... -y se interrumpió-.
Después de todo, acaso no tenga gran importancia -dijo como para sí- y podría prescindir de humillarme...
Trató de cambiar de postura y no pudo.
She made an effort to alter her position, but failed: her face changed; she seemed to experience some inward sensation--the precursor, perhaps, of the last pang.
La expresión de su faz se alteró.
Parecía experimentar una sensación extraña: acaso la precursora del fin.
"Well, I must get it over.
-Haré mejor en hablar.
Eternity is before me: I had better tell her.--Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you will see there."
Estoy al borde de la eternidad.
Vete al cajón de mi armario y saca una carta que hallarás allí.
I obeyed her directions.
-Y cuando hube obedecido, ordenó-:
"Read the letter," she said.
Léela.
It was short, and thus conceived:--
La carta, muy breve, decía:
"Madam,--Will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre, and to tell me how she is?
«Señora: ¿Tendrá usted la bondad de enviarme la dirección de mi sobrina Jane Eyre y decirme cómo está?
It is my intention to write shortly and desire her to come to me at Madeira.
Me propongo escribirla y traerla conmigo a Madera.

Providence has blessed my endeavours to secure a competency; and as I am unmarried and childless, I wish to adopt her during my life, and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave.--I am, Madam, &c., &c.,
La Providencia ha favorecido mi trabajo y, como soy soltero y sin hijos, me propongo adoptar a mi sobrina y cederla a mi muerte cuanto poseo.
"JOHN EYRE, Madeira."
«De usted, atto. etc. -JAME EYRE, Madera.»
It was dated three years back.
La carta estaba fechada tres años antes.
"Why did I never hear of this?"
I asked.
-¿Cómo no se me informó de eso? -pregunté.
"Because I disliked you too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand in lifting you to prosperity.
-Porque yo no deseaba mover una sola mano en favor tuyo.

I could not forget your conduct to me, Jane--the fury with which you once turned on me; the tone in which you declared you abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the unchildlike look and voice with which you affirmed that the very thought of me made you sick, and asserted that I had treated you with miserable cruelty.

Yo no podía olvidar tu comportamiento conmigo, Jane, la furia con que una vez te revolviste contra mí, el tono con que declaraste que me odiabas más que a nadie en el mundo, que todos mis pensamientos hacia ti eran de aversión y que te trataba con horrible crueldad.

I could not forget my own sensations when you thus started up and poured out the venom of your mind: I felt fear as if an animal that I had struck or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes and cursed me in a man's voice.--Bring me some water!
No podía olvidar tampoco lo que experimentaba cuando te volvías contra mí y comenzabas a increparme.
Era como si un animal a quien hubiese golpeado me mirara con ojos humanos y me hablase para recriminarme.
Oh, make haste!"
¡Tráeme agua!
Apresúrate.
"Dear Mrs. Reed," said I, as I offered her the draught she required, "think no more of all this, let it pass away from your mind.
-Querida tía -dije, al llevarle lo que pedía-, no piense más en eso.
Perdone mi violento lenguaje.
Forgive me for my passionate language: I was a child then; eight, nine years have passed since that day."
Yo era entonces una niña.
Han pasado ocho o nueve años desde entonces.
She heeded nothing of what I said; but when she had tasted the water and drawn breath, she went on thus--
No hizo caso de lo que decía.
Después de beber y respirar profundamente, continuó:
"I tell you I could not forget it; and I took my revenge: for you to be adopted by your uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was what I could not endure.
-Te dije que no te perdonaría aquello y, en efecto, tomé mi desquite, porque la idea de que fueras adoptada por tu tío y vivieras bien era insoportable para mí.
I wrote to him; I said I was sorry for his disappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead: she had died of typhus fever at Lowood.
Le escribí diciéndole que sentía comunicárselo, pero que habías muerto de tifus en Lowood.
Now act as you please: write and contradict my assertion--expose my falsehood as soon as you like.
Ahora haz lo que quieras.
Escribe desmintiéndome, si te parece.
You were born, I think, to be my torment: my last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which, but for you, I should never have been tempted to commit."
Creo que has nacido para ser mi tormento; hasta en mi última hora he de ser torturada por el recuerdo de un mal que no debía cometer ni aun tratándose de ti.
"If you could but be persuaded to think no more of it, aunt, and to regard me with kindness and forgiveness"
-Quisiera que no pensase más en ello, tía, y que me mirase con afecto.

"You have a very bad disposition," said she, "and one to this day I feel it impossible to understand: how for nine years you could be patient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out all fire and violence, I can never comprehend."
-Tienes muy malos instintos -repuso-, y aún hoy no comprendo cómo has sido capaz de permanecer nueve años en el colegio sin rebelarte.
"My disposition is not so bad as you think: I am passionate, but not vindictive.
-Mis instintos no son tan malos como usted piensa.
Soy vehemente, pero no vengativa.
Many a time, as a little child, I should have been glad to love you if you would have let me; and I long earnestly to be reconciled to you now: kiss me, aunt."
Durante mucho tiempo, mientras fui niña, hubiera deseado quererla mucho, si usted me lo hubiera permitido, y ahora deseo reconciliarme con usted.
Béseme, tía.
I approached my cheek to her lips: she would not touch it.
Aproximé mis mejillas a sus labios, pero no me tocó.
She said I oppressed her by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water.
Dijo que la ahogaba inclinándome así sobre la cama, y me pidió más agua.

As I laid her down--for I raised her and supported her on my arm while she drank--I covered her ice-cold and clammy hand with mine: the feeble fingers shrank from my touch--the glazing eyes shunned my gaze.
La incorporé para que bebiese y, al volverla a acostar, coloqué mis manos sobre las suyas, heladas, que se retiraron de mi contacto, mientras su apagada mirada esquivaba la mía.
"Love me, then, or hate me, as you will," I said at last, "you have my full and free forgiveness: ask now for God's, and be at peace."
-Quiérame u ódieme, como desee -dije, al fin-.
En uno u otro caso, la perdono de corazón.
¡Dios la perdone también!
¡Pobre mujer!
Poor, suffering woman! it was too late for her to make now the effort to change her habitual frame of mind: living, she had ever hated me--dying, she must hate me still.
Era demasiado tarde para que cambiase de carácter.
Me había odiado en vida y era, al parecer, inevitable que me odiara en su agonía.
The nurse now entered, and Bessie followed.
Entró la enfermera, seguida de Bessie.
I yet lingered half-an-hour longer, hoping to see some sign of amity: but she gave none.
Permanecí en la estancia media hora más, esperando que mi tía diese algún indicio de alivio, pero no dio ninguno.
She was fast relapsing into stupor; nor did her mind again rally: at twelve o'clock that night she died.
Permaneció sumida en el habitual sopor y a medianoche falleció.
I was not present to close her eyes, nor were either of her daughters.
Ni sus hijas ni yo estuvimos presentes para cerrar sus ojos.
They came to tell us the next morning that all was over.
She was by that time laid out.
A la mañana siguiente nos dijeron que todo había terminado.
Eliza entró a ver a su madre por última vez.
Eliza and I went to look at her: Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping, said she dared not go.
Georgiana que estaba deshecha en llanto, dijo que no se atrevía.
La antes robusta y enérgica Sarah Reed yacía rígida e inmóvil, con los párpados cerrados.
There was stretched Sarah Reed's once robust and active frame, rigid and still: her eye of flint was covered with its cold lid; her brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of her inexorable soul.
En su entrecejo y sus duras facciones estaba impreso aún el sello de la inflexibilidad de su alma.
A strange and solemn object was that corpse to me.
Aquel cadáver me produjo un efecto extraño y solemne.

I gazed on it with gloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or hopeful, or subduing did it inspire; only a grating anguish for _her_ woes--not _my_ loss--and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of death in such a form.
Le miré con espanto y tristeza.
Nada había en él que sugiriese imágenes suaves, de piedad o de esperanza.
Eliza surveyed her parent calmly.
Eliza miró a su madre con serenidad.
After a silence of some minutes she observed--
Después de algunos minutos de silencio, comentó:
"With her constitution she should have lived to a good old age: her life was shortened by trouble."
-Tenía una constitución muy robusta y hubiera vivido mucho más a no haber abreviado su existencia los disgustos.
Su boca se contrajo por un momento.
And then a spasm constricted her mouth for an instant: as it passed away she turned and left the room, and so did I. Neither of us had dropt a tear.
Luego salió del cuarto y yo la seguí.
Ninguna de las dos habíamos vertido una sola lágrima.
CHAPTER XXII
XXII
Mr. Rochester had given me but one week's leave of absence: yet a month elapsed before I quitted Gateshead.
Mr.
Rochester me había concedido una semana de permiso, pero pasó un mes antes de que yo abandonase Gateshead.

I wished to leave immediately after the funeral, but Georgiana entreated me to stay till she could get off to London, whither she was now at last invited by her uncle, Mr. Gibson, who had come down to direct his sister's interment and settle the family affairs.

Pretendí irme en seguida de los funerales, mas Georgiana me obligó a estar con ella hasta su marcha a Londres, donde al fin había sido invitada por su tía Gibson, que acudió para arreglar los asuntos familiares.

Georgiana said she dreaded being left alone with Eliza; from her she got neither sympathy in her dejection, support in her fears, nor aid in her preparations; so I bore with her feeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and did my best in sewing for her and packing her dresses.
Georgiana afirmaba que temía quedar sola con Eliza porque no podía contar para nada con su simpatía ni su ayuda.
Soporté lo mejor que pude sus quejas egoístas y la auxilié con todas mis fuerzas a hacer su equipaje.
It is true, that while I worked, she would idle; and I thought to myself, "If you and I were destined to live always together, cousin, we would commence matters on a different footing.
Mientras yo trabajaba, ella permanecía inactiva, y yo pensaba para mí: «Si nosotras hubiéramos de vivir juntas, primita, las cosas se organizarían sobre una base diferente.

I should not settle tamely down into being the forbearing party; I should assign you your share of labour, and compel you to accomplish it, or else it should be left undone: I should insist, also, on your keeping some of those drawling, half-insincere complaints hushed in your own breast.
Ya me encargaría yo de marcarte tu tarea y te obligaría a cumplirla.
También te persuadiría de que guardases parte de tus lamentaciones en el fondo de tu alma.
It is only because our connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly mournful season, that I consent thus to render it so patient and compliant on my part."
Si tengo tanta paciencia y soy tan complaciente contigo, se debe a la triste ocasión en que te hallas y a que se trata de una cosa pasajera.»
At last I saw Georgiana off; but now it was Eliza's turn to request me to stay another week.
Al fin Georgiana partió, pero entonces fue Eliza quien me pidió que me quedase otra semana.

Her plans required all her time and attention, she said; she was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day long she stayed in her own room, her door bolted within, filling trunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication with any one.

Sus proyectos absorbían todo su tiempo y su atención y, antes de partir para su desconocido destino, se pasaba el día cerrando baúles, vaciando cajones, quemando papeles, todo ello dentro de su cuarto y con el cerrojo echado.
She wished me to look after the house, to see callers, and answer notes of condolence.
Me necesitaba, pues, para que yo atendiese la casa, recibiese pésames y contestase cartas.
One morning she told me I was at liberty.
Al fin, una mañana me dijo que me dejaba en libertad, y añadió:
"And," she added, "I am obliged to you for your valuable services and discreet conduct!
-Le agradezco mucho su discreción y sus valiosos servicios.
There is some difference between living with such an one as you and with Georgiana: you perform your own part in life and burden no one.
¡Qué diferencia entre vivir con una persona como usted o con una como Georgiana!
Usted sabe llenar su misión en la vida.
To-morrow," she continued, "I set out for the Continent.
Mañana -continuó- parto para el continente.
I shall take up my abode in a religious house near Lisle--a nunnery you would call it; there I shall be quiet and unmolested.
Me instalaré en una residencia de religiosas, cerca de Lisle, una especie de monasterio donde viviré tranquila y aislada.

I shall devote myself for a time to the examination of the Roman Catholic dogmas, and to a careful study of the workings of their system: if I find it to be, as I half suspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all things decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Rome and probably take the veil."

Quiero dedicar mi tiempo al examen de los dogmas catolicoromanos, y si, como casi supongo, encuentro que son los que mejor permiten hacer las cosas bien y ordenadamente, abrazaré la fe romana y probablemente me haré monja.
I neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to dissuade her from it.
No manifesté sorpresa por tal resolución ni intenté disuadirla de ella.
"The vocation will fit you to a hair," I thought: "much good may it do you!"
When we parted, she said: "Good-bye, cousin Jane Eyre; I wish you well: you have some sense."
Al despedirme, me dijo: -Adiós, prima Jane Eyre.
Le deseo buena suerte.
Es usted sensata.
I then returned: "You are not without sense, cousin Eliza; but what you have, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French convent.
-También usted, prima Eliza -repuse.
However, it is not my business, and so it suits you, I don't much care."
"You are in the right," said she; and with these words we each went our separate way.
Y con estas palabras nos despedimos.

As I shall not have occasion to refer either to her or her sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an advantageous match with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that Eliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the convent where she passed the period of her novitiate, and which she endowed with her fortune.

Como no habrá ocasión de referirme de nuevo a ninguna de mis primas, me limitaré a mencionar que Georgiana hizo un buen matrimonio con un hombre rico y distinguido y que Eliza profesó como monja después de un año de noviciado y es actualmente superiora de su convento.
How people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or short, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation.

I had known what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long walk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was to come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a good fire, and to be unable to get either.
Neither of these returnings was very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew me to a given point, increasing in its strength of attraction the nearer I came.
The return to Thornfield was yet to be tried.
My journey seemed tedious--very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night spent at an inn; fifty miles the next day.
Mi viaje fue aburrido, muy aburrido.
Una jornada de cincuenta millas, una noche en una posada y cincuenta millas más al día siguiente.
During the first twelve hours I thought of Mrs. Reed in her last moments; I saw her disfigured and discoloured face, and heard her strangely altered voice.
Durante las primeras horas del viaje pensé en los últimos momentos de mi tía: creía ver su desfigurada faz y escuchar su alterada voz.
I mused on the funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and servants--few was the number of relatives--the gaping vault, the silent church, the solemn service.
Recordaba el sepelio: el ataúd, el carruaje fúnebre, la comitiva de criados y colonos -parientes había muy pocos-, la cripta, la silente iglesia, el solemne oficio...

Then I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I beheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a convent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed their separate peculiarities of person and character.
Pensé en Georgiana y en Eliza, figurándome a la una brillando en un salón de baile, y a la otra habitando una celda conventual, y analicé y comparé sus respectivos caracteres.
The evening arrival at the great town of--scattered these thoughts; night gave them quite another turn: laid down on my traveller's bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.
La noche pasada en la gran ciudad de... desvaneció estos pensamientos.
Acostada en mi cama de viajera, sustituí los recuerdos por cábalas sobre el porvenir.
I was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there?
Volvía a Thornfield, pero ¿cuánto tiempo pasaría allí?
Not long; of that I was sure.
Seguramente no mucho.
Mrs.
I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim of my absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Mr. Rochester had left for London three weeks ago, but he was then expected to return in a fortnight.
Fairfax me escribió a Gateshead diciendo que los invitados se habían ido ya y que Mr.
Rochester se había ido a Londres hacía tres semanas y se le esperaba dentro de quince días.
Mrs.

Mrs. Fairfax surmised that he was gone to make arrangements for his wedding, as he had talked of purchasing a new carriage: she said the idea of his marrying Miss Ingram still seemed strange to her; but from what everybody said, and from what she had herself seen, she could no longer doubt that the event would shortly take place.
Fairfax suponía que iba a arreglar asuntos relativos a su matrimonio, puesto que él habló de adquirir un coche nuevo.
A la anciana le resultaba muy rara la idea de que su señor se casase con Blanche Ingram, pero según oyera a todos, la boda no debía dilatarse mucho.
"You would be strangely incredulous if you did doubt it," was my mental comment.
«¡Muy incrédula eres! -comenté mentalmente-.
"I don't doubt it."
¡Yo no experimento duda alguna!»
The question followed, "Where was I to go?"
La cuestión inmediata a estudiar era adónde iría yo.
Soñé por la noche con Blanche, que me cerraba las puertas de Thornfield y me señalaba el camino.

I dreamt of Miss Ingram all the night: in a vivid morning dream I saw her closing the gates of Thornfield against me and pointing me out another road; and Mr. Rochester looked on with his arms folded--smiling sardonically, as it seemed, at both her and me.
Mr.
Rochester nos miraba a las dos, cruzado de brazos, sonriendo sarcásticamente.
I had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I did not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote.
No avisé a Mrs.
Fairfax el día de mi regreso, porque no quería que enviasen coche alguno a buscarme a Millcote.

I proposed to walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving my box in the ostler's care, did I slip away from the George Inn, about six o'clock of a June evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a road which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.

Me proponía recorrer la distancia dando un paseo, y así, después de dejar mi equipaje al cuidado del dueño de la posada, a las seis de una tarde de junio eché a andar por el antiguo camino de Thornfield, que se deslizaba a través de los prados y era muy poco frecuentado entonces.

It was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft: the haymakers were at work all along the road; and the sky, though far from cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: its blue--where blue was visible--was mild and settled, and its cloud strata high and thin.
The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled it--it seemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen of marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.

I felt glad as the road shortened before me: so glad that I stopped once to ask myself what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it was not to my home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to a place where fond friends looked out for me and waited my arrival.

A medida que iba caminando me sentía más contenta, hasta el punto de que más de una vez me detuve para preguntarme el motivo de tal alegría, ya que, en realidad, no me dirigía a mi casa ni a un lugar donde me aguardasen con impaciencia amigos cariñosos.

"Mrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure," said I; "and little Adele will clap her hands and jump to see you: but you know very well you are thinking of another than they, and that he is not thinking of you."
«Mrs.

Fairfax me acogerá con una tranquila sonrisa y Adèle me tomará las manos y comenzará a saltar cuando me vea -pensé-, pero la verdad es que ellas piensan en cosas distintas de mí, como yo pienso en cosas distintas de ellas.»
But what is so headstrong as youth?
What so blind as inexperience?

These affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of again looking on Mr. Rochester, whether he looked on me or not; and they added--"Hasten! hasten! be with him while you may: but a few more days or weeks, at most, and you are parted from him for ever!"
And then I strangled a new-born agony--a deformed thing which I could not persuade myself to own and rear--and ran on.
They are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, the labourers are just quitting their work, and returning home with their rakes on their shoulders, now, at the hour I arrive.
En las praderas de Thornfield los labradores comenzaban a abandonar el trabajo y volvían a sus casas con las herramientas al hombro.
I have but a field or two to traverse, and then I shall cross the road and reach the gates.
Sólo me faltaba atravesar un par de prados antes de llegar a las verjas.
How full the hedges are of roses!
Los setos de los bordes estaban llenos de rosas.
But I have no time to gather any; I want to be at the house.
Pero no me detuve a tomar ninguna, tanta era la prisa que sentía por llegar a la casa.
I passed a tall briar, shooting leafy and flowery branches across the path; I see the narrow stile with stone steps; and I see--Mr.
Pasé bajo un alto zarzal que abovedaba el sendero con sus ramas de blancas florecillas, distinguí el estrecho portillo con escalones de piedra y vi... a Mr.
Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in his hand; he is writing.
Rochester sentado en ellos, con un libro y un lápiz en la mano.
Estaba escribiendo.
Well, he is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a moment I am beyond my own mastery.
No era ciertamente un fantasma, y, sin embargo, sentí un estremecimiento nervioso y estuve a punto de perder el dominio de mí misma.
What does it mean?
¿Qué hacer?
I did not think I should tremble in this way when I saw him, or lose my voice or the power of motion in his presence.
Nunca había pensado que pudiera temblar de aquel modo ante su presencia, que perdiera así la voz y hasta el movimiento al verle.
I will go back as soon as I can stir: I need not make an absolute fool of myself.
Me urgía retroceder, para no mostrarme ante él temblorosa como una tonta.
I know another way to the house.
Conocía otro camino para ir a la casa.
It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for he has seen me.
Pero aunque hubiese conocido veinte, todo era inútil, porque él me vio antes de que pudiera retirarme.
"Hillo!" he cries; and he puts up his book and his pencil.
-¡Caramba! -exclamó-.
"There you are!
¿Conque está usted aquí?
Come on, if you please."
¡Venga, venga!

I suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being scarcely cognisant of my movements, and solicitous only to appear calm; and, above all, to control the working muscles of my face--which I feel rebel insolently against my will, and struggle to express what I had resolved to conceal.

Supongo que debí ir, en efecto, aunque no sé cómo, pues me hallaba inconsciente de mis movimientos y sólo me ocupaba en fingir tranquilidad y en dominar los músculos de mi rostro que, insolentemente rebeldes a mi voluntad, se obstinaban en revelar lo que debía permanecer oculto.
But I have a veil--it is down: I may make shift yet to behave with decent composure.
Pude, sin embargo, presentarme con la mayor compostura posible.
"And this is Jane Eyre?
-Conque Jane Eyre, ¿eh?
Are you coming from Millcote, and on foot?
De Millcote y a pie...

Yes--just one of your tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come clattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into the vicinage of your home along with twilight, just as if you were a dream or a shade.
Es una de las peculiaridades de usted: no pedir un carruaje para venir por la carretera como una persona corriente, sino aparecer junto a su casa a la caída de la tarde, como una aparición...
What the deuce have you done with yourself this last month?"
¿Qué diablos ha estado haciendo todo este mes?
"I have been with my aunt, sir, who is dead."
-Estaba con mi tía, que ha muerto, señor.
"A true Janian reply!
Good angels be my guard!
-¡Una contestación muy de Jane Eyre!
She comes from the other world--from the abode of people who are dead; and tells me so when she meets me alone here in the gloaming!
¡Los ángeles, me ayuden!
¡Lo primero que me dice al encontrarnos es que viene de estar con muertos, en el otro mundo!
If I dared, I'd touch you, to see if you are substance or shadow, you elf!--but I'd as soon offer to take hold of a blue _ignis fatuus_ light in a marsh.
Si me atreviera, la tocaría, a ver si es de carne y hueso, o bien una visión, que se disipara a mi contacto, como un fuego fatuo en los pantanos...
Truant! truant!" he added, when he had paused an instant.
¡Pícara! -añadió, después de un momento de silencio-.
"Absent from me a whole month, and forgetting me quite, I'll be sworn!"
¡Un mes ausente y olvidada de mí por completo, estoy seguro!

I knew there would be pleasure in meeting my master again, even though broken by the fear that he was so soon to cease to be my master, and by the knowledge that I was nothing to him: but there was ever in Mr. Rochester (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of communicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs he scattered to stray and stranger birds like me, was to feast genially.
Sentía verdadero placer en reunirme con Mr.
Rochester, aunque acibarado por el pensamiento de que en breve dejaría de verle y de que, además, nada había de común entre él y yo.
His last words were balm: they seemed to imply that it imported something to him whether I forgot him or not.
Pero de sus palabras emanaba una sensación que me placía en extremo.
Parecían indicar que le interesaba saber si yo me acordaba de él o no.
And he had spoken of Thornfield as my home--would that it were my home!
Y había hablado de Thornfield como de mi casa...
He did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by.
I inquired soon if he had not been to London.
Le pregunté si había estado en Londres.
"Yes; I suppose you found that out by second-sight."
-Sí.
Y supongo que lo sabe usted gracias a su doble vista.
"Mrs. Fairfax told me in a letter."
-Me lo escribió Mrs.
Fairfax.
"And did she inform you what I went to do?"
-¿Y le informó de lo que fui a hacer?
"Oh, yes, sir!
-Sí, señor.
Everybody knew your errand."
Todos lo saben.
"You must see the carriage, Jane, and tell me if you don't think it will suit Mrs. Rochester exactly; and whether she won't look like Queen Boadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions.
-Tiene usted que ver el coche, Jane, y decirme si cree que es apropiado o no para Mrs.
Rochester y si viajando en él parecerá una reina apoyada en sus rojos cojines.
I wish, Jane, I were a trifle better adapted to match with her externally.
Por cierto que sería mucho mejor que ella y yo hiciéramos mejor pareja, físicamente hablando.
Tell me now, fairy as you are--can't you give me a charm, or a philter, or something of that sort, to make me a handsome man?"
Usted, que es un hada, puede proporcionarme un filtro, realizar algún conjuro o cosa parecida, para convertirme en un hombre guapo.
"It would be past the power of magic, sir;" and, in thought, I added, "A loving eye is all the charm needed: to such you are handsome enough; or rather your sternness has a power beyond beauty."
-Eso no entra en las posibilidades de la magia, señor -respondí mientras pensaba: «Todo el conjuro que se necesita son los ojos de una enamorada.
Para ella sería usted lo más hermoso que se pudiera desear.»
Mr.

Mr. Rochester had sometimes read my unspoken thoughts with an acumen to me incomprehensible: in the present instance he took no notice of my abrupt vocal response; but he smiled at me with a certain smile he had of his own, and which he used but on rare occasions.
Rochester había leído a menudo mis pensamientos.
Aquella vez no pareció atender mucho mis palabras.
He seemed to think it too good for common purposes: it was the real sunshine of feeling--he shed it over me now.
Me sonrió de un modo peculiar, que rara vez empleaba, quizá porque aquella sonrisa, a la que asomaba toda su alma, no le pareciese conveniente para ser aplicada a las situaciones vulgares de la vida.
"Pass, Janet," said he, making room for me to cross the stile: "go up home, and stay your weary little wandering feet at a friend's threshold."
-Pase, Jane -dijo, separándose a un lado del portillo-, pase y descanse sus piececitos fatigados en la casa de un amigo.
All I had now to do was to obey him in silence: no need for me to colloquise further.
Obedecí sin decirle nada; sobraba para mí todo diálogo ulterior.
I got over the stile without a word, and meant to leave him calmly.
An impulse held me fast--a force turned me round.
I said--or something in me said for me, and in spite of me--

No obstante, un impulso interior me hizo detenerme, una fuerza desconocida me hizo girar sobre mí misma y decirle, no sé si yo o algo que me hacía hablar a pesar mío: -Gracias por su mucha amabilidad, Mr.
"Thank you, Mr. Rochester, for your great kindness.
I am strangely glad to get back again to you: and wherever you are is my home--my only home."
Rochester.
Estoy muy satisfecha de volver a verle, y considero que dondequiera que usted esté está mi casa, mi única casa.
I walked on so fast that even he could hardly have overtaken me had he tried.
Y me alejé tan de prisa, que difícilmente hubiera podido él alcanzarme aunque se lo hubiera propuesto.
Little Adele was half wild with delight when she saw me.
Adèle se volvió casi loca de alegría al verme.
Mrs.
Mrs. Fairfax received me with her usual plain friendliness.
Fairfax me acogió con su acostumbrada afabilidad.
Leah smiled, and even Sophie bid me "bon soir" with glee.
Aquello me resultó muy agradable.
This was very pleasant; there is no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and feeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.
Nada complace más que sentirse amado por los que le rodean a uno y apreciar que la propia presencia aumenta su satisfacción.
I that evening shut my eyes resolutely against the future: I stopped my cars against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and coming grief.
Cerré, pues, mis ojos al porvenir y taponé mis oídos contra la voz que me aconsejaba ponerme en guardia previniendo la próxima separación.
Cuando tomamos el té y Mrs.

Fairfax inició su labor, mientras yo me sentaba en una silla junto a ella y Adéle se arrodillaba en la alfombra, una sensación de mutuo afecto pareció envolvernos a todos como un círculo de áurea paz.

When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken her knitting, and I had assumed a low seat near her, and Adele, kneeling on the carpet, had nestled close up to me, and a sense of mutual affection seemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, I uttered a silent prayer that we might not be parted far or soon; but when, as we thus sat, Mr. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to take pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable--when he said he supposed the old lady was all right now that she had got her adopted daughter back again, and added that he saw Adele was "prete a croquer sa petite maman Anglaise"--I half ventured to hope that he would, even after his marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of his protection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of his presence.
Murmuré una plegaria sin palabras pidiendo a Dios que no nos separásemos nunca, y cuando Mr.

Rochester entró sin anunciarse y nos miró, complacido ante el espectáculo de aquel grupo tan amistoso, cuando dijo que suponía que la anciana estaría satisfecha al ver que su hija adoptiva regresaba y añadió que Adèle le parecía préte a croques sa petite maman Anglaise, casi comencé a alimentar la esperanza de que él, aun después de casarse, nos conservaría bajo su protección y no nos privaría en absoluto de su presencia.
A fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall.
A mi vuelta a Thornfield Hall sucedió una quincena de tranquilidad absoluta.
Nothing was said of the master's marriage, and I saw no preparation going on for such an event.
No se hablaba nada del casamiento del dueño, ni yo veía preparativo alguno.
Almost every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had yet heard anything decided: her answer was always in the negative.
Casi a diario preguntaba a Mrs.
Fairfax si sabía que hubiera algo decidido y siempre recibía la misma negativa.

Once she said she had actually put the question to Mr. Rochester as to when he was going to bring his bride home; but he had answered her only by a joke and one of his queer looks, and she could not tell what to make of him.
Según dijo, sólo una vez preguntó sobre el asunto a Mr.
Rochester, pero éste respondió con una broma y ella no pudo sacar nada en limpio.

One thing specially surprised me, and that was, there were no journeyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure it was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was that distance to an ardent lover?
Una cosa que me sorprendía mucho era que Rochester no visitaba Ingram Park.
Si bien este lugar estaba sito a veinte millas, en los límites de otro condado, ¿qué era esa distancia para un enamorado ardiente?
To so practised and indefatigable a horseman as Mr. Rochester, it would be but a morning's ride.
Un jinete tan experto e infatigable como Rochester la recorrería en una mañana de cabalgar.
I began to cherish hopes I had no right to conceive: that the match was broken off; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had changed their minds.
Comencé a acariciar esperanzas que no tenía motivo alguno para concebir: que el enlace se hubiese roto, que el rumor hubiera sido infundado, que una de las dos partes hubiera rectificado su opinión.
I used to look at my master's face to see if it were sad or fierce; but I could not remember the time when it had been so uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings.
Trataba de adivinar si en el rostro de Rochester se apreciaba alguna cosa desagradable o violenta, pero jamás me había parecido su cara tan límpida y exenta de malas inclinaciones.
If, in the moments I and my pupil spent with him, I lacked spirits and sank into inevitable dejection, he became even gay.
Never had he called me more frequently to his presence; never been kinder to me when there--and, alas! never had I loved him so well.
Nunca me llamó a su presencia tan frecuentemente como entonces, nunca había sido más amable para conmigo y nunca, ¡ay!, le había amado yo más a él...
CHAPTER XXIII
XXIII
A splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant as were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our wave- girt land.
It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the South, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest them on the cliffs of Albion.

Hacía un tiempo espléndido, como de mediados de verano, con un cielo tan puro y un sol tan radiante, que se diría que una bandada de días italianos, a la manera de magníficos pájaros, hubiese venido desde el Sur hasta Inglaterra.

The hay was all got in; the fields round Thornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees were in their dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply tinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows between.
El heno había sido segado por completo.
Los campos circundantes estaban verdes, los árboles en flor, los bosques pomposos y los setos magníficos de frutos y florecillas.
On Midsummer-eve, Adele, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay Lane half the day, had gone to bed with the sun.
I watched her drop asleep, and when I left her, I sought the garden.

Una tarde de aquel verano, Adèle, que se había fatigado mucho cogiendo fresas silvestres por la tarde en el camino de Hay, se acostó en cuanto se puso el sol, y yo, después de asegurarme de que la niña dormía, bajé al jardín.
It was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:--"Day its fervid fires had wasted," and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched summit.
Era la hora más grata de las veinticuatro del día.

Where the sun had gone down in simple state--pure of the pomp of clouds--spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and furnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and wide, soft and still softer, over half heaven.

Por Occidente, donde el sol acababa de desaparecer, se extendía ahora una espléndida mancha de púrpura, ardiente como el rubí o como la llama, surgiendo tras lo alto de una colina, y extendiéndose más tenue a medida que se elevaba, hasta la mitad del cielo.
The east had its own charm or fine deep blue, and its own modest gem, a casino and solitary star: soon it would boast the moon; but she was yet beneath the horizon.
Por Oriente, el cielo ostentaba un suave azul y brillaba en él una estrella como una joya.
En breve saldría la luna, pero ahora no asomaba todavía en el horizonte.

I walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent--that of a cigar--stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a handbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the orchard.
Primero paseé ante la casa, mas un bien conocido olor de cigarro que salía por la abierta ventana de la biblioteca me hizo comprender que podían verme, y entonces me interné en el huerto.

No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eden-like; it was full of trees, it bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut it out from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened it from the lawn.
Imposible encontrar un sitio más paradisíaco.
Estaba lleno de árboles y flores, un alto muro lo separaba del patio y una avenida de hayas conducía al prado de frente al edificio.

At the bottom was a sunk fence; its sole separation from lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and terminating in a giant horse-chestnut, circled at the base by a seat, led down to the fence.
Un seto aislaba el huerto de los solitarios campos, y un caminito bordeado de laureles y que terminaba en un gigantesco castaño rodeado de un asiento circular conducía al extremo del seto.
Here one could wander unseen.

While such honey-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as if I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and fruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by the light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step is stayed--not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning fragrance.
El silencio era absoluto, la sombra grata.
Mas apenas había caminado algunos pasos me detuve al percibir cierta cálida fragancia en el ambiente.

Sweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been yielding their evening sacrifice of incense: this new scent is neither of shrub nor flower; it is--I know it well--it is Mr. Rochester's cigar.
No procedía de los rosales silvestres, ni de los abrótanos, jazmines, claveles y rosas que colmaban el jardín.
No: aquel nuevo aroma era el del cigarro de Mr.
I look round and I listen.
Rochester.
Miré a mi alrededor y escuché.
I see trees laden with ripening fruit.
I hear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form is visible, no coming step audible; but that perfume increases: I must flee.
Vi árboles cargados de fruta y oí trinar a un ruiseñor, pero no distinguí ninguna forma humana ni sentí paso alguno.
Sin embargo, el aroma se hacía más intenso.
I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Mr. Rochester entering.
Debía marcharme.
Me dirigí a un portillo que daba al campo y en aquel momento divisé a Mr.
Rochester.
Me detuve, procurando pasar disimulada bajo la hiedra que cubría el muro.
I step aside into the ivy recess; he will not stay long: he will soon return whence he came, and if I sit still he will never see me.
Mr.
Rochester seguramente no estaría mucho tiempo allí y, si yo me quedaba donde estaba, podía pasar inadvertida.

But no--eventide is as pleasant to him as to me, and this antique garden as attractive; and he strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry-tree branches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which they are laden; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a knot of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or to admire the dew-beads on their petals.
Pero aquel antiguo jardín era tan agradable para él como para mí.
Lo recorría lentamente, parándose de vez en cuando, ora para contemplar las parras cargadas de uvas grandes como ciruelas, ora para coger una cereza o para contemplar una flor.
A great moth goes humming by me; it alights on a plant at Mr. Rochester's foot: he sees it, and bends to examine it.
Una enorme libélula voló a mi lado, se detuvo en una planta a los pies de Rochester y éste se inclinó a fin de examinarla.
"Now, he has his back towards me," thought I, "and he is occupied too; perhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed."
«Ahora está de espaldas a mí -pensé-; acaso, si me deslizo en silencio, pueda irme sin que me oiga.»

I trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel might not betray me: he was standing among the beds at a yard or two distant from where I had to pass; the moth apparently engaged him.
Avancé sobre la hierba, queriendo evitar que mis pasos sobre la arena me traicionaran.
Cuando pasé a una vara o dos de él, que parecía absorto en contemplar la libélula, dijo, sin volverse:
"I shall get by very well," I meditated.
As I crossed his shadow, thrown long over the garden by the moon, not yet risen high, he said quietly, without turning--
"Jane, come and look at this fellow."
-Venga a ver esto, Jane.
I had made no noise: he had not eyes behind--could his shadow feel?
No había hecho ruido, él no me dirigía la mirada.
¿Cómo sabía que yo me hallaba allí?
I started at first, and then I approached him.
Me detuve y al fin me acerqué a él.
-Mire qué alas tiene -dijo-.
"Look at his wings," said he, "he reminds me rather of a West Indian insect; one does not often see so large and gay a night-rover in England; there! he is flown."
Parece un insecto de las Antillas.
Nunca he visto ninguno tan grande y hermoso en Inglaterra.
¡Ah, ya vuela!
The moth roamed away.
La libélula se había ido.
I was sheepishly retreating also; but Mr. Rochester followed me, and when we reached the wicket, he said--
Yo inicié también la retirada, pero Rochester me siguió.
Al llegar al portillo dijo:
-Quedémonos.
"Turn back: on so lovely a night it is a shame to sit in the house; and surely no one can wish to go to bed while sunset is thus at meeting with moonrise."
Es lamentable permanecer en casa en una noche tan hermosa como ésta.
¿A quién puede complacerle acostarse a esta hora?

It is one of my faults, that though my tongue is sometimes prompt enough at an answer, there are times when it sadly fails me in framing an excuse; and always the lapse occurs at some crisis, when a facile word or plausible pretext is specially wanted to get me out of painful embarrassment.
Vea: mientras la última claridad del crepúsculo brilla a lo lejos, por el otro extremo del horizonte nace la luna.

Uno de mis defectos es que, aunque habitualmente tengo la lengua pronta para cualquier respuesta, en ocasiones no sé encontrar palabras adecuadas con que negarme a algo, y ello coincide siempre con los momentos en que más precisaría un pretexto plausible.
I did not like to walk at this hour alone with Mr. Rochester in the shadowy orchard; but I could not find a reason to allege for leaving him.
No me agradaba pasear a solas a aquellas horas con Mr.
Rochester por el huerto, pero no supe cómo excusarme.

I followed with lagging step, and thoughts busily bent on discovering a means of extrication; but he himself looked so composed and so grave also, I became ashamed of feeling any confusion: the evil--if evil existent or prospective there was--seemed to lie with me only; his mind was unconscious and quiet.
Le seguí con lentos pasos, pensando en el modo de librarme de aquella complicación.
Pero él parecía tan sereno y grave, que me avergoncé de mis temores.
"Jane," he recommenced, as we entered the laurel walk, and slowly strayed down in the direction of the sunk fence and the horse-chestnut, "Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, is it not?"
-Jane -comenzó cuando íbamos por el sendero entre laureles hacia el castaño rodeado de un banco-, ¿verdad que Thornfield es un sitio muy agradable en verano?
"Yes, sir."
-Sí, señor.
"You must have become in some degree attached to the house,--you, who have an eye for natural beauties, and a good deal of the organ of Adhesiveness?"
-Usted debe de sentir cierto cariño a la casa, porque tiene usted muy desarrollada su capacidad afectiva y sabe apreciar lo bello.
"I am attached to it, indeed."
-En efecto, experimento afecto hacia Thornfield.
"And though I don't comprehend how it is, I perceive you have acquired a degree of regard for that foolish little child Adele, too; and even for simple dame Fairfax?"
-Y hasta me parece que, no sé cómo, ha tomado usted cariño a esa tontita de Adèle y a esa pobre Mrs.
Fairfax.
"Yes, sir; in different ways, I have an affection for both."
-Sí, señor: las aprecio, a cada una en un sentido.
"And would be sorry to part with them?"
-¿Le disgustaría separarse de ellas?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"Pity!" he said, and sighed and paused.
-Es lástima -se interrumpió y suspiró.
Luego siguió diciendo-:

"It is always the way of events in this life," he continued presently: "no sooner have you got settled in a pleasant resting-place, than a voice calls out to you to rise and move on, for the hour of repose is expired."
Siempre sucede en la vida que, cuando uno encuentra un sitio donde se halla a gusto, se ve en la precisión de abandonarlo...
"Must I move on, sir?"
I asked.
"Must I leave Thornfield?"
-¿Es necesario que me vaya de Thornfield? -pregunté.
"I believe you must, Jane.
I am sorry, Janet, but I believe indeed you must."
-Lo siento, Jane, pero creo que sí.
This was a blow: but I did not let it prostrate me.
Me sentí anonadada, mas lo disimulé.
"Well, sir, I shall be ready when the order to march comes."
-Bien, señor.
Me preparé para cuando usted me dé la orden de irme.
"It is come now--I must give it to-night."
-Esta misma noche.
"Then you _are_ going to be married, sir?"
-¿Es que va a casarse?
"Ex-act-ly--pre-cise-ly: with your usual acuteness, you have hit the nail straight on the head."
-E-xac-ta-men-te -silabeó-.
Se muestra usted tan sagaz como de costumbre. -¿Pronto señor?
"Soon, sir?"
-Tan pronto que...

"Very soon, my--that is, Miss Eyre: and you'll remember, Jane, the first time I, or Rumour, plainly intimated to you that it was my intention to put my old bachelor's neck into the sacred noose, to enter into the holy estate of matrimony--to take Miss Ingram to my bosom, in short (she's an extensive armful: but that's not to the point--one can't have too much of such a very excellent thing as my beautiful Blanche): well, as I was saying--listen to me, Jane!
Miss Eyre: usted recordará que cuando yo, o la voz pública, le informaron de mi intención de ofrecer mi cerviz de soltero al sagrado yugo del matrimonio, de acoger en mi amante pecho a Miss Ingram...
You're not turning your head to look after more moths, are you?
That was only a lady-clock, child, 'flying away home.'
Pero escúcheme, Jane, y no vuelva la cabeza para mirar las mariposas...

I wish to remind you that it was you who first said to me, with that discretion I respect in you--with that foresight, prudence, and humility which befit your responsible and dependent position--that in case I married Miss Ingram, both you and little Adele had better trot forthwith.

Usted recordará que fue la primera en decirme, con toda discreción y respeto, como conviene a su posición, que en caso de que yo me casara con Miss Ingram, era preferible que usted y Adèle se fueran de la casa.

I pass over the sort of slur conveyed in this suggestion on the character of my beloved; indeed, when you are far away, Janet, I'll try to forget it: I shall notice only its wisdom; which is such that I have made it my law of action.

Prescindo de la calumniosa mancha que esa sugerencia arroja sobre el angelical carácter de mi adorada y me limito, mi dulce Jane, a apreciar lo que en su indicación hay de prudente y a convertirla en mi línea de conducta.
Adele must go to school; and you, Miss Eyre, must get a new situation."
Adèle será enviada al colegio y usted, Miss Eyre, no tiene más salida que buscar otro empleo.
-Sí señor.
Yo fui la primera en indicárselo, más suponía...

"Yes, sir, I will advertise immediately: and meantime, I suppose--" I was going to say, "I suppose I may stay here, till I find another shelter to betake myself to:" but I stopped, feeling it would not do to risk a long sentence, for my voice was not quite under command.
Iba a concluir: «que podría continuar aquí hasta que hallase otro puesto»; pero callé.
No me atrevía a hablar mucho, temiendo que mi voz delatara lo que sentía.
"In about a month I hope to be a bridegroom," continued Mr. Rochester; "and in the interim, I shall myself look out for employment and an asylum for you."
-La boda se celebrará de aquí a un mes -siguió Rochester-, y he buscado ya otro empleo para usted. -Gracias, señor: siento que... -No, no; nada de gracias.
"Thank you, sir; I am sorry to give--" "Oh, no need to apologise!
Entiendo que cuando un empleado cumple su deber tan bien como usted lo ha cumplido, tiene derecho a que su patrón le ayude.

I consider that when a dependent does her duty as well as you have done yours, she has a sort of claim upon her employer for any little assistance he can conveniently render her; indeed I have already, through my future mother-in-law, heard of a place that I think will suit: it is to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs. Dionysius O'Gall of Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught, Ireland.
Mi futura suegra me ha hablado de una plaza que seguramente le convendrá: se trata de encargarse de la educación de las cinco hijas de Mr.
Dionysius O'Gall, de Bitternutt Lodge, en Connaught.
Es en Irlanda.
You'll like Ireland, I think: they're such warm-hearted people there, they say."
Le gustará Irlanda.
Según dicen, los irlandeses son muy afectuosos.
"It is a long way off, sir."
-Está muy lejos, señor.
"No matter--a girl of your sense will not object to the voyage or the distance."
-¿Qué importa?
A una muchacha como usted no creo que le asuste un viaje largo.
"Not the voyage, but the distance: and then the sea is a barrier--"
-No es el viaje, sino la distancia y el mar, que es una barrera que me separaría de...
"From what, Jane?"
-¿De qué?
"From England and from Thornfield: and--"
-De Inglaterra, y de Thornfield, y de...
"Well?"
"From _you_, sir."
-De usted, señor...
I said this almost involuntarily, and, with as little sanction of free will, my tears gushed out.
I did not cry so as to be heard, however; I avoided sobbing.
Lo dije casi involuntariamente, mientras lágrimas silenciosas bañaban mi rostro.

The thought of Mrs. O'Gall and Bitternutt Lodge struck cold to my heart; and colder the thought of all the brine and foam, destined, as it seemed, to rush between me and the master at whose side I now walked, and coldest the remembrance of the wider ocean--wealth, caste, custom intervened between me and what I naturally and inevitably loved.

La mención del señor O'Gall, de Bitternutt Lodge, había dejado frío mi corazón, y más aún el pensamiento del mar, del mar inmenso, revuelto y espumoso, que había de interponerse entre mi persona y aquel hombre a cuyo lado paseaba y a quien amaba de un modo espontáneo, superior a mi voluntad.
"It is a long way," I again said.
-Es muy lejos -repetí.
"It is, to be sure; and when you get to Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught, Ireland, I shall never see you again, Jane: that's morally certain.
-Desde luego.
Y cuando usted esté en Bitternutt Lodge, no volveremos a vernos más.
I never go over to Ireland, not having myself much of a fancy for the country.
Me parece indudable.
No creo ir nunca a Irlanda; no es un país que me atraiga en exceso...
We have been good friends, Jane; have we not?"
Hemos sido buenos amigos, ¿verdad,Jane?
"Yes, sir."
-Sí. -Bien.
"And when friends are on the eve of separation, they like to spend the little time that remains to them close to each other.
Pues cuando dos buenos amigos se separan, emplean el corto tiempo que les queda de estar juntos en hablar un poco de sí mismos.

Come! we'll talk over the voyage and the parting quietly half-an-hour or so, while the stars enter into their shining life up in heaven yonder: here is the chestnut tree: here is the bench at its old roots.
Ea, hablemos tranquilamente durante media hora, mientras las estrellas brillan en el cielo que nos cubre...
Come, we will sit there in peace to-night, though we should never more be destined to sit there together."
Sentémonos en este banco del castaño, ya que nuestro destino es no volver a sentarnos juntos más.
He seated me and himself.
Cuando nos hubimos acomodado, continuó:
"It is a long way to Ireland, Janet, and I am sorry to send my little friend on such weary travels: but if I can't do better, how is it to be helped?
-En efecto, Jane: el viaje a Irlanda es largo y la travesía incómoda y siento que mi amiguita haya de verse obligada a...
Pero ¿cómo ayudarla si no?
Are you anything akin to me, do you think, Jane?"
¿Experimenta usted algún sentimiento respecto a mí, Jane?
I could risk no sort of answer by this time: my heart was still.
No pude contestar.
Mi corazón desbordaba.

"Because," he said, "I sometimes have a queer feeling with regard to you--especially when you are near me, as now: it is as if I had a string somewhere under my left ribs, tightly and inextricably knotted to a similar string situated in the corresponding quarter of your little frame.
-Porque yo lo experimento por usted -continuó-, sobre todo cuando estamos juntos, como ahora.
Es como si en el lado izquierdo de mi pecho tuviese una cuerda que vibrara al mismo ritmo que otra que usted tuviese en análogo lugar y se uniera de un modo invisible a la mía.

And if that boisterous Channel, and two hundred miles or so of land come broad between us, I am afraid that cord of communion will be snapt; and then I've a nervous notion I should take to bleeding inwardly.
Y si ese endiablado canal y doscientas millas de tierra van a separarnos, temo que ese lazo que nos une se rompa.
Por lo qué a mí concierne, estoy seguro de que la rotura va a producirme una incontenible hemorragia.
As for you,--you'd forget me."
"That I _never_ should, sir: you know--" Impossible to proceed.
Y usted... -Yo nunca, señor, usted sabe...
No pude continuar.
"Jane, do you hear that nightingale singing in the wood?
-¿Oye cómo canta ese ruiseñor, Jane?
Listen!"
Escuche.
In listening, I sobbed convulsively; for I could repress what I endured no longer; I was obliged to yield, and I was shaken from head to foot with acute distress.
Escuché y de pronto rompí a llorar convulsivamente, estremeciéndome de pies a cabeza.
Imposible soportar más lo que sufría.
When I did speak, it was only to express an impetuous wish that I had never been born, or never come to Thornfield.
Cuando pude hablar, fue para expresar con vehemencia el deseo de no haber nacido nunca o no haber ido jamás a Thornfield. -¿Cómo?
"Because you are sorry to leave it?"
¿Le disgusta tanto irse de aquí?

The vehemence of emotion, stirred by grief and love within me, was claiming mastery, and struggling for full sway, and asserting a right to predominate, to overcome, to live, rise, and reign at last: yes,--and to speak.
-Me disgusta irme de Thornfield.

Amo este lugar, y lo amo porque en él he vivido una vida agradable y plena, momentáneamente al menos, porque no he sido rebajada a vivir entre seres inferiores ni excluida de toda relación con cuanto es superior y dinámico.
"I grieve to leave Thornfield: I love Thornfield:--I love it, because I have lived in it a full and delightful life,--momentarily at least.
I have not been trampled on.
He podido hablar con alguien a quien admiro, en cuyo trato me complazco...
I have not been petrified.
I have not been buried with inferior minds, and excluded from every glimpse of communion with what is bright and energetic and high.
Un cerebro poderoso, amplio, original...
I have talked, face to face, with what I reverence, with what I delight in,--with an original, a vigorous, an expanded mind.
En una palabra, le he conocido a usted, Mr.
I have known you, Mr. Rochester; and it strikes me with terror and anguish to feel I absolutely must be torn from you for ever.
Rochester, y me asusta pensar en irme de su lado.
I see the necessity of departure; and it is like looking on the necessity of death."
Reconozco que debo marchar, pero lo reconozco como podría reconocer la necesidad de morir.
"Where do you see the necessity?" he asked suddenly.
-¿Y qué necesidad tiene de irse? -preguntó de pronto.
"Where?
You, sir, have placed it before me."
-Usted mismo me lo ha dicho, señor.
"In what shape?"
-¿A propósito de qué?
"In the shape of Miss Ingram; a noble and beautiful woman,--your bride."
-De Miss Ingram, su noble y bella prometida...
"My bride!
-¿Qué prometida?
Yo no tengo prometida.
What bride?
I have no bride!"
"But you will have."
-Pero se propone tenerla...
"Yes;--I will!--I will!"
He set his teeth.
-Sí, me lo propongo... -masculló.
"Then I must go:--you have said it yourself."
-De modo que debo irme.
Usted lo ha dicho.
"No: you must stay!
-No: usted se quedará.
I swear it--and the oath shall be kept."
Se lo juro y cumpliré el juramento.
"I tell you I must go!"
I retorted, roused to something like passion.
-¡Y yo le digo que me iré! -exclamé con vehemencia-.
"Do you think I can stay to become nothing to you?
Do you think I am an automaton?--a machine without feelings? and can bear to have my morsel of bread snatched from my lips, and my drop of living water dashed from my cup?
¿Piensa que me es posible vivir a su lado sin ser nada para usted?
¿Cree que soy una autómata, una máquina sin sentimientos humanos?
Do you think, because I am poor, obscure, plain, and little, I am soulless and heartless?
¿Piensa que porque soy pobre y oscura carezco de alma y de corazón?
You think wrong!--I have as much soul as you,--and full as much heart!
¡Se equivoca!
¡Tengo tanto corazón y tanta alma como usted!
And if God had gifted me with some beauty and much wealth, I should have made it as hard for you to leave me, as it is now for me to leave you.
Y si Dios me hubiese dado belleza y riquezas, le sería a usted tan amargo separarse de mí como lo es a mí separarme de usted.

I am not talking to you now through the medium of custom, conventionalities, nor even of mortal flesh;--it is my spirit that addresses your spirit; just as if both had passed through the grave, and we stood at God's feet, equal,--as we are!"
Le hablo prescindiendo de convencionalismos, como si estuviésemos más allá de la tumba, ante Dios, y nos hallásemos en un plano de igualdad, ya que en espíritu lo somos.
"As we are!" repeated Mr. Rochester--"so," he added, enclosing me in his arms.
-¡Lo somos! -repitió Rochester.
Gathering me to his breast, pressing his lips on my lips: "so, Jane!"
Y tomándome en sus brazos me oprimió contra su pecho y unió sus labios a los míos-.
¡Sí, Jane!

"Yes, so, sir," I rejoined: "and yet not so; for you are a married man--or as good as a married man, and wed to one inferior to you--to one with whom you have no sympathy--whom I do not believe you truly love; for I have seen and heard you sneer at her.
-O tal vez no -repuse, tratando de soltarme-, porque usted va a casarse con una mujer con quien no simpatiza, a quien no puedo creer que ame.
I would scorn such a union: therefore I am better than you--let me go!"
Yo rechazaría una unión así.
Luego yo soy mejor que usted.
¡Déjeme marchar!
"Where, Jane?
-¿Adónde, Jane?
To Ireland?"
¡A Irlanda!
"Yes--to Ireland.
-Sí, a Irlanda.
I have spoken my mind, and can go anywhere now."
Lo he pensado bien y ahora creo que debo irme.
"Jane, be still; don't struggle so, like a wild frantic bird that is rending its own plumage in its desperation."
-Quédese, Jane.
No luche consigo misma como un ave que, en su desesperación, despedaza su propio plumaje.
"I am no bird; and no net ensnares me; I am a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you."
-No soy un ave, sino un ser humano con voluntad personal, que ejercitaré alejándome de usted.
Another effort set me at liberty, and I stood erect before him.
Haciendo un esfuerzo, logré soltarme y permanecí en pie ante él.
"And your will shall decide your destiny," he said: "I offer you my hand, my heart, and a share of all my possessions."
También su voluntad va a decidir de su destino -repuso-.
Le ofrezco mi mano, mi corazón y cuanto poseo.
"You play a farce, which I merely laugh at."
-Se burla usted, pero yo me río de su oferta.
"I ask you to pass through life at my side--to be my second self, and best earthly companion."
-La pido, que viva siempre a mi lado, que sea mi mujer.
"For that fate you have already made your choice, and must abide by it."
-Respecto a eso, ya tiene usted hecha su elección.
"Jane, be still a few moments: you are over-excited: I will be still too."
-Espere un poco, Jane.
Está usted muy excitada.
A waft of wind came sweeping down the laurel-walk, and trembled through the boughs of the chestnut: it wandered away--away--to an indefinite distance--it died.
Una ráfaga de viento recorrió el sendero bordeado de laureles, agitó las ramas del castaño y se extinguió a lo lejos.
The nightingale's song was then the only voice of the hour: in listening to it, I again wept.
No se percibía otro ruido que el canto del ruiseñor.
Al oírlo, volví a llorar.
Mr. Rochester sat quiet, looking at me gently and seriously.
Rochester, sentado, me contemplaba en silencio, con serenidad, grave y amablemente.
Some time passed before he spoke; he at last said--
Cuando habló al fin, dijo:
"Come to my side, Jane, and let us explain and understand one another."
-Siéntese a mi lado, Jane, y expliquémonos.
"I will never again come to your side: I am torn away now, and cannot return."
-No volveré más a su lado.
"But, Jane, I summon you as my wife: it is you only I intend to marry."
-Jane, ¿no oye que deseo hacerla mi mujer?
Es con usted con quien quiero casarme.
I was silent: I thought he mocked me.
Callé, suponiendo que se burlaba.
"Come, Jane--come hither."
-Venga, Jane.
"Your bride stands between us."
-No.
Su novia nos separa.
He rose, and with a stride reached me.
Se puso en pie y me alcanzó de un salto.
"My bride is here," he said, again drawing me to him, "because my equal is here, and my likeness.
-Mi novia está aquí -dijo, atrayéndome hacia sí-: es mi igual y me gusta.
Jane, will you marry me?"
¿Quiere casarse conmigo, Jane?
Still I did not answer, and still I writhed myself from his grasp: for I was still incredulous.
No le contesté; luchaba para librarme de él.
No le creía.
"Do you doubt me, Jane?"
-¿Duda de mí, Jane?
"Entirely."
-En absoluto.
"You have no faith in me?"
-¿No tiene fe en mí?
"Not a whit."
-Ni una gota.
"Am I a liar in your eyes?" he asked passionately.
-Entonces, ¿me considera usted un bellaco? -dijo con vehemencia-.
"Little sceptic, you _shall_ be convinced.
Usted se convencerá, incrédula.
What love have I for Miss Ingram?
