¿Acaso amo a Blanche Ingram?
None: and that you know.
No, y usted lo sabe.
What love has she for me?
¿Acaso me ama ella a mí?

None: as I have taken pains to prove: I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was not a third of what was supposed, and after that I presented myself to see the result; it was coldness both from her and her mother.
No, y me he preocupado de comprobarlo.
He hecho llegar hasta ella el rumor de que mi fortuna no era ni la tercera parte de lo que se suponía, y luego me he presentado a Blanche y a su madre.
I would not--I could not--marry Miss Ingram.
Las dos me han acogido con frialdad.
No puedo, ni debo, casarme con Blanche Ingram.
You--you strange, you almost unearthly thing!--I love as my own flesh.
You--poor and obscure, and small and plain as you are--I entreat to accept me as a husband."
A usted, tan rara, tan insignificante, tan vulgar, es a quien quiero como a mi propia carne, y a quien ruego que me acepte por esposo.
"What, me!"

I ejaculated, beginning in his earnestness--and especially in his incivility--to credit his sincerity: "me who have not a friend in the world but you--if you are my friend: not a shilling but what you have given me?"
-¿A mí? -exclamé, empezando a creerle, en vista de su apasionamiento y, sobre todo, de su ruda franqueza-.
¡A mí, que no tengo en el mundo otro amigo que usted, si es que usted se considera amigo mío, y que no poseo un chelín, no siendo los que usted me paga!
"You, Jane, I must have you for my own--entirely my own.
-A usted, Jane.
Quiero que sea mía, únicamente mía.
Will you be mine?
¿Acepta?
¡Diga inmediatamente que sí!
Say yes, quickly."
-Mr.
"Mr. Rochester, let me look at your face: turn to the moonlight."
Rochester, déjeme mirarle la cara.
Vuélvase de modo que le ilumine la luna.
"Why?"
-¿Para qué?
"Because I want to read your countenance--turn!"
-Porque quiero leer en su rostro.
"There! you will find it scarcely more legible than a crumpled, scratched page.
Read on: only make haste, for I suffer."
-Bien; ya está.
Creo que mi rostro no le va a parecer más legible que una hoja tachada, pero en fin, lea lo que quiera, con tal de que sea pronto.
His face was very much agitated and very much flushed, and there were strong workings in the features, and strange gleams in the eyes.
Su faz estaba muy agitada.
Tenía las facciones contraídas y una extraña luz brillaba en sus ojos.
"Oh, Jane, you torture me!" he exclaimed.
-¡Me tortura usted, Jane! -exclamó-.
"With that searching and yet faithful and generous look, you torture me!"
Por muy franca y bondadosa que sea su mirada, me escudriña de un modo...
"How can I do that?
-¿Cómo voy a torturarle?
If you are true, and your offer real, my only feelings to you must be gratitude and devotion--they cannot torture."
Si dice usted la verdad y su oferta es sincera, mis sentimientos no pueden ser otros que los de una gratitud infinita.
¿Cómo voy a torturarle con ella?
"Gratitude!" he ejaculated; and added wildly--"Jane accept me quickly.
-¿Gratitud?
Say, Edward--give me my name--Edward--I will marry you."
"Are you in earnest?
Jane -ordenó, perentoriamente-, dígame así: «Edward, quiero casarme contigo.»
Do you truly love me?
Do you sincerely wish me to be your wife?"
-¿Es posible que me quiera usted de verdad?
"I do; and if an oath is necessary to satisfy you, I swear it."
¿Qué se propone hacerme su mujer? -Sí; se lo juro, si lo desea.
"Then, sir, I will marry you."
-Entonces, señor, sí quiero casarme con usted.
"Edward--my little wife!"
-Señor, no.
Di Edward, mujercita mía.
"Dear Edward!"
-¡Oh, querido Edward!
"Come to me--come to me entirely now," said he; and added, in his deepest tone, speaking in my ear as his cheek was laid on mine, "Make my happiness--I will make yours."
-Ven, ven conmigo -y rozando mis mejillas con las suyas y hablándome al oído, murmuró-: Hazme feliz y yo te haré feliz a ti.
"God pardon me!" he subjoined ere long; "and man meddle not with me: I have her, and will hold her."
"There is no one to meddle, sir.
I have no kindred to interfere."
"No--that is the best of it," he said.

And if I had loved him less I should have thought his accent and look of exultation savage; but, sitting by him, roused from the nightmare of parting--called to the paradise of union--I thought only of the bliss given me to drink in so abundant a flow.

De haberle amado menos, hubiese pensado que su aspecto y su mirada mostraban una alegría casi salvaje, pero libre de la pesadilla de la marcha, abriéndose ante mí el paraíso de la dicha que se me ofrecía, sólo pensaba en beber hasta la última gota de aquel néctar.
Again and again he said, "Are you happy, Jane?"
And again and again I answered, "Yes."
Una y otra vez, Rochester me preguntaba: «¿Te sientes feliz, Jane?»
After which he murmured, "It will atone--it will atone.
Y una y otra vez le respondía: «Sí.»
Have I not found her friendless, and cold, and comfortless?
Will I not guard, and cherish, and solace her?
Is there not love in my heart, and constancy in my resolves?
It will expiate at God's tribunal.
I know my Maker sanctions what I do.
For the world's judgment--I wash my hands thereof.
Le oí murmurar para sí: -Sé que Dios no deja de aprobar lo que hago.
For man's opinion--I defy it."
La opinión del mundo me es indiferente, y desafío la crítica de los hombres.
But what had befallen the night?
The moon was not yet set, and we were all in shadow: I could scarcely see my master's face, near as I was.
La luna ya no brillaba, estábamos en sombras y yo no podía ver apenas el rostro de Rochester, a pesar de lo cerca que me hallaba de él.
And what ailed the chestnut tree? it writhed and groaned; while wind roared in the laurel walk, and came sweeping over us.
El viento soplaba entre los laureles y movía, con sordo rumor, las ramas del castaño. -Tenemos que entrar -dijo Rochester-: el tiempo cambia.
"We must go in," said Mr. Rochester: "the weather changes.
Quisiera estar contigo hasta mañana, Jane.
I could have sat with thee till morning, Jane."
«Y yo contigo», pensé.
"And so," thought I, "could I with you."

I should have said so, perhaps, but a livid, vivid spark leapt out of a cloud at which I was looking, and there was a crack, a crash, and a close rattling peal; and I thought only of hiding my dazzled eyes against Mr. Rochester's shoulder.
Y quizá lo hubiese dicho si en aquel momento un relámpago no me hubiera dejado deslumbrada, obligándome a ocultar mis ofuscados ojos contra el hombro de Rochester.
Comenzó a llover con furia.
The rain rushed down.
He hurried me up the walk, through the grounds, and into the house; but we were quite wet before we could pass the threshold.
Él me arrastró velozmente por el sendero hacia la casa, pero antes de que cruzásemos el umbral estábamos empapados.
He was taking off my shawl in the hall, and shaking the water out of my loosened hair, when Mrs. Fairfax emerged from her room.
Mientras Rochester me quitaba el chal y alisaba mi cabello despeinado por el agua, Mrs.
Fairfax salió de su cuarto.
I did not observe her at first, nor did Mr. Rochester.
Ni él ni yo reparamos en ella.
The lamp was lit.
La lámpara estaba encendida.
The clock was on the stroke of twelve.
El reloj daba en aquellos momentos las doce.
"Hasten to take off your wet things," said he; "and before you go, good- night--good-night, my darling!"
-Quítate en seguida la ropa, ¡Estás calada!
Buenas noches, queridita -dijo Rochester.
He kissed me repeatedly.
Me besó repetidas veces.
When I looked up, on leaving his arms, there stood the widow, pale, grave, and amazed.
Al separarme de él distinguí a la viuda, mirándonos, grave, pálida y asombrada.
I only smiled at her, and ran upstairs.
La sonreí y corrí escaleras arriba.
"Explanation will do for another time," thought I. Still, when I reached my chamber, I felt a pang at the idea she should even temporarily misconstrue what she had seen.

But joy soon effaced every other feeling; and loud as the wind blew, near and deep as the thunder crashed, fierce and frequent as the lightning gleamed, cataract-like as the rain fell during a storm of two hours' duration, I experienced no fear and little awe.
«Dejemos la explicación para otra vez», pensé.

No obstante, ya en mi cuarto me turbó algo la idea de suponer lo que ella podría pensar de lo que había visto, pero mi alegría borró pronto los demás sentimientos y pese a la violencia con que soplaba el viento, a la frecuencia y fragor con que sonaba el trueno, a los lívidos relámpagos y a la lluvia que cayó a torrentes durante dos horas, no sentía ni el más pequeño temor.
Mr. Rochester came thrice to my door in the course of it, to ask if I was safe and tranquil: and that was comfort, that was strength for anything.
Mientras persistió la tormenta, Rochester llamó tres veces a mi puerta para preguntarme si necesitaba algo.

Before I left my bed in the morning, little Adele came running in to tell me that the great horse-chestnut at the bottom of the orchard had been struck by lightning in the night, and half of it split away.
A la mañana siguiente, antes de levantarme, Adèle vino corriendo a decirme que por la noche había caído un rayo en el castaño del huerto y lo había medio destruido.
CHAPTER XXIV
XXIV
As I rose and dressed, I thought over what had happened, and wondered if it were a dream.
Una vez levantada y vestida, pensé en lo sucedido y me pareció un sueño.
I could not be certain of the reality till I had seen Mr. Rochester again, and heard him renew his words of love and promise.
No estaba segura de su realidad hasta que viese a Rochester y le oyese renovar sus promesas y sus frases de amor.
Mientras me peinaba, me miré al espejo y mi rostro no me pareció feo.

While arranging my hair, I looked at my face in the glass, and felt it was no longer plain: there was hope in its aspect and life in its colour; and my eyes seemed as if they had beheld the fount of fruition, and borrowed beams from the lustrous ripple.
Brillaban en él una expresión de esperanza y un vivido color.
Mis ojos parecían haberse bañado en la fuente de la dicha y adquirido en ella un esplendor inusitado.
I had often been unwilling to look at my master, because I feared he could not be pleased at my look; but I was sure I might lift my face to his now, and not cool his affection by its expression.
Con frecuencia había temido que Rochester se sintiera desagradado por mi aspecto, pero ahora me sentía segura de que mi semblante, tal como estaba hoy, no enfriaría su afecto.
I took a plain but clean and light summer dress from my drawer and put it on: it seemed no attire had ever so well become me, because none had I ever worn in so blissful a mood.
Saqué del cajón un sencillo y limpio vestido de verano y me lo puse.

I was not surprised, when I ran down into the hall, to see that a brilliant June morning had succeeded to the tempest of the night; and to feel, through the open glass door, the breathing of a fresh and fragrant breeze.
Me pareció que nunca me había sentado tan bien.
No me sorprendió al bajar al vestíbulo que una bella mañana de verano hubiera sucedido a la tempestad.
Nature must be gladsome when I was so happy.
Aspiré la brisa, fresca y fragante.

A beggar-woman and her little boy--pale, ragged objects both--were coming up the walk, and I ran down and gave them all the money I happened to have in my purse--some three or four shillings: good or bad, they must partake of my jubilee.
Una mendiga con un niño avanzada por el camino y corrí a darles cuanto llevaba: tres o cuatro chelines.
Quería que todos y todo participaran de mi júbilo, de un modo u otro.
The rooks cawed, and blither birds sang; but nothing was so merry or so musical as my own rejoicing heart.
Graznaban las cornejas y cantaban los pájaros, pero nada me era tan grato como la alegría de mi corazón.
Mrs.
Mrs. Fairfax surprised me by looking out of the window with a sad countenance, and saying gravely--"Miss Eyre, will you come to breakfast?"
Fairfax se asomó a la ventana y con grave acento me dijo: -Miss Eyre, ¿viene a desayunar?
Mientras desayunábamos, se mantuvo fría y silenciosa.
During the meal she was quiet and cool: but I could not undeceive her then.
Pero yo no podía explicarme con ella aún.
I must wait for my master to give explanations; and so must she.
Necesitaba que Rochester me repitiese lo que me dijera la noche antes.
I ate what I could, and then I hastened upstairs.
I met Adele leaving the schoolroom.
Desayuné todo lo de prisa que pude, subí y encontré a Adèle que salía del cuarto de estudio.
"Where are you going?
-¿Adónde vas?
Es hora de dar la lección.
It is time for lessons."
-Mrs.
"Mr. Rochester has sent me away to the nursery."
Rochester me ha dicho que vaya a jugar.
"Where is he?"
-¿Dónde está?
"In there," pointing to the apartment she had left; and I went in, and there he stood.
-Allí -contestó señalando el cuarto del que salía.
Entré y le hallé, en efecto.
"Come and bid me good-morning," said he.
-Saludémonos -me dijo.
I gladly advanced; and it was not merely a cold word now, or even a shake of the hand that I received, but an embrace and a kiss.
Avancé hacia él, que me acogió no con una simple palabra o con un apretón de manos, sino con un abrazo y un beso.
It seemed natural: it seemed genial to be so well loved, so caressed by him.
Me parecía natural y admirable que me quisiera y me acariciara tanto.
"Jane, you look blooming, and smiling, and pretty," said he: "truly pretty this morning.
-Jane -me dijo-: esta mañana estás agradable, sonriente, bonita...
Is this my pale, little elf?
Is this my mustard- seed?
No pareces el duendecillo de otras veces.
This little sunny-faced girl with the dimpled cheek and rosy lips; the satin-smooth hazel hair, and the radiant hazel eyes?"
¿Es posible que sea la misma esa muchachita de radiante rostro, rosadas mejillas, rojos labios, sedosa cabellera y brillantes ojos castaños?
(I had green eyes, reader; but you must excuse the mistake: for him they were new-dyed, I suppose.)
Yo tenía ojos verdes, lector; pero debes perdonar el error: supongo que para él mostraban un nuevo reflejo.
"It is Jane Eyre, sir."
-Soy la misma Jane Eyre.
"Soon to be Jane Rochester," he added: "in four weeks, Janet; not a day more.
-Pronto serás Jane Rochester.
De aquí a cuatro semanas.
Do you hear that?"
¡Ni un día más!
¿Lo oyes?
I did, and I could not quite comprehend it: it made me giddy.
Lo oía sí, pero apenas lo comprendía.
The feeling, the announcement sent through me, was something stronger than was consistent with joy--something that smote and stunned.
It was, I think almost fear.
Aquella noticia me causaba una sensación tal, que más que alegría rayaba en estupefacción, casi en miedo.
"You blushed, and now you are white, Jane: what is that for?"
-Te has puesto pálida, Jane.
¿Qué te pasa?
"Because you gave me a new name--Jane Rochester; and it seems so strange."
-Me da usted un nombre que me resulta tan extraño...
-Mrs.
"Yes, Mrs. Rochester," said he; "young Mrs. Rochester--Fairfax Rochester's girl-bride."
Rochester-contestó-, la joven Mrs.
Rochester; la esposa de Fairfax Rochester.
"It can never be, sir; it does not sound likely.
-Me parece imposible.
Human beings never enjoy complete happiness in this world.
I was not born for a different destiny to the rest of my species: to imagine such a lot befalling me is a fairy tale--a day-dream."
Semejante felicidad se me figura un sueño, un cuento de hadas.
"Which I can and will realise.
I shall begin to-day.
-Que yo convertiré en realidad.
This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send me certain jewels he has in his keeping,--heirlooms for the ladies of Thornfield.
Hoy he escrito a mi banquero para que envíe ciertas joyas que tiene en custodia: las joyas de la familia.
In a day or two I hope to pour them into your lap: for every privilege, every attention shall be yours that I would accord a peer's daughter, if about to marry her."
Espero poder dártelas dentro de un par de días.
Quiero que disfrutes de todas las atenciones, de todas las delicadezas que merecería la hija de un par si me casara con ella.
"Oh, sir!--never rain jewels!
-No hablemos de joyas.
I don't like to hear them spoken of.
¡Joyas para Jane Eyre!
Jewels for Jane Eyre sounds unnatural and strange: I would rather not have them."
Vale más no tenerlas.

"I will myself put the diamond chain round your neck, and the circlet on your forehead,--which it will become: for nature, at least, has stamped her patent of nobility on this brow, Jane; and I will clasp the bracelets on these fine wrists, and load these fairy-like fingers with rings."
-Yo mismo te pondré al cuello el collar de diamantes y la diadema en esa frente que tiene por naturaleza un aspecto tan noble.
Yo mismo ceñiré con pulseras tus finas muñecas y con anillos tus deditos de hada.
"No, no, sir! think of other subjects, and speak of other things, and in another strain.
-Pensemos y hablemos de otras cosas, no de esas que me resultan extrañas.
Don't address me as if I were a beauty; I am your plain, Quakerish governess."
No se dirija a mí como si fuera una belleza.
No soy más que una vulgar institutriz.
"You are a beauty in my eyes, and a beauty just after the desire of my heart,--delicate and aerial."
-A mis ojos eres una belleza tal como me gusta: vaporosa, delicada...
"Puny and insignificant, you mean.
-Quiere usted decir mezquina e insignificante.
You are dreaming, sir,--or you are sneering.
O sueña usted o se burla de mí...
For God's sake don't be ironical!"
¡No se chancee, por Dios!
"I will make the world acknowledge you a beauty, too," he went on, while I really became uneasy at the strain he had adopted, because I felt he was either deluding himself or trying to delude me.
-Yo haré que todo el mundo reconozca tu belleza -dijo.
Yo me sentía realmente contrariada de la actitud que había adoptado, porque comprendía que él trataba de ilusionarme o de ilusionarse-.
"I will attire my Jane in satin and lace, and she shall have roses in her hair; and I will cover the head I love best with a priceless veil."
Cubriré a mi Jane de rasos y blondas, pondré flores en sus cabellos, adornaré la cabeza que amo...
"And then you won't know me, sir; and I shall not be your Jane Eyre any longer, but an ape in a harlequin's jacket--a jay in borrowed plumes.
-Y no me conocerá usted entonces ni seré su Jane Eyre, sino un arlequín, un grajo con plumas de pavo real.
Prefería que no se empeñase en considerarme como una bella dama.

I would as soon see you, Mr. Rochester, tricked out in stage-trappings, as myself clad in a court-lady's robe; and I don't call you handsome, sir, though I love you most dearly: far too dearly to flatter you.
Don't flatter me."
Así como yo no le llamo hermoso, a pesar de lo mucho que le amo, para no adularle, tampoco debe usted adularme a mí.
He pursued his theme, however, without noticing my deprecation.
Pero él continuó hablando sin hacer caso alguno de mi opinión.
"This very day I shall take you in the carriage to Millcote, and you must choose some dresses for yourself.
-Voy a llevarte en coche a Millcote hoy mismo para que elijas los vestidos que gustes.
I told you we shall be married in four weeks.
Te digo que nos casaremos dentro de cuatro semanas.
The wedding is to take place quietly, in the church down below yonder; and then I shall waft you away at once to town.
Celebraremos la boda en la intimidad, en esa iglesita cercana, y luego iremos a Londres.
Estaremos allí unos días y luego conduciré a mi tesoro a países más soleados: Francia, con sus viñedos; Italia, con sus llanuras.

After a brief stay there, I shall bear my treasure to regions nearer the sun: to French vineyards and Italian plains; and she shall see whatever is famous in old story and in modern record: she shall taste, too, of the life of cities; and she shall learn to value herself by just comparison with others."
Y mi tesorito conocerá cuanto hay digno de verse: los recuerdos de la Antigüedad, las cosas modernas...
Se acostumbrará a vivir en las ciudades y aprenderá a estimarse en lo que merece comparándose con las demás.
"Shall I travel?--and with you, sir?"
-¿Viajaré con usted?

"You shall sojourn at Paris, Rome, and Naples: at Florence, Venice, and Vienna: all the ground I have wandered over shall be re-trodden by you: wherever I stamped my hoof, your sylph's foot shall step also.
-Iremos a París, a Roma, a Nápoles, a Florencia, a Venecia y a Viena.
Recorreré contigo todos los países que he recorrido solo y tu pie pisará donde antes he pisado yo.
Ten years since, I flew through Europe half mad; with disgust, hate, and rage as my companions: now I shall revisit it healed and cleansed, with a very angel as my comforter."
Desde hace diez años he recorrido Europa medio loco, con el odio, la furia y el disgusto reinando en mi corazón.
Ahora la recorreré sereno y purificado, acompañado de un ángel que me consolará...
I laughed at him as he said this.
Reí y le dije:
"I am not an angel," I asserted; "and I will not be one till I die: I will be myself.
-No soy un ángel ni lo seré hasta que muera.
Seré como soy, Mr.
Rochester.
Mr. Rochester, you must neither expect nor exact anything celestial of me--for you will not get it, any more than I shall get it of you: which I do not at all anticipate."
No espere usted de mí nada celestial, porque no lo encontrará.
Además, presumo que usted...
"What do you anticipate of me?"
-¿Qué presumes?

"For a little while you will perhaps be as you are now,--a very little while; and then you will turn cool; and then you will be capricious; and then you will be stern, and I shall have much ado to please you: but when you get well used to me, you will perhaps like me again,--_like_ me, I say, not _love_ me.
-Presumo que durante algún tiempo quizá siga usted como ahora, pero luego se enfriará, se hará malhumorado y antojadizo y yo tendré que esforzarme mucho para agradarle.
Creo, no obstante, que cuando esté bien acostumbrado a mí me apreciará.
Fíjese que no digo que me ame.
I suppose your love will effervesce in six months, or less.
Supongo que la vehemencia de su amor durará seis meses o quizá menos.
I have observed in books written by men, that period assigned as the farthest to which a husband's ardour extends.
Es el plazo que en los libros se asigna al amor del más ardoroso marido.
Yet, after all, as a friend and companion, I hope never to become quite distasteful to my dear master."
Ahora bien, como compañera y amiga, espero no resultar desagradable a mi querido dueño.
"Distasteful! and like you again!
-¿Desagradable?
¿Volver a apreciarte?
I think I shall like you again, and yet again: and I will make you confess I do not only _like_, but _love_ you--with truth, fervour, constancy."
¡No te dejaré de apreciar nunca!
No sólo te apreciaré, sino que he de amarte con sinceridad, fervor y constancia.
"Yet are you not capricious, sir?"
-¿No es usted caprichoso?

"To women who please me only by their faces, I am the very devil when I find out they have neither souls nor hearts--when they open to me a perspective of flatness, triviality, and perhaps imbecility, coarseness, and ill-temper: but to the clear eye and eloquent tongue, to the soul made of fire, and the character that bends but does not break--at once supple and stable, tractable and consistent--I am ever tender and true."

-Con las mujeres que sólo me gustan por su aspecto, soy un verdadero demonio cuando descubro que no tienen alma ni corazón, cuando abren ante mí las perspectivas de su mal carácter, su vulgaridad y su estupidez.
Pero para una mujer de límpidos ojos, de lengua elocuente, de alma ardorosa, de carácter flexible y firme, dócil y enérgico a la vez, seré siempre fiel y afectuoso.
"Had you ever experience of such a character, sir?
-¿Ha conocido usted a alguien así?
Did you ever love such an one?"
¿Ha amado a alguien que fuera de tal modo?
"I love it now."
-Amo ahora a una persona así.
"But before me: if I, indeed, in any respect come up to your difficult standard?"
-Pero, antes que a mí, ¿no ha amado a nadie que encarnara un tipo tan difícil de encontrar?
"I never met your likeness.
-Jane: nunca he hallado a nadie como tú.

Jane, you please me, and you master me--you seem to submit, and I like the sense of pliancy you impart; and while I am twining the soft, silken skein round my finger, it sends a thrill up my arm to my heart.
Nadie me ha sometido, nadie ha influido tan dulcemente como tú lo has hecho.
I am influenced--conquered; and the influence is sweeter than I can express; and the conquest I undergo has a witchery beyond any triumph I can win.
Esta influencia que ejerces sobre mí es mucho más encantadora de cuanto se pueda expresar.
Why do you smile, Jane?
Pero ¿por qué sonríes, Jane?
What does that inexplicable, that uncanny turn of countenance mean?"
"I was thinking, sir (you will excuse the idea; it was involuntary), I was thinking of Hercules and Samson with their charmers--"
-Estaba pensando (y perdóneme, porque la idea ha acudido involuntariamente a mi mente) en Hércules y Sansón y en sus respectivas amadas.
"You were, you little elfish--"
-¿Y en qué más, duendecillo mío?
"Hush, sir!
You don't talk very wisely just now; any more than those gentlemen acted very wisely.
However, had they been married, they would no doubt by their severity as husbands have made up for their softness as suitors; and so will you, I fear.
-Pensaba que si aquellos caballeros se hubiesen casado, su severidad como maridos hubiera superado en mucho a su dulzura de enamorados.
Y sospecho que a usted le pasará igual.
I wonder how you will answer me a year hence, should I ask a favour it does not suit your convenience or pleasure to grant."
Me agradaría saber cómo contestará cuando de aquí a un año le pida cualquier favor que usted no juzgue oportuno concederme.
"Ask me something now, Jane,--the least thing: I desire to be entreated--"
-Pídemelo ahora, Jane.
¿Qué más da?
"Indeed I will, sir; I have my petition all ready."
-Lo haré así.
"Speak!
-Habla.
But if you look up and smile with that countenance, I shall swear concession before I know to what, and that will make a fool of me."
Pero si me miras y sonríes de ese modo, te prometeré hacer lo que me solicites antes de saber lo que es, y quizá con ello haga una tontería.
-No lo creo.
"Not at all, sir; I ask only this: don't send for the jewels, and don't crown me with roses: you might as well put a border of gold lace round that plain pocket handkerchief you have there."
Sólo quiero que no haga traer las joyas y que no me corone de rosas.
Sería tan ilógico como si mandara bordar en oro ese sencillo pañuelo que lleva usted.
"I might as well 'gild refined gold.'
-Más bien querrás decir que sería como dorar el oro...
I know it: your request is granted then--for the time.
Bien: se te concede por ahora lo que pides.
I will remand the order I despatched to my banker.
Rectificaré la orden que he enviado a mi banquero.
But you have not yet asked for anything; you have prayed a gift to be withdrawn: try again."
Pero esto no es pedir, sino obtener que se te deje de hacer un don.
Pídeme otra cosa, pues.
"Well then, sir, have the goodness to gratify my curiosity, which is much piqued on one point."
-Entonces, señor, le ruego que satisfaga mi curiosidad sobre cierto extremo.
He looked disturbed.
-¿Cómo? -dijo, con alguna turbación-.
"What? what?" he said hastily.
"Curiosity is a dangerous petition: it is well I have not taken a vow to accord every request--"
Las peticiones que hace la curiosidad son arriesgadas.
Celebro no haber prometido complacerte en todo.
"But there can be no danger in complying with this, sir."
-Ningún riesgo puede haber en satisfacer esa curiosidad.
"Utter it, Jane: but I wish that instead of a mere inquiry into, perhaps, a secret, it was a wish for half my estate."
"Now, King Ahasuerus!
-¿Tú qué sabes, Jane?
Acaso, a hacerme preguntas sobre algo que convenga mantener en secreto, prefiriera que me pidieses la mitad de mis bienes.
What do I want with half your estate?
Do you think I am a Jew-usurer, seeking good investment in land?
-¿Y para qué necesito la mitad de sus bienes?
¿Acaso se figura que soy un judío usurero?
I would much rather have all your confidence.
Prefiero conseguir las confidencias de usted.
You will not exclude me from your confidence if you admit me to your heart?"
¿Va usted a excluirme de sus confidencias cuando me acepta en su corazón?
"You are welcome to all my confidence that is worth having, Jane; but for God's sake, don't desire a useless burden!
Don't long for poison--don't turn out a downright Eve on my hands!"
-No te rehusaré ninguna confidencia confesable, Jane; pero, por amor de Dios, no te obstines en que te haga confidencias inútiles.
"Why not, sir?
-¿Por qué no obstinarme?
You have just been telling me how much you liked to be conquered, and how pleasant over-persuasion is to you.
Usted mismo me ha dicho que lo que le place de mí es mi fuerza de persuasión.
Don't you think I had better take advantage of the confession, and begin and coax and entreat--even cry and be sulky if necessary--for the sake of a mere essay of my power?"
"I dare you to any such experiment.
Encroach, presume, and the game is up."
"Is it, sir?
You soon give in.
How stern you look now!
Your eyebrows have become as thick as my finger, and your forehead resembles what, in some very astonishing poetry, I once saw styled, 'a blue-piled thunderloft.'
That will be your married look, sir, I suppose?"
"If that will be _your_ married look, I, as a Christian, will soon give up the notion of consorting with a mere sprite or salamander.
But what had you to ask, thing,--out with it?"
"There, you are less than civil now; and I like rudeness a great deal better than flattery.
I had rather be a _thing_ than an angel.
This is what I have to ask,--Why did you take such pains to make me believe you wished to marry Miss Ingram?"
En resumen, ¿por qué se empeña usted en hacerme sufrir dándome a entender que iba a casarse con Blanche Ingram?
"Is that all?
-¿No es más que eso?
Thank God it is no worse!"
¡Menos mal!
And now he unknit his black brows; looked down, smiling at me, and stroked my hair, as if well pleased at seeing a danger averted.
-y sonrió, desarrugó el entrecejo y pasó la mano por mi cabellera, con la satisfecha expresión de quien ha visto alejarse el peligro-.
"I think I may confess," he continued, "even although I should make you a little indignant, Jane--and I have seen what a fire-spirit you can be when you are indignant.
You glowed in the cool moonlight last night, when you mutinied against fate, and claimed your rank as my equal.
Janet, by-the-bye, it was you who made me the offer."
"Of course I did.
But to the point if you please, sir--Miss Ingram?"

"Well, I feigned courtship of Miss Ingram, because I wished to render you as madly in love with me as I was with you; and I knew jealousy would be the best ally I could call in for the furtherance of that end."
He fingido cortejar a Blanche Ingram porque deseaba que te enamoraras tan locamente de mí como yo lo estaba de ti.
Sabía que los celos eran el mejor modo de conseguir lo que me proponía.
"Excellent!
-¡Admirable!
Now you are small--not one whit bigger than the end of my little finger.
Es usted más pequeñito que la punta de mi meñique.
It was a burning shame and a scandalous disgrace to act in that way.
¿No le daba vergüenza?
Did you think nothing of Miss Ingram's feelings, sir?"
¿Cómo jugaba así con los sentimientos de Blanche?
"Her feelings are concentrated in one--pride; and that needs humbling.
-Todos sus sentimientos se reducen a uno: el orgullo.
Y conviene humillarlo.
Were you jealous, Jane?"
¿Estabas celosa, Jane?
"Never mind, Mr. Rochester: it is in no way interesting to you to know that.
-Eso no le interesa.
Answer me truly once more.
Do you think Miss Ingram will not suffer from your dishonest coquetry?
¿Cree que Blanche Ingram no sufrirá con el proceder de usted?
Won't she feel forsaken and deserted?"
¿No piensa que se considerará abandonada y desairada?
"Impossible!--when I told you how she, on the contrary, deserted me: the idea of my insolvency cooled, or rather extinguished, her flame in a moment."
-Ya te he dicho que es ella quien me ha abandonado a mí.
El pensar en mi insolvencia enfrió o, mejor dicho, extinguió su ardor instantáneamente.
"You have a curious, designing mind, Mr. Rochester.
-Es usted original, Mr.
Rochester.
I am afraid your principles on some points are eccentric."
Tiene usted principios muy extraños.
"My principles were never trained, Jane: they may have grown a little awry for want of attention."
-Si hubiesen sido encauzados cuando empezaban a desarrollarse, mis principios no serían como son.
"Once again, seriously; may I enjoy the great good that has been vouchsafed to me, without fearing that any one else is suffering the bitter pain I myself felt a while ago?"
-En serio: ¿cree que puedo gozar de esta gran alegría sin amargármela con el pensamiento de que otra mujer sufre lo que yo sufría antes?
-Puedes, chiquita mía.
"That you may, my good little girl: there is not another being in the world has the same pure love for me as yourself--for I lay that pleasant unction to my soul, Jane, a belief in your affection."
No hay nadie en el mundo que me quiera como tú.
Ya ves, Jane, que tengo el consuelo de creer que me quieres.
I turned my lips to the hand that lay on my shoulder.
Puse mis labios sobre su mano, que estaba apoyada en mi hombro.
I loved him very much--more than I could trust myself to say--more than words had power to express.
Le amaba mucho, en efecto, más de lo que yo pudiera decir, más de cuanto las palabras pueden expresar.
"Ask something more," he said presently; "it is my delight to be entreated, and to yield."
-Pídeme algo más -dijo-.
Mi mayor placer es complacerte.
I was again ready with my request.
"Communicate your intentions to Mrs. Fairfax, sir: she saw me with you last night in the hall, and she was shocked.
-Entonces manifieste usted sus propósitos a Mrs.
Fairfax antes de que yo la vea.
Give her some explanation before I see her again.
Ayer nos sorprendió en el vestíbulo y se extrañó.
It pains me to be misjudged by so good a woman."
Me disgusta que una mujer tan bondadosa como ella me juzgue mal.
"Go to your room, and put on your bonnet," he replied.
-Vete a tu cuarto y ponte el sombrero -dijo-.
"I mean you to accompany me to Millcote this morning; and while you prepare for the drive, I will enlighten the old lady's understanding.
Tienes que acompañarme a Millcote.
Entretanto, yo hablaré a la buena señora.
Did she think, Janet, you had given the world for love, and considered it well lost?"
"I believe she thought I had forgotten my station, and yours, sir."
"Station! station!--your station is in my heart, and on the necks of those who would insult you, now or hereafter.--Go."
I was soon dressed; and when I heard Mr. Rochester quit Mrs. Fairfax's parlour, I hurried down to it.
Me vestí rápidamente y, cuando sentí a Mr.
Rochester salir del gabinete de Mrs.
Fairfax, me dirigí allí.
The old lady, had been reading her morning portion of Scripture--the Lesson for the day; her Bible lay open before her, and her spectacles were upon it.
La anciana había estado leyendo la Biblia; el tomo se hallaba abierto y tenía las gafas puestas sobre él.
Her occupation, suspended by Mr. Rochester's announcement, seemed now forgotten: her eyes, fixed on the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind stirred by unwonted tidings.

Parecía haber olvidado su ocupación, interrumpida por la noticia que Rochester le diera, y sus ojos, fijos en la blanca pared, expresaban la sorpresa propia de un cerebro sensato que asiste al desarrollo de cosas insólitas.
Seeing me, she roused herself: she made a sort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but the smile expired, and the sentence was abandoned unfinished.
Al verme se levantó, hizo un esfuerzo para sonreír y me dijo algunas palabras de felicitación.
Pero su sonrisa expiró y hasta acabó interrumpiendo su enhorabuena.
She put up her spectacles, shut the Bible, and pushed her chair back from the table.
Cerró la Biblia, apartó las gafas y retiró su silla un poco hacia atrás.
"I feel so astonished," she began, "I hardly know what to say to you, Miss Eyre.
-Estoy asombrada -confesó-.
Casi no sé qué decirla.
I have surely not been dreaming, have I?
¿No habré estado soñando?
Sometimes I half fall asleep when I am sitting alone and fancy things that have never happened.
A veces me adormezco cuando estoy sentada a solas, imagino cosas que no han ocurrido jamás.

It has seemed to me more than once when I have been in a doze, that my dear husband, who died fifteen years since, has come in and sat down beside me; and that I have even heard him call me by my name, Alice, as he used to do.
Una vez me pareció que mi difunto marido, muerto hace quince años, se sentaba a mi lado y me llamaba por mi nombre, Alice, como acostumbraba.
Now, can you tell me whether it is actually true that Mr. Rochester has asked you to marry him?
Dígame: ¿es cierto que el señor le ha pedido relaciones?
Don't laugh at me.
No se ría de mí.
But I really thought he came in here five minutes ago, and said that in a month you would be his wife."
Pero me ha parecido que él ha estado aquí hace cinco minutos y me ha dicho que dentro de un mes será usted su esposa.
"He has said the same thing to me," I replied.
-Lo mismo me ha dicho a mí -repliqué.
"He has!
Do you believe him?
-¿Y le cree usted?
Have you accepted him?"
¿Ha aceptado?
"Yes."
-Sí.
She looked at me bewildered.
Me miró, turbada.
"I could never have thought it.
-¡Nunca se me hubiera ocurrido semejante cosa!
He is a proud man: all the Rochesters were proud: and his father, at least, liked money.
He, too, has always been called careful.
Él, que es un hombre orgulloso, como todos los Rochester...
He means to marry you?"
¿Es posible que quiera casarse con usted?
"He tells me so."
-Así me lo ha dicho.
She surveyed my whole person: in her eyes I read that they had there found no charm powerful enough to solve the enigma.
Me miró de pies a cabeza, y leí en sus ojos que no veía en mí hechizos tales que justificaran aquel misterio.
"It passes me!" she continued; "but no doubt, it is true since you say so.
-Me parece increíble -dijo, al fin-, pero no lo dudo, puesto que usted lo dice.
How it will answer, I cannot tell: I really don't know.
Cómo resultará todo, no me atrevo a predecirlo.
Equality of position and fortune is often advisable in such cases; and there are twenty years of difference in your ages.
Es muy aconsejable en estos casos que la fortuna y la edad sean análogos, y él le lleva veinte años.
He might almost be your father."
Podría casi ser su padre.
"No, indeed, Mrs. Fairfax!" exclaimed I, nettled; "he is nothing like my father!
-Nada de eso, Mrs.
Fairfax -protesté-.
No one, who saw us together, would suppose it for an instant.
Nadie que nos viera juntos diría que puede ser mi padre.
Mr. Rochester looks as young, and is as young, as some men at five-and- twenty."
Mr.
Rochester parece y es tan joven como un hombre de veinticinco años.
"Is it really for love he is going to marry you?" she asked.
-¿Se casa con usted por amor, en realidad? -preguntó.
I was so hurt by her coldness and scepticism, that the tears rose to my eyes.
Me sentí tan herida por su frío escepticismo, que las lágrimas acudieron a mis ojos.
"I am sorry to grieve you," pursued the widow; "but you are so young, and so little acquainted with men, I wished to put you on your guard.
-Siento haberla disgustado -dijo la viuda-, pero usted es muy joven, no está acostumbrada a tratar con los hombres y quisiera ponerla en guardia.
It is an old saying that 'all is not gold that glitters;' and in this case I do fear there will be something found to be different to what either you or I expect."
Ya sabe que no es oro todo lo que reluce.
En este caso, temo que todo termine de un modo que ni usted ni yo desearíamos.
"Why?--am I a monster?"
-¿Acaso soy un monstruo? -pregunté-.
I said: "is it impossible that Mr. Rochester should have a sincere affection for me?"
¿Es imposible que Mr.
Rochester sienta algún afecto por mí?
"No: you are very well; and much improved of late; and Mr. Rochester, I daresay, is fond of you.
-No.
Es usted agradable y mejorará con el tiempo, y reconozco que Mr.
I have always noticed that you were a sort of pet of his.
Rochester parece apreciarla.
Vengo observando hace tiempo su predilección por usted.
There are times when, for your sake, I have been a little uneasy at his marked preference, and have wished to put you on your guard: but I did not like to suggest even the possibility of wrong.

Ha habido ocasiones en que he estado a punto de advertirla que se pusiera en guardia contra esa excesiva preferencia, pero temía ofenderla, porque es usted tan modesta, tan discreta y tan prudente, que pensaba que sabría guardarse por sí misma.
I knew such an idea would shock, perhaps offend you; and you were so discreet, and so thoroughly modest and sensible, I hoped you might be trusted to protect yourself.
Last night I cannot tell you what I suffered when I sought all over the house, and could find you nowhere, nor the master either; and then, at twelve o'clock, saw you come in with him."
No puede usted imaginar lo que sufrí anoche cuando la busqué por toda la casa sin encontrarla y cuando la vi volver con él tan tarde...
"Well, never mind that now," I interrupted impatiently; "it is enough that all was right."
-Todo eso no importa -interrumpí, con impaciencia-.
Ya ve que todo va bien.
"I hope all will be right in the end," she said: "but believe me, you cannot be too careful.
-Espero que vaya bien hasta el fin, mas, créame, toda precaución es poca.
Try and keep Mr. Rochester at a distance: distrust yourself as well as him.
Procure mantenerse a cierta distancia del señor.
No confíe en él ni en usted misma.
Gentlemen in his station are not accustomed to marry their governesses."
Caballeros de la clase de Mr.
Rochester no suelen casarse con institutrices.
I was growing truly irritated: happily, Adele ran in.
Mi irritación crecía.
Afortunadamente, Adèle apareció en aquel momento.
"Let me go,--let me go to Millcote too!" she cried.
-¡Lléveme a Millcote! -exclamó-.
"Mr. Rochester won't: though there is so much room in the new carriage.
En el coche hay bastante sitio.
Pida a Mr.
Beg him to let me go mademoiselle."
Rochester que me lleve.
Él dice que no...
"That I will, Adele;" and I hastened away with her, glad to quit my gloomy monitress.
-Se lo diré, Adèle -repuse-.
Y la saqué de la habitación, sintiéndome satisfecha de separarme de la anciana.
The carriage was ready: they were bringing it round to the front, and my master was pacing the pavement, Pilot following him backwards and forwards.
El coche estaba listo y Rochester paseaba ante la fachada de la casa, seguido de Piloto.
"Adele may accompany us, may she not, sir?"
-¿No quiere que nos acompañe Adèle? -pregunté.
"I told her no.
-Ya le he dicho a ella que no.
I'll have no brats!--I'll have only you."
No quiero llevar chiquillos.
"Do let her go, Mr. Rochester, if you please: it would be better."
-Llevémosla, Mr.
Rochester.
Es mejor...
"Not it: she will be a restraint."
-No: que se quede.
He was quite peremptory, both in look and voice.
Su acento y su mirada eran tan autoritarios que, sin poderlo evitar, los consejos de Mrs.
The chill of Mrs. Fairfax's warnings, and the damp of her doubts were upon me: something of unsubstantiality and uncertainty had beset my hopes.
I half lost the sense of power over him.
Fairfax acudieron a mi cerebro y la dudas que ella experimentaba se me comunicaron, empañando mis esperanzas con una sombra de incertidumbre.
I was about mechanically to obey him, without further remonstrance; but as he helped me into the carriage, he looked at my face.
Le obedecí maquinalmente sin replicar.
Al ayudarme a subir al coche me miró.
"What is the matter?" he asked; "all the sunshine is gone.
-¿Qué pasa? -preguntó-.
Do you really wish the bairn to go?
Toda tu alegría se ha desvanecido.
Will it annoy you if she is left behind?"
¿Quieres realmente llevar a la pequeña?
"I would far rather she went, sir."
-Lo preferiría.
"Then off for your bonnet, and back like a flash of lightning!" cried he to Adele.
-Entonces corre a buscar tu sombrero y vuelve como un relámpago -ordenó a Adèle.
She obeyed him with what speed she might.
Ella obedeció tan deprisa como pudo.
"After all, a single morning's interruption will not matter much," said he, "when I mean shortly to claim you--your thoughts, conversation, and company--for life."

-Después de todo -dijo él-, no es mucho sufrir una interrupción de una mañana cuando de aquí a poco voy a poder reclamarte íntegramente tus pensamientos, tu compañía y tu conversación para toda la vida.
Adele, when lifted in, commenced kissing me, by way of expressing her gratitude for my intercession: she was instantly stowed away into a corner on the other side of him.
Adèle, al subir al coche, comenzó a besarme en muestra de gratitud, pero él la hizo inmediatamente sentarse en un ángulo del asiento, en el lado opuesto al mío.
She then peeped round to where I sat; so stern a neighbour was too restrictive to him, in his present fractious mood, she dared whisper no observations, nor ask of him any information.
Adèle me miraba a hurtadillas, ya que su vecino de asiento se mostraba tan poco agradable para ella que no se atrevía a decirle ni preguntarle nada.
"Let her come to me," I entreated: "she will, perhaps, trouble you, sir: there is plenty of room on this side."
-Déjela venir a mi lado -dije-.
Ahí quizá le moleste y aquí sobra sitio.
He handed her over as if she had been a lapdog.
"I'll send her to school yet," he said, but now he was smiling.
La cogió como si hubiera sido un perrito faldero y la cambió de lugar mientras decía, aunque ahora sonriendo: -Acabaré mandándola al colegio.
Adele heard him, and asked if she was to go to school "sans mademoiselle?"
Adèle que le oyó, se apresuró a preguntar si iba a ir al colegio sans mademoiselle.
-Sí -contestó él-, sans mademoiselle.

"Yes," he replied, "absolutely sans mademoiselle; for I am to take mademoiselle to the moon, and there I shall seek a cave in one of the white valleys among the volcano-tops, and mademoiselle shall live with me there, and only me."
Me la voy a llevar a la Luna.
La meteré en una cueva, en uno de los blancos valles que se extienden entre las cumbres de los volcanes, y allí vivirá conmigo, sólo conmigo.
"She will have nothing to eat: you will starve her," observed Adele.
-Pero no tendrá nada que comer y se morirá -observó Adèle.
"I shall gather manna for her morning and night: the plains and hillsides in the moon are bleached with manna, Adele."
-Yo recogeré maná para ella dos veces al día.
Las llanuras y montes de la Luna están llenos de maná.
"She will want to warm herself: what will she do for a fire?"
-Tendrá que calentarse.
¿Cómo encenderá fuego?
"Fire rises out of the lunar mountains: when she is cold, I'll carry her up to a peak, and lay her down on the edge of a crater."
-Las montañas de la Luna arrojan fuego por los cráteres de sus volcanes.
Cuando Jane tenga frío la colocaré en uno de ellos.
"Oh, qu' elle y sera mal--peu comfortable!
-Oh, qu'elle y será mal... peu confortable!
And her clothes, they will wear out: how can she get new ones?"
Y cuando se le estropee la ropa, ¿dónde comprará otra nueva?
Mr. Rochester professed to be puzzled.
Rochester estaba empeñado en maravillarla.
"Hem!" said he.
"What would you do, Adele?
Cudgel your brains for an expedient.
How would a white or a pink cloud answer for a gown, do you think?
-Para eso están las nubes, mujer.
¿No crees que de una nube blanca o rosada se puede cortar un buen vestido?
And one could cut a pretty enough scarf out of a rainbow."
Y con el arco iris puede muy bien hacerse un lindo chal.
"She is far better as she is," concluded Adele, after musing some time: "besides, she would get tired of living with only you in the moon.
-Mademoiselle está mejor como ahora -dijo Adèle, agregando-: Además se aburriría de vivir sola con usted en la Luna.
If I were mademoiselle, I would never consent to go with you."
Si yo fuera ella, no consentiría en irme allí con usted.
"She has consented: she has pledged her word."
-Pues ella me ha dado su palabra de acompañarme.
"But you can't get her there; there is no road to the moon: it is all air; and neither you nor she can fly."
-No sé cómo va a llevarla.
A la Luna no hay caminos, no siendo el aire, y ni usted ni ella saben volar.
"Adele, look at that field."
-Mira ese prado, Adèle.
¿Lo ves?

We were now outside Thornfield gates, and bowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was well laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty timber trees on each side glistened green and rain-refreshed.

"In that field, Adele, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight since--the evening of the day you helped me to make hay in the orchard meadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest me on a stile; and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began to write about a misfortune that befell me long ago, and a wish I had for happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight was fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped two yards off me.
Pues en él, hace dos semanas, estaba yo sentado en un portillo, con un lápiz y un libro, cuando de pronto, noté que una figura llegaba por el sendero y se detenía a dos pasos de mí.
I looked at it.
It was a little thing with a veil of gossamer on its head.
Miré y vi una cosa pequeñita, con un velo de telarañas en la cabeza.
I beckoned it to come near me; it stood soon at my knee.
Se acercó y se sentó en mis rodillas.
I never spoke to it, and it never spoke to me, in words; but I read its eyes, and it read mine; and our speechless colloquy was to this effect--
No nos dijimos nada, pero yo leía en sus ojos y ella en los míos y nuestras miradas mantuvieron un coloquio.

"It was a fairy, and come from Elf-land, it said; and its errand was to make me happy: I must go with it out of the common world to a lonely place--such as the moon, for instance--and it nodded its head towards her horn, rising over Hay-hill: it told me of the alabaster cave and silver vale where we might live.

Me dijo que era un hada que venía del país de la Fantasía a fin de hacerme dichoso, asegurándome que para ello era necesario abandonar la Tierra y buscar un sitio solitario, como por ejemplo, la Luna.
Me indicó que en ella había un valle de plata y una cueva de alabastro donde yo podría estar muy contento.
I said I should like to go; but reminded it, as you did me, that I had no wings to fly.
Le dije que me gustaría ir, pero que no tenía alas para volar.
"'Oh,' returned the fairy, 'that does not signify!
Here is a talisman will remove all difficulties;' and she held out a pretty gold ring.
«Eso no ofrece dificultad -contestó el hada- Toma este anillo de oro.
Es un talismán.
'Put it,' she said, 'on the fourth finger of my left hand, and I am yours, and you are mine; and we shall leave earth, and make our own heaven yonder.'
Ponlo en el anular de mi mano izquierda y tú te convertirás en mío y yo en tuya.
Entonces podremos abandonar la Tierra y volar al cielo.»
She nodded again at the moon.
The ring, Adele, is in my breeches-pocket, under the disguise of a sovereign: but I mean soon to change it to a ring again."
Llevo el anillo en el bolsillo, Adèle.
Ahora tiene la forma de una moneda, pero pienso convertirlo muy pronto en anillo.
"But what has mademoiselle to do with it?
-¿Qué tiene que ver Mademoiselle con todo eso?
I don't care for the fairy: you said it was mademoiselle you would take to the moon?"
Usted ha dicho que iba a llevar a Mademoiselle a la Luna...
"Mademoiselle is a fairy," he said, whispering mysteriously.
-Mademoiselle es un hada -cuchicheó al oído de la niña.
Yo la dije que no le creyese.

Whereupon I told her not to mind his badinage; and she, on her part, evinced a fund of genuine French scepticism: denominating Mr. Rochester "un vrai menteur," and assuring him that she made no account whatever of his "contes de fee," and that "du reste, il n'y avait pas de fees, et quand meme il y en avait:" she was sure they would never appear to him, nor ever give him rings, or offer to live with him in the moon.
Ella, con su escepticismo francés, no le creyó, en efecto.

Trató a Rochester de un vrai menteur y le aseguró que ella no creía en sus conies de fées, que du reste, il n'y avrait pas de fées, et quand méme il y en avait, no se aparecerían a él ni le darían anillos ni se ofrecerían a vivir con él en la Luna.
The hour spent at Millcote was a somewhat harassing one to me.
La hora que pasamos en Millcote fue muy embarazosa para mí.
Mr. Rochester obliged me to go to a certain silk warehouse: there I was ordered to choose half-a-dozen dresses.
Rochester me obligó a entrar en un almacén donde me ordenó que eligiera media docena de vestidos.
I hated the business, I begged leave to defer it: no--it should be gone through with now.
Yo aborrecía el ir de compras y le rogué que lo aplazase, pero no lo conseguí.
By dint of entreaties expressed in energetic whispers, I reduced the half-dozen to two: these however, he vowed he would select himself.
Logré, mediante enérgicos cuchicheos, que la media docena se redujese a dos, pero puso la condición de elegirlos él mismo.
With anxiety I watched his eye rove over the gay stores: he fixed on a rich silk of the most brilliant amethyst dye, and a superb pink satin.
Sus miradas se detuvieron sobre una rica seda color amatista y un soberbio raso color de rosa.
I told him in a new series of whispers, that he might as well buy me a gold gown and a silver bonnet at once: I should certainly never venture to wear his choice.
With infinite difficulty, for he was stubborn as a stone, I persuaded him to make an exchange in favour of a sober black satin and pearl-grey silk.

A través de una nueva serie de cuchicheos le dije que lo mismo podía haber elegido un vestido de oro y una corona de plata y, con grandes dificultades, porque se empeñaba en ser duro como el granito, logré convencerle de que optase por un satén negro y una seda color gris perla más modestos.
"It might pass for the present," he said; "but he would yet see me glittering like a parterre."
Convino, al fin, en ello, advirtiéndome que sólo cedía por aquella vez, pero que en lo sucesivo quería verme vestida con más colores que un pénsil florido.
Glad was I to get him out of the silk warehouse, and then out of a jewellers shop: the more he bought me, the more my cheek burned with a sense of annoyance and degradation.
Salí con la satisfacción del almacén, si bien para entrar en la joyería.
Cuantas más cosas compraba, más me ruborizaba yo, sintiéndome humillada y a disgusto.
Volví al coche contrariadísima.

As we re-entered the carriage, and I sat back feverish and fagged, I remembered what, in the hurry of events, dark and bright, I had wholly forgotten--the letter of my uncle, John Eyre, to Mrs. Reed: his intention to adopt me and make me his legatee.
Entonces me acordé de la carta de mi tío John Eyre, olvidada en el torbellino de los sucesos de aquellos días, en la que anunciaba su propósito de adoptarme.
«Sería mucho peor -medité- que yo tuviese cierta independencia.

"It would, indeed, be a relief," I thought, "if I had ever so small an independency; I never can bear being dressed like a doll by Mr. Rochester, or sitting like a second Danae with the golden shower falling daily round me.
Me sería insoportable verme vestida siempre por Mr.
Rochester como una muñeca, vivir como una segunda Dánae, bajo una lluvia de oro.

I will write to Madeira the moment I get home, and tell my uncle John I am going to be married, and to whom: if I had but a prospect of one day bringing Mr. Rochester an accession of fortune, I could better endure to be kept by him now."
En cuanto vuelva a casa escribiré a mi tío John diciéndole que voy a casarme y con quién.
Si tengo la esperanza de proporcionar algún día a Rochester algún aumento de sus bienes, sobrellevaré mejor estas cosas.»

And somewhat relieved by this idea (which I failed not to execute that day), I ventured once more to meet my master's and lover's eye, which most pertinaciously sought mine, though I averted both face and gaze.
Algo tranquilizada por mi propósito -que, no obstante, no debía aquel día llevar a la práctica-, miré a mi señor y enamorado.

He smiled; and I thought his smile was such as a sultan might, in a blissful and fond moment, bestow on a slave his gold and gems had enriched: I crushed his hand, which was ever hunting mine, vigorously, and thrust it back to him red with the passionate pressure.
Le vi sonreír y me pareció que aquella sonrisa era la de un sultán en el agradable momento de cubrir de joyas y oro a una de sus esclavas.
Cogí su mano, y mientras él estrechaba con fuerza la mía, le dije:
"You need not look in that way," I said; "if you do, I'll wear nothing but my old Lowood frocks to the end of the chapter.
-No me mire de ese modo.
De lo contrario, no llevaré en lo sucesivo otras ropas que las que usaba en Lowood.
I'll be married in this lilac gingham: you may make a dressing-gown for yourself out of the pearl-grey silk, and an infinite series of waistcoats out of the black satin."
He chuckled; he rubbed his hands.
Me casaré con este mismo vestidillo que llevo y usted podrá emplear para hacerse chalecos la tela que ha comprado.
"Oh, it is rich to see and hear her?" he exclaimed.
-¡Qué gracia me hace verte y oírte! -exclamó él-.
"Is she original?
¡Qué original eres!
Is she piquant?
I would not exchange this one little English girl for the Grand Turk's whole seraglio, gazelle- eyes, houri forms, and all!"
¡No cambiaría esta inglesita por todo el serrallo del Gran Turco, con sus ojos de gacela, sus formas de hurí y demás encantos!
The Eastern allusion bit me again.
Esta alusión oriental me hirió de nuevo.
"I'll not stand you an inch in the stead of a seraglio," I said; "so don't consider me an equivalent for one.
Dije: -No hablemos de serrallos.

If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, sir, to the bazaars of Stamboul without delay, and lay out in extensive slave- purchases some of that spare cash you seem at a loss to spend satisfactorily here."
Si usted me considerase como equivalente de una de esas hermosas de los harenes y me tomara en tal sentido, haría mejor en ir a adquirir esclavas en los bazares de Estambul.
"And what will you do, Janet, while I am bargaining for so many tons of flesh and such an assortment of black eyes?"
-¿Y qué harías tú mientras tanto?
"I'll be preparing myself to go out as a missionary to preach liberty to them that are enslaved--your harem inmates amongst the rest.
-Me prepararía para ser misionera e iría a predicar la abolición de la esclavitud, incluyendo la de las esclavas de su harén.

I'll get admitted there, and I'll stir up mutiny; and you, three-tailed bashaw as you are, sir, shall in a trice find yourself fettered amongst our hands: nor will I, for one, consent to cut your bonds till you have signed a charter, the most liberal that despot ever yet conferred."
Me introduciría en él y las amotinaría.

Caería usted en nuestras manos y, por muy vigoroso que usted sea, no saldría de ellas hasta que hubiera devuelto a sus mujeres su albedrío, otorgándoles una constitución tan liberal como jamás déspota alguno haya concedido.
"I would consent to be at your mercy, Jane."
-Me confiaría entonces a tu clemencia, Jane.
"I would have no mercy, Mr. Rochester, if you supplicated for it with an eye like that.
While you looked so, I should be certain that whatever charter you might grant under coercion, your first act, when released, would be to violate its conditions."

-Yo no tendría clemencia para usted si me miraba como me mira ahora, porque estaría segura de que su primer acto sería violar las cláusulas de la Constitución que nos concediese, tan pronto como le dejásemos en libertad.
"Why, Jane, what would you have?
I fear you will compel me to go through a private marriage ceremony, besides that performed at the altar.
You will stipulate, I see, for peculiar terms--what will they be?"
"I only want an easy mind, sir; not crushed by crowded obligations.
Do you remember what you said of Celine Varens?--of the diamonds, the cashmeres you gave her?
I will not be your English Celine Varens.
I shall continue to act as Adele's governess; by that I shall earn my board and lodging, and thirty pounds a year besides.
I'll furnish my own wardrobe out of that money, and you shall give me nothing but--"
"Well, but what?"
"Your regard; and if I give you mine in return, that debt will be quit."
"Well, for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven't your equal," said he.
We were now approaching Thornfield.
Entretanto, habíamos llegado a Thornfield.
"Will it please you to dine with me to-day?" he asked, as we re-entered the gates.
"No, thank you, sir."
"And what for, 'no, thank you?' if one may inquire."
"I never have dined with you, sir: and I see no reason why I should now: till--"
"Till what?
You delight in half-phrases."
"Till I can't help it."
"Do you suppose I eat like an ogre or a ghoul, that you dread being the companion of my repast?"
"I have formed no supposition on the subject, sir; but I want to go on as usual for another month."
"You will give up your governessing slavery at once."
"Indeed, begging your pardon, sir, I shall not.
I shall just go on with it as usual.
I shall keep out of your way all day, as I have been accustomed to do: you may send for me in the evening, when you feel disposed to see me, and I'll come then; but at no other time."
"I want a smoke, Jane, or a pinch of snuff, to comfort me under all this, 'pour me donner une contenance,' as Adele would say; and unfortunately I have neither my cigar-case, nor my snuff-box.
But listen--whisper.

It is your time now, little tyrant, but it will be mine presently; and when once I have fairly seized you, to have and to hold, I'll just--figuratively speaking--attach you to a chain like this" (touching his watch-guard).
"Yes, bonny wee thing, I'll wear you in my bosom, lest my jewel I should tyne."
He said this as he helped me to alight from the carriage, and while he afterwards lifted out Adele, I entered the house, and made good my retreat upstairs.
Rochester me ayudó a apearme y, mientras bajaba a Adèle yo me apresuré a subir las escaleras.
He duly summoned me to his presence in the evening.
Cuando me invitó a reunirme con él aquella noche,
I had prepared an occupation for him; for I was determined not to spend the whole time in a _tete-a-tete_ conversation.
yo había resuelto que se ocupase en algo, porque no estaba dispuesta a pasar todo el tiempo en una conversación íntima téte-à-téte.
I remembered his fine voice; I knew he liked to sing--good singers generally do.
Recordaba la buena voz de Rochester y sabía que le gustaba cantar como a casi todos los que tienen una hermosa voz.
I was no vocalist myself, and, in his fastidious judgment, no musician, either; but I delighted in listening when the performance was good.
En cuanto a mí, aunque no fuese buena cantante -ni, según él, buena música-, me deleitaba oír cantar bien.
No sooner had twilight, that hour of romance, began to lower her blue and starry banner over the lattice, than I rose, opened the piano, and entreated him, for the love of heaven, to give me a song.
Así, tan pronto como el anochecer comenzó a desplegar su azul y estrellada bandera más allá de las ventanas, abrí el piano y rogué a Rochester que cantara en obsequio mío.
He said I was a capricious witch, and that he would rather sing another time; but I averred that no time was like the present.
"Did I like his voice?" he asked.
-¿Te gusta mi voz? -preguntó.
"Very much."
-Mucho -repuse.
I was not fond of pampering that susceptible vanity of his; but for once, and from motives of expediency, I would e'en soothe and stimulate it.
No deseaba halagar su vanidad, pero por una vez y dado el caso de que se trataba, me pareció oportuno hacerlo.
"Then, Jane, you must play the accompaniment."
-Entonces, Jane, tendrás que acompañarme al piano.
"Very well, sir, I will try."
-Con mucho gusto.
I did try, but was presently swept off the stool and denominated "a little bungler."
Comencé, si bien casi en seguida fui arrojada del taburete sin ceremonias y calificada de chapucerilla.
Being pushed unceremoniously to one side--which was precisely what I wished--he usurped my place, and proceeded to accompany himself: for he could play as well as sing.
Él se sentó en mi lugar y comenzó a acompañar su melodía con la música.
Tocaba tan bien como cantaba.
I hied me to the window-recess.
And while I sat there and looked out on the still trees and dim lawn, to a sweet air was sung in mellow tones the following strain:--
Yo me senté junto a una ventana y, mientras miraba los árboles y el campo oscuro, le oí cantar la siguiente tonada:
"The truest love that ever heart Felt at its kindled core, Did through each vein, in quickened start, The tide of being pour.
El más verdadero amor que nadie ha jamás sentido inflama mi corazón y acelera sus latidos.
Her coming was my hope each day, Her parting was my pain; The chance that did her steps delay Was ice in every vein.
Soy feliz cuando la veo e infeliz cuando ha partido.
Si tarda en llegar, inquieto, se hiela en mi sangre el ritmo.
I dreamed it would be nameless bliss, As I loved, loved to be; And to this object did I press As blind as eagerly.
Por la indecible ventura de verme correspondido, yo haría lo que no haría ningún otro ser nacido.
But wide as pathless was the space That lay our lives between, And dangerous as the foamy race Of ocean-surges green.

Por ese amor cruzaré los infinitos abismos que nos separan; del mar los hirvientes remolinos; como un salteador, yo me arrojaré al camino y atropellaré por todo lo que pueda desunirnos; obstáculos venceré; desafiaré peligros; con razón o sin razón, sin miedo a premio o castigo.
And haunted as a robber-path Through wilderness or wood; For Might and Right, and Woe and Wrath, Between our spirits stood.
I dangers dared; I hindrance scorned; I omens did defy: Whatever menaced, harassed, warned, I passed impetuous by.
Pese a la saña y al odio de todos mis enemigos, alcanzaré el arco iris detrás del que peregrino.
On sped my rainbow, fast as light; I flew as in a dream; For glorious rose upon my sight That child of Shower and Gleam.
Combatiré contra todo, sin que humanos ni divinos logren oponer barreras al triunfo de mis designios.
Still bright on clouds of suffering dim Shines that soft, solemn joy; Nor care I now, how dense and grim Disasters gather nigh.
Hasta que de mi adorada los delicados deditos enlacen mi ruda mano con eslabones de lirios, mientras con un beso selle el juramento ofrecido de acompañarme si muero y acompañarme si vivo.
I care not in this moment sweet, Though all I have rushed o'er Should come on pinion, strong and fleet, Proclaiming vengeance sore:
Though haughty Hate should strike me down, Right, bar approach to me, And grinding Might, with furious frown, Swear endless enmity.
My love has placed her little hand With noble faith in mine, And vowed that wedlock's sacred band Our nature shall entwine.
My love has sworn, with sealing kiss, With me to live--to die; I have at last my nameless bliss.
As I love--loved am I!"
He rose and came towards me, and I saw his face all kindled, and his full falcon-eye flashing, and tenderness and passion in every lineament.
Se levantó y avanzó hacia mí.
Vi en su rostro pintada tal emoción y en sus ojos relampaguear tan ardiente llama, que me sentí desasosegada por un momento.
I quailed momentarily--then I rallied.
Pero reaccioné.

Soft scene, daring demonstration, I would not have; and I stood in peril of both: a weapon of defence must be prepared--I whetted my tongue: as he reached me, I asked with asperity, "whom he was going to marry now?"
Eran de temer peligrosas escenas de ternura y debía precaverme contra ellas.
Así, al acercarse, le pregunté con aspereza que con quién pensaba casarse ahora.
"That was a strange question to be put by his darling Jane."
-¡Vaya una pregunta que me haces, Jane!
"Indeed!
-Nada de eso.
I considered it a very natural and necessary one: he had talked of his future wife dying with him.
Es muy natural.
¿No ha hablado de que su futura esposa le acompañe si muere?
What did he mean by such a pagan idea? _I_ had no intention of dying with him--he might depend on that."
No tengo propósito alguno de llevar a la práctica esa idea pagana de morir con usted.
"Oh, all he longed, all he prayed for, was that I might live with him!
Death was not for such as I."
-Desde luego: me basta con que me acompañes en la vida.
"Indeed it was: I had as good a right to die when my time came as he had: but I should bide that time, and not be hurried away in a suttee."
La muerte no se ha hecho para un ser como tú. -Sí se ha hecho, pero cuando llegue mi hora y no antes.
"Would I forgive him for the selfish idea, and prove my pardon by a reconciling kiss?"
-Bien: ¿me perdonas ese egoísta pensamiento y me demuestras tu perdón besándome?
"No: I would rather be excused."
-Prefiero no hacerlo.
Here I heard myself apostrophised as a "hard little thing;" and it was added, "any other woman would have been melted to marrow at hearing such stanzas crooned in her praise."
Me apostrofó, acusándome de ser más dura que una piedra y afirmó que «cualquier otra mujer se hubiera emocionado profundamente escuchando aquellos versos entonados en alabanza suya.»

I assured him I was naturally hard--very flinty, and that he would often find me so; and that, moreover, I was determined to show him divers rugged points in my character before the ensuing four weeks elapsed: he should know fully what sort of a bargain he had made, while there was yet time to rescind it.

Le aseguré que mi carácter era duro como el pedernal y que estaba dispuesta a mostrarle todos los aspectos malos de mi modo de ser durante las próximas cuatro semanas, a fin de que supiese qué clase de compromiso iba a contraer mientras estuviese aún a tiempo de rescindirlo.
"Would I be quiet and talk rationally?"
-¿Quieres callarte o hablar con sentido común?
"I would be quiet if he liked, and as to talking rationally, I flattered myself I was doing that now."
-Me callaré, si quiere, pero en cuanto a hablar con sentido común, perdone que le diga que eso es lo que estaba haciendo ahora.
He fretted, pished, and pshawed.
Se irritó, bramó y pateó, pero yo me mantuve inflexible.
"Very good," I thought; "you may fume and fidget as you please: but this is the best plan to pursue with you, I am certain.
«Haz lo que te parezca -pensaba-, porque estoy segura de que este sistema es el mejor que puedo seguir contigo.

I like you more than I can say; but I'll not sink into a bathos of sentiment: and with this needle of repartee I'll keep you from the edge of the gulf too; and, moreover, maintain by its pungent aid that distance between you and myself most conducive to our real mutual advantage."
Te quiero más de lo que te imaginas, pero no deseo caer en las complicaciones que produce no refrenar el sentimiento.
Cuanto mayor distancia exista ahora entre tú y yo, mejor será después para ambos.»

From less to more, I worked him up to considerable irritation; then, after he had retired, in dudgeon, quite to the other end of the room, I got up, and saying, "I wish you good-night, sir," in my natural and wonted respectful manner, I slipped out by the side-door and got away.
Cada vez más irritado, Rochester se retiró á un rincón del cuarto.
Yo entonces me levanté tranquilamente, dije con la expresión respetuosa habitual en mí: «Buenas noches, señor», y salí.
The system thus entered on, I pursued during the whole season of probation; and with the best success.
Perseveré durante todo el tiempo que faltaba en la actitud adoptada, con excelentes resultados.

He was kept, to be sure, rather cross and crusty; but on the whole I could see he was excellently entertained, and that a lamb-like submission and turtle-dove sensibility, while fostering his despotism more, would have pleased his judgment, satisfied his common-sense, and even suited his taste less.
Porque, si bien mi sistema contrariaba el despotismo y los arranques de Rochester, por otro lado concordaba con su razón, su sentido común y, en el fondo, creo que hasta con sus gustos.
In other people's presence I was, as formerly, deferential and quiet; any other line of conduct being uncalled for: it was only in the evening conferences I thus thwarted and afflicted him.
En presencia de extraños yo me manifestaba, como antes, deferente e impasible, y sólo en nuestras veladas a solas me permitía contrariarle y zaherirle.

He continued to send for me punctually the moment the clock struck seven; though when I appeared before him now, he had no such honeyed terms as "love" and "darling" on his lips: the best words at my service were "provoking puppet," "malicious elf," "sprite," "changeling," &c.
Cada tarde, a las siete en punto, enviaba a por mí y, cuando yo me presentaba, las dulces frases de «amor mío», «querida» y otras análogas estaban ausentes de sus labios.
Las mejores que me dedicaba eran «muñeca deslenguada», «espíritu maligno», «bruja», «veleta», etc.
For caresses, too, I now got grimaces; for a pressure of the hand, a pinch on the arm; for a kiss on the cheek, a severe tweak of the ear.
En vez de caricias, me hacía muecas; en vez de apretarme la mano, me daba pellizcos; en vez de besarme, me aplicaba severos tirones de orejas.
It was all right: at present I decidedly preferred these fierce favours to anything more tender.
Pero yo prefería estas muestras de afecto a otras más íntimas.
Mrs. Fairfax, I saw, approved me: her anxiety on my account vanished; therefore I was certain I did well.
Noté que Mrs.
Fairfax aprobaba mi actitud y que sus temores se desvanecían.
Meantime, Mr. Rochester affirmed I was wearing him to skin and bone, and threatened awful vengeance for my present conduct at some period fast coming.
Rochester afirmaba que yo le estaba quemando la sangre y me amenazaba con fieras venganzas en lo futuro.
I laughed in my sleeve at his menaces.
Pero me reía de sus amenazas, creía obrar con acierto y pensaba que después sabría obrar lo mismo, ya que si el procedimiento de ahora no resultaba adecuado después, otro se encontraría.
"I can keep you in reasonable check now," I reflected; "and I don't doubt to be able to do it hereafter: if one expedient loses its virtue, another must be devised."
Mi tarea, sin embargo, no era fácil.
Muchas veces hubiese preferido complacer a Rochester en vez de atormentarle.
Yet after all my task was not an easy one; often I would rather have pleased than teased him.
Mi futuro esposo se había convertido para mí en la única cosa importante de este mundo, y creo que aun del otro.
My future husband was becoming to me my whole world; and more than the world: almost my hope of heaven.
He stood between me and every thought of religion, as an eclipse intervenes between man and the broad sun.
Él se había interpuesto entre mis sentimientos religiosos y yo como un eclipse se interpone entre el Sol y la Tierra.
I could not, in those days, see God for His creature: of whom I had made an idol.
En aquella época, el hombre de quien había hecho un ídolo me impedía ver otra cosa que no fuera él.
CHAPTER XXV
XXV
The month of courtship had wasted: its very last hours were being numbered.
Los últimos momentos del mes estipulado estaban a punto de expirar.
Todos los preparativos para el día de la boda se hallaban completos, al menos por mi parte.

There was no putting off the day that advanced--the bridal day; and all preparations for its arrival were complete. _I_, at least, had nothing more to do: there were my trunks, packed, locked, corded, ranged in a row along the wall of my little chamber; to-morrow, at this time, they would be far on their road to London: and so should I (D.V.),--or rather, not I, but one Jane Rochester, a person whom as yet I knew not.
Mis equipajes estaban listos, atados, dispuestos para ser enviados a Londres al siguiente día.
También entonces debía salir yo, o mejor dicho, Jane Rochester, una persona a quien no conocía aún.
The cards of address alone remained to nail on: they lay, four little squares, in the drawer.
Mr. Rochester had himself written the direction, "Mrs. Rochester, --- Hotel, London," on each: I could not persuade myself to affix them, or to have them affixed.
El propio Edward había escrito las etiquetas de mis equipajes.
«Mrs.
Rochester, Hotel...
Londres.»
No me resolvía a pegarlas aún.
Mrs. Rochester!
¡Mrs.
Rochester!

She did not exist: she would not be born till to-morrow, some time after eight o'clock a.m.; and I would wait to be assured she had come into the world alive before I assigned to her all that property.
Semejante ser no comenzaría a existir hasta la mañana siguiente, poco después de las ocho, y me parecía mejor esperar a que naciese para asignarle con entera propiedad aquellos objetos.

It was enough that in yonder closet, opposite my dressing-table, garments said to be hers had already displaced my black stuff Lowood frock and straw bonnet: for not to me appertained that suit of wedding raiment; the pearl-coloured robe, the vapoury veil pendent from the usurped portmanteau.

Entretanto, no podía concebir que me perteneciesen las prendas que sustituirían mi negro vestido y mi sombrero lowoodianos: el traje de boda, el vestido color perla, el vaporoso velo que se hallaban colocados en el guardarropa que había en mi dormitorio.
I shut the closet to conceal the strange, wraith-like apparel it contained; which, at this evening hour--nine o'clock--gave out certainly a most ghostly shimmer through the shadow of my apartment.

«Os dejo solos», murmuré al cerrar el guardarropa para evitar la extraña apariencia, casi fantasmal, que a aquella hora, nueve de la noche, ofrecían los ropajes blancos entre las sombras de la habitación.
"I will leave you by yourself, white dream," I said.
"I am feverish: I hear the wind blowing: I will go out of doors and feel it."
Tenía fiebre; fuera soplaba el viento y quería aspirar el aire puro.

It was not only the hurry of preparation that made me feverish; not only the anticipation of the great change--the new life which was to commence to-morrow: both these circumstances had their share, doubtless, in producing that restless, excited mood which hurried me forth at this late hour into the darkening grounds: but a third cause influenced my mind more than they.
No eran sólo el ajetreo de los preparativos ni la espera del gran cambio que iba a producirse en mi vida lo que me hacía sentirme febril.
I had at heart a strange and anxious thought.
Something had happened which I could not comprehend; no one knew of or had seen the event but myself: it had taken place the preceding night.
Existía para ello una tercera causa que nadie sino yo conocía, y que había sucedido la noche antes.

Mr. Rochester that night was absent from home; nor was he yet returned: business had called him to a small estate of two or three farms he possessed thirty miles off--business it was requisite he should settle in person, previous to his meditated departure from England.
Mr.
Rochester se hallaba en unas propiedades situadas a una distancia de treinta millas, donde fue a arreglar ciertos asuntos antes de su viaje.
I waited now his return; eager to disburthen my mind, and to seek of him the solution of the enigma that perplexed me.
