Y yo, al presente, esperaba su regreso, confiando encontrar en él la solución del enigma que me inquietaba.
Stay till he comes, reader; and, when I disclose my secret to him, you shall share the confidence.
I sought the orchard, driven to its shelter by the wind, which all day had blown strong and full from the south, without, however, bringing a speck of rain.
Bajé al huerto.
Todo el día había soplado viento del Sur, trayendo, de vez en cuando, algunos ramalazos de lluvia.

Instead of subsiding as night drew on, it seemed to augment its rush and deepen its roar: the trees blew steadfastly one way, never writhing round, and scarcely tossing back their boughs once in an hour; so continuous was the strain bending their branchy heads northward--the clouds drifted from pole to pole, fast following, mass on mass: no glimpse of blue sky had been visible that July day.
Las nubes cubrían el cielo en masas compactas, sin que un solo trocito de cielo azul hubiese brillado durante todo aquel día de julio.
It was not without a certain wild pleasure I ran before the wind, delivering my trouble of mind to the measureless air-torrent thundering through space.
Experimenté cierto violento placer sintiendo el azote del aire que refrescaba mi turbada mente.
Descending the laurel walk, I faced the wreck of the chestnut-tree; it stood up black and riven: the trunk, split down the centre, gasped ghastly.
Por el camino bordeado de laureles, llegué hasta el gran castaño medio destrozado por el rayo.

The cloven halves were not broken from each other, for the firm base and strong roots kept them unsundered below; though community of vitality was destroyed--the sap could flow no more: their great boughs on each side were dead, and next winter's tempests would be sure to fell one or both to earth: as yet, however, they might be said to form one tree--a ruin, but an entire ruin.
"You did right to hold fast to each other," I said: as if the monster- splinters were living things, and could hear me.

"I think, scathed as you look, and charred and scorched, there must be a little sense of life in you yet, rising out of that adhesion at the faithful, honest roots: you will never have green leaves more--never more see birds making nests and singing idyls in your boughs; the time of pleasure and love is over with you: but you are not desolate: each of you has a comrade to sympathise with him in his decay."
En aquel momento, una luna color de sangre apareció momentáneamente entre las nubes para volver a ocultarse tras ellas después.

As I looked up at them, the moon appeared momentarily in that part of the sky which filled their fissure; her disk was blood-red and half overcast; she seemed to throw on me one bewildered, dreary glance, and buried herself again instantly in the deep drift of cloud.
The wind fell, for a second, round Thornfield; but far away over wood and water, poured a wild, melancholy wail: it was sad to listen to, and I ran off again.
Por un segundo, el viento pareció quedar inmóvil en torno a Thornfield.
Luego volvió a soplar con fuerza.
Anduve de un lado a otro del huerto.

Here and there I strayed through the orchard, gathered up the apples with which the grass round the tree roots was thickly strewn; then I employed myself in dividing the ripe from the unripe; I carried them into the house and put them away in the store-room.
La hierba, en torno a los manzanos, estaba cubierta de manzanas caídas.
Comencé a recogerlas, separando las verdes de las maduras.

Then I repaired to the library to ascertain whether the fire was lit, for, though summer, I knew on such a gloomy evening Mr. Rochester would like to see a cheerful hearth when he came in: yes, the fire had been kindled some time, and burnt well.
Llevé éstas a la casa y las coloqué en la despensa, de donde fui a la biblioteca para asegurarme de que el fuego estaba encendido.
Aunque era verano, sabía que, dado lo sombrío del tiempo, a Rochester le agradaría encontrar una buena lumbre.
I placed his arm-chair by the chimney-corner: I wheeled the table near it: I let down the curtain, and had the candles brought in ready for lighting.
Acerqué su sillón a la chimenea y la mesa al sillón y coloqué en ella las bujías.

More restless than ever, when I had completed these arrangements I could not sit still, nor even remain in the house: a little time-piece in the room and the old clock in the hall simultaneously struck ten.
Una vez hechos aquellos preparativos, no sabía si salir o quedarme en casa, porque me sentía muy inquieta.
Un pequeño reloj que había en el aposento y el viejo reloj del vestíbulo dieron simultáneamente las diez.
"How late it grows!"
«¡Qué tarde es! -pensé-.
I said.
"I will run down to the gates: it is moonlight at intervals; I can see a good way on the road.
Voy a acercarme hasta las verjas.
La luna sale a ratos y puedo otear el camino.
He may be coming now, and to meet him will save some minutes of suspense."
Si me reúno con Edward en cuanto lo vea, evitaré algunos minutos de espera.»
El viento agitaba con violencia los altos árboles que sombreaban la entrada de la propiedad.

The wind roared high in the great trees which embowered the gates; but the road as far as I could see, to the right hand and the left, was all still and solitary: save for the shadows of clouds crossing it at intervals as the moon looked out, it was but a long pale line, unvaried by one moving speck.
El camino, a izquierda y derecha, en cuanto alcanzaba la vista, estaba solitario.
Sólo se veían sobre él, a intervalos, las pálidas sombras de las nubes cuando, por unos segundos, brillaba la luna.
A puerile tear dimmed my eye while I looked--a tear of disappointment and impatience; ashamed of it, I wiped it away.
Una lágrima pueril, lágrima de impaciencia y disgusto, acudió a mis ojos.
I lingered; the moon shut herself wholly within her chamber, and drew close her curtain of dense cloud: the night grew dark; rain came driving fast on the gale.
La luna parecía haberse encerrado herméticamente en su celeste estancia, porque no había vuelto a aparecer.
La noche se hacía cada vez más oscura y la lluvia iba en aumento.
"I wish he would come!
I wish he would come!"
I exclaimed, seized with hypochondriac foreboding.
«¡Quiero que venga, quiero que venga!», deseé con un ansia casi histérica.
I had expected his arrival before tea; now it was dark: what could keep him?
Le esperaba antes del té y era ya noche cerrada.
Had an accident happened?
¿Le había sucedido algún accidente?
The event of last night again recurred to me.
Recordé el suceso de la noche anterior y lo interpreté como un presagio de desventura.
I interpreted it as a warning of disaster.
I feared my hopes were too bright to be realised; and I had enjoyed so much bliss lately that I imagined my fortune had passed its meridian, and must now decline.

Presentía que mis esperanzas eran demasiado hermosas para que se realizasen y hasta pensé que había sido tan dichosa últimamente que mi fortuna, después de llegar a su cenit, debía comenzar indefectiblemente a declinar.
"Well, I cannot return to the house," I thought; "I cannot sit by the fireside, while he is abroad in inclement weather: better tire my limbs than strain my heart; I will go forward and meet him."
«No puedo volver a casa -reflexioné- y estar al lado del fuego, mientras él soporta fuera la inclemencia de la noche.
Prefiero tener los miembros fatigados antes que el corazón oprimido.
Avanzaré por el camino hasta que encuentre a Edward.»
Y avancé.
I set out; I walked fast, but not far: ere I had measured a quarter of a mile, I heard the tramp of hoofs; a horseman came on, full gallop; a dog ran by his side.
No había recorrido aún un cuarto de milla cuando sentí ruido de cascos.
Un caballo, seguido por un perro, llegaba a todo galope.
Away with evil presentiment!
¡Enhoramala todos los presentimientos!
It was he: here he was, mounted on Mesrour, followed by Pilot.
Allí estaba él, montado en Mesrour y acompañado por Piloto.
He saw me; for the moon had opened a blue field in the sky, and rode in it watery bright: he took his hat off, and waved it round his head.
Me vio a la luz de la luna que había salido otra vez, se quitó el sombrero y lo agitó en torno a su cabeza.
I now ran to meet him.
Corrí a reunirme con él.
"There!" he exclaimed, as he stretched out his hand and bent from the saddle: "You can't do without me, that is evident.
-¡Está visto que no puedes vivir sin mí! -exclamó-.
Step on my boot-toe; give me both hands: mount!"
Pon el pie sobre mi bota, dame las manos y ¡arriba!
I obeyed: joy made me agile: I sprang up before him.
Obedecí.
La alegría me prestaba agilidad.
A hearty kissing I got for a welcome, and some boastful triumph, which I swallowed as well as I could.
Monté en la delantera del arzón.
Un ardiente beso fue el saludo que cambiamos.
He checked himself in his exultation to demand, "But is there anything the matter, Janet, that you come to meet me at such an hour?
Is there anything wrong?"
Él preguntó en seguida: -¿Qué pasa, Jane, para que hayas venido a buscarme a estas horas?
"No, but I thought you would never come.
-Creí que no llegaba usted nunca.
I could not bear to wait in the house for you, especially with this rain and wind."
Me era insoportable esperarle en casa con esta lluvia y este huracán. -Estás mojada como una sirena.
"Rain and wind, indeed!
Cúbrete con mi abrigo.
Yes, you are dripping like a mermaid; pull my cloak round you: but I think you are feverish, Jane: both your cheek and hand are burning hot.
Pero creo que tienes fiebre, Jane.
Te arden las manos y las mejillas.
I ask again, is there anything the matter?"
Si ha pasado algo, dímelo. -Ahora no me pasa nada.
"Nothing now; I am neither afraid nor unhappy."
No tengo temor ni me siento infeliz.
"Then you have been both?"
-Entonces, ¿lo has sentido antes?
"Rather: but I'll tell you all about it by-and-bye, sir; and I daresay you will only laugh at me for my pains."
-Luego le explicaré.
Seguramente se reirá de mí...
"I'll laugh at you heartily when to-morrow is past; till then I dare not: my prize is not certain.
-Mañana reiré todo lo que quieras.
Antes no: no tengo aún segura mi presa...
This is you, who have been as slippery as an eel this last month, and as thorny as a briar-rose?
Me refiero a ti, que durante este mes último has sido para mí tan escurridiza como una anguila y más espinosa que una rosa silvestre.
I could not lay a finger anywhere but I was pricked; and now I seem to have gathered up a stray lamb in my arms.
No podía tocarte ni con un dedo sin que me pincharas.
¡Y ahora en cambio te tengo en mis brazos como una mansa cordera!
You wandered out of the fold to seek your shepherd, did you, Jane?"
¿Cómo es que has salido del redil para venir a buscar a tu pastor, Jane?
"I wanted you: but don't boast.
-Deseaba verle.
Pero no cante victoria...
Here we are at Thornfield: now let me get down."
Ya estamos en Thornfield.
Ayúdeme a apearme.
He landed me on the pavement.
Me puso en tierra.

As John took his horse, and he followed me into the hall, he told me to make haste and put something dry on, and then return to him in the library; and he stopped me, as I made for the staircase, to extort a promise that I would not be long: nor was I long; in five minutes I rejoined him.
John se llevó el caballo y él me siguió a la casa.
Me indicó que fuese a cambiarme de ropa, lo que hice a toda prisa.
I found him at supper.
Cinco minutos después, volvía y le hallaba cenando.
"Take a seat and bear me company, Jane: please God, it is the last meal but one you will eat at Thornfield Hall for a long time."
-Siéntate y come conmigo, Jane.
Es la última vez que comerás en Thornfield durante mucho tiempo.
I sat down near him, but told him I could not eat.
Me senté junto a él, pero no comí.
"Is it because you have the prospect of a journey before you, Jane?
Is it the thoughts of going to London that takes away your appetite?"
-¿Acaso el pensamiento del largo viaje que hemos de hacer a Londres te quita el apetito?
"I cannot see my prospects clearly to-night, sir; and I hardly know what thoughts I have in my head.
-Hoy veo todas las cosas confusas y casi no sé ni lo que tengo en el cerebro.
Everything in life seems unreal."
Todo lo que me rodea me parece fantástico.
-Menos yo.
"Except me: I am substantial enough--touch me."
Yo soy absolutamente real.
Tócame y lo verás.
"You, sir, are the most phantom-like of all: you are a mere dream."
-Usted me parece lo más fantástico de todo, casi una cosa soñada...
He held out his hand, laughing.
"Is that a dream?" said he, placing it close to my eyes.
He had a rounded, muscular, and vigorous hand, as well as a long, strong arm.
Alargó su brazo musculoso, recio, lo puso ante mis ojos y dijo, riendo:
"Yes; though I touch it, it is a dream," said I, as I put it down from before my face.
-¿Es esto un sueño acaso? -Aunque sea tangible, es un sueño -dije-.
"Sir, have you finished supper?"
¿Ha terminado usted?
"Yes, Jane."
-Sí, Jane.
I rang the bell and ordered away the tray.
Toqué la campanilla y mandé quitar el servicio.
When we were again alone, I stirred the fire, and then took a low seat at my master's knee.
Cuando quedamos solos, aticé el fuego y luego me senté ante Rochester en un asiento bajo.
"It is near midnight," I said.
-Es casi medianoche -dije.
"Yes: but remember, Jane, you promised to wake with me the night before my wedding."
-Sí, Jane, pero recuerda que me prometiste velar conmigo la noche antes de mi boda.
"I did; and I will keep my promise, for an hour or two at least: I have no wish to go to bed."
-Y lo cumpliré, al menos por una hora o dos.
No tengo ganas de acostarme.
"Are all your arrangements complete?"
-¿Tienes todas las cosas arregladas?
"All, sir."
-Todas.
"And on my part likewise," he returned, "I have settled everything; and we shall leave Thornfield to-morrow, within half-an-hour after our return from church."
-Por mi parte también -repuso él- y nos iremos de Thornfield mañana mismo, media hora después de volver de la iglesia.
"Very well, sir."
-Bueno...
"With what an extraordinary smile you uttered that word--'very well,' Jane!
-¡De qué modo tan raro lo has dicho!
What a bright spot of colour you have on each cheek! and how strangely your eyes glitter!
¡Cómo brillan tus mejillas y tus ojos!
Are you well?"
¿Te encuentras bien, Jane?
"I believe I am."
-Creo que sí.
"Believe!
-¡Crees!
What is the matter?
Vamos, dime qué te pasa.
Tell me what you feel."
-No sabría explicarme.
"I could not, sir: no words could tell you what I feel.
Quisiera que nunca se acabaran estos momentos.
I wish this present hour would never end: who knows with what fate the next may come charged?"
¿Quién sabe lo que nos reserva el destino?
"This is hypochondria, Jane.
-Todo eso son nervios, Jane.
You have been over-excited, or over-fatigued."
Estás sobreexcitada o acaso muy fatigada.
"Do you, sir, feel calm and happy?"
-¿Y usted se siente tranquilo y feliz?
"Calm?--no: but happy--to the heart's core."
-Feliz, sí; tranquilo, no.
I looked up at him to read the signs of bliss in his face: it was ardent and flushed.
Le miré, tratando de descubrir en su rostro la expresión de su dicha.
Estaba arrebatado. -Vamos, confía en mí, Jane -continuó-.
"Give me your confidence, Jane," he said: "relieve your mind of any weight that oppresses it, by imparting it to me.
Alivia tu pecho confiándome el peso que lo oprime.
¿Qué temes?
What do you fear?--that I shall not prove a good husband?"
¿Sospechas que no voy a ser un buen esposo?
"It is the idea farthest from my thoughts."
-Nada más lejos de mis pensamientos.
"Are you apprehensive of the new sphere you are about to enter?--of the new life into which you are passing?"
-¿Te asustan los nuevos ambientes en que vas a vivir, la nueva existencia que vas a llevar?
"No."
-No.
"You puzzle me, Jane: your look and tone of sorrowful audacity perplex and pain me.
-Me asombras, Jane.
Tu aspecto y tu acento me dejan perplejo y me entristecen.
I want an explanation."
Explícate.
"Then, sir, listen.
-Entonces, escuche.
You were from home last night?"
Usted no estuvo en casa la noche de ayer...
"I was: I know that; and you hinted a while ago at something which had happened in my absence:--nothing, probably, of consequence; but, in short, it has disturbed you.
Let me hear it.
-Ya, ya sé que no estuve...
Y adivino que ha sucedido algo en mi ausencia, y que me lo ocultas.
Mrs. Fairfax has said something, perhaps? or you have overheard the servants talk?--your sensitive self-respect has been wounded?"
Algo que te ha disgustado, aunque seguramente no tendrá importancia.
¿Te ha dicho algo Mrs.
Fairfax?
¿Te ha ofendido alguno de los criados?
"No, sir."
-No -repuse.
It struck twelve--I waited till the time-piece had concluded its silver chime, and the clock its hoarse, vibrating stroke, and then I proceeded.
Era medianoche.
Esperé a que el argentino timbre del relojito del aposento y la pesada campana del gran reloj del vestíbulo hubiesen terminado de dar la hora, y continué-:

"All day yesterday I was very busy, and very happy in my ceaseless bustle; for I am not, as you seem to think, troubled by any haunting fears about the new sphere, et cetera: I think it a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, because I love you.
Todo el día de ayer estuve muy ocupada arreglando mis cosas y sintiéndome feliz con esa ocupación, porque no estoy, como usted se figura, asustada de vivir en un nuevo ambiente, etcétera.
Lo que pienso es en lo magnífico que ha de serme vivir con usted, porque le amo.
No, sir, don't caress me now--let me talk undisturbed.

Yesterday I trusted well in Providence, and believed that events were working together for your good and mine: it was a fine day, if you recollect--the calmness of the air and sky forbade apprehensions respecting your safety or comfort on your journey.
Ayer yo creía en la Providencia y esperaba que todo se desenlazaría en bien de usted y mío.
Hacía un día excelente y por ello no sentía inquietud alguna respecto a su viaje.
I walked a little while on the pavement after tea, thinking of you; and I beheld you in imagination so near me, I scarcely missed your actual presence.
Después de tomar el té, salí a pasear un poco ante la casa, y con tal intensidad pensaba en usted, que casi me parecía tenerle presente.

I thought of the life that lay before me--_your_ life, sir--an existence more expansive and stirring than my own: as much more so as the depths of the sea to which the brook runs are than the shallows of its own strait channel.
I wondered why moralists call this world a dreary wilderness: for me it blossomed like a rose.
Me asombraba de que los moralistas llamen a este mundo un valle de lágrimas, porque a mí me parecía un jardín de rosas.
Al oscurecer, el aire refrescó y el cielo se cubrió de nubes.
Entré.

Just at sunset, the air turned cold and the sky cloudy: I went in, Sophie called me upstairs to look at my wedding-dress, which they had just brought; and under it in the box I found your present--the veil which, in your princely extravagance, you sent for from London: resolved, I suppose, since I would not have jewels, to cheat me into accepting something as costly.
Sophie me llamó para que examinara mi vestido de boda, que acababa de traer en aquel momento.

Encontré el velo que usted me regala y que, en su principesca extravagancia, ha hecho que me traigan de Londres, sin duda con objeto de chasquearme en mi propósito de no aceptar objetos costosos, como hice cuando me negué a aceptar las joyas.
I smiled as I unfolded it, and devised how I would tease you about your aristocratic tastes, and your efforts to masque your plebeian bride in the attributes of a peeress.
Sonreí al apreciar el empeño de usted en enmascarar a su humilde prometida con el disfraz de una gran señora.

I thought how I would carry down to you the square of unembroidered blond I had myself prepared as a covering for my low-born head, and ask if that was not good enough for a woman who could bring her husband neither fortune, beauty, nor connections.

Estaba meditando sobre el modo de presentarle el retazo de blonda sin bordar que había preparado para cubrir mi humilde cabeza el día de la boda, y proyectaba decirle que era bastante para una mujer que no le aporta ni fortuna, ni belleza, ni una alianza ilustre.

I saw plainly how you would look; and heard your impetuous republican answers, and your haughty disavowal of any necessity on your part to augment your wealth, or elevate your standing, by marrying either a purse or a coronet."
Imaginaba mentalmente las democráticas contestaciones de usted, y su perversa insistencia en afirmar que no necesitaba ni aumento de riqueza ni unirse a nadie que le dé el brillo de sus blasones...
"How well you read me, you witch!" interposed Mr. Rochester: "but what did you find in the veil besides its embroidery?
-¡Cómo adivinas mis pensamientos, brujilla! -interrumpió Rochester-.
Pero ¿qué has hallado en ese velo, aparte de sus bordados?
Did you find poison, or a dagger, that you look so mournful now?"
¿Un puñal, un veneno?
Porque, a juzgar por tu modo de...
"No, no, sir; besides the delicacy and richness of the fabric, I found nothing save Fairfax Rochester's pride; and that did not scare me, because I am used to the sight of the demon.
-No, no, no halle más que su riqueza y su delicada manufactura.
But, sir, as it grew dark, the wind rose: it blew yesterday evening, not as it blows now--wild and high--but 'with a sullen, moaning sound' far more eerie.
I wished you were at home.
Pero entretanto oscurecía, arreciaba el viento y yo hubiera deseado que usted estuviese en casa.
I came into this room, and the sight of the empty chair and fireless hearth chilled me.
Vine a esta habitación y me impresionó el espectáculo de este sillón vacío y esta chimenea apagada.
Me acosté en seguida.
For some time after I went to bed, I could not sleep--a sense of anxious excitement distressed me.
No podía dormir.
Me sentía desasosegada y nerviosa.

The gale still rising, seemed to my ear to muffle a mournful under-sound; whether in the house or abroad I could not at first tell, but it recurred, doubtful yet doleful at every lull; at last I made out it must be some dog howling at a distance.
Creí oír de pronto, no sabía si dentro o fuera de la casa, un extraño sonido, algo triste y lúgubre, al parecer lejano.
I was glad when it ceased.
Cesó, al fin, con mucha satisfacción mía.
On sleeping, I continued in dreams the idea of a dark and gusty night.
I continued also the wish to be with you, and experienced a strange, regretful consciousness of some barrier dividing us.
Al dormirme soñé que era de noche, una noche oscura, y que yo deseaba estar con usted, pero que entre ambos surgía una barrera que, no sé cómo, nos separaba.

During all my first sleep, I was following the windings of an unknown road; total obscurity environed me; rain pelted me; I was burdened with the charge of a little child: a very small creature, too young and feeble to walk, and which shivered in my cold arms, and wailed piteously in my ear.
Durante este primer sueño yo seguía un camino desconocido rodeada de una oscuridad absoluta.
La lluvia me calaba y yo iba cargada con un niñito, demasiado pequeño para andar solo y cuyo llanto sonaba de un modo lastimero en mis oídos.

I thought, sir, that you were on the road a long way before me; and I strained every nerve to overtake you, and made effort on effort to utter your name and entreat you to stop--but my movements were fettered, and my voice still died away inarticulate; while you, I felt, withdrew farther and farther every moment."
Usted seguía aquel camino, muy lejos de mí, y yo me esforzaba en alcanzarle y en hacerle pararse a esperar tratando de pronunciar su nombre tan alto como podía.
Pero mis movimientos y mi voz estaban como paralizados y experimentaba la impresión de que usted se alejaba más cada vez.
"And these dreams weigh on your spirits now, Jane, when I am close to you?
-¿De modo que era eso lo que tenías cuando te he encontrado?
¿Un mero sueño?
Little nervous subject!
¡Qué nerviosilla eres!
Forget visionary woe, and think only of real happiness!
Déjate de visiones y piensa en la felicidad real que nos aguarda.
You say you love me, Janet: yes--I will not forget that; and you cannot deny it. _Those_ words did not die inarticulate on your lips.
Vamos; dime que me quieres, Jane.
I heard them clear and soft: a thought too solemn perhaps, but sweet as music--
Esas palabras me suenan tan dulces como la música...
'I think it is a glorious thing to have the hope of living with you, Edward, because I love you.'
Do you love me, Jane?--repeat it."
¿Me amas, Jane?
"I do, sir--I do, with my whole heart."
-Sí; con todo mi corazón.
"Well," he said, after some minutes' silence, "it is strange; but that sentence has penetrated my breast painfully.
-Bien -dijo él, tras unos minutos de silencio-.
Es raro, pero tus palabras me han producido una sensación casi dolorosa.
Why?
¿Por qué será?

I think because you said it with such an earnest, religious energy, and because your upward gaze at me now is the very sublime of faith, truth, and devotion: it is too much as if some spirit were near me.
Acaso por la afectuosa energía con que las has pronunciado, por la mirada de fe, de lealtad y de confianza que las acompañaba.
Me ha parecido que había un espíritu junto a mí...

Look wicked, Jane: as you know well how to look: coin one of your wild, shy, provoking smiles; tell me you hate me--tease me, vex me; do anything but move me: I would rather be incensed than saddened."
Mientras me mires como me miras ahora, Jane, mientras sonrías como sabes sonreírme, aunque me digas que me odias, aunque me injuries y me atormentes, no podré renegar de ti, te amaré y...
"I will tease you and vex you to your heart's content, when I have finished my tale: but hear me to the end."
-Temo disgustarle al final de mi relato.
Escúcheme. -Creí que ya me lo habías dicho todo.
"I thought, Jane, you had told me all.
I thought I had found the source of your melancholy in a dream."
Pensaba que la causa de tu tristeza estaba en ese sueño.
I shook my head.
Moví la cabeza.
"What! is there more?
-¿Cómo?
¿Hay algo más?
But I will not believe it to be anything important.
I warn you of incredulity beforehand.
Espero que no sea nada importante.
Go on."
Sigue.
The disquietude of his air, the somewhat apprehensive impatience of his manner, surprised me: but I proceeded.
La inquietud de su aspecto, cierta impaciencia de sus ademanes, me extrañaron.
Continué:
"I dreamt another dream, sir: that Thornfield Hall was a dreary ruin, the retreat of bats and owls.
-Aún soñé otra cosa: que Thornfield estaba en ruinas y era guarida de búhos y murciélagos.
I thought that of all the stately front nothing remained but a shell-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking.
De toda la fachada sólo quedaba en pie un frágil lienzo de pared.
I wandered, on a moonlight night, through the grass- grown enclosure within: here I stumbled over a marble hearth, and there over a fallen fragment of cornice.
Yo erraba, a la luz de la luna, entre las ruinas en las que crecía la hierba, tropezando, ora con un trozo de mármol, ora con un caído fragmento de cornisa.
Wrapped up in a shawl, I still carried the unknown little child: I might not lay it down anywhere, however tired were my arms--however much its weight impeded my progress, I must retain it.
Seguía llevando al niñito desconocido, envuelto en un chal.
Me era imposible ponerle en el suelo, y por mucho que su peso me fatigase, había de continuar llevándole.
I heard the gallop of a horse at a distance on the road; I was sure it was you; and you were departing for many years and for a distant country.
A lo lejos, en el camino, oía las pisadas de un caballo y estaba segura de que era el de usted, que partía para un lejano país, donde permanecería muchos años.

I climbed the thin wall with frantic perilous haste, eager to catch one glimpse of you from the top: the stones rolled from under my feet, the ivy branches I grasped gave way, the child clung round my neck in terror, and almost strangled me; at last I gained the summit.
Traté de escalar el muro a toda prisa, para poder verle desde arriba.
Las piedras se desmoronaban bajo mis pies, la hiedra a que trataba de asirme cedía; el niño, abrazado a mi cuello y aterrorizado, casi me estrangulaba.
I saw you like a speck on a white track, lessening every moment.
Pero al fin llegué.
Usted era ya un punto en la distancia y se alejaba por momentos.
The blast blew so strong I could not stand.
Soplaba un viento tan fuerte que no me podía sostener.

I sat down on the narrow ledge; I hushed the scared infant in my lap: you turned an angle of the road: I bent forward to take a last look; the wall crumbled; I was shaken; the child rolled from my knee, I lost my balance, fell, and woke."
Me senté en el estrecho borde del muro, colocando al niño sobre mi regazo.
Usted dobló una curva del camino y, cuando yo le dirigía una última mirada, la pared se derrumbó, el niño cayó de mis rodillas, perdí el equilibrio y me desperté.
"Now, Jane, that is all."
-¿Eso es todo, Jane?
"All the preface, sir; the tale is yet to come.
-Todo el prólogo.
Ahora falta el relato.
On waking, a gleam dazzled my eyes; I thought--Oh, it is daylight!
Al despertarme, una luz hirió mis ojos.
Pensé que ya era de día.
But I was mistaken; it was only candlelight.
Pero no era más que el resplandor de una vela.
Supuse que Sophie estaba en la alcoba.
Sophie, I supposed, had come in.
There was a light in the dressing-table, and the door of the closet, where, before going to bed, I had hung my wedding-dress and veil, stood open; I heard a rustling there.
Alguien había dejado una bujía en la mesa, y el cuartito guardarropa, donde yo colocara mi velo y mi vestido de boda, se hallaba abierto.
I asked, 'Sophie, what are you doing?'
«¿Qué hace usted, Sophie?», pregunté.
No one answered; but a form emerged from the closet; it took the light, held it aloft, and surveyed the garments pendent from the portmanteau.
'Sophie!
Nadie contestó, pero una figura surgió del ropero, cogió la vela y empezó a examinar los vestidos.
Sophie!'
I again cried: and still it was silent.
«¡Sophie!», volví a exclamar.
I had risen up in bed, I bent forward: first surprise, then bewilderment, came over me; and then my blood crept cold through my veins.
La figura seguía en silencio.
Me incorporé en la cama, me incliné hacia delante y sentí que se me helaba la sangre en las venas.
Mr. Rochester, this was not Sophie, it was not Leah, it was not Mrs. Fairfax: it was not--no, I was sure of it, and am still--it was not even that strange woman, Grace Poole."
Porque aquella mujer no era ninguna de las que en esta casa conozco; no era Sophie, ni Leah, ni Mrs.
Fairfax, ni siquiera -estoy segura de ello- Grace Poole.
"It must have been one of them," interrupted my master.
-Forzosamente había de ser una de ellas -interrumpió Rochester.
"No, sir, I solemnly assure you to the contrary.
-No; le juro que no.
The shape standing before me had never crossed my eyes within the precincts of Thornfield Hall before; the height, the contour were new to me."
La mujer que yo tenía ante mí no ha cruzado jamás sus miradas con las mías desde que vivo en Thornfield.
Todo en su aspecto era nuevo para mí.
"Describe it, Jane."
-Descríbemela, Jane.
"It seemed, sir, a woman, tall and large, with thick and dark hair hanging long down her back.
-Me pareció alta y corpulenta, con una negra cabellera cayéndole sobre la espalda.
I know not what dress she had on: it was white and straight; but whether gown, sheet, or shroud, I cannot tell."
No me fijé en cómo iba vestida; sólo sé que llevaba un traje blanco.
"Did you see her face?"
-¿Le viste la cara?
"Not at first.
-Primero no.
But presently she took my veil from its place; she held it up, gazed at it long, and then she threw it over her own head, and turned to the mirror.
Pero luego cogió el velo, lo examinó largamente, se lo puso y se miró el espejo.
At that moment I saw the reflection of the visage and features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass."
Entonces distinguí su rostro en el cristal.
"And how were they?"
-¿Cómo era?
"Fearful and ghastly to me--oh, sir, I never saw a face like it!
-Me pareció horrible.
Nunca he visto cara como aquella: una cara descolorida, espantosa.
It was a discoloured face--it was a savage face.
I wish I could forget the roll of the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!"
Quisiera poder olvidar aquel desorbitado movimiento de sus ojos inyectados en sangre, y sus facciones hinchadas como si fuesen a estallar.
"Ghosts are usually pale, Jane."
-Los fantasmas son pálidos, por regla general.
"This, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow furrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes.
-Pues éste no lo era.
Tenía los labios protuberantes y amoratados, arrugado el entrecejo, los párpados muy abiertos sobre sus ojos enrojecidos.
Shall I tell you of what it reminded me?"
¿Sabe lo que me recordaba?
"You may."
-¿El qué?
"Of the foul German spectre--the Vampyre."
-La aparición de las leyendas germanas: el vampiro...
"Ah!--what did it do?"
-¡Ah!
¿Y qué hizo?
"Sir, it removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and flinging both on the floor, trampled on them."
-Se quitó el velo de la cabeza, lo rasgó en dos, lo tiró al suelo y lo pisoteó.
"Afterwards?"
-¿Y luego?
"It drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps it saw dawn approaching, for, taking the candle, it retreated to the door.
-Descorrió las cortinas de la ventana y miró hacia fuera.
Just at my bedside, the figure stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me--she thrust up her candle close to my face, and extinguished it under my eyes.
En seguida cogió la vela y se dirigió a la puerta.
Se paró junto a mi lecho, apagó la bujía y se inclinó sobre mí.
I was aware her lurid visage flamed over mine, and I lost consciousness: for the second time in my life--only the second time--I became insensible from terror."
Tuve la sensación de que su rostro tocaba casi el mío y perdí el conocimiento.
Es la segunda vez en mi vida -sólo la segunda- en que el terror me ha hecho desmayarme.
"Who was with you when you revived?"
-¿Y había alguien contigo cuando te recobraste?
"No one, sir, but the broad day.
-Nadie.
Era de día ya.
I rose, bathed my head and face in water, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled I was not ill, and determined that to none but you would I impart this vision.
Sumergí la cabeza en agua, bebí, comprobé que, aunque débil, no me encontraba enferma y determiné no comunicar a nadie aquella visión.
Now, sir, tell me who and what that woman was?"
Ahora dígame: ¿quién es esa mujer?
"The creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain.
-Una creación de tu mente.
I must be careful of you, my treasure: nerves like yours were not made for rough handling."
Tienes que cuidarte.
Eres demasiado nerviosa.
"Sir, depend on it, my nerves were not in fault; the thing was real: the transaction actually took place."
-No fue cosa de mis nervios.
Todo lo que digo ocurrió en realidad.
"And your previous dreams, were they real too?
-¿También los sueños anteriores?
Is Thornfield Hall a ruin?
¿Acaso Thornfield Hall es una ruina?
Am I severed from you by insuperable obstacles?
¿Estoy separado de ti por insuperables obstáculos?
Am I leaving you without a tear--without a kiss--without a word?"
¿Te he abandonado sin una lágrima, sin un beso, sin una palabra?
"Not yet."
-Aún no.
"Am I about to do it?
-¿Y parezco inclinado a hacerlo?
Why, the day is already commenced which is to bind us indissolubly; and when we are once united, there shall be no recurrence of these mental terrors: I guarantee that."
Porque ya estamos en el día en que nos uniremos con un lazo indisoluble.
Y una vez unidos, no se repetirán esas terroríficas alucinaciones, te lo aseguro...
"Mental terrors, sir!
-¡Alucinaciones!
I wish I could believe them to be only such: I wish it more now than ever; since even you cannot explain to me the mystery of that awful visitant."
¡Qué más quisiera yo que lo fuesen!
Y lo desearía ahora más que nunca, en vista de que usted no puede aclararme la personalidad de esa para mí extraña visitante.
"And since I cannot do it, Jane, it must have been unreal."
-Puesto que no puedo decírtelo, es que no ha existido, esto es seguro.

"But, sir, when I said so to myself on rising this morning, and when I looked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful aspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there--on the carpet--I saw what gave the distinct lie to my hypothesis,--the veil, torn from top to bottom in two halves!"
-Cuando me he levantado esta mañana y he ido al ropero para asegurarme de que todo estaba en orden, he encontrado la prueba de que no había soñado: el velo, tirado en el suelo y partido en dos...
I felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; he hastily flung his arms round me.
Rochester se estremeció.
Me abrazó por la cintura, exclamando:
"Thank God!" he exclaimed, "that if anything malignant did come near you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed.
-¡Gracias a Dios que ese velo ha sido lo único que ha sufrido daño!
Oh, to think what might have happened!"
¡Oh, cuando pienso en lo que pudo haber sucedido!
He drew his breath short, and strained me so close to him, I could scarcely pant.
Me apretó con tal fuerza contra su pecho, que casi no me dejaba respirar.
After some minutes' silence, he continued, cheerily--
Continuó, tras una pausa:
"Now, Janet, I'll explain to you all about it.
-Te lo explicaré todo, Jane.
It was half dream, half reality.
Ha sido medio sueño y medio realidad.
A woman did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that woman was--must have been--Grace Poole.
Sin duda una mujer entró en tu cuarto.
Y no fue -no pudo ser- otra que Grace Poole.
You call her a strange being yourself: from all you know, you have reason so to call her--what did she do to me? what to Mason?
Te parece un ser extraño, y no te falta razón, si consideramos lo que nos hizo a Mason y a mí.

In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed her entrance and her actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you were, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her own: the long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated stature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the spiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like her.

Sin duda encontrándote medio dormida y algo febril, la viste entrar y le atribuiste una forma fantástica distinta a la que tiene en realidad: el largo cabello desmelenado, la faz oscura e hinchada, la exagerada estatura.
Todo ello son ficciones de pesadilla.
El episodio del velo es real, y muy apropiado al modo de ser de esa mujer.
I see you would ask why I keep such a woman in my house: when we have been married a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now.
Ya veo que deseas preguntarme por qué conservo en mi casa a una persona así...
Pues bien, te lo diré cuando llevemos casados un año y un día, pero no ahora
Are you satisfied, Jane?
¿Estas satisfecha, Jane?
Do you accept my solution of the mystery?"
¿Aceptas esta solución del misterio?
Reflexioné.
Tal solución, en efecto, parecía la única verdadera.

I reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one: satisfied I was not, but to please him I endeavoured to appear so--relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered him with a contented smile.
No me sentía satisfecha, pero por complacerle traté de parecerlo.
Le correspondí, pues, con una sonrisa de aquiescencia.
And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.
Y como era bastante más de la una, me dispuse a dejarle.
"Does not Sophie sleep with Adele in the nursery?" he asked, as I lit my candle.
-¿No duerme Sophie con Adèle? -me preguntó cuando cogí mi bujía.
"Yes, sir."
-Sí.
"And there is room enough in Adele's little bed for you.
-En el cuarto de Adèle hay sitio suficiente para ti.
Debes dormir allí esta noche, Jane.
You must share it with her to-night, Jane: it is no wonder that the incident you have related should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep alone: promise me to go to the nursery."
No me extraña que el incidente que me has relatado te haya puesto nerviosa, y si pasas la noche sola no podrás dormir.
Prométeme acostarte en la alcoba de Adèle.
"I shall be very glad to do so, sir."
-Lo haré con gusto.
"And fasten the door securely on the inside.
-Y cierra la puerta por dentro.
Wake Sophie when you go upstairs, under pretence of requesting her to rouse you in good time to- morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before eight.
Despierta a Sophie cuando entres, con el pretexto de que te llame mañana temprano, para vestirte y desayunarte antes de las ocho.
And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janet.
Y ahora basta de pensamientos sombríos.
Olvida tus preocupaciones, Jane.
¿Oyes en qué suave brisa se ha convertido el viento de antes?
Don't you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is no more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here" (he lifted up the curtain)--"it is a lovely night!"
Tampoco la lluvia bate ya los cristales.
Mira qué noche tan hermosa -concluyó, corriendo el visillo para que yo mirara.
It was.
Era cierto.
Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping before the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off eastward in long, silvered columns.
La mitad del cielo estaba azul y límpido.
Las nubes, impulsadas por el viento, desaparecían, formando grandes y argentadas masas, en el horizonte.
The moon shone peacefully.
La luna brillaba, serena.
"Well," said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, "how is my Janet now?"
-¿Cómo se siente ahora mi Jane? -preguntó mirándome a los ojos.
"The night is serene, sir; and so am I."
-La noche es serena y yo también lo estoy.
"And you will not dream of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy love and blissful union."
-Nada de soñar esta noche con terrores y pesadillas, sino con dulces sueños de amor y de felicidad.
This prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of sorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all.
Su deseo se cumplió a medias, porque no tuve ni pesadillas ni sueños agradables, ya que no dormí nada.

With little Adele in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood--so tranquil, so passionless, so innocent--and waited for the coming day: all my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun rose I rose too.
Con Adèle entre los brazos velé su sueño -e1 sueño tranquilo, despreocupado y puro de la infancia- y así esperé que alborease el día.
En cuanto el sol salió, me levanté.

I remember Adele clung to me as I left her: I remember I kissed her as I loosened her little hands from my neck; and I cried over her with strange emotion, and quitted her because I feared my sobs would break her still sound repose.
Recuerdo cuando me separé de Adèle abrazada a mí, cómo separé sus bracitos de mi cuello y cómo lloré, mirándola, con emoción reprimida, para que mis sollozos no turbaran su sueño.
She seemed the emblem of my past life; and here I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored, type of my unknown future day.
Ella simbolizaba para mí la vida pasada, como mi prometido, al que iba ahora a reunirme, simbolizaba mi ignorado porvenir, temido, pero adorado.
CHAPTER XXVI
XXVI
Sophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in accomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose, impatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come.
Sophie vino a las siete a vestirme, en lo que tardó bastante, hasta el punto de que Rochester, impaciente, sin duda, por mi tardanza, envió a preguntar el motivo de que yo no acudiera.
She was just fastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with a brooch; I hurried from under her hands as soon as I could.
En aquel momento ella estaba colocando sobre mi cabeza el velo -que al fin había tenido que ser mi liso velo de blonda- y sujetándolo con un broche.
Me escapé de entre sus manos en cuanto pude.
"Stop!" she cried in French.
-¡Espere! -exclamó ella, en francés-.
"Look at yourself in the mirror: you have not taken one peep."
¡No se ha mirado aún al espejo!
So I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my usual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger.
Me volví desde la puerta y vi en el cristal una figura tan distinta, con su velo y sus ropas, de la mía, que casi me pareció otra persona.
"Jane!" called a voice, and I hastened down.
-¡Jane! -gritó una voz.
Bajé apresuradamente.
I was received at the foot of the stairs by Mr. Rochester.
Rochester me recibió al pie de la escaleras.
"Lingerer!" he said, "my brain is on fire with impatience, and you tarry so long!"
-Vamos -dijo-.
Estoy ardiendo de impaciencia; ¡hay que ver lo que tardabas!

He took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over, pronounced me "fair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life, but the desire of his eyes," and then telling me he would give me but ten minutes to eat some breakfast, he rang the bell.
Me condujo al comedor, me examinó y dijo que yo era «tan bonita como un lirio, y no sólo el orgullo de su vida, sino el encanto de sus ojos».
One of his lately hired servants, a footman, answered it.
Luego agregó que me concedía diez minutos para desayunar y tocó la campanilla.
"Is John getting the carriage ready?"
-¿Ha enganchado John el coche?
"Yes, sir."
-Sí, señor.
"Is the luggage brought down?"
-¿Y el equipaje?
"They are bringing it down, sir."
-Están sacándolo.
"Go you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk are there: return and tell me."
-Vaya a la iglesia, vea si está el Padre Wood y el sacristán y vuelva a decírmelo.
The church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the footman soon returned.
Como no ignora el lector, la iglesia estaba muy cerca.
El criado, pues, regresó enseguida.
"Mr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice."
-El Padre Wood, señor, estaba poniéndose la sobrepelliz.
"And the carriage?"
-¿Y el coche?
"The horses are harnessing."
-Ya está.
"We shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment we return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the coachman in his seat."
-No iremos en él a la iglesia, pero necesitamos que esté listo para cuando regresemos, con el equipaje colocado y el cochero en el pescante.
"Yes, sir."
-Bien, señor.
"Jane, are you ready?"
-¿Estás ya, Jane?
I rose.
Me levanté.
There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait for or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I. Mrs. Fairfax stood in the hall as we passed.
Sólo Mrs.
Fairfax estaba en el vestíbulo cuando pasamos.

I would fain have spoken to her, but my hand was held by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly follow; and to look at Mr. Rochester's face was to feel that not a second of delay would be tolerated for any purpose.
Hubiera querido hablarla, pero una mano de hierro asió mi brazo y me vi obligada a caminar a un paso que apenas me era posible mantener.
Una mirada al rostro de Rochester me indicó que él no quería perder ni un segundo.
I wonder what other bridegroom ever looked as he did--so bent up to a purpose, so grimly resolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such flaming and flashing eyes.
I know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I gazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both seemed migrated into Mr. Rochester's frame.
No sé si el día era bueno o malo, porque, mientras nos dirigíamos a la iglesia, yo no miraba ni la tierra ni el cielo.
I wanted to see the invisible thing on which, as we went along, he appeared to fasten a glance fierce and fell.
I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he seemed breasting and resisting.
Mi corazón estaba todo en mis ojos, y éstos contemplaban, estáticos, a Rochester, buscando en su apariencia la exteriorización de los sentimientos que parecía reprimir con dificultad.
At the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of breath.
Se paró ante la puerta del cementerio al notar que yo no podía ya ni respirar, y me dijo:
"Am I cruel in my love?" he said.
-Mi amor es un poco cruel...
"Delay an instant: lean on me, Jane."
Descansa un momento, Jane.
And now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising calm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy morning sky beyond.
Y entonces pude distinguir la parda y antigua casa de Dios alzándose ante mí.
Una corneja volaba en torno al campanario bajo el cielo carmesí de la mañana.

I remember something, too, of the green grave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of strangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes graven on the few mossy head-stones.
Entre los verdes montículos de las tumbas vi las figuras de dos forasteros que se detenían entre ellas para leer los epitafios de sus lápidas.
I noticed them, because, as they saw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not they were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the ceremony.
Noté que, al atisbarnos, desaparecieron detrás de la iglesia y no dudé de que iban a asistir a la ceremonia.
By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; he was earnestly looking at my face from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily fled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold.
Pero Rochester no les observó, porque su mirada se concentraba en mi rostro, del que me parece que habían huido todos los colores.
Yo tenía la frente húmeda y los labios fríos.
When I rallied, which I soon did, he walked gently with me up the path to the porch.
Cuando hube descansado, él me condujo lentamente hasta el pórtico.
We entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in his white surplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside him.
Entramos en el silencioso y humilde templo.
El sacerdote, revestido con su blanca sobrepelliz, estaba ante el altar y el sacristán a su lado.
All was still: two shadows only moved in a remote corner.
No había nadie más, excepto dos sombras que se agitaban en un remoto rincón.

My conjecture had been correct: the strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault of the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails the old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the remains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the civil wars, and of Elizabeth, his wife.
Mi suposición había sido acertada.

Los dos desconocidos, entrando antes que nosotros, se hallaban dentro inclinados ahora sobre la cripta que guardaba los restos de los Rochester, y contemplando las tumbas de mármol en las que un ángel arrodillado custodiaba los restos de Damer de Rochester, muerto en Marston Moor durante las guerras civiles, y de Elizabeth, su mujer.
Our place was taken at the communion rails.
Nos arrodillamos ante la barandilla donde los fieles se posternaban para comulgar.
Hearing a cautious step behind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers--a gentleman, evidently--was advancing up the chancel.
Oí un paso cauteloso a mis espaldas y, volviendo un poco el rostro, vi a uno de los dos forasteros, un caballero por las apariencias, que se aproximaba al presbiterio.
The service began.
Comenzó el servicio.
The explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then the clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly towards Mr. Rochester, went on.
Se hizo primero la manifestación de nuestro propósito de contraer matrimonio y después el sacerdote avanzó hacia nosotros y dijo:

"I require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it; for be ye well assured that so many as are coupled together otherwise than God's Word doth allow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony lawful."

-Os pido que ambos declaréis (como si contestarais cuando, el Día del Juicio, los secretos de todos los corazones sean declarados íntegramente) si cualquiera de vosotros tiene o cree tener impedimentos de cualquier clase que os impidan uniros en matrimonio legal, porque, de existir, aunque os unierais, vuestro matrimonio no sería válido ante Dios ni, por tanto, legal.
He paused, as the custom is.
Calló, según costumbre.
When is the pause after that sentence ever broken by reply?
¿Hay acaso alguna ocasión en que ese silencio formulario sea roto?
Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years.
Quizá no suceda ni una vez en cien años.

And the clergyman, who had not lifted his eyes from his book, and had held his breath but for a moment, was proceeding: his hand was already stretched towards Mr. Rochester, as his lips unclosed to ask, "Wilt thou have this woman for thy wedded wife?"--when a distinct and near voice said--
El sacerdote, que no había separado los ojos de su libro, y que sólo se había interrumpido por un momento, iba a continuar.
Ya su mano se dirigía a Rochester y sus labios se abrían para preguntarle si me tomaba por legítima esposa, cuando una voz clara y muy próxima dijo:
"The marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment."
-Ese matrimonio no puede efectuarse.
Afirmo que existe un impedimento.
El sacerdote miró al que hablaba y permaneció mudo.
El sacristán hizo lo mismo.

The clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did the same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled under his feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning his head or eyes, he said, "Proceed."
Rochester dio un salto, como si hubiera sentido temblar la tierra bajo sus pies.
En seguida recuperó su serenidad y, sin volver la cabeza, dijo: -Continúe.
Profound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low intonation.
A su palabra, pronunciada en voz baja y clara, siguió un profundo silencio.
Presently Mr. Wood said--
El padre Wood repuso:
"I cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been asserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood."
-No puedo continuar antes de que se investigue la certeza o falsedad de lo que acaba de asegurarse.
"The ceremony is quite broken off," subjoined the voice behind us.
No debe celebrarse la ceremonia -repitió la voz de antes-.
"I am in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to this marriage exists."
Puedo probar que existe un insuperable impedimento.
Rochester oyó, pero no movió la cabeza.
Mr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: he stood stubborn and rigid, making no movement but to possess himself of my hand.
Permanecía obstinado y rígido.
Su mano asía la mía, y aquella mano ardiente parecía de hierro.
What a hot and strong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was his pale, firm, massive front at this moment!
En cambio, su rostro cuadrado, su frente enérgica, estaban pálidos como el mármol.
How his eye shone, still watchful, and yet wild beneath!
Sus ojos brillaban, atentos, inmóviles y, sin embargo, con una expresión casi feroz.
Mr. Wood seemed at a loss.
"What is the nature of the impediment?" he asked.
-¿De qué clase es ése impedimento? -preguntó el turbado padre Wood-.
"Perhaps it may be got over--explained away?"
Acaso sea hacedero eliminarlo...
"Hardly," was the answer.
-Difícilmente -dijo la voz de antes-.
"I have called it insuperable, and I speak advisedly."
He dicho que era insuperable y he hablado sabiendo lo que decía.
The speaker came forward and leaned on the rails.
He continued, uttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly--
El desconocido se acercó a la barandilla y siguió, con energía y claridad, pero sin alzar la voz:
"It simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage.
-El impedimento consiste en que Mr.
Mr. Rochester has a wife now living."
Rochester está casado y su mujer vive aún.

My nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated to thunder--my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt frost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning.
Aquellas palabras, pronunciadas en voz baja, hicieron vibrar mis nervios cual si hubieran sonado fuertes como el trueno.
Mi sangre sintió una impresión tal como el fuego o el hielo no hubieran sido capaces de producir.
I looked at Mr. Rochester: I made him look at me.
His whole face was colourless rock: his eye was both spark and flint.
He disavowed nothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things.
Miré a Rochester y él me miró: sus ojos permanecían fijos y duros, en actitud de desafiar al mundo entero.
Without speaking, without smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he only twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.
Sin hablar, sin sonreír, sin indicio alguno de que me considerase como un ser viviente, ciñó mi talle con la mano y me atrajo hacia sí.
"Who are you?" he asked of the intruder.
-¿Quién es usted? -preguntó al intruso.
"My name is Briggs, a solicitor of --- Street, London."
-Me llamo Briggs, procurador de Londres.
"And you would thrust on me a wife?"
-¿Y asegura usted que soy casado?
"I would remind you of your lady's existence, sir, which the law recognises, if you do not."
-Puedo asegurar la existencia de su mujer.
La ley lo reconocerá, si usted lo niega.
"Favour me with an account of her--with her name, her parentage, her place of abode."
-Hágame el favor de decirme su nombre, quiénes eran sus padres, dónde nació...
"Certainly."
-Con mucho gusto.
Mr. Briggs calmly took a paper from his pocket, and read out in a sort of official, nasal voice:--
El señor Briggs sacó un papel de su bolsillo y leyó con una voz nasal, protocolaria:

"'I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D. --- (a date of fifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in the county of ---, and of Ferndean Manor, in ---shire, England, was married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason, merchant, and of Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at --- church, Spanish Town, Jamaica.
-«Afirmo y puedo probar que el 20 de octubre de... (una fecha de quince años antes), Edward Fairfax Rochester, de Thornfield Hall, en el condado de... y de Ferndean Manor, en...
(Inglaterra), casó con mi hermana Bertha Antoinette en Puerto España (Jamaica), en la iglesia de...
The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church--a copy of it is now in my possession.
Poseo una copia del certificado de su partida de casamiento.
Signed, Richard Mason.'"
Firmado: Richard Mason.»
"That--if a genuine document--may prove I have been married, but it does not prove that the woman mentioned therein as my wife is still living."
-Aun suponiendo que se tratara de un documento auténtico eso probaría que he estado casado, pero no que mi mujer viva aún.
"She was living three months ago," returned the lawyer.
-Vivía hace tres meses -replicó el procurador.
"How do you know?"
-¿Cómo lo sabe?
"I have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will scarcely controvert."
-Tengo un testigo del hecho.
"Produce him--or go to hell."
-Preséntelo o váyase al infierno, si no...
"I will produce him first--he is on the spot.
-Prefiero presentarlo.
Está aquí Mr.
Mr. Mason, have the goodness to step forward."
Mason: tenga la bondad.

Mr. Rochester, on hearing the name, set his teeth; he experienced, too, a sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to him as I was, I felt the spasmodic movement of fury or despair run through his frame.
The second stranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a pale face looked over the solicitor's shoulder--yes, it was Mason himself.

Rochester, al oír tal nombre, rechinó los dientes y experimentó un estremecimiento convulsivo El otro forastero, que hasta entonces permaneciera retirado, avanzó y la pálida faz de Mason en persona apareció sobre el hombro del procurador.
Mr. Rochester turned and glared at him.
Rochester se volvió y le miró.

His eye, as I have often said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in its gloom; and his face flushed--olive cheek and hueless forehead received a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and he stirred, lifted his strong arm--he could have struck Mason, dashed him on the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from his body--but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, "Good God!"
Una sombría luz brilló en sus ojos, la sangre afluyó a sus morenas mejillas y su fuerte brazo se distendió.
Hubiera podido aplastar a Mason, de un golpe, sin duda.
Pero Mason dio un salto hacia atrás, gritando: «¡Dios mío!», y la furia de Rochester se desvaneció.
Contempt fell cool on Mr. Rochester--his passion died as if a blight had shrivelled it up: he only asked--"What have _you_ to say?"
Limitóse a preguntarle: -¿Qué tienes que decir?
An inaudible reply escaped Mason's white lips.
De los pálidos labios de Mason escapó una réplica inaudible.
"The devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly.
-El diablo te lleve si no contestas con más claridad.
I again demand, what have you to say?"
¿Qué tienes que decir, repito?
"Sir--sir," interrupted the clergyman, "do not forget you are in a sacred place."
-Señor -interrumpió el sacerdote-, no olvide que está usted en un sitio sagrado
Then addressing Mason, he inquired gently, "Are you aware, sir, whether or not this gentleman's wife is still living?"
-y dirigiéndose a Mason le preguntó con amabilidad-: ¿Le consta a usted que la esposa de este caballero vive realmente?
"Courage," urged the lawyer,--"speak out."
-¡Ánimo! -intervino el procurador-.
"She is now living at Thornfield Hall," said Mason, in more articulate tones: "I saw her there last April.
Hable. -Vive en Thornfield Hall -dijo Mason, más claramente-.
La vi en abril pasado.
I am her brother."
Soy su hermano.
"At Thornfield Hall!" ejaculated the clergyman.
-¡En Thornfield Hall! -exclamó el sacerdote-.
"Impossible!
Es imposible.
I am an old resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at Thornfield Hall."
Hace mucho que habito en la vecindad y jamás he oído hablar de ninguna Mrs.
Rochester en esa casa.
I saw a grim smile contort Mr. Rochester's lips, and he muttered--
Una horrible sonrisa contrajo la boca de Rochester al contestar:
"No, by God!
I took care that none should hear of it--or of her under that name."
-Ya me preocupé bastante de que nadie supiera nada de ella, al menos como mi mujer.
He mused--for ten minutes he held counsel with himself: he formed his resolve, and announced it-- "Enough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel.
Calló, reflexionó durante unos minutos y, al fin, como si hubiese adoptado una resolución, habló: -Basta, acabemos de una vez.
Wood, close your book and take off your surplice; John Green (to the clerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day."
Wood, cierre el libro y quítese la sobrepelliz.
Usted, John Green -se dirigía al sacristán-, puede irse.
Por hoy no se celebra la boda.
The man obeyed.
El hombre obedeció.
Mr. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: "Bigamy is an ugly word!--I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred me, or Providence has checked me,--perhaps the last.
Rochester siguió diciendo: -Ciertamente, la palabra bigamia suena muy mal.
Sin embargo, yo iba a convertirme en bígamo, de no habérmelo impedido el destino o la Providencia.
I am little better than a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me, deserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless fire and deathless worm.
Quizá esta última...
Reconozco que he obrado diabólicamente...
Señores: mi plan ha fracasado.
Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:--what this lawyer and his client say is true: I have been married, and the woman to whom I was married lives!
Lo que este procurador y su cliente aseguran es verdad.
Estoy casado y mi mujer vive aún.
You say you never heard of a Mrs. Rochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a time inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept there under watch and ward.
Es verdad que usted no ha oído hablar de mi mujer, Wood, pero sí le habrán mencionado una loca que albergo en mi casa.
Some have whispered to you that she is my bastard half-sister: some, my cast-off mistress.
Algunos le dirían que se trata de una hermana bastarda, otros le afirmarán que es una antigua amante.

I now inform you that she is my wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,--Bertha Mason by name; sister of this resolute personage, who is now, with his quivering limbs and white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear.
Pero declaro ahora que es mi mujer, con la que me casé hace quince años.
Se llama Bertha Mason y es hermana de este atrevido personaje, que con su temblor y su palidez les demuestra lo que un bravo corazón masculino es capaz de afrontar.
Cheer up, Dick!--never fear me!--I'd almost as soon strike a woman as you.
Tranquilízate, Dick, no temas; no te pegaré.
¡Casi sería capaz de pegar a una mujer antes que a ti!
Bertha Mason is mad; and she came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs through three generations!
Bertha Mason está loca y desciende de una familia cuyos miembros han sido locos o maniáticos a lo largo de tres generaciones.
Her mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman and a drunkard!--as I found out after I had wed the daughter: for they were silent on family secrets before.
La madre de mi mujer estaba loca y alcohólica.
Lo supe después de casado, porque, desde luego, me ocultaron antes tales secretos de familia.
Bertha, like a dutiful child, copied her parent in both points.
Bertha, como buena hija, imitaba a su genitora en ambos aspectos.
I had a charming partner--pure, wise, modest: you can fancy I was a happy man.
I went through rich scenes!
Tuve una encantadora compañera.
¡No pueden imaginarse lo admirable que era y lo feliz que fui yo con aquella mujer pura, prudente y modesta... !
Oh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it!
¡Oh, qué escenas hubo entre nosotros!
¡Una cosa celestial!
But I owe you no further explanation.
Pero sobra entrar en más explicaciones.
Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite you all to come up to the house and visit Mrs. Poole's patient, and _my wife_!
Briggs, Wood, Mason: les invito a venir a mi casa a conocer a la paciente de Grace Poole y esposa mía.
You shall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge whether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy with something at least human.
Así verán ustedes con qué clase de ser me casé y si tengo o no derecho a romper el pacto matrimonial y buscar consuelo en un ser que ni siquiera pueda llamarse humano.

This girl," he continued, looking at me, "knew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: she thought all was fair and legal and never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad, and embruted partner!
Esta muchacha, Wood -agregó, mirándome-, no conocía el secreto más que usted mismo, y creía que todo era limpio y legal.
Jamás pudo ocurrírsele que iba a unirse a un hombre ligado a una compañera malvada, loca y embrutecida.
Come all of you--follow!"
¡Ea, óiganme!
Still holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came after.
Salió de la iglesia arrastrándome consigo.
Los tres hombres nos seguían.
At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.
Ante la casa encontramos el coche.
"Take it back to the coach-house, John," said Mr. Rochester coolly; "it will not be wanted to-day."
-Llévelo a la cochera, John -dijo fríamente Rochester-.
Hoy no nos hace falta.
At our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Adele, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet and greet us.
Al entrar, Mr.
Fairfax, Adèle, Sophie y Leah avanzaron a nuestro encuentro.
"To the right-about--every soul!" cried the master; "away with your congratulations!
-¡Alto! -gritó Rochester-.
Nada de felicitaciones.
Who wants them?
¿Para qué las quiero?
Not I!--they are fifteen years too late!"
¡Llegan con quince años de retraso!
He passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still beckoning the gentlemen to follow him, which they did.
Subió las escaleras, siempre llevándome tomada del brazo y siempre seguidos los dos de los hombres.

We mounted the first staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey: the low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester's master-key, admitted us to the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.
Cruzamos la galería y ascendimos al tercer piso.
La llave maestra que llevaba Rochester nos abrió paso al cuarto tapizado, con su enorme lecho y su gabinete de puertas pintadas.
"You know this place, Mason," said our guide; "she bit and stabbed you here."
-Tú ya conoces el sitio -dijo Rochester a Mason-.
Aquí es donde ella te mordió.
He lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this, too, he opened.
Corrió las tapicerías que cubrían la pared, descubriendo otra puerta, que abrió seguidamente.
In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded by a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a chain.
Nos hallamos en una habitación sin ventanas, en la que ardía una lumbre protegida por un alto y fuerte guardafuegos.
Del techo pendía una lámpara sostenida por una cadena.
Grace Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in a saucepan.
Grace Poole, inclinada sobre el fuego, parecía cocinar algo en una cacerola.
In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure ran backwards and forwards.
En el fondo del cuarto se veía una figura que se movía de un lado para otro.

What it was, whether beast or human being, one could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all fours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it was covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild as a mane, hid its head and face.

No era fácil, a primera vista, percibir si se trataba de un ser humano o no, ya que en aquel momento se arrastraba en cuatro pies y gruñía como un animal feroz, pero iba vestida y una oscura cabellera cubría su cabeza y su rostro.
"Good-morrow, Mrs. Poole!" said Mr. Rochester.
-Buenos días, Grace -dijo Rochester-: ¿Cómo está usted?
"How are you? and how is your charge to-day?"
¿Y la persona que tiene a su cargo?
"We're tolerable, sir, I thank you," replied Grace, lifting the boiling mess carefully on to the hob: "rather snappish, but not 'rageous."
-No vamos mal, señor-replicó Grace, dejando cuidadosamente la cazuela a un lado de la lumbre-.
Está algo arisca, pero no furiosa.
A fierce cry seemed to give the lie to her favourable report: the clothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.
En aquel momento, un grito penetrante pareció desmentir aquella aserción.
La hiena vestida se puso en pie, mostrándose en toda su elevada estatura.
"Ah! sir, she sees you!" exclaimed Grace: "you'd better not stay."
-¡Les ha visto, señor! -exclamó Grace-.
Vale más que se vayan.
"Only a few moments, Grace: you must allow me a few moments."
-Sólo estaremos unos momentos, Grace.
Tráigala.
"Take care then, sir!--for God's sake, take care!"
-Tenga cuidado, señor.
¡Por amor de Dios, tenga cuidado!
The maniac bellowed: she parted her shaggy locks from her visage, and gazed wildly at her visitors.
La loca avanzó, separó de su rostro el cabello que lo cubría y miró con fiereza a sus visitantes.
I recognised well that purple face,--those bloated features.
Reconocí bien aquel rostro encendido, aquellas facciones hinchadas.
Mrs. Poole advanced.
Grace se adelantó. -Sepárense -dijo Rochester, apartándola-.
"Keep out of the way," said Mr. Rochester, thrusting her aside: "she has no knife now, I suppose, and I'm on my guard."
Ya estoy prevenido.
Supongo que ahora no tendrá un cuchillo, ¿eh?
"One never knows what she has, sir: she is so cunning: it is not in mortal discretion to fathom her craft."
-Nunca se sabe lo que puede tener, señor.
Es tan astuta, que con ella no hay precaución que valga.
"We had better leave her," whispered Mason.
-Valdrá más que nos vayamos -murmuró Mason.
"Go to the devil!" was his brother-in-law's recommendation.
-¡Vete al diablo! -contestó su cuñado.
"'Ware!" cried Grace.
-¡Cuidado! -gritó Grace.
The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously.
Los tres visitantes retrocedieron a la vez.
Rochester se puso delante de mí.
Mr. Rochester flung me behind him: the lunatic sprang and grappled his throat viciously, and laid her teeth to his cheek: they struggled.
La loca cayó sobre él y asió rabiosamente su garganta, mientras trataba de morderle el rostro.
Ambos forcejearon.
She was a big woman, in stature almost equalling her husband, and corpulent besides: she showed virile force in the contest--more than once she almost throttled him, athletic as he was.
Ella era alta y corpulenta, tanto como su marido, y estaba dotada de una fuerza tremenda.
Varias veces estuvo a punto de derribar a Rochester, a pesar de lo vigoroso que éste era.
He could have settled her with a well-planted blow; but he would not strike: he would only wrestle.
Cierto que él hubiera podido inmovilizarla, descargándole un golpe violento, pero no intentaba más que sujetarla.
Al fin logró tomarla por los brazos.
At last he mastered her arms; Grace Poole gave him a cord, and he pinioned them behind her: with more rope, which was at hand, he bound her to a chair.
Grace Poole le tendió una cuerda y Rochester ató a la espalda las muñecas de la loca, lo que realizó a despecho de las sacudidas y empellones que ella daba.
The operation was performed amidst the fiercest yells and the most convulsive plunges.
Mr. Rochester then turned to the spectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.
Entonces, Rochester se volvió a los espectadores y les contempló con una sonrisa triste y amarga. -¡Esta es mi mujer! -exclamó-.
"That is _my wife_," said he.
Tales son las únicas relaciones que puedo mantener con ella.
"Such is the sole conjugal embrace I am ever to know--such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure hours!

And _this_ is what I wished to have" (laying his hand on my shoulder): "this young girl, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth of hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted her just as a change after that fierce ragout.

¡Y ésta -añadió, poniendo su mano en mi hombro-, esta muchacha es la que yo deseaba tener, ésta que veis, grave y silenciosa en la misma boca del Infierno, contemplando sin perder la serenidad las gesticulaciones de ese demonio!
Wood and Briggs, look at the difference!
¡Aprecien la diferencia, Wood y Briggs!

Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder--this face with that mask--this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of the gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged!
Comparen estos ojos límpidos con esos ojos inyectados en sangre, este rostro con esa máscara, y júzguenme, usted, sacerdote de Dios, y usted, hombre de leyes.
Júzguenme y recuerden que como juzguen serán juzgados.
Off with you now.
Y ahora vámonos.
I must shut up my prize."
Todos nos retiramos.
We all withdrew.
Mr. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some further order to Grace Poole.
Rochester se detuvo unos momentos más, dando órdenes a Grace.
The solicitor addressed me as he descended the stair.
El procurador me habló cuando bajábamos la escalera.
"You, madam," said he, "are cleared from all blame: your uncle will be glad to hear it--if, indeed, he should be still living--when Mr. Mason returns to Madeira."
-Su tío, señorita -dijo-, celebrará saber que la hemos evitado un grave disgusto, si vive aún cuando Mr.
Mason pase por Madera.
"My uncle!
-¿Mi tío?
What of him?
Do you know him?"
¿Lo conoce usted?
"Mr. Mason does.
-Le conoce Mr.
Mason.
Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of his house for some years.
Mr.
Eyre ha sido su corresponsal en Funchal durante varios años.
Cuando su tío recibió la carta de usted notificándole su próxima boda con Mr.

When your uncle received your letter intimating the contemplated union between yourself and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason, who was staying at Madeira to recruit his health, on his way back to Jamaica, happened to be with him.
Rochester, Mr.
Mason se hallaba en Madera para mejorar su salud antes de continuar a Jamaica.
Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence; for he knew that my client here was acquainted with a gentleman of the name of Rochester.
Mr.
Eyre le habló del asunto, porque sabía que mi cliente era pariente de una persona llamada Rochester.
Mr. Mason, astonished and distressed as you may suppose, revealed the real state of matters.
Mr.
Mason, tan asombrado y disgustado como usted puede suponer, le reveló cuál era el verdadero estado de cosas.
Your uncle, I am sorry to say, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of his disease--decline--and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely he will ever rise.
Siento decirla que su tío padece ahora una enfermedad que, desgraciadamente, deja pocas esperanzas de curación.
He could not then hasten to England himself, to extricate you from the snare into which you had fallen, but he implored Mr. Mason to lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage.
No podía, pues, venir a Inglaterra para impedir que usted cayese en la trampa que se le tendía, pero rogó a Mr.
Mason que volviese y evitara el ilegal matrimonio.
He referred him to me for assistance.
Mr.
I used all despatch, and am thankful I was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also.
Mason consultó conmigo, que he puesto en el asunto todo interés.
Celebro haber llegado a tiempo.

Were I not morally certain that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would advise you to accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, I think you had better remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of Mr. Eyre.
Si no tuviera la certeza íntima de que su tío habrá fallecido, antes de que usted pudiera llegar a Madera, la aconsejaría que fuese allí con Mr.
Mason, pero en el estado actual de cosas, creo que vale más que se quede en Inglaterra hasta que reciba noticias acerca de su tío.
Have we anything else to stay for?" he inquired of Mr. Mason.
-Y preguntó a Mason-: ¿Tenemos algo más. que hacer aquí?
"No, no--let us be gone," was the anxious reply; and without waiting to take leave of Mr. Rochester, they made their exit at the hall door.
-No, no, vámonos -contestó Mason apresuradamente.
Sin despedirse de Rochester, ganaron la puerta de la casa.
The clergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or reproof, with his haughty parishioner; this duty done, he too departed.
El sacerdote se detuvo algo más para dirigir algunas palabras, de reproche o reprimenda, a su perverso feligrés, y cumplido tal deber, se marchó.
I heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to which I had now withdrawn.
Le sentí bajar a través de la entornada puerta de mi habitación, a la que me había retirado.

The house cleared, I shut myself in, fastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded--not to weep, not to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but--mechanically to take off the wedding dress, and replace it by the stuff gown I had worn yesterday, as I thought, for the last time.
Corrí el cerrojo y procedí -sin lágrimas ni lamentos- a sustituir en mis maletas las ropas de boda por mis antiguos vestidos.
