I then sat down: I felt weak and tired.
Una vez hecho esto, me senté.
Sentíame febril y fatigada.
I leaned my arms on a table, and my head dropped on them.
Apoyé los brazos en la mesa y descansé la cabeza sobre mis brazos.
And now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen, moved--followed up and down where I was led or dragged--watched event rush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but _now_, _I thought_.
Ahora comenzaba a sentir.
Hasta entonces había visto, oído y actuado, pero ahora sentía y pensaba.
La mañana había transcurrido con bastante tranquilidad -a excepción de la escena con la loca-, ya que la conversación de la iglesia no había tenido el carácter de altercado.

The morning had been a quiet morning enough--all except the brief scene with the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy; there was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no defiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken, a calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made; some stern, short questions put by Mr. Rochester; answers, explanations given, evidence adduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master; then the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all was over.
No hubo amenazas, desafíos, lágrimas ni sollozos.

Alguien alegó serenamente un impedimento al matrimonio, se cambiaron breves preguntas y respuestas, mi prometido reconoció la verdad, se vio la prueba viviente de ella, los intrusos se fueron y todo quedaba en paz.
I was in my own room as usual--just myself, without obvious change: nothing had smitten me, or scathed me, or maimed me.
Yo me hallaba en mi cuarto, como de costumbre, sin que nada hubiese cambiado en mí.
And yet where was the Jane Eyre of yesterday?--where was her life?--where were her prospects?
Sin embargo, ¿qué era de la Jane Eyre de la víspera?
¿Qué de sus perspectivas y esperanzas?
Jane Eyre, who had been an ardent, expectant woman--almost a bride, was a cold, solitary girl again: her life was pale; her prospects were desolate.

Jane Eyre, que era el día anterior una mujer llena de dulces anhelos, una casi desposada, se había convertido otra vez en una muchacha desamparada y sola, con una vida gris, llena de desoladas perspectivas ante ella.

A Christmas frost had come at midsummer; a white December storm had whirled over June; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed the blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes which last night blushed full of flowers, to-day were pathless with untrodden snow; and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and flagrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and white as pine-forests in wintry Norway.
La nieve de diciembre había caído en medio del verano, el hielo helaba las manzanas maduras, un viento invernal arrancaba de sus tallos las rosas.
Los bosques, que doce horas antes mostrábanse fragantes y espléndidos como tropicales árboles, eran ahora inmensos, solitarios, glaciales como los bosques de pinos en el invierno de Noruega...
My hopes were all dead--struck with a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born in the land of Egypt.
Mis esperanzas habían muerto de repente; mis deseos, el día anterior rebosantes de vida, estaban convertidos en lívidos cadáveres.
I looked on my cherished wishes, yesterday so blooming and glowing; they lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could never revive.

I looked at my love: that feeling which was my master's--which he had created; it shivered in my heart, like a suffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized it; it could not seek Mr. Rochester's arms--it could not derive warmth from his breast.
Y mi amor, aquel sentimiento que Rochester había despertado en mí, yacía, angustiado, en mi corazón, como un niño en una cuna fría.
Ya no podía buscar el brazo de Rochester ni encontrar calor en su pecho.
Oh, never more could it turn to him; for faith was blighted--confidence destroyed!
Mi fe y mi confianza quedaban destruidas.
Mr. Rochester was not to me what he had been; for he was not what I had thought him.
Rochester no volvería a ser para mí lo que fue, porque resultaba distinto a como yo le había imaginado.
I would not ascribe vice to him; I would not say he had betrayed me; but the attribute of stainless truth was gone from his idea, and from his presence I must go: _that_ I perceived well.
No deseaba increparle ni quería reprocharle su traición, pero se me aparecía privado de la sinceridad que yo le atribuyese.
Debía marchar de su lado.
When--how--whither, I could not yet discern; but he himself, I doubted not, would hurry me from Thornfield.
Cuándo y cómo, no lo sabía, pero adivinaba que él mismo me aconsejaría partir de Thornfield.
Real affection, it seemed, he could not have for me; it had been only fitful passion: that was balked; he would want me no more.
Era imposible, a mi juicio, que hubiese sentido hacia mí verdadero afecto; sólo fue, sin duda, un capricho momentáneo.
I should fear even to cross his path now: my view must be hateful to him.
Debía procurar no cruzarme en su camino, porque ahora mi presencia había de resultarle odiosa, sin duda.
Oh, how blind had been my eyes!
¡Oh, qué ciega había estado!
How weak my conduct!
¡Qué débil había sido!
Cerré los ojos.
My eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round me, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow.
La oscuridad me rodeó.
Sentí una inmensa lasitud y parecióme yacer en el lecho de un río seco, sintiendo retumbar entre las lejanas montañas el rumor del torrente que se aproximaba por el cauce.

Self-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, I seemed to have laid me down in the dried-up bed of a great river; I heard a flood loosened in remote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise I had no will, to flee I had no strength.
Pero no deseaba incorporarme ni tenía fuerzas para huir de la riada.
I lay faint, longing to be dead.
Al contrario: ansiaba la muerte.

One idea only still throbbed life-like within me--a remembrance of God: it begot an unuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in my rayless mind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to express them--
En aquel momento pensé en Dios, y mentalmente le dirigí una plegaria:
"Be not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help."
«Ayúdame, ya que nadie me ayudará, en la turbación que me amenaza.»
It was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert it--as I had neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips--it came: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me.
Y la turbación cayó sobre mí.
Todo el peso de aquel torrente que oía avanzar, gravitó sobre mi corazón.
The whole consciousness of my life lorn, my love lost, my hope quenched, my faith death-struck, swayed full and mighty above me in one sullen mass.
La conciencia de mi vida rota, de mi amor perdido, de mi esperanza deshecha, me abrumó como una inmensa masa.
Imposible describir la amargura de aquel momento.
That bitter hour cannot be described: in truth, "the waters came into my soul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters; the floods overflowed me."
Bien puede decirse que «las olas inundaron mi alma, me sentí hundir en el légamo, en el seno de las aguas profundas, y las ondas pasaron sobre mi cabeza».
CHAPTER XXVII
XXVII
Some time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and seeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I asked, "What am I to do?"
Varias veces durante la tarde, mientras el sol declinaba, me pregunté: «¿Qué haré?»
But the answer my mind gave--"Leave Thornfield at once"--was so prompt, so dread, that I stopped my ears.
I said I could not bear such words now.

Pero la respuesta que me daba la razón: «Vete en seguida de Thornfield», me era tan dura de oír, que procuraba tapar los oídos a tal consejo, y me decía: «Lo peor no es que haya dejado de ser la prometida de Edward Rochester.

"That I am not Edward Rochester's bride is the least part of my woe," I alleged: "that I have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and found them all void and vain, is a horror I could bear and master; but that I must leave him decidedly, instantly, entirely, is intolerable.
Este brusco despertar del más bello sueño, este hallar que cuanto imaginara era falso y vano, puedo soportarlo por horroroso que sea.
Pero la idea de abandonarle es, resuelta, indudable y enteramente imposible.
I cannot do it."
No puedo hacerlo.»
But, then, a voice within me averred that I could do it and foretold that I should do it.
Una voz interior me objetaba que sí podía y debía hacerlo.

I wrestled with my own resolution: I wanted to be weak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw laid out for me; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the throat, told her tauntingly, she had yet but dipped her dainty foot in the slough, and swore that with that arm of iron he would thrust her down to unsounded depths of agony.
La conciencia, inexorable, asió la pasión por el cuello, la vituperó, la pisoteó bajo sus pies.
"Let me be torn away," then I cried.
"Let another help me!"
«Déjame buscar la ayuda de alguien», gemí.

"No; you shall tear yourself away, none shall help you: you shall yourself pluck out your right eye; yourself cut off your right hand: your heart shall be the victim, and you the priest to transfix it."
«No; tú sola debes ayudarte; tú debes arrancar, si es necesario, tu ojo derecho y cortar tu propia mano.
Sólo tu corazón debe ser la víctima de tu error.»
I rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a judge haunted,--at the silence which so awful a voice filled.
My head swam as I stood erect.
Me incorporé, aterrorizada de aquella soledad en la que oía pronunciar tan despiadado juicio y del silencio que llenaba aquella inexorable voz.
I perceived that I was sickening from excitement and inanition; neither meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for I had taken no breakfast.
Al ponerme en pie sentí que se me iba la cabeza.
No sólo estaba agotada por la excitación, sino extenuada, ya que no había comido ni bebido nada en todo el día.

And, with a strange pang, I now reflected that, long as I had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask how I was, or to invite me to come down: not even little Adele had tapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought me.
Y entonces reparé en que nadie había venido a verme, ni preguntado por mí.
Ni Adéle había llamado a mi puerta, ni Mrs.
Fairfax me había avisado para comer.
"Friends always forget those whom fortune forsakes," I murmured, as I undrew the bolt and passed out.
«Los amigos siempre olvidan a quienes olvida la fortuna», pensé.
Descorrí el cerrojo y salí.
I stumbled over an obstacle: my head was still dizzy, my sight was dim, and my limbs were feeble.
Tropecé con un obstáculo y estuve a punto de caer.
I could not soon recover myself.
Me sentía débil y mareada.
I fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm caught me.
Un brazo vigoroso me sujetó.
I looked up--I was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a chair across my chamber threshold.
"You come out at last," he said.
Rochester, sentado en una silla, se hallaba ante el umbral de mi habitación.
-Al fin sales -dijo-.
Hace mucho que espero y escucho.
"Well, I have been waiting for you long, and listening: yet not one movement have I heard, nor one sob: five minutes more of that death-like hush, and I should have forced the lock like a burglar.
Ni un movimiento, ni un solo sollozo he sentido.
¡Cinco minutos más de esta espera intolerable y habría forzado la puerta, como un ladrón!
So you shun me?--you shut yourself up and grieve alone!
I would rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence.
You are passionate.
I expected a scene of some kind.
¡Oh, preferiría que me apostrofases de vehemencia, que tus lágrimas manaran sobre mi pecho!
I was prepared for the hot rain of tears; only I wanted them to be shed on my breast: now a senseless floor has received them, or your drenched handkerchief.
But I err: you have not wept at all!
Pero me he equivocado.
¡No lloras!
I see a white cheek and a faded eye, but no trace of tears.
Tu rostro está pálido y tus ojos marchitos, pero en ellos no hay huellas de lágrimas.
I suppose, then, your heart has been weeping blood?"
Temo que sea tu corazón el que haya vertido lágrimas de sangre...
"Well, Jane! not a word of reproach?
Dime algo, Jane.
¿No me reprochas?
Nothing bitter--nothing poignant?
¿No se te ocurre nada ofensivo que decirme?
Nothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion?
You sit quietly where I have placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look."
Te veo inmóvil, pasiva, mirándome con serenidad...
"Jane, I never meant to wound you thus.
No me propuse herirte, Jane.

If the man who had but one little ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of his bread and drank of his cup, and lay in his bosom, had by some mistake slaughtered it at the shambles, he would not have rued his bloody blunder more than I now rue mine.
Estoy en la situación del pastor que tuviera una oveja, a la que quisiera como si fuera su hija, con quien compartiera su pan y su agua, y a la que un día degollara por error.
Sí, ése es mi estado de alma...
Will you ever forgive me?"
¿No me perdonarás nunca?
Reader, I forgave him at the moment and on the spot.
¡Le perdoné en aquel mismo momento, lector!

There was such deep remorse in his eye, such true pity in his tone, such manly energy in his manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in his whole look and mien--I forgave him all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only at my heart's core.
¡Había tan profundo remordimiento en sus ojos, tan sincera compasión en su acento y, sobre todo, tan inalterable amor en él y en mí!
Sí; le perdoné con todo mi corazón, aunque no lo expresase con palabras.
"You know I am a scoundrel, Jane?" ere long he inquired wistfully--wondering, I suppose, at my continued silence and tameness, the result rather of weakness than of will.
-¿Sabes que soy un canalla, Jane? -me preguntó, tras un largo silencio, atribuyendo, sin duda, mi silencio y mi calma más al abatimiento que a mi propia voluntad.
"Yes, sir."
-Sí.
"Then tell me so roundly and sharply--don't spare me."
-Dímelo, pues, con franqueza, con dureza.
No calles nada.
"I cannot: I am tired and sick.
-No puedo.
I want some water."
Me siento muy enferma y cansada.
He heaved a sort of shuddering sigh, and taking me in his arms, carried me downstairs.
Tengo sed...
Emitió un profundo suspiro y, tomándome en sus brazos, me hizo bajar las escaleras.
No me di cuenta al principio de adónde me llevaba.
At first I did not know to what room he had borne me; all was cloudy to my glazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for, summer as it was, I had become icy cold in my chamber.
Luego sentí el estimulante calor del fuego.
A pesar de estar en verano, me sentía fría como el hielo.
He put wine to my lips; I tasted it and revived; then I ate something he offered me, and was soon myself.
Me ofreció una copa de vino y me sentí revivir.
Comí algo que me dio y recuperé totalmente mis energías.
I was in the library--sitting in his chair--he was quite near.
Me encontré en la biblioteca, sentada en el sillón donde él solía sentarse.

"If I could go out of life now, without too sharp a pang, it would be well for me," I thought; "then I should not have to make the effort of cracking my heart-strings in rending them from among Mr. Rochester's.
Rochester estaba a mi lado.
Pensé que me valdría más morir en aquel momento.
I must leave him, it appears.
I do not want to leave him--I cannot leave him."
"How are you now, Jane?"
Sabía que debía abandonarle, y, sin embargo, no quería, no podía hacerlo. -¿Cómo estás ahora, Jane?
"Much better, sir; I shall be well soon."
-Mucho mejor.
"Taste the wine again, Jane."
-Toma más vino.
I obeyed him; then he put the glass on the table, stood before me, and looked at me attentively.
Le obedecí.
Dejé el vaso en la mesa y me miró con detenimiento.

Suddenly he turned away, with an inarticulate exclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; he walked fast through the room and came back; he stooped towards me as if to kiss me; but I remembered caresses were now forbidden.
I turned my face away and put his aside.
Se volvió de repente, lanzando una vehemente exclamación, comenzó a pasear por el cuarto y al fin se inclinó hacia mí como para besarme.
Recordando que ahora las caricias estaban prohibidas entre nosotros, aparté el rostro.
"What!--How is this?" he exclaimed hastily.
-¡Cómo! -exclamó Rochester.
"Oh, I know! you won't kiss the husband of Bertha Mason?
Y agregó amargamente-: Ya: no quieres besar al marido de Bertha Mason.
You consider my arms filled and my embraces appropriated?"
Supongo que consideras que con las caricias de ella tengo bastante.
"At any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, sir."
"Why, Jane?
I will spare you the trouble of much talking; I will answer for you--Because I have a wife already, you would reply.--I guess rightly?"
"Yes."

"If you think so, you must have a strange opinion of me; you must regard me as a plotting profligate--a base and low rake who has been simulating disinterested love in order to draw you into a snare deliberately laid, and strip you of honour and rob you of self-respect.
Me tienes sin duda por un odioso intrigante que me preparaba a hacerte perder el honor y el decoro.
What do you say to that?

I see you can say nothing in the first place, you are faint still, and have enough to do to draw your breath; in the second place, you cannot yet accustom yourself to accuse and revile me, and besides, the flood-gates of tears are opened, and they would rush out if you spoke much; and you have no desire to expostulate, to upbraid, to make a scene: you are thinking how _to act_--_talking_ you consider is of no use.

Si no lo dices es: primero porque te faltan las fuerzas, segundo porque no te acostumbras a la idea de acusarme e increparme y, en fin, porque las puertas de tus lágrimas están abiertas y si hablases mucho romperías en llanto.
Sé que no quieres llorar, explicarte, hacer una escena, sino que te propones, en vez de hablar, actuar.
I know you--I am on my guard."
Lo sé.
Estoy preparado a ello.
"Sir, I do not wish to act against you," I said; and my unsteady voice warned me to curtail my sentence.
-No deseo proceder contra usted -dije con entrecortada voz.
"Not in your sense of the word, but in mine you are scheming to destroy me.
-En el sentido que tú das a las palabras, no; pero en el que yo le doy, sí.
Te aprestas a aniquilarme.
You have as good as said that I am a married man--as a married man you will shun me, keep out of my way: just now you have refused to kiss me.
Piensas que, puesto que soy un hombre casado, debes apartarte de mi camino.
Por eso ahora no has querido besarme.

You intend to make yourself a complete stranger to me: to live under this roof only as Adele's governess; if ever I say a friendly word to you, if ever a friendly feeling inclines you again to me, you will say,--'That man had nearly made me his mistress: I must be ice and rock to him;' and ice and rock you will accordingly become."
Te propones convertirte para mí en una extraña, vivir bajo mi mismo techo exclusivamente como institutriz de Adèle, rechazando mis palabras y mis aproximaciones como si fueras de piedra y de hielo.

I cleared and steadied my voice to reply: "All is changed about me, sir; I must change too--there is no doubt of that; and to avoid fluctuations of feeling, and continual combats with recollections and associations, there is only one way--Adele must have a new governess, sir."
-Señor -repuse-: todo ha cambiado para mí de tal forma que, para evitar enojosos recuerdos e ideas tristes, es preciso que busque usted una nueva institutriz para Adèle.

"Oh, Adele will go to school--I have settled that already; nor do I mean to torment you with the hideous associations and recollections of Thornfield Hall--this accursed place--this tent of Achan--this insolent vault, offering the ghastliness of living death to the light of the open sky--this narrow stone hell, with its one real fiend, worse than a legion of such as we imagine.
-Adèle irá a un colegio.
Jane, you shall not stay here, nor will I. I was wrong ever to bring you to Thornfield Hall, knowing as I did how it was haunted.
No deseo atormentarte reteniéndote en Thornfield Hall.

I charged them to conceal from you, before I ever saw you, all knowledge of the curse of the place; merely because I feared Adele never would have a governess to stay if she knew with what inmate she was housed, and my plans would not permit me to remove the maniac elsewhere--though I possess an old house, Ferndean Manor, even more retired and hidden than this, where I could have lodged her safely enough, had not a scruple about the unhealthiness of the situation, in the heart of a wood, made my conscience recoil from the arrangement.
Y ahora debo decirte que, si al principio oculté la existencia de una perturbada aquí, era porque temía que ninguna institutriz hubiera querido residir en una casa en esas condiciones.

Cierto que yo podía haber llevado a la loca a otro sitio aún más escondido que poseo: Ferndean Manor, cuya insalubre situación en el corazón de un bosque tal vez me hubiera librado tan pronto de esa carga que arrastro.
Probably those damp walls would soon have eased me of her charge: but to each villain his own vice; and mine is not a tendency to indirect assassination, even of what I most hate.
Pero por perversas que sean mis inclinaciones, la de acometer un asesinato indirecto no figura entre ellas.
"Concealing the mad-woman's neighbourhood from you, however, was something like covering a child with a cloak and laying it down near a upas-tree: that demon's vicinage is poisoned, and always was.
Ocultarte la existencia de esa loca era inútil, lo reconozco...
Toda la casa, toda la vecindad, está emponzoñada con su presencia.

But I'll shut up Thornfield Hall: I'll nail up the front door and board the lower windows: I'll give Mrs. Poole two hundred a year to live here with _my wife_, as you term that fearful hag: Grace will do much for money, and she shall have her son, the keeper at Grimsby Retreat, to bear her company and be at hand to give her aid in the paroxysms, when _my wife_ is prompted by her familiar to burn people in their beds at night, to stab them, to bite their flesh from their bones, and so on--"
Pago doscientas libras al año a Grace Poole para que custodie a esa bruja infernal que tú llamas mi mujer.
Y dentro de poco, su hijo, que es celador en el asilo de Grimsby, vendrá a ayudarle en su tarea de vigilar a mi mujer cuando sufre esos paroxismos en cuyo curso incendia camas, muerde y...
"Sir," I interrupted him, "you are inexorable for that unfortunate lady: you speak of her with hate--with vindictive antipathy.
It is cruel--she cannot help being mad."
-Es usted implacable con esa desventurada señora -interrumpí-.
La menciona usted con aversión y odio, como si ella tuviese la culpa de su locura.
"Jane, my little darling (so I will call you, for so you are), you don't know what you are talking about; you misjudge me again: it is not because she is mad I hate her.
-Jane, queridita (y perdona que te llame así, porque para mí lo eres), me juzgas mal.
If you were mad, do you think I should hate you?"
¿Crees que yo te odiaría si tú estuvieses loca?
"I do indeed, sir."
-Sin duda.
"Then you are mistaken, and you know nothing about me, and nothing about the sort of love of which I am capable.
-Te engañas.
Ignoras cómo soy, la clase de amor que soy capaz de experimentar.
Every atom of your flesh is as dear to me as my own: in pain and sickness it would still be dear.
Te quiero más que a mí mismo, y si sufrieses, te querría más aún.
Tu inteligencia es mi tesoro y si se perturbase me serías todavía más amada.

Your mind is my treasure, and if it were broken, it would be my treasure still: if you raved, my arms should confine you, and not a strait waistcoat--your grasp, even in fury, would have a charm for me: if you flew at me as wildly as that woman did this morning, I should receive you in an embrace, at least as fond as it would be restrictive.
Aunque enloquecieses, aunque te lanzases sobre mí como esa mujer esta mañana, te recibiría con un abrazo.
No me apartaría de ti con horror, como de ella, y nadie te cuidaría más que yo mismo.

I should not shrink from you with disgust as I did from her: in your quiet moments you should have no watcher and no nurse but me; and I could hang over you with untiring tenderness, though you gave me no smile in return; and never weary of gazing into your eyes, though they had no longer a ray of recognition for me.
Y no sería menos tierno para ti aunque no me dedicases una sonrisa ni me reconocieran tus ojos.
Pero no sigamos hablando de eso.
--But why do I follow that train of ideas?
I was talking of removing you from Thornfield.
Yo me refería a hacerte partir de Thornfield.
All, you know, is prepared for prompt departure: to-morrow you shall go.
Todo está preparado para tu marcha.
Mañana puedes irte.
I only ask you to endure one more night under this roof, Jane; and then, farewell to its miseries and terrors for ever!
Sólo te pido que pases una noche más bajo este techo y luego ¡adiós miserias y terrores!
I have a place to repair to, which will be a secure sanctuary from hateful reminiscences, from unwelcome intrusion--even from falsehood and slander."
No faltará un lugar que sea como un santuario donde refugiarse y olvidar los resultados odiosos...
"And take Adele with you, sir," I interrupted; "she will be a companion for you."
-Quédese con Adèle -interrumpí-: será una compañera para usted.
"What do you mean, Jane?
I told you I would send Adele to school; and what do I want with a child for a companion, and not my own child,--a French dancer's bastard?
-Ya te he dicho que la enviaré a un colegio.
¿Para qué me sirve la compañía de una niña?
Why do you importune me about her!
¡Y ni siquiera mi propia hija, sino la bastarda de una bailarina francesa!
I say, why do you assign Adele to me for a companion?"
¿Por qué me importunas aconsejándome que la conserve en mi compañía?
"You spoke of a retirement, sir; and retirement and solitude are dull: too dull for you."
-Porque hablaba usted de retirarse, y la soledad y el retiro no serán beneficiosos para usted.
"Solitude! solitude!" he reiterated with irritation.
-¡Soledad! -repitió él, con irritación-.
"I see I must come to an explanation.
Es preciso que nos expliquemos.
I don't know what sphynx-like expression is forming in your countenance.
No sé lo que significa la expresión enigmática de tu rostro, pero lo que yo me propongo, sí lo sé.
You are to share my solitude.
Do you understand?"
Tú compartirás mi soledad.
I shook my head: it required a degree of courage, excited as he was becoming, even to risk that mute sign of dissent.
Moví negativamente la cabeza.
Hacía falta cierto valor para manifestar aquella oposición, dado lo excitado que él se encontraba.
He had been walking fast about the room, and he stopped, as if suddenly rooted to one spot.
Interrumpió sus paseos, se detuvo ante mí y me miró.
He looked at me long and hard: I turned my eyes from him, fixed them on the fire, and tried to assume and maintain a quiet, collected aspect.
Separé mis ojos de los suyos y los fijé en el fuego, esforzándome en adoptar un aspecto sereno y recogido.
"Now for the hitch in Jane's character," he said at last, speaking more calmly than from his look I had expected him to speak.
-Ya hemos tropezado con una dificultad de tu temperamento -dijo con más calma de la que cabía esperar de su aspecto-.
"The reel of silk has run smoothly enough so far; but I always knew there would come a knot and a puzzle: here it is.
Hasta ahora tu carácter iba devanándose suavemente como un carrete de seda, pero yo sabía que alguna vez habríamos de encontrar un nudo...
Now for vexation, and exasperation, and endless trouble!
¡Y ya lo tenemos aquí!
By God!
I long to exert a fraction of Samson's strength, and break the entanglement like tow!"
He recommenced his walk, but soon again stopped, and this time just before me.
Volvió a pasear, se paró en seguida y me habló acercando su boca a mi oído.
"Jane! will you hear reason?" (he stooped and approached his lips to my ear); "because, if you won't, I'll try violence."
-Jane, ¿quieres oír la voz de la razón?
¡Porque, si no, emplearé la violencia!
His voice was hoarse; his look that of a man who is just about to burst an insufferable bond and plunge headlong into wild license.
Su voz, su aspecto, eran los de un hombre que ha llegado al límite de lo que puede soportar y está dispuesto a entregarse a cualquier exceso.
I saw that in another moment, and with one impetus of frenzy more, I should be able to do nothing with him.
En otro momento, no hubiera estado en mi mano dominarle.
The present--the passing second of time--was all I had in which to control and restrain him--a movement of repulsion, flight, fear would have sealed my doom,--and his.
Ahora comprendí que un movimiento cualquiera, fuese de temor, de repulsión, o de huida, hubiese producido consecuencias irreparables.
Yo no le temía.
But I was not afraid: not in the least.
Me sentía fortalecida por una fuerza misteriosa.
I felt an inward power; a sense of influence, which supported me.
The crisis was perilous; but not without its charm: such as the Indian, perhaps, feels when he slips over the rapid in his canoe.
La situación era expuesta, pero no dejaba de tener cierto atractivo, análogo a la emoción que deben experimentar los indios cuando remontan una torrentera en sus frágiles canoas.
I took hold of his clenched hand, loosened the contorted fingers, and said to him, soothingly--
Cogí la mano de Rochester, y le dije, suavemente:
"Sit down; I'll talk to you as long as you like, and hear all you have to say, whether reasonable or unreasonable."
-Siéntese, hable lo que quiera y diga cuanto le plazca, sea razonable o no.
He sat down: but he did not get leave to speak directly.
Se sentó, mas no habló inmediatamente.
I had been struggling with tears for some time: I had taken great pains to repress them, because I knew he would not like to see me weep.
Now, however, I considered it well to let them flow as freely and as long as they liked.
If the flood annoyed him, so much the better.
Hasta entonces yo había reprimido mis lágrimas, temiendo que le disgustasen, pero ahora no tenía por qué contenerlas.
So I gave way and cried heartily.
Soon I heard him earnestly entreating me to be composed.
Si le desagradaban, tanto mejor.
I said I could not while he was in such a passion.
Oí su voz diciéndome que no sollozara.
"But I am not angry, Jane: I only love you too well; and you had steeled your little pale face with such a resolute, frozen look, I could not endure it.
Repuse que no me era posible dejar de llorar mientras le viera en aquel estado. -No estoy furioso contra ti, Jane.
Como te quiero mucho no he podido soportar la expresión resuelta y helada de tu rostro.
Hush, now, and wipe your eyes."
Vamos, sécate las lágrimas.
His softened voice announced that he was subdued; so I, in my turn, became calm.
La aumentada dulzura de su voz me hizo comprender que se había tranquilizado.
Now he made an effort to rest his head on my shoulder, but I would not permit it.
Me tranquilicé, pues, a mi vez.
Él trató de apoyar su cabeza sobre mi hombro, pero no se lo permití.
Then he would draw me to him: no.
Trató de atraerme hacia sí.
Me negué.
"Jane!
Jane!" he said, in such an accent of bitter sadness it thrilled along every nerve I had; "you don't love me, then?
-Jane, Jane -dijo con tan amarga tristeza que me hizo estremecer hasta el fondo de mi alma-, no me quieres ¿verdad?
It was only my station, and the rank of my wife, that you valued?
No deseabas ser mi mujer sino por las ventajas que te traía, ¿eh?
Now that you think me disqualified to become your husband, you recoil from my touch as if I were some toad or ape."
Ahora que me consideras imposible como marido, te repugna mi contacto como el de un sapo o un mono.
These words cut me: yet what could I do or I say?
Aquellas palabras me hirieron.
I ought probably to have done or said nothing; but I was so tortured by a sense of remorse at thus hurting his feelings, I could not control the wish to drop balm where I had wounded.
¿Qué podía contestarle?
Probablemente lo mejor hubiera sido no decir ni hacer nada, pero no pude contener el deseo de calmar su dolor:
"I _do_ love you," I said, "more than ever: but I must not show or indulge the feeling: and this is the last time I must express it."
-Le quiero -dije- más que nunca.
Se lo digo por última vez, porque no puedo permitirme ese sentimiento.
"The last time, Jane!
-¡Por última vez, Jane!
What! do you think you can live with me, and see me daily, and yet, if you still love me, be always cold and distant?"
¿Es posible que pienses vivir a mi lado, verme a diario y mantenerte siempre fría y distante de mí?
"No, sir; that I am certain I could not; and therefore I see there is but one way: but you will be furious if I mention it."
-No, eso no sería posible.
Sólo cabe una solución, pero temo enfurecerle si la menciono.
"Oh, mention it!
-¡Menciónala!
If I storm, you have the art of weeping."
Tú sabes calmar mis exaltaciones.
"Mr. Rochester, I must leave you."
-Mr.
Rochester, es preciso que me separe de usted.
"For how long, Jane?
-¿Por cuánto tiempo?
For a few minutes, while you smooth your hair--which is somewhat dishevelled; and bathe your face--which looks feverish?"
Supongo que por el preciso para peinarte, porque estás desmelenada, y para lavarte, porque tienes la cara ardiendo.
"I must leave Adele and Thornfield.
I must part with you for my whole life: I must begin a new existence among strange faces and strange scenes."
-Tengo que irme de Thornfield, separarme de usted para siempre, y empezar una nueva vida en otro ambiente y entre otras personas.
"Of course: I told you you should.
-Lo mismo creo, prescindiendo a la locura de alejarte de mí.
I pass over the madness about parting from me.
You mean you must become a part of me.
Iremos a sitios donde no nos conozcan y serás, de hecho y ante el mundo, mi mujer.
As to the new existence, it is all right: you shall yet be my wife: I am not married.
You shall be Mrs. Rochester--both virtually and nominally.
Te tendré a mi lado y no me separaré de ti mientras viva.
I shall keep only to you so long as you and I live.
You shall go to a place I have in the south of France: a whitewashed villa on the shores of the Mediterranean.
Iremos a algún sitio del sur de Francia; viviremos en una villa blanca, frente al Mediterráneo.
There you shall live a happy, and guarded, and most innocent life.
Y allí llevaremos una vida honorable, segura y feliz.
Never fear that I wish to lure you into error--to make you my mistress.
No veas egoísmo en mí, no creas que trato de hacerte mi amante.
Why did you shake your head?
¿Por qué mueves la cabeza, Jane?
Jane, you must be reasonable, or in truth I shall again become frantic."
Debes ser razonable.
De lo contrario, volveré a ponerme frenético.
His voice and hand quivered: his large nostrils dilated; his eye blazed: still I dared to speak.
Temblaban su voz y sus dedos, las aletas de su nariz se dilataban, sus ojos despedían lumbre.
Sin embargo, me atrevía a contestar:
"Sir, your wife is living: that is a fact acknowledged this morning by yourself.
If I lived with you as you desire, I should then be your mistress: to say otherwise is sophistical--is false."
-Su mujer existe, como usted mismo ha reconocido, y si yo viviese con usted en la forma que se indica, no sería más que su amante.
"Jane, I am not a gentle-tempered man--you forget that: I am not long- enduring; I am not cool and dispassionate.
-Jane: no soy un hombre de buen carácter; no soy capaz de soportar mucho; no soy desapasionado y frío.
Out of pity to me and yourself, put your finger on my pulse, feel how it throbs, and--beware!"
Toca mi pulso.
Me presentó la muñeca.
He bared his wrist, and offered it to me: the blood was forsaking his cheek and lips, they were growing livid; I was distressed on all hands.
La sangre había huido de sus mejillas y sus labios, lívidos a la sazón,.y parecía afluir en tumulto a sus manos.
To agitate him thus deeply, by a resistance he so abhorred, was cruel: to yield was out of the question.
Hacerle sufrir con una negativa implacable era cruel, tratar de tranquilizarle era imposible, y complacerle, más aún.
I did what human beings do instinctively when they are driven to utter extremity--looked for aid to one higher than man: the words "God help me!" burst involuntarily from my lips.
Hice, pues, lo que todos los seres humanos en tales extremos.
Las palabras «¡Dios me ayude!» brotaron, casi voluntariamente, de mis labios.
"I am a fool!" cried Mr. Rochester suddenly.
"I keep telling her I am not married, and do not explain to her why.
-¡Qué necio soy! -exclamó Rochester súbitamente-.
I forget she knows nothing of the character of that woman, or of the circumstances attending my infernal union with her.
No te he explicado aún las circunstancias en que me uní a esa infernal mujer ni su carácter.
Oh, I am certain Jane will agree with me in opinion, when she knows all that I know!
Cuando lo sepas todo, Jane, estoy seguro de que concordarás conmigo.
Just put your hand in mine, Janet--that I may have the evidence of touch as well as sight, to prove you are near me--and I will in a few words show you the real state of the case.
Pon tu mano en la mía para sentirme seguro de tu proximidad y en pocas palabras te lo explicaré todo.
Can you listen to me?"
¿Me escucharás?
"Yes, sir; for hours if you will."
-Le escucharé cuanto quiera, aunque sea varias horas.
"I ask only minutes.
-Bastan unos minutos.
Jane, did you ever hear or know that I was not the eldest son of my house: that I had once a brother older than I?"
¿Has oído decir, Jane, que yo no era el primogénito de mi familia, sino que tenía un hermano mayor?
"I remember Mrs. Fairfax told me so once."
-Mrs.
Fairfax me lo dijo una vez.
"And did you ever hear that my father was an avaricious, grasping man?"
-¿Y sabes también que mi padre era un hombre avaro, sórdido?
"I have understood something to that effect."
-Algo de eso he oído.

"Well, Jane, being so, it was his resolution to keep the property together; he could not bear the idea of dividing his estate and leaving me a fair portion: all, he resolved, should go to my brother, Rowland.
-Bien: entonces no te extrañará saber que no quería distribuir sus propiedades dándome una parte a mí.
Yet as little could he endure that a son of his should be a poor man.
I must be provided for by a wealthy marriage.
Como, por otro lado, tampoco querría que un hijo suyo fuese un pordiosero, arregló para mí un matrimonio con una mujer rica.
He sought me a partner betimes.
Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was his old acquaintance.
Tenía en las Antillas un antiguo amigo: Mason, un plantador de Jamaica.
He was certain his possessions were real and vast: he made inquiries.
Mi padre sabía que sus posesiones eran muy importantes.
Mr. Mason, he found, had a son and daughter; and he learned from him that he could and would give the latter a fortune of thirty thousand pounds: that sufficed.
Mason tenía un hijo y una hija y dotaba a ésta con treinta mil libras.
A mi padre le pareció bastante.
When I left college, I was sent out to Jamaica, to espouse a bride already courted for me.
Cuando salí del colegio me enviaron a Jamaica.
My father said nothing about her money; but he told me Miss Mason was the boast of Spanish Town for her beauty: and this was no lie.
Mi padre no me había hablado de la fortuna de mi futura mujer, pero me había dicho que era la beldad más cortejada de la isla, y en eso no mentía.
I found her a fine woman, in the style of Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic.
A mí me pareció una bella mujer, alta, morena, majestuosa, por el estilo de Blanche Ingram.
Her family wished to secure me because I was of a good race; and so did she.
Su familia deseaba asegurarme, porque yo pertenecía a una casta ilustre, y lo consiguieron.
They showed her to me in parties, splendidly dressed.
I seldom saw her alone, and had very little private conversation with her.
Me invitaban, me hacían ver a Bertha Mason en reuniones en las que descollaba por sus espléndidos atavíos.
Raras veces hablábamos a solas.
She flattered me, and lavishly displayed for my pleasure her charms and accomplishments.
Bertha me lisonjeaba todo lo que podía.
All the men in her circle seemed to admire her and envy me.
Cuantos hombres giraban en torno suyo la admiraban a ella y me envidiaban a mí.
I was dazzled, stimulated: my senses were excited; and being ignorant, raw, and inexperienced, I thought I loved her.
Excitado por su atractivo, inexperto como era entonces, pensé estar enamorado de ella.
There is no folly so besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience, the rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a man to its commission.
Las estúpidas rivalidades juveniles, la ceguera de la poca edad, son lo que más influye en estos casos.
Her relatives encouraged me; competitors piqued me; she allured me: a marriage was achieved almost before I knew where I was.
Su familia me alentaba, los competidores que tenía aguijoneaban mi amor propio, y, en resumen, me casé con ella sin conocerla casi.
Oh, I have no respect for myself when I think of that act!--an agony of inward contempt masters me.
¡Cuánto me desprecio a mí mismo al pensarlo!
I never loved, I never esteemed, I did not even know her.

I was not sure of the existence of one virtue in her nature: I had marked neither modesty, nor benevolence, nor candour, nor refinement in her mind or manners--and, I married her:--gross, grovelling, mole-eyed blockhead that I was!
Yo no la amaba, ignoraba si era virtuosa o no, no había apreciado en su carácter ni bondad, ni modestia, ni candor, ni delicadeza... ¡y, sin embargo, me casé!
With less sin I might have--But let me remember to whom I am speaking."
¡Oh, qué estúpido fui!
"My bride's mother I had never seen: I understood she was dead.
»No había visto nunca a la madre de mi novia, y la creía muerta.
The honeymoon over, I learned my mistake; she was only mad, and shut up in a lunatic asylum.
Cuando transcurrió la luna de miel, comprendí mi error: mi suegra estaba loca, en un manicomio.
There was a younger brother, too--a complete dumb idiot.
Mi mujer tenía un hermano menor completamente idiota.

The elder one, whom you have seen (and whom I cannot hate, whilst I abhor all his kindred, because he has some grains of affection in his feeble mind, shown in the continued interest he takes in his wretched sister, and also in a dog-like attachment he once bore me), will probably be in the same state one day.

El mayor es el que conoces, y a quien no puedo odiar, aunque abomine de toda su casta, porque en su débil cerebro hay algunos elementos afectuosos, que prueba con su cariño a su hermana y con la adhesión, casi de perro leal, que siente hacia mí.
No obstante, probablemente acabará perdiendo la razón por completo.
My father and my brother Rowland knew all this; but they thought only of the thirty thousand pounds, and joined in the plot against me."
Mi padre y mi hermano Rowland conocían todo esto, pero no pensaron más que en las treinta mil libras y se pusieron de acuerdo para hacerme contraer aquel matrimonio.

"These were vile discoveries; but except for the treachery of concealment, I should have made them no subject of reproach to my wife, even when I found her nature wholly alien to mine, her tastes obnoxious to me, her cast of mind common, low, narrow, and singularly incapable of being led to anything higher, expanded to anything larger--
»Aun descubiertas estas cosas, yo, pese a la ocultación que representaban, no había reprochado nada a mi mujer.
Pero su carácter era absolutamente opuesto al mío, sus gustos discrepantes de los que yo tenía.
Su mentalidad baja, vulgar, mezquina, era incapaz de comprender nada grande.
Pronto encontré imposible pasar una velada, ni siquiera una hora, a su lado y sentirme a gusto.
Entre nosotros no cabía una conversación agradable.

when I found that I could not pass a single evening, nor even a single hour of the day with her in comfort; that kindly conversation could not be sustained between us, because whatever topic I started, immediately received from her a turn at once coarse and trite, perverse and imbecile--when I perceived that I should never have a quiet or settled household, because no servant would bear the continued outbreaks of her violent and unreasonable temper, or the vexations of her absurd, contradictory, exacting orders--even then I restrained myself: I eschewed upbraiding, I curtailed remonstrance; I tried to devour my repentance and disgust in secret; I repressed the deep antipathy I felt.
A cuanto yo hablaba respondía con contestaciones groseras y chabacanas, perversas y estúpidas.
Ningún criado paraba en la casa, porque no podían soportar los arrebatos de mal carácter de mi mujer, sus abusos ni sus órdenes absurdas y contradictorias.
Con todo, yo devoraba mi disgusto, procurando ocultar la antipatía que ella me inspiraba.
"Jane, I will not trouble you with abominable details: some strong words shall express what I have to say.
»No quiero disgustarte con detalles odiosos, Jane; vale más resumir.

I lived with that woman upstairs four years, and before that time she had tried me indeed: her character ripened and developed with frightful rapidity; her vices sprang up fast and rank: they were so strong, only cruelty could check them, and I would not use cruelty.
Viví con esa mujer más de cuatro años y en tal lapso su perverso carácter y sus malas inclinaciones se desarrollaron con increíble rapidez.
What a pigmy intellect she had, and what giant propensities!
How fearful were the curses those propensities entailed on me!
Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother, dragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must attend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.
Bertha Mason, digna hija de una madre degenerada, me hizo sufrir todas las torturas, todas las agonías que cabía esperar de su temperamento inmoderado y vicioso.
"My brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years my father died too.
»Mi hermano había muerto entre tanto y, al final de aquellos cuatro años, mi padre murió también.
I was rich enough now--yet poor to hideous indigence: a nature the most gross, impure, depraved I ever saw, was associated with mine, and called by the law and by society a part of me.
Yo era rico, aunque espiritualmente pobre, puesto que sufría la odiosa miseria de soportar la compañía del ser más degradado y abominable que conociera jamás, y que era mi esposa ante la ley.
And I could not rid myself of it by any legal proceedings: for the doctors now discovered that _my wife_ was mad--her excesses had prematurely developed the germs of insanity.
Ni siquiera podía librarme de ella por procedimientos legales, porque los médicos acababan de descubrir que estaba loca.
Sus excesos habían acelerado su insania...
Jane, you don't like my narrative; you look almost sick--shall I defer the rest to another day?"
Pero veo, Jane, que mi narración te deprime.
¿Prefieres que la terminemos otro día?
"No, sir, finish it now; I pity you--I do earnestly pity you."
-No, terminemos ahora.

"Pity, Jane, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of tribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those who offer it; but that is the sort of pity native to callous, selfish hearts; it is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed with ignorant contempt for those who have endured them.

Me da usted mucha lástima. -Algunas personas, Jane, consideran ofensivo que les tengan lástima, porque cierta clase de compasión -la que experimentan los corazones endurecidos y egoístas- es una híbrida mezcla de disgusto por lo que les disgusta y de satisfacción por el mal ajeno.

But that is not your pity, Jane; it is not the feeling of which your whole face is full at this moment--with which your eyes are now almost overflowing--with which your heart is heaving--with which your hand is trembling in mine.
Pero tu piedad no es de esa especie: lo siento en la expresión de tus ojos, en el temblor de tus manos, en los latidos de tu corazón.
Your pity, my darling, is the suffering mother of love: its anguish is the very natal pang of the divine passion.
I accept it, Jane; let the daughter have free advent--my arms wait to receive her."
Tu compasión hacia mí, querida, es hija de tu amor y la acepto con los brazos abiertos.
"Now, sir, proceed; what did you do when you found she was mad?"
-Continúe.
¿Qué hizo usted cuando supo que su mujer estaba loca?
"Jane, I approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was all that intervened between me and the gulf.
-Me hallaba al borde de la desesperación.

In the eyes of the world, I was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but I resolved to be clean in my own sight--and to the last I repudiated the contamination of her crimes, and wrenched myself from connection with her mental defects.
A los ojos del mundo yo estaba evidentemente cubierto de deshonor, pero resolví absolverme ante mí mismo rompiendo todo lazo con ella.

Still, society associated my name and person with hers; I yet saw her and heard her daily: something of her breath (faugh!) mixed with the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been her husband--that recollection was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to me; moreover, I knew that while she lived I could never be the husband of another and better wife; and, though five years my senior (her family and her father had lied to me even in the particular of her age), she was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as she was infirm in mind.

La sociedad unía mi nombre al suyo, yo la veía a diario, respiraba el aire que su aliento contaminaba y, además, era su esposo -lo que me resultaba más odioso que nada- y sabía que mientras viviera, no podría unirme a una mujer mejor que ella.
Tenía cinco años más que yo -su familia me había ocultado ese detalle-, pero físicamente estaba tan robusta como mentalmente enferma.
Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.
De modo que, a los veintiséis años de edad, yo era un hombre desesperado.
»Una noche me despertaron sus aullidos.

"One night I had been awakened by her yells--(since the medical men had pronounced her mad, she had, of course, been shut up)--it was a fiery West Indian night; one of the description that frequently precede the hurricanes of those climates.
(Desde que fuera declarada loca la teníamos encerrada, naturalmente.)
Era una bochornosa noche antillana, y se sentía en el ambiente caliginoso la proximidad de un huracán.
Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up and opened the window.
No pudiendo dormir, me levanté y abrí la ventana.
The air was like sulphur-steams--I could find no refreshment anywhere.
El aire tormentoso olía a azufre.
Infinitos mosquitos invadieron mi cuarto.

Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly round the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull like an earthquake--black clouds were casting up over it; the moon was setting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball--she threw her last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of tempest.
Se oía el rumor del mar como un terremoto, negras nubes cubrían el cielo y la luna, roja y enorme como una ardiente bala de cañón, se reflejaba en las olas.
El ambiente y la atmósfera pesada influían en mi ánimo.
En mis oídos sonaban los gritos de la perturbada.

I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and my ears were filled with the curses the maniac still shrieked out; wherein she momentarily mingled my name with such a tone of demon-hate, with such language!--no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary than she: though two rooms off, I heard every word--the thin partitions of the West India house opposing but slight obstruction to her wolfish cries.
Súbitamente la oí pronunciar mi nombre con demoníaco acento de odio y percibí su abominable lenguaje.
Aunque dormía dos cuartos más allá del mío, el estilo de construcción de las casas de aquel país no permitía ahogar sus aullidos de loba.
"'This life,' said I at last, 'is hell: this is the air--those are the sounds of the bottomless pit!
»Pensé que aquella vida era un infierno y aquellos gritos los lamentos terroríficos de los condenados.
I have a right to deliver myself from it if I can.
Tengo derecho a librarme de esto, si puedo -reflexioné-.
The sufferings of this mortal state will leave me with the heavy flesh that now cumbers my soul.
Y sin duda me libraré si abandono mi carne mortal.
Of the fanatic's burning eternity I have no fear: there is not a future state worse than this present one--let me break away, and go home to God!'
No temo a los castigos del más allá, porque no pueden ser más horribles que los que sufro aquí.
¡Rompamos la cadena y entreguémonos en manos de Dios!
"I said this whilst I knelt down at, and unlocked a trunk which contained a brace of loaded pistols: I mean to shoot myself.
»Y pensando así, abrí un baúl que contenía un par de pistolas con el propósito de suicidarme.

I only entertained the intention for a moment; for, not being insane, the crisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the wish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.
Pero mi intención sólo duró un momento, porque la crisis de desesperación que la había originado se disipó al cabo de un segundo.
"A wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the open casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the air grew pure.
I then framed and fixed a resolution.
»Entretanto un fresco aire que soplaba de Occidente agitó el mar.
Estalló la tormenta, tronó y relampagueó copiosamente y después el cielo quedó despejado.

While I walked under the dripping orange-trees of my wet garden, and amongst its drenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of the tropics kindled round me--I reasoned thus, Jane--and now listen; for it was true Wisdom that consoled me in that hour, and showed me the right path to follow.
Paseé balo los naranjos del humedecido jardín, entre los ananás y los granados.
El alba refulgente de los trópicos apuntaba ya cuando en mi cerebro surgía la resolución acertada, acertada sin duda porque me la dictaba la suprema sabiduría.

"The sweet wind from Europe was still whispering in the refreshed leaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; my heart, dried up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled with living blood--my being longed for renewal--my soul thirsted for a pure draught.
»El dulce viento de Europa soplaba aún sobre las hojas frescas por la lluvia y el Atlántico tronaba en la playa.
I saw hope revive--and felt regeneration possible.
Mi corazón se expandió, mi alma se sintió renacer.
Veía revivir mi esperanza y creía posible la regeneración.
From a flowery arch at the bottom of my garden I gazed over the sea--bluer than the sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:--
Desde un arco florido del jardín, miré al mar, más azul aún que el cielo.
Más allá estaba el Viejo Mundo y en él se me abrían las perspectivas más claras...
"'Go,' said Hope, 'and live again in Europe: there it is not known what a sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you.
»"Vete a vivir a Europa -dijo mi esperanza-.
Allí nadie conoce la carga ominosa que pesa sobre ti.
You may take the maniac with you to England; confine her with due attendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel yourself to what clime you will, and form what new tie you like.
Puedes llevar contigo a la loca y confinarla en Thornfield con las debidas precauciones.
Y tú viajarás como y por donde quieras, viviendo según te plazca.
That woman, who has so abused your long- suffering, so sullied your name, so outraged your honour, so blighted your youth, is not your wife, nor are you her husband.
Esa mujer que ha empañado tu nombre, ultrajado tu honor, marchitado tu juventud, no es ya tu esposa, ni tú su marido.
See that she is cared for as her condition demands, and you have done all that God and humanity require of you.
Haz que la cuiden como su estado lo aconseja y habrás cumplido cuanto Dios y los hombres te pueden exigir.
Let her identity, her connection with yourself, be buried in oblivion: you are bound to impart them to no living being.
Place her in safety and comfort: shelter her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.'
Olvida su identidad y su relación contigo."
"I acted precisely on this suggestion.
»Seguí esa sugestión.

My father and brother had not made my marriage known to their acquaintance; because, in the very first letter I wrote to apprise them of the union--having already begun to experience extreme disgust of its consequences, and, from the family character and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to me--I added an urgent charge to keep it secret: and very soon the infamous conduct of the wife my father had selected for me was such as to make him blush to own her as his daughter-in-law.

Mi padre y mi hermano no habían hablado de mi casamiento, porque yo se lo había pedido así en mi primera carta después de casarme, cuando comencé a comprender las consecuencias de aquella unión y a adivinar el abominable porvenir que se me presentaba.
Far from desiring to publish the connection, he became as anxious to conceal it as myself.
Informado de la infame conducta de su nuera, mi padre se apresuró a ocultar cuidadosamente mi matrimonio.
"To England, then, I conveyed her; a fearful voyage I had with such a monster in the vessel.
»La traje, pues, a Inglaterra.
El viaje, con tal monstruo en el buque, fue lo horrible que puedes suponer.
Glad was I when I at last got her to Thornfield, and saw her safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret inner cabinet she has now for ten years made a wild beast's den--a goblin's cell.
Me sentí satisfecho cuando la vi instalada en ese cuarto interior del tercer piso, que ella, de diez años a esta parte, ha convertido en el cubil de una fiera, en la guarida de un demonio.

I had some trouble in finding an attendant for her, as it was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be placed; for her ravings would inevitably betray my secret: besides, she had lucid intervals of days--sometimes weeks--which she filled up with abuse of me.
Me fue difícil encontrar quien la atendiese, asegurándome a la vez de su silencio, porque la loca tiene intervalos de lucidez, que dedica a difamarme.
At last I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat.
Al fin encontré a Grace Poole, empleada en el asilo de Grimsby.
She and the surgeon, Carter (who dressed Mason's wounds that night he was stabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to my confidence.
Ella y el médico Carter, el que curó a Mason la noche en que a éste le mordió su hermana, son los únicos que conocen mi secreto.
Mrs. Fairfax may indeed have suspected something, but she could have gained no precise knowledge as to facts.
Mrs.
Fairfax debe de haber sospechado algo, pero no ha podido averiguar los hechos concretamente.

Grace has, on the whole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of her own, of which it appears nothing can cure her, and which is incident to her harassing profession, her vigilance has been more than once lulled and baffled.
Grace ha probado ser una buena guardiana, aunque en ocasiones ha tenido descuidos, como el que produjo el incendio de mi cuarto.
La loca es a la vez maligna y astuta y jamás deja de aprovechar los descuidos de su celadora.

The lunatic is both cunning and malignant; she has never failed to take advantage of her guardian's temporary lapses; once to secrete the knife with which she stabbed her brother, and twice to possess herself of the key of her cell, and issue therefrom in the night-time.
Una vez logró esconder el cuchillo con que agredió a su hermano y por dos veces consiguió coger la llave de su celda.
On the first of these occasions, she perpetrated the attempt to burn me in my bed; on the second, she paid that ghastly visit to you.
La primera quemó mi cama, la segunda entró como un fantasma en tu alcoba.

I thank Providence, who watched over you, that she then spent her fury on your wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back vague reminiscences of her own bridal days: but on what might have happened, I cannot endure to reflect.
Doy gracias a la Providencia, que hizo que la demente descargase su furia en tu velo de boda, porque Dios sabe lo que pudo haber ocurrido.
When I think of the thing which flew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage over the nest of my dove, my blood curdles--"
Cuando pienso en cómo saltó sobre mí esta mañana y me acuerdo de que estuvo en tu habitación, se me hiela la sangre.
"And what, sir," I asked, while he paused, "did you do when you had settled her here?
Where did you go?"
-¿Y qué hizo usted una vez que la hubo dejado aquí?
"What did I do, Jane?
I transformed myself into a will-o'-the-wisp.
Where did I go?
I pursued wanderings as wild as those of the March-spirit.
-Me convertí en una especie de judío errante.
I sought the Continent, and went devious through all its lands.
Recorrí todo el continente.
My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent woman, whom I could love: a contrast to the fury I left at Thornfield--"
Mi propósito era encontrar una mujer inteligente y buena a la que pudiese amar, algo muy distinto de la furia de Thornfield.
"But you could not marry, sir."
-Pero no podía casarse con ella.
"I had determined and was convinced that I could and ought.
-Estaba convencido de que podía y debía.
It was not my original intention to deceive, as I have deceived you.
Mi intención primitiva no era ocultar la situación, como te la he ocultado a ti.

I meant to tell my tale plainly, and make my proposals openly: and it appeared to me so absolutely rational that I should be considered free to love and be loved, I never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to understand my case and accept me, in spite of the curse with which I was burdened."
Me proponía contar francamente mi historia, pues me parecía palmario que tenía derecho a amar y a ser amado.
Estaba seguro de que no dejaría de encontrar una mujer capaz de comprender mi situación y aceptarla, a pesar de la carga que pesaba sobre mí.
"Well, sir?"
-¿Y entonces?
"When you are inquisitive, Jane, you always make me smile.
-Cuando te pones inquisitiva, Jane, me haces sonreír.
You open your eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless movement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and you wanted to read the tablet of one's heart.
Abres los ojos como un pájaro anhelante y realizas de vez en cuando algún pequeño movimiento, como si no te satisficiera lo que oyes.
But before I go on, tell me what you mean by your 'Well, sir?'
Antes de continuar, dime lo que quieres indicar con tus: «¿Y entonces?»
It is a small phrase very frequent with you; and which many a time has drawn me on and on through interminable talk: I don't very well know why."
Es una muletilla muy frecuente en ti.
"I mean,--What next?
How did you proceed?
-Quiero decir: «¿Qué más?»
What came of such an event?"
«¿Qué ocurrió después?»
"Precisely! and what do you wish to know now?"
-Ya.
¿Y qué quieres saber?
"Whether you found any one you liked: whether you asked her to marry you; and what she said."
-Si encontró una mujer que le gustase, si le propuso casarse y si aceptó.
"I can tell you whether I found any one I liked, and whether I asked her to marry me: but what she said is yet to be recorded in the book of Fate.
For ten long years I roved about, living first in one capital, then another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris; occasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence.
-Durante diez años erré de una capital a otra.
Estuve en San Petersburgo, más frecuentemente en París, alguna vez en Roma, Nápoles y Florencia.
Provided with plenty of money and the passport of an old name, I could choose my own society: no circles were closed against me.
Poseía dinero, ostentaba un nombre distinguido y ningún círculo se me cerraba.
I sought my ideal of a woman amongst English ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German grafinnen.
Busqué mi ideal femenino entre las damas inglesas, las condesas francesas, las signoras italianas y las alemanas gräfinen.
I could not find her.
Nunca hallé lo que buscaba.
Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I thought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced the realisation of my dream: but I was presently undeserved.
Alguna vez creía encontrarlo a través de una mirada, de un ademán, de un acento apasionado, pero pronto caía en la decepción.
You are not to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person.
No imagines que buscaba un ideal perfecto de cuerpo y de alma.
I longed only for what suited me--for the antipodes of the Creole: and I longed vainly.
No buscaba sino una mujer que fuese la antípoda de Bertha Mason.
Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever so free, I--warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of incongruous unions--would have asked to marry me.
Disappointment made me reckless.
Entre cuantas conocí no hallé ninguna que me decidiera a pedirla en matrimonio.
I tried dissipation--never debauchery: that I hated, and hate.
Desilusionado, me entregué a la disipación, aunque no al libertinaje, porque esto lo odiaba y lo odio.
That was my Indian Messalina's attribute: rooted disgust at it and her restrained me much, even in pleasure.
¡Y además era el tributo característico de mi Mesalina antillana!
Any enjoyment that bordered on riot seemed to approach me to her and her vices, and I eschewed it.
Bastaba que fuese así para que lo aborreciese.
"Yet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of mistresses.
»No pudiendo vivir solo, me busqué amantes.
The first I chose was Celine Varens--another of those steps which make a man spurn himself when he recalls them.
La primera fue Céline Varens.
You already know what she was, and how my liaison with her terminated.
Ya sabes lo que sucedió con ella.
She had two successors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a German, Clara; both considered singularly handsome.
La siguieron otras dos: Giacinta, que era italiana, y Clara, alemana, ambas consideradas como beldades.
What was their beauty to me in a few weeks?
¿De qué me sirvió su belleza?
Giacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of her in three months.
Giacinta era ineducada y violenta y me hartó a los tres meses.
Clara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not one whit to my taste.
Clara era honrada y tranquila, pero de corta inteligencia y escasa sensibilidad.
I was glad to give her a sufficient sum to set her up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of her.
No congeniábamos.
Así que preferí darle una cantidad que le permitiera vivir honorablemente y me libré de ella.
But, Jane, I see by your face you are not forming a very favourable opinion of me just now.
Veo por tu cara, Jane, que no formas buena opinión de mí.
You think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don't you?"
Me consideras un hombre sin principios ni sentimientos, ¿no?
"I don't like you so well as I have done sometimes, indeed, sir.
-Desde luego, le juzgo peor de lo que antes solía juzgarle.
Did it not seem to you in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one mistress and then another?
¿No le parece indigno vivir así, unas veces con una amante y otras con otra?
You talk of it as a mere matter of course."
Usted habla de ello como de una cosa sin importancia.
"It was with me; and I did not like it.
It was a grovelling fashion of existence: I should never like to return to it.
-No me agradaba aquella vida.
Hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and always by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is degrading.
Tener una amante es lo más parecido a tener una esclava: ambas, por naturaleza, son seres inferiores, y vivir íntimamente con inferiores es degradante.
I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with Celine, Giacinta, and Clara."
Ahora recuerdo con disgusto el tiempo que pasé con Céline, Giacinta y Clara.

I felt the truth of these words; and I drew from them the certain inference, that if I were so far to forget myself and all the teaching that had ever been instilled into me, as--under any pretext--with any justification--through any temptation--to become the successor of these poor girls, he would one day regard me with the same feeling which now in his mind desecrated their memory.
I did not give utterance to this conviction: it was enough to feel it.

Comprendí que las palabras de Rochester eran sinceras, pero con todo, no podía sustraerme a la sensación de que, deseando él en cierto sentido hacerme sucesora de aquellas muchachas, podía llegar a experimentar por mí el mismo sentimiento de disgusto que ahora manifestaba hacia ellas.
I impressed it on my heart, that it might remain there to serve me as aid in the time of trial.
Guardé esto en mi corazón, porque podía serme útil en el momento crítico.
"Now, Jane, why don't you say 'Well, sir?'
I have not done.
-¿Cómo no dices ahora «¿Y entonces?», Jane?
You are looking grave.
You disapprove of me still, I see.
Veo que me repruebas.
But let me come to the point.
Pero vamos al final.

Last January, rid of all mistresses--in a harsh, bitter frame of mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life--corroded with disappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against all womankind (for I began to regard the notion of an intellectual, faithful, loving woman as a mere dream), recalled by business, I came back to England.

En enero pasado, libre de mi última amante, con el corazón amargado y endurecido como consecuencia de una vida estéril y solitaria, muy mal dispuesto contra todos los hombres, y comenzando a considerar la posibilidad de hallar una mujer inteligente, fiel y cariñosa como una fantasía, volvía a Inglaterra, adonde me llamaban mis asuntos.
"On a frosty winter afternoon, I rode in sight of Thornfield Hall.
Abhorred spot!
I expected no peace--no pleasure there.
»En una helada tarde de invierno avisté Thornfield Hall, el aborrecido lugar en que no esperaba hallar satisfacción ni placer algunos.
On a stile in Hay Lane I saw a quiet little figure sitting by itself.
En el camino de Hay vi una figurilla sentada.

I passed it as negligently as I did the pollard willow opposite to it: I had no presentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the arbitress of my life--my genius for good or evil--waited there in humble guise.
No presentí que iba a convertirse en árbitro de mi vida, para bien o para mal.
I did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour's accident, it came up and gravely offered me help.
No, no lo sabía cuando, al caer Mesrour, ella, gravemente, me ofreció su ayuda.
Childish and slender creature!
¡Qué infantilidad!
It seemed as if a linnet had hopped to my foot and proposed to bear me on its tiny wing.
Me pareció como si un jilguero hubiese aparecido a mis pies ofreciéndome llevarme en sus débiles alas.
I was surly; but the thing would not go: it stood by me with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a sort of authority.
Sin embargo, aquella criatura insistió en su ofrecimiento, hablando con una especie de autoridad.
I must be aided, and by that hand: and aided I was.
Sin duda estaba escrito que yo recibiese ayuda de aquella mano, y la recibí.
"When once I had pressed the frail shoulder, something new--a fresh sap and sense--stole into my frame.
»Cuando me hube apoyado en su frágil hombro sentí una insólita impresión de alivio.

It was well I had learnt that this elf must return to me--that it belonged to my house down below--or I could not have felt it pass away from under my hand, and seen it vanish behind the dim hedge, without singular regret.
Me agradó saber que aquel duendecillo no iba a desvanecerse bajo mi mano, sino que iría a mi propia casa.
I heard you come home that night, Jane, though probably you were not aware that I thought of you or watched for you.
Te sentí volver aquella noche, aunque tú ignorases que pensaba en ti y espiaba tu regreso.
The next day I observed you--myself unseen--for half-an- hour, while you played with Adele in the gallery.
Al día siguiente te estuve observando durante media hora mientras jugabas con Adèle en la galería.
It was a snowy day, I recollect, and you could not go out of doors.
Recuerdo que hacía mal tiempo y no podíais salir al aire libre.
I was in my room; the door was ajar: I could both listen and watch.
Yo estaba en mi habitación con la puerta entornada, y te veía y oía.
Adele claimed your outward attention for a while; yet I fancied your thoughts were elsewhere: but you were very patient with her, my little Jane; you talked to her and amused her a long time.
Noté, pequeña Jane, lo paciente y bondadosa que eras con Adèle.
When at last she left you, you lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook yourself slowly to pace the gallery.
Cuando la niña se fue, quedaste en la galería y te vi contemplar por las ventanas la nieve que caía y escuchar el fragor del viento.
Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out at the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again you paced gently on and dreamed.
Tenías una expresión soñadora, tus ojos brillaban y de todo tu aspecto trascendía una dulce excitación.

I think those day visions were not dark: there was a pleasurable illumination in your eye occasionally, a soft excitement in your aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious, hypochondriac brooding: your look revealed rather the sweet musings of youth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up and on to an ideal heaven.
Todo en ti revelaba que sentías cantar en tu interior las músicas de la juventud y de la esperanza...
The voice of Mrs. Fairfax, speaking to a servant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and at yourself, Janet!
La voz de Mrs.
Fairfax llamando a un criado te arrancó de tu meditación y ¡de qué modo sonreíste!
There was much sense in your smile: it was very shrewd, and seemed to make light of your own abstraction.
Tu sonrisa parecía decir: "Mis sueños son muy bellos, pero es necesario que recuerde que no son reales.
It seemed to say--'My fine visions are all very well, but I must not forget they are absolutely unreal.
I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eden in my brain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at my feet a rough tract to travel, and around me gather black tempests to encounter.'
En mi alma hay un cielo corrido y un florido Edén, pero sé bien que en la realidad debo pisar un duro suelo y soportar el embate de las tempestades que me asaltan."
You ran downstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly house accounts to make up, or something of that sort, I think it was.
Bajaste las escaleras y pediste a Mrs.
Fairfax que te diera algo que hacer: las cuentas de la casa, o cosa parecida.
I was vexed with you for getting out of my sight.
Me disgusté que desaparecieras de ante mi vista.
"Impatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my presence.
»Esperé con impaciencia que llegara la noche para mandar que fueras a mi presencia.
An unusual--to me--a perfectly new character I suspected was yours: I desired to search it deeper and know it better.
Me parecía que tu carácter era distinto al corriente y para comprobarlo deseaba conocerlo mejor.
You entered the room with a look and air at once shy and independent: you were quaintly dressed--much as you are now.
Entraste en el salón con un aire a la vez modesto y seguro.
Ibas humildemente vestida, como ahora...
I made you talk: ere long I found you full of strange contrasts.
Encontré tu conversación original y llena de contrastes.

Your garb and manner were restricted by rule; your air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined by nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of making herself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or blunder; yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing eye to your interlocutor's face: there was penetration and power in each glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready and round answers.
Tus modales eran algo cohibidos, parecías desconfiada, mostrabas un temperamento exquisito por naturaleza, pero no acostumbrado a la convivencia social.
Estabas como temerosa de cometer algún descuido, pero tu mirada era penetrante y enérgica, y tus respuestas fáciles y prontas.
Noté que te acostumbrabas en seguida a mí, y que existía una simpatía entre tú y tu malhumorado patrón.

Very soon you seemed to get used to me: I believe you felt the existence of sympathy between you and your grim and cross master, Jane; for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain pleasant ease tranquillised your manner: snarl as I would, you showed no surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at my moroseness; you watched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious grace I cannot describe.
No mostrabas enojo ni sorpresa por mis salidas de tono y me contemplabas sonriendo de cuando en cuando con una gracia a la vez profunda y sencilla que no acierto a describir.
I was at once content and stimulated with what I saw: I liked what I had seen, and wished to see more.
Me sentí contento y animado y decidí seguir tratándote.
Yet, for a long time, I treated you distantly, and sought your company rarely.
Sin embargo, durante mucho tiempo me mantuve distante de ti y te vi pocas veces.

I was an intellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making this novel and piquant acquaintance: besides, I was for a while troubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely its bloom would fade--the sweet charm of freshness would leave it.
Como un epicúreo deseaba experimentar el placer de tu trato con más intensidad haciéndolo poco frecuente.
Tenía, además, el temor de que, si manoseaba demasiado la flor, sus pétalos se ajaran, su dulce lozanía se desvaneciera.
I did not then know that it was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant resemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem.
Ignoraba que no se trataba de una lozanía momentánea, como la de una flor, sino de un brillo permanente, como el de una piedra preciosa.

Moreover, I wished to see whether you would seek me if I shunned you--but you did not; you kept in the schoolroom as still as your own desk and easel; if by chance I met you, you passed me as soon, and with as little token of recognition, as was consistent with respect.
Además, deseaba ver si, no buscándote, procurabas buscarme tú.
Pero no: cuando pasabas a mi lado me demostrabas tan poco interés como era compatible con el respeto.
Your habitual expression in those days, Jane, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you were not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no actual pleasure.
