Tu expresión habitual en aquellos días era pensativa.
No te hallabas abatida, porque no estabas enferma; ni optimista, porque tenías muy pocas esperanzas y ninguna satisfacción.
I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever thought of me, and resolved to find this out.
"I resumed my notice of you.

There was something glad in your glance, and genial in your manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social heart; it was the silent schoolroom--it was the tedium of your life--that made you mournful.
Yo quería saber lo que pensabas de mí -y ante todo si pensabas en mí- y pronto averigüé que no me engañaba por la alegría de tu mirada y hasta por tus modales cuando conversabas conmigo.

I permitted myself the delight of being kind to you; kindness stirred emotion soon: your face became soft in expression, your tones gentle; I liked my name pronounced by your lips in a grateful happy accent.
Me concedí el placer de ser estimado por ti, y en breve aprecié que a la estimación seguía tu emoción en mi presencia.
Tu rostro se suavizaba, se dulcificaba tu acento; mi nombre, pronunciado por tus labios, tomaba sonidos agradables.

I used to enjoy a chance meeting with you, Jane, at this time: there was a curious hesitation in your manner: you glanced at me with a slight trouble--a hovering doubt: you did not know what my caprice might be--whether I was going to play the master and be stern, or the friend and be benignant.
Me mirabas dudosa, sin saber la causa de que desempeñara ante ti el papel de amigo afectuoso.

I was now too fond of you often to simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched my hand out cordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your young, wistful features, I had much ado often to avoid straining you then and there to my heart."
Cada vez que te tendía la mano, tal rubor y tal expresión de felicidad acudían a tus juveniles facciones que había de hacer verdaderos esfuerzos para no estrecharte contra mi corazón.
-¡No me hable de aquellos días! -interrumpí, enjugando algunas furtivas lágrimas.

"Don't talk any more of those days, sir," I interrupted, furtively dashing away some tears from my eyes; his language was torture to me; for I knew what I must do--and do soon--and all these reminiscences, and these revelations of his feelings only made my work more difficult.
Sus palabras me atormentaban.
Yo sabía lo que había de hacer sin pérdida de tiempo, y tales recuerdos servían sólo para convertir en más difícil lo que era inevitable realizar.
"No, Jane," he returned: "what necessity is there to dwell on the Past, when the Present is so much surer--the Future so much brighter?"
-Cierto -contestó él-.
¿Para qué evocar el pasado cuando el presente es mucho más seguro y el porvenir mucho más luminoso?
I shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.
Me estremecí al oír aquella frase.
"You see now how the case stands--do you not?" he continued.
-¿Comprendes mi caso ahora? -continuó-.
"After a youth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary solitude, I have for the first time found what I can truly love--I have found you.
Tras una juventud y una madurez pasadas, mitad en una infinita miseria y mitad en una soledad infinita, daba, por primera vez, con alguien digno de mi amor, te encontraba a ti.
You are my sympathy--my better self--my good angel.
I am bound to you with a strong attachment.
Te consideré mi ángel bueno y un amor ferviente y profundo brotó de mi corazón.

I think you good, gifted, lovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in my heart; it leans to you, draws you to my centre and spring of life, wraps my existence about you, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in one.
Resolví consagrarte mi vida y hacerte arder en la propia y pura llama que me devoraba a mí.
"It was because I felt and knew this, that I resolved to marry you.
»Por eso quise casarme contigo.
To tell me that I had already a wife is empty mockery: you know now that I had but a hideous demon.
Decirme que ya tengo una esposa es gastarme una burla cruel, porque lo que tengo, en realidad, es un abominable demonio.
I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I feared a stubbornness that exists in your character.
I feared early instilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding confidences.
Hice mal tratando de ocultarte su existencia, pero lo hice porque conocía tus prejuicios y deseaba tenerte segura antes de aventurarme a tales confidencias.

This was cowardly: I should have appealed to your nobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now--opened to you plainly my life of agony--described to you my hunger and thirst after a higher and worthier existence--shown to you, not my _resolution_ (that word is weak), but my resistless _bent_ to love faithfully and well, where I am faithfully and well loved in return.

Reconozco que fui cobarde, porque debí haber apelado desde el principio a tu magnanimidad y a tu comprensión como lo hago ahora, describirte las torturas de mi vida, comunicarte, no mi resolución, porque ésta no es la palabra adecuada, sino mi inclinación a quererte fiel y honradamente, esperando ser correspondido por ti del mismo modo.
Then I should have asked you to accept my pledge of fidelity and to give me yours.
Sólo después de hablarte francamente debía haberte prometido mi fidelidad y pedido la tuya.
Jane--give it me now."
Pues que lo hago ahora, prométeme tú ahora serme fiel, Jane.
A pause.
Calló.
"Why are you silent, Jane?"
Luego dijo: -¿Por qué no hablas?
I was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped my vitals.
La prueba que yo sufría era terrible.
Una mano de hierro desgarraba mi alma.
Terrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning!
¡Oh, qué tremendo momento, qué esfuerzo, qué lucha conmigo misma!
Not a human being that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved; and him who thus loved me I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce love and idol.
Ninguna mujer había sido más amada que yo lo era, yo idolatraba a quien me amaba así, y era preciso renunciar al amor de mi ídolo...
One drear word comprised my intolerable duty--"Depart!"
Porque mi deber, mi insoportable deber estaba bien claro: debía partir.
"Jane, you understand what I want of you?
-¿Has entendido lo que deseo de ti, Jane?
Just this promise--'I will be yours, Mr. Rochester.'"
Sólo esta promesa: «Seré tuya, Edward».
"Mr. Rochester, I will _not_ be yours."
-No seré suya, Mr.
Rochester.
Another long silence.
Siguió otro largo silencio.

"Jane!" recommenced he, with a gentleness that broke me down with grief, and turned me stone-cold with ominous terror--for this still voice was the pant of a lion rising--"Jane, do you mean to go one way in the world, and to let me go another?"
-Jane -comenzó él, en un tono que me intimidó, porque recordaba el rugido de un león-, ¿quieres decir que te propones seguir un camino distinto al mío?
"I do."
-Sí.
"Jane" (bending towards and embracing me), "do you mean it now?"
-¿Y ahora, Jane? -dijo, inclinándose hacia mí y abrazándome.
"I do."
-También.
"And now?" softly kissing my forehead and cheek.
-¿Y ahora? -dijo, besando dulcemente mi frente y mis mejillas.
"I do," extricating myself from restraint rapidly and completely.
-También -repuse, librándome de sus brazos. -¡Oh, Jane, esto es doloroso, es inicuo!
"Oh, Jane, this is bitter!
This--this is wicked.
It would not be wicked to love me."
-No hay más remedio.
"It would to obey you."
A wild look raised his brows--crossed his features: he rose; but he forebore yet.
Bajo sus cejas brilló una terrible mirada.
Se incorporó, pero logró dominarse.
I laid my hand on the back of a chair for support: I shook, I feared--but I resolved.
Me apoyé en una silla para no caer.
Estaba espantada, temblorosa, pero no por ello menos decidida.
"One instant, Jane.
-Un instante, Jane.
Give one glance to my horrible life when you are gone.
Piensa en lo que será mi horrible vida cuando te hayas ido.
All happiness will be torn away with you.
Contigo se irá toda mi felicidad.
What then is left?
¿Qué me quedará?
For a wife I have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer me to some corpse in yonder churchyard.
¡Esa loca de ahí arriba!
¡Como si me quedara un cadáver en el cementerio!
What shall I do, Jane?
¿Qué haré?
Where turn for a companion and for some hope?"
¿Dónde hallaré compañía y consuelo?
"Do as I do: trust in God and yourself.
-Donde yo.
Believe in heaven.
En Dios y en usted mismo.
Hope to meet again there."
Confíe en que volveremos a encontrarnos en el cielo.
"Then you will not yield?"
-¿No quieres ayudarme?
"No."
-No.
"Then you condemn me to live wretched and to die accursed?"
-¿Me condenas a vivir miserablemente y a morir maldito?
His voice rose.
-exclamó, alzando la voz.
"I advise you to live sinless, and I wish you to die tranquil."
-Le aconsejo que viva librándose de pecar y le deseo que muera en paz.
"Then you snatch love and innocence from me?
-¿Me privas del amor puro?
You fling me back on lust for a passion--vice for an occupation?"
¿Me obligas a que caiga en la pasión y en el vicio?
"Mr. Rochester, I no more assign this fate to you than I grasp at it for myself.
-No hago con usted más que lo que hago conmigo misma.
We were born to strive and endure--you as well as I: do so.
Todos hemos nacido para sufrir; soportemos el sufrimiento.
You will forget me before I forget you."
Antes me olvidará usted a mí que yo a usted.
"You make me a liar by such language: you sully my honour.
-Veo que me consideras un embustero.
I declared I could not change: you tell me to my face I shall change soon.
Te digo que me será imposible cambiar y tú me dices que cambiaré muy pronto.
And what a distortion in your judgment, what a perversity in your ideas, is proved by your conduct!
¡Qué error en tus juicios y cuánta perversidad en tus ideas acredita tu conducta!

Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to despair than to transgress a mere human law, no man being injured by the breach? for you have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom you need fear to offend by living with me?"
Para ti vale más sumir en la desesperación a un ser humano que transgredir una ley meramente convencional sin perjudicar a nadie.
¡Porque no tienes amigos ni parientes que puedan juzgarte mal si vives conmigo!
This was true: and while he spoke my very conscience and reason turned traitors against me, and charged me with crime in resisting him.
Esto era cierto, y al oírle mi conciencia y mi razón se rebelaron contra mí, calificando de crimen mi resistencia a escucharle.
They spoke almost as loud as Feeling: and that clamoured wildly.
"Oh, comply!" it said.

"Think of his misery; think of his danger--look at his state when left alone; remember his headlong nature; consider the recklessness following on despair--soothe him; save him; love him; tell him you love him and will be his.
El sentimiento murmuraba en mi interior: «Piensa en su miseria, piensa en los riesgos a que le expones abandonándole, piensa en su desesperación.
Sálvale, pues, ámale y dile que le amas.
Who in the world cares for _you_? or who will be injured by what you do?"
¿Quién se preocupa de ti en el mundo?
¿Quién te pedirá cuenta de tus acciones?»
Still indomitable was the reply--"_I_ care for myself.
La réplica fue inmediata: «Yo me preocupo de mí.
The more solitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained I am, the more I will respect myself.
Cuanto más sola, con menos amigos y más abandonada me encuentre, más debo cuidar de mi decoro.
I will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by man.
Respetaré la ley dada por Dios y sancionada por los hombres.
I will hold to the principles received by me when I was sane, and not mad--as I am now.
Seguiré los principios que me fueron inculcados cuando estaba en mi plena razón y no loca, como ahora me siento.

Laws and principles are not for the times when there is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body and soul rise in mutiny against their rigour; stringent are they; inviolate they shall be.

Las leyes y los principios no son para observarlos cuando no se presenta la ocasión de romperlos, sino para acordarse de ellos en los momentos de prueba, cuando el cuerpo y el alma se sublevan contra sus rigores.
If at my individual convenience I might break them, what would be their worth?

They have a worth--so I have always believed; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am insane--quite insane: with my veins running fire, and my heart beating faster than I can count its throbs.

La ley y los principios tienen un valor, como siempre he creído, excepto ahora, que estoy perturbada (lo estoy puesto que por mis venas corre fuego y mi corazón late de un modo tal, que no puedo contener sus latidos).
Preconceived opinions, foregone determinations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant my foot."
No debo moverme en otro terreno, sino en el seguro de los conceptos admitidos como buenos, en el de las determinaciones previstas para casos como éste.
Desenvolvámonos, pues, en él.»
I did.
Y lo hice.
Mr. Rochester, reading my countenance, saw I had done so.
Rochester lo leyó en mi rostro y su furia desbordó.
His fury was wrought to the highest: he must yield to it for a moment, whatever followed; he crossed the floor and seized my arm and grasped my waist.
Asió mi brazo, me cogió por la cintura y me contempló con centelleantes ojos.

He seemed to devour me with his flaming glance: physically, I felt, at the moment, powerless as stubble exposed to the draught and glow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed my soul, and with it the certainty of ultimate safety.
Desde el punto de vista físico, me sentía impotente, pero me quedaba el alma y ésta tiene, muchas veces, sin darse cuenta, un intérprete en la mirada.
The soul, fortunately, has an interpreter--often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter--in the eye.
My eye rose to his; and while I looked in his fierce face I gave an involuntary sigh; his gripe was painful, and my over-taxed strength almost exhausted.
Le miré, pues, a la enfurecida faz e involuntariamente suspiré.
"Never," said he, as he ground his teeth, "never was anything at once so frail and so indomitable.
-Nunca he visto -rugió él, rechinando los dientesnada a la vez tan frágil y tan indómito.
A mere reed she feels in my hand!"
(And he shook me with the force of his hold.)
En mis manos es como una caña que puedo romper con los dedos.
"I could bend her with my finger and thumb: and what good would it do if I bent, if I uptore, if I crushed her?
Pero ¿qué gano con quebrarla, con aniquilarla?
Consider that eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing looking out of it, defying me, with more than courage--with a stern triumph.
Ahí está su mirada, su mirada resuelta, libre, feroz, triunfante.
Whatever I do with its cage, I cannot get at it--the savage, beautiful creature!
If I tear, if I rend the slight prison, my outrage will only let the captive loose.
Con su envoltura carnal puedo hacer lo que quiera, pero lo que habita en ella escapará siempre a mi voluntad.
Conqueror I might be of the house; but the inmate would escape to heaven before I could call myself possessor of its clay dwelling-place.
And it is you, spirit--with will and energy, and virtue and purity--that I want: not alone your brittle frame.
Y es su alma, su alma enérgica y pura, lo que yo deseo de ella, no sólo su cuerpo.
Of yourself you could come with soft flight and nestle against my heart, if you would: seized against your will, you will elude the grasp like an essence--you will vanish ere I inhale your fragrance.
Y esa alma puede venir a mí, apretarse contra mi pecho, emanar de ella como un aroma...
Oh! come, Jane, come!"
¡Ven, Jane, ven!
As he said this, he released me from his clutch, and only looked at me.
Y hablando así, me soltó y se limitó a mirarme.
The look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an idiot, however, would have succumbed now.
I had dared and baffled his fury; I must elude his sorrow: I retired to the door.
Yo había triunfado de su furor; bien podía, pues, triunfar de su tristeza.
Me dirigí a la puerta.
"You are going, Jane?"
-¿Te vas, Jane?
"I am going, sir."
-Me voy.
"You are leaving me?"
-¿Me abandonas?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"You will not come?
You will not be my comforter, my rescuer?
-¿No volverás más a consolarme?
My deep love, my wild woe, my frantic prayer, are all nothing to you?"
Mi amor, mi dolor, mi frenético ruego, ¿no son nada para ti?
What unutterable pathos was in his voice!
Qué infinito sentimiento había en su voz!
How hard it was to reiterate firmly, "I am going."
¡Y qué amargo era tener que repetirle firmemente!:
"Jane!"
-Me voy. -¡Jane!
"Mr. Rochester!"
-Mr.
Rochester.
"Withdraw, then,--I consent; but remember, you leave me here in anguish.
-Vete, vete si quieres, pero recuerda la angustia en que me dejas.
Go up to your own room; think over all I have said, and, Jane, cast a glance on my sufferings--think of me."
Vete a tu cuarto, medita en cuanto te he dicho, piensa en lo que sufro, piensa en mí, Jane.
He turned away; he threw himself on his face on the sofa.
Y se dejó caer sobre un sofá, con el rostro entre las manos.
"Oh, Jane! my hope--my love--my life!" broke in anguish from his lips.
Then came a deep, strong sob.
-¡Oh, Jane, mi esperanza, mi amor, mi vida! -gimió desoladamente, dejando escapar un profundo sollozo.
I had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back--walked back as determinedly as I had retreated.
Yo estaba casi en la puerta, pero me volví tan decidida como antes me había alejado.
I knelt down by him; I turned his face from the cushion to me; I kissed his cheek; I smoothed his hair with my hand.
Me arrodillé junto a él, volví su rostro hacia mí, le besé en la mejilla y acaricié su cabello.
"God bless you, my dear master!"
-Dios le bendiga -dije-.
I said.
"God keep you from harm and wrong--direct you, solace you--reward you well for your past kindness to me."
Dios le libre de mal, Dios le pague todo lo bueno que ha sido conmigo.
"Little Jane's love would have been my best reward," he answered; "without it, my heart is broken.
-El amor de mi Jane era mi última esperanza -dijo- y sin ella mi corazón se destrozará.
But Jane will give me her love: yes--nobly, generously."
Pero Jane me dará aún su amor, su amor noble y generoso.
La sangre afluyó a su rostro, sus ojos volvieron a centellear.
Up the blood rushed to his face; forth flashed the fire from his eyes; erect he sprang; he held his arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at once quitted the room.
Se incorporó y trató de abrazarme.
Pero pude eludirle y salí de la estancia. -¡Adiós! -gimió desesperadamente mi corazón al abandonarle-.
"Farewell!" was the cry of my heart as I left him.
Despair added, "Farewell for ever!"
¡Adiós para siempre!
* * * * * That night I never thought to sleep; but a slumber fell on me as soon as I lay down in bed.
No creía poder dormir aquella noche, pero apenas me acosté me acometió una pesadilla.
I was transported in thought to the scenes of childhood: I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead; that the night was dark, and my mind impressed with strange fears.
Me sentí transportada a la niñez y soñé en el cuarto rojo de Gateshead.
Era una noche oscura y mi mente sentía extraños terrores.
The light that long ago had struck me into syncope, recalled in this vision, seemed glidingly to mount the wall, and tremblingly to pause in the centre of the obscured ceiling.
La luz que, vista tantos años atrás, me asustara hasta el punto de hacerme desmayar, reaparecía en mi sueño, escalaba los muros y se detenía, temblorosa, en el centro del oscuro artesonado del techo.
I lifted up my head to look: the roof resolved to clouds, high and dim; the gleam was such as the moon imparts to vapours she is about to sever.
Alcé la cabeza para mirarla y el techo se convirtió en un mar de altas y sombrías nubes.
Luego entre ellas apareció la luna.
I watched her come--watched with the strangest anticipation; as though some word of doom were to be written on her disk.
Yo la contemplaba como si en su disco hubiese de aparecer grabada alguna sentencia que me concerniese.

She broke forth as never moon yet burst from cloud: a hand first penetrated the sable folds and waved them away; then, not a moon, but a white human form shone in the azure, inclining a glorious brow earthward.
La luna penetró a través de las nubes, descendiendo más cada vez, mientras una mano misteriosa parecía apartar los sombríos vapores.
Después ya no era la luna, sino una blanca faz humana la que me miraba.
It gazed and gazed on me.
It spoke to my spirit: immeasurably distant was the tone, yet so near, it whispered in my heart--
Aquella faz me habló, habló a mi alma, y aunque su voz sonaba inconmensurablemente remota, yo la sentía cuchichear en mi corazón.
"My daughter, flee temptation."
-Hija mía, huye de la tentación.
"Mother, I will."
-Lo haré, madre.
So I answered after I had waked from the trance-like dream.
Tal fue la respuesta que di al despertar de mi sueño.
It was yet night, but July nights are short: soon after midnight, dawn comes.
Era de noche aún, pero las noches de julio son cortas.
No mucho más tarde de medianoche comenzó a alborear.
«Es hora de comenzar lo que debo hacer», pensé.
"It cannot be too early to commence the task I have to fulfil," thought I. I rose: I was dressed; for I had taken off nothing but my shoes.
Me levanté.
Me había acostado vestida, sin quitarme más que los zapatos.
I knew where to find in my drawers some linen, a locket, a ring.
Busqué en los cajones alguna ropa blanca.
In seeking these articles, I encountered the beads of a pearl necklace Mr. Rochester had forced me to accept a few days ago.
Hallé un collarcito de perlas que Rochester me había obligado a aceptar días antes.
I left that; it was not mine: it was the visionary bride's who had melted in air.
Dejé aparte aquel recuerdo de mis fantásticas bodas: no era mío.

The other articles I made up in a parcel; my purse, containing twenty shillings (it was all I had), I put in my pocket: I tied on my straw bonnet, pinned my shawl, took the parcel and my slippers, which I would not put on yet, and stole from my room.

Con lo demás hice un paquete, guardé en el bolsillo los únicos veinte chelines que poseía, me coloqué mi gorrito y mi chal, cogí el paquete y las zapatillas para andar por la casa sin ruido, y salí cautelosamente del cuarto. -Adiós, amable Mrs.
"Farewell, kind Mrs. Fairfax!"
I whispered, as I glided past her door.
Fairfax -murmuré cuando pasaba ante la puerta de su cuarto-.
"Farewell, my darling Adele!"
I said, as I glanced towards the nursery.
¡Adiós, querida Adèle! -añadí lanzando una mirada a su alcobita.
No thought could be admitted of entering to embrace her.
Era imposible pensar en entrar y abrazarla.
I had to deceive a fine ear: for aught I knew it might now be listening.
I would have got past Mr. Rochester's chamber without a pause; but my heart momentarily stopping its beat at that threshold, my foot was forced to stop also.
Me proponía pasar ante el cuarto de Rochester sin pararme, pero mi corazón detuvo allí sus latidos y mis pies hubieron de detenerse también.
No sleep was there: the inmate was walking restlessly from wall to wall; and again and again he sighed while I listened.
Rochester no dormía.
Le sentí pasear por su alcoba, suspirando de vez en cuando.

There was a heaven--a temporary heaven--in this room for me, if I chose: I had but to go in and to say-- "Mr. Rochester, I will love you and live with you through life till death," and a fount of rapture would spring to my lips.
¡Y pensar que en aquella habitación se encerraba el cielo para mí!
Yo podía haber entrado y decirle: «Edward: te amo y quiero vivir contigo para siempre.»
I thought of this.
¡Qué bello hubiera sido!
That kind master, who could not sleep now, was waiting with impatience for day.
Aquel hombre insomne esperaba sin duda con impaciencia la mañana.
He would send for me in the morning; I should be gone.
Cuando me enviase a buscar, no me encontraría.
He would have me sought for: vainly.
He would feel himself forsaken; his love rejected: he would suffer; perhaps grow desperate.
Se sentiría despreciado, rechazado su amor, sufriría, se desesperaría quizá...
I thought of this too.
My hand moved towards the lock: I caught it back, and glided on.
Mi mano avanzó hacia el picaporte.
Drearily I wound my way downstairs: I knew what I had to do, and I did it mechanically.
Pero me contuve y descendí apresuradamente las escaleras.
I sought the key of the side-door in the kitchen; I sought, too, a phial of oil and a feather; I oiled the key and the lock.
Busqué en la cocina la llave de la puerta trasera, y la engrasé con aceite.
I got some water, I got some bread: for perhaps I should have to walk far; and my strength, sorely shaken of late, must not break down.
Comí pan y bebí agua, porque acaso necesitaría caminar largo tiempo.
All this I did without one sound.
Lo hice todo sin ruido alguno.
I opened the door, passed out, shut it softly.
Abrí y volví a cerrar suavemente.
Dim dawn glimmered in the yard.
Sobre el patio se extendía la opaca claridad del todavía lejano amanecer.
The great gates were closed and locked; but a wicket in one of them was only latched.
Las verjas estaban cerradas, pero tenían un postigo cerrado simplemente con un picaporte.
Through that I departed: it, too, I shut; and now I was out of Thornfield.
Pasé el postigo y me hallé fuera de Thornfield.
A mile off, beyond the fields, lay a road which stretched in the contrary direction to Millcote; a road I had never travelled, but often noticed, and wondered where it led: thither I bent my steps.
A campo traviesa alcancé, una milla más allá, una carretera que seguía la dirección contraria a Millcote.
Muchas veces la había visto, pero nunca la recorrí, e ignoraba a dónde conducía.
No reflection was to be allowed now: not one glance was to be cast back; not even one forward.
No reflexionaba en nada, no miraba hacia atrás, no pensaba en el pasado ni en lo futuro.
Not one thought was to be given either to the past or the future.
The first was a page so heavenly sweet--so deadly sad--that to read one line of it would dissolve my courage and break down my energy.
El pasado parecíame una página tan divinamente dulce que leer una sola línea de ella hubiera quebrantado mi resolución.
The last was an awful blank: something like the world when the deluge was gone by.
Y el porvenir era una página en blanco, como el mundo después del diluvio.
I skirted fields, and hedges, and lanes till after sunrise.
Recorrí campos, senderos y setos hasta después de salir el sol.
I believe it was a lovely summer morning: I know my shoes, which I had put on when I left the house, were soon wet with dew.
Creo que hacía una hermosa mañana de verano.
Mis zapatos estaban húmedos de rocío.
But I looked neither to rising sun, nor smiling sky, nor wakening nature.
Pero yo no reparaba en el sol naciente, ni el límpido cielo, ni en la naturaleza que despertaba.

He who is taken out to pass through a fair scene to the scaffold, thinks not of the flowers that smile on his road, but of the block and axe-edge; of the disseverment of bone and vein; of the grave gaping at the end: and I thought of drear flight and homeless wandering--and oh! with agony I thought of what I left.
I could not help it.
Quien a través de un bello panorama se dirige al cadalso, no repara en las flores que sonríen en su camino, sino en el patíbulo y la tumba que le esperan.
Yo, pues, pensaba en mi situación, de fugitiva sin hogar, y -¡oh, con qué angustia!- en lo que dejaba atrás.
I thought of him now--in his room--watching the sunrise; hoping I should soon come to say I would stay with him and be his.
Creía a Rochester en su cuarto, contemplando salir el sol, esperando que yo apareciese para decirle que me quedaba a su lado...
I longed to be his; I panted to return: it was not too late; I could yet spare him the bitter pang of bereavement.
Hasta estudié la posibilidad de regresar.
No era demasiado tarde: aún podía ahorrarle aquella amargura.
As yet my flight, I was sure, was undiscovered.
Mi fuga no debía haber sido descubierta.
I could go back and be his comforter--his pride; his redeemer from misery, perhaps from ruin.
Podía volver sobre mis pasos, consolarle, librarle de su miseria moral, acaso de su ruina...
Oh, that fear of his self-abandonment--far worse than my abandonment--how it goaded me!
El pensamiento de su soledad me angustiaba más que la mía propia.
It was a barbed arrow-head in my breast; it tore me when I tried to extract it; it sickened me when remembrance thrust it farther in.
Birds began singing in brake and copse: birds were faithful to their mates; birds were emblems of love.
Comenzaban a cantar los pájaros en las ramas: los pájaros, fieles a sus parejas, símbolo del amor...
What was I?
In the midst of my pain of heart and frantic effort of principle, I abhorred myself.
Dentro de mi corazón herido, me aborrecía a mí misma.
I had no solace from self-approbation: none even from self-respect.
Ninguna satisfacción encontraba en la idea de que había procedido correctamente para salvar mi decoro.
I had injured--wounded--left my master.
Había herido y dañado a mi querido dueño...
I was hateful in my own eyes.
Me consideré odiosa a mis propios ojos.
Still I could not turn, nor retrace one step.
Sin embargo, no desanduve lo andado.
God must have led me on.
As to my own will or conscience, impassioned grief had trampled one and stifled the other.
Lloraba incansablemente mientras seguía mi solitario camino.
I was weeping wildly as I walked along my solitary way: fast, fast I went like one delirious.
A poco me hundí en una especie de delirio.
Una progresiva debilidad invadió mis miembros, me sentí desvanecer y caí.
A weakness, beginning inwardly, extending to the limbs, seized me, and I fell: I lay on the ground some minutes, pressing my face to the wet turf.
Permanecí tendida algunos minutos, con el rostro contra la hierba.
I had some fear--or hope--that here I should die: but I was soon up; crawling forwards on my hands and knees, and then again raised to my feet--as eager and as determined as ever to reach the road.
Sentí el temor -o la esperanza- de morir allí, pero al fin me puse en pie y continué mi marcha, más firmemente resuelta que nunca a alcanzar el lejano camino.
When I got there, I was forced to sit to rest me under the hedge; and while I sat, I heard wheels, and saw a coach come on.
Cuando llegué a él hube de sentarme, fatigada, en la cuneta.
Sentí ruido de ruedas y vi aproximarse una diligencia.
I stood up and lifted my hand; it stopped.
Levanté la mano; paró.
I asked where it was going: the driver named a place a long way off, and where I was sure Mr. Rochester had no connections.
Pregunté al cochero adónde se dirigía.
Me dio el nombre de un lugar muy lejano, en el que yo sabía que Rochester no tenía relaciones.
I asked for what sum he would take me there; he said thirty shillings; I answered I had but twenty; well, he would try to make it do.
Pregunté cuánto me cobraba por llevarme allí, y repuso que treinta chelines.
Contesté que no poseía más de veinte y accedió a transportarme durante un trayecto proporcionado a la suma.
He further gave me leave to get into the inside, as the vehicle was empty: I entered, was shut in, and it rolled on its way.
Entré en el coche vacío, el cochero cerró la portezuela y el vehículo se puso en marcha.
Gentle reader, may you never feel what I then felt!
Amable lector: ¡ojalá no sientas nunca lo que yo sentí entonces!
May your eyes never shed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from mine.
¡Ojalá no llores nunca las ardientes y tumultuosas lágrimas que yo lloré en aquella ocasión!
May you never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in that hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the instrument of evil to what you wholly love.
¡Ojalá no eleves nunca al cielo una plegaria tan desesperada y angustiosa como la que entonces brotó de mis labios!
¡Ojalá no te veas nunca en el caso de ser instrumento del dolor de aquel a quien amas, como me sucedía a mí!
CHAPTER XXVIII
XXVIII
Two days are passed.
Han pasado dos días.
It is a summer evening; the coachman has set me down at a place called Whitcross; he could take me no farther for the sum I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the world.
The coach is a mile off by this time; I am alone.
Es una tarde de verano.
El coche me ha dejado en un lugar llamado Whitcross, ya que la cantidad pagada no alcanzaba para transportar más adelante y yo no poseía ni otro chelín siquiera.
Ahora la diligencia se encuentra a una milla de mí y yo me hallo sola.
At this moment I discover that I forgot to take my parcel out of the pocket of the coach, where I had placed it for safety; there it remains, there it must remain; and now, I am absolutely destitute.
En este momento descubro que he olvidado mi paquete en la valija del cochero, donde lo había colocado para mayor seguridad.
Y, puesto que allí está, no hay más remedio que dejarlo continuar allí.
Whitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; it is but a stone pillar set up where four roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at a distance and in darkness.
Whitcross no es una ciudad ni una aldea, sino un simple poste indicador colocado en la confluencia de cuatro caminos y enyesado de blanco, supongo que para poderlo reconocer en la oscuridad.
Four arms spring from its summit: the nearest town to which these point is, according to the inscription, distant ten miles; the farthest, above twenty.
De aquel poste salen cuatro brazos que señalan cuatro distintas direcciones.
La población más próxima dista diez millas; la más lejana, veinte, según se lee en los brazos indicadores.
From the well-known names of these towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a north-midland shire, dusk with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I see.
Por los muy conocidos nombres de aquellas ciudades, comprendí que me hallaba en un condado del Norte.
There are great moors behind and on each hand of me; there are waves of mountains far beyond that deep valley at my feet.
La comarca estaba rodeada de montañas y a mi alrededor se extendían grandes páramos y pantanos.

The population here must be thin, and I see no passengers on these roads: they stretch out east, west, north, and south--white, broad, lonely; they are all cut in the moor, and the heather grows deep and wild to their very verge.
La población debía de ser poco densa; escasos viajeros recorrían aquellos caminos.
Yet a chance traveller might pass by; and I wish no eye to see me now: strangers would wonder what I am doing, lingering here at the sign-post, evidently objectless and lost.
Pero si alguno pasaba, ningún interés tenía yo en que me viera, ya que todos se hubieran maravillado de encontrarme perdida y sin sitio alguno al que ir, al lado de un poste indicador, en un camino.
I might be questioned: I could give no answer but what would sound incredible and excite suspicion.
Quizá me preguntaran, yo acaso no supiera qué responder, y era probable que se extrañasen y sospecharan de mí.
Not a tie holds me to human society at this moment--not a charm or hope calls me where my fellow-creatures are--none that saw me would have a kind thought or a good wish for me.
Ninguna ayuda humana cabía esperar, nadie que me viera me dedicaría un pensamiento amable o un buen deseo.
I have no relative but the universal mother, Nature: I will seek her breast and ask repose.
No tenía otro amigo que la madre de todos: la naturaleza, y de ella únicamente debía solicitar calor y abrigo.

I struck straight into the heath; I held on to a hollow I saw deeply furrowing the brown moorside; I waded knee-deep in its dark growth; I turned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in a hidden angle, I sat down under it.
Me interné entre los matorrales y a poco mis pies se hundieron en el cieno de un pantano.
Retrocedí y, encontrando un saliente propicio en una roca de granito, me senté en él.
High banks of moor were about me; the crag protected my head: the sky was over that.
Las márgenes del pantano me rodeaban, la roca protegía mi cabeza y el cielo cubría todas las cosas.
Some time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread that wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might discover me.
Pasó tiempo antes de que me sintiese tranquila, porque temía que merodeasen por allí animales peligrosos, o que me descubriera algún cazador, furtivo o no.
If a gust of wind swept the waste, I looked up, fearing it was the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, I imagined it a man.
Si soplaba el viento, se me figuraba el bramido de un toro; si alguna cerceta levantaba el vuelo a lo lejos, confundía su figura con la sombra de un hombre.
Finding my apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep silence that reigned as evening declined at nightfall, I took confidence.
Al fin, viendo que mis temores eran infundados y que reinaba la soledad en torno mío, recobré la confianza.
As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched, dreaded; now I regained the faculty of reflection.
Hasta entonces no había pensado en nada, limitándome a ver, temer y escuchar.
Pero ahora comenzaba a reflexionar de nuevo.
What was I to do?
¿Qué hacer?
Where to go?
¿Adónde ir?
¡Aterradoras preguntas!

Oh, intolerable questions, when I could do nothing and go nowhere!--when a long way must yet be measured by my weary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation--when cold charity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant sympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before my tale could be listened to, or one of my wants relieved!
Tal vez la más cercana morada humana estuviera a mayor distancia de la que mis debilitadas fuerzas pudieran recorrer.
Había de apelar a la fría caridad para lograr un albergue, corriendo el riesgo de tropezar con una repulsa casi cierta y aun con otros peligros.
Toqué una mata de brezo.
I touched the heath: it was dry, and yet warm with the heat of the summer day.
Todavía estaba caliente del sol que durante el día de verano la había besado.
I looked at the sky; it was pure: a kindly star twinkled just above the chasm ridge.
En el cielo sereno una estrella titilaba precisamente sobre mí.
The dew fell, but with propitious softness; no breeze whispered.
Caía un ligero rocío; no soplaba el viento.
Nature seemed to me benign and good; I thought she loved me, outcast as I was; and I, who from man could anticipate only mistrust, rejection, insult, clung to her with filial fondness.
La naturaleza me pareció benigna y bondadosa para conmigo y pensé que, si de los hombres no me cabía esperar sino repulsas o insultos, en ella podía encontrar apoyo y abrigo.
To-night, at least, I would be her guest, as I was her child: my mother would lodge me without money and without price.
Al menos por una noche, debía ser su huésped: como madre mía que era, me daría alojamiento sin cobrármelo.
I had one morsel of bread yet: the remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed through at noon with a stray penny--my last coin.
Yo tenía aún un pedazo de pan, resto de una cantidad que comprara en una población que habíamos atravesado, con un penique olvidado que encontré en mi bolsillo.
I saw ripe bilberries gleaming here and there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a handful and ate them with the bread.
Entre los matorrales veíanse, aquí y allá, arándanos maduros.
Cogí un puñado y los comí con el pan.
My hunger, sharp before, was, if not satisfied, appeased by this hermit's meal.
El agudo apetito que un momento antes sentía se apaciguó, ya que no se satisficiera, con aquella eremítica colación.
I said my evening prayers at its conclusion, and then chose my couch.
Después de comer recité una plegaria, y me dispuse a acostarme.
Beside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down my feet were buried in it; rising high on each side, it left only a narrow space for the night-air to invade.
La hierba crecía muy alto junto a la roca.
I folded my shawl double, and spread it over me for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was my pillow.
Me tendí en ella colocando sobre mí, a guisa de manta, mi chal doblado y apoyando la cabeza en una pequeña protuberancia del suelo.
Thus lodged, I was not, at least--at the commencement of the night, cold.
Instalada así no sentí, al menos al principio de la noche, frío alguno.
My rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke it.
Hubiera, pues, podido hallarme bastante a gusto, a no ser por el dolor de mi corazón.
It plained of its gaping wounds, its inward bleeding, its riven chords.
Las heridas de mi alma volvían a abrirse.

It trembled for Mr. Rochester and his doom; it bemoaned him with bitter pity; it demanded him with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird with both wings broken, it still quivered its shattered pinions in vain attempts to seek him.
Sufría por Rochester, experimentaba por él una amarga tristeza, y mi corazón, impotente como un pájaro con las alas rotas, gemía y se despedazaba en su vano deseo de prestarle ayuda.
Worn out with this torture of thought, I rose to my knees.
Mis sombríos pensamientos me impedían dormir.
Me incorporé.
Night was come, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for the companionship of fear.
Era de noche ya, una noche serena que alejaba del alma todo temor.
Brillaban en el cielo las estrellas.

We know that God is everywhere; but certainly we feel His presence most when His works are on the grandest scale spread before us; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where His worlds wheel their silent course, that we read clearest His infinitude, His omnipotence, His omnipresence.
La presencia de Dios es sensible en todas partes, pero nunca tanto como cuando contemplamos sus máximas obras.
En aquella serena noche, en aquel cielo despejado en que giraban, silentes, los infinitos mundos creados por Él, se experimentaba más que nunca su infinitud, su omnipotencia, su omnipresencia.
I had risen to my knees to pray for Mr. Rochester.
Rogué por Rochester.
Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty Milky- way.
Remembering what it was--what countless systems there swept space like a soft trace of light--I felt the might and strength of God.
Mientras lo hacía, mis ojos llorosos contemplaron la Vía Láctea.
Sure was I of His efficiency to save what He had made: convinced I grew that neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured.

Pensando en los incontables mundos que encerraba aquella vaga bruma luminosa, sentí el infinito poder de Dios, comprendí que podría salvar a quien Él quisiera, que nada era perecedero, que ni un alma tan sólo podía perderse.
I turned my prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the Saviour of spirits.
Mi plegaria se convirtió en acción de gracias, al recordar que el Padre de todas las cosas había sido también nuestro Salvador.
Mr. Rochester was safe; he was God's, and by God would he be guarded.
Rochester sería salvado porque era de Dios y Dios le preservaría.
I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere long in sleep forgot sorrow.
Volví a acurrucarme en el suelo y me dormí, olvidada toda la angustia.
But next day, Want came to me pale and bare.
Al día siguiente, la necesidad, pálida y descarnada, apareció ante mí.

Long after the little birds had left their nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime of day to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried--when the long morning shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky--I got up, and I looked round me.

Mucho después de que los pájaros abandonaran sus nidos en busca de alimento, mucho después de que la aurora apareciera en Oriente y libara, como dulce miel, el rocío que cubría la maleza, cuando las sombras de la madrugada se habían disipado hacía largo rato y el sol iluminaba ya cielos y tierra, me desperté y, levantándome, miré en torno mío.
What a still, hot, perfect day!
El día era magnífico y cálido.
What a golden desert this spreading moor!
El páramo circundante parecía un dorado desierto, en el que yo hubiera deseado vivir para siempre.
Everywhere sunshine.
Todo esplendía al sol.
I wished I could live in it and on it.
I saw a lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet bilberries.
Un lagarto trepaba por la roca y una abeja volaba sobre los arándanos.
I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that I might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here.
Habría deseado convertirme en lagarto o en abeja, residir allí, encontrar en aquella edad refugio y alimento.
But I was a human being, and had a human being's wants: I must not linger where there was nothing to supply them.
Pero era un ser humano y los humanos tenemos otras necesidades.
No podía quedarme donde estaba.
I rose; I looked back at the bed I had left.
Miré el improvisado lecho que acababa de abandonar.

Hopeless of the future, I wished but this--that my Maker had that night thought good to require my soul of me while I slept; and that this weary frame, absolved by death from further conflict with fate, had now but to decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil of this wilderness.
Desesperanzada como estaba respecto al futuro, no habría deseado cosa mejor sino que el Creador hubiese arrebatado aquella noche mi alma de mi cuerpo, evitándome una ulterior lucha con el destino.
Life, however, was yet in my possession, with all its requirements, and pains, and responsibilities.
No era así: vivía, con todas las amarguras, luchas y responsabilidades que ello implicaba.
The burden must be carried; the want provided for; the suffering endured; the responsibility fulfilled.
Era preciso cargar con la vida como con un pesado fardo, proveer a mis necesidades, soportar los sufrimientos, afrontar mis obligaciones.
I set out.
Me puse en camino.
Whitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now fervent and high.
Una vez en Whitcross, seguí una carretera donde daba el sol, alto y cálido ya.
By no other circumstance had I will to decide my choice.
Ninguna otra circunstancia influyó en la elección de ruta.

I walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done enough, and might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost overpowered me--might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a stone I saw near, submit resistlessly to the apathy that clogged heart and limb--I heard a bell chime--a church bell.
Anduve largo tiempo.
Cuando, al fin, fatigada, me senté en una piedra, oí cerca de mí repicar una campana, la campana de una iglesia.
I turned in the direction of the sound, and there, amongst the romantic hills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw a hamlet and a spire.
Miré hacia donde la campana sonaba y, entre pintorescas colinas, distinguí una aldea y un campanario.

All the valley at my right hand was full of pasture- fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran zig-zag through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the sombre woodland, the clear and sunny lea.
A mi derecha se extendía un valle cubierto de prados, maizales y bosques.
Recalled by the rumbling of wheels to the road before me, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up the hill, and not far beyond were two cows and their drover.
Un arroyo zigzagueaba entre árboles, praderas y campos de cereal.
Human life and human labour were near.
I must struggle on: strive to live and bend to toil like the rest.
Una carreta pesadamente cargada subía la colina y, no lejos, pastaban dos vacas, vigiladas por su pastor.
About two o'clock p.m.
I entered the village.
A cosa de las dos, entré en la aldea.
At the bottom of its one street there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window.
A la entrada de una de sus calles había una tiendecita en cuyo escaparate se exhibían varios panecillos.
I coveted a cake of bread.
Deseé uno de ellos con verdadera codicia.
With that refreshment I could perhaps regain a degree of energy: without it, it would be difficult to proceed.
Pensaba que comiéndolo adquiriría energías, sin las cuales me sería difícil continuar adelante.
The wish to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as I was amongst my fellow-beings.
El deseo de readquirir mi fuerza y mi vigor había renacido en mí en cuanto me hallé en contacto con mis semejantes.
I felt it would be degrading to faint with hunger on the causeway of a hamlet.
Hubiera sido muy degradante desmayarme de inanición en la calle de una aldea.
Had I nothing about me I could offer in exchange for one of these rolls?
¿No llevaba nada sobre mí que ofrecer a cambio de uno de aquellos panecillos?
I considered.
Medité.
I had a small silk handkerchief tied round my throat; I had my gloves.
Poseía un pañolito de seda, puesto al cuello, y los guantes.
I could hardly tell how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded.
I did not know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably they would not; but I must try.
Muy duro era hablar a nadie del extremo de necesidad en que me encontraba, y muy probablemente nadie querría aquellas pobres prendas, pero resolví intentarlo.
I entered the shop: a woman was there.
Entré en la tienda.
En ella había una mujer.
Seeing a respectably-dressed person, a lady as she supposed, she came forward with civility.
Viendo a una persona decentemente vestida, una señora como sin duda supuso, avanzó atentamente hacia mí.
How could she serve me?
¿En qué podía servirme?, se apresuró a preguntar.
I was seized with shame: my tongue would not utter the request I had prepared.
I dared not offer her the half-worn gloves, the creased handkerchief: besides, I felt it would be absurd.
La vergüenza me invadió, no acertaba a decir las palabras que había preparado y comprendí, además, lo absurdo de la proposición que iba a hacer.
I only begged permission to sit down a moment, as I was tired.
Le pedí, pues, solamente permiso para sentarme unos minutos, porque me hallaba fatigada.
Disappointed in the expectation of a customer, she coolly acceded to my request.
She pointed to a seat; I sank into it.
Disgustada al ver que su supuesta cliente no era tal, accedió fríamente a mi ruego, señalándome una silla.
I felt sorely urged to weep; but conscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, I restrained it.
Sentí ganas de llorar, pero, comprendiendo lo inoportuno de tal manifestación, me contuve.
Soon I asked her "if there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman in the village?"
Luego le pregunté si en el pueblo había alguna costurera.
"Yes; two or three.
-Sí, dos o tres.
Quite as many as there was employment for."
Las necesarias para la aldea.
I reflected.
Reflexioné.
I was driven to the point now.
I was brought face to face with Necessity.
I stood in the position of one without a resource, without a friend, without a coin.
Me hallaba cara a cara con la necesidad, sin recursos, sin un amigo.
I must do something.
Era preciso hacer algo.
What?
¿Qué?
I must apply somewhere.
Lo que fuera.
Where?
Pero ¿dónde?
"Did she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was wanted?"
-¿Conoce a alguna persona de la vecindad que necesite criada?
"Nay; she couldn't say."
-No.
"What was the chief trade in this place?
-¿Cuál es la industria principal de aquí?
What did most of the people do?"
¿A qué se dedica la gente?
"Some were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver's needle-factory, and at the foundry."
-Muchos son labradores y otros trabajan en la fábrica de agujas de Mr.
Oliver.
"Did Mr. Oliver employ women?"
-¿Emplea mujeres Mr.
Oliver?
"Nay; it was men's work."
-No; sólo hombres.
"And what do the women do?"
"I knawn't," was the answer.
-¿Pues qué hacen las mujeres de este lugar? -No sé -contestó-.
"Some does one thing, and some another.
Unas una cosa, otras otra...
Poor folk mun get on as they can."
Los pobres se arreglan siempre como pueden.
She seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had I to importune her?
Parecía molesta por mis preguntas.
Además, ¿qué derecho tenía yo a importunarla?
A neighbour or two came in; my chair was evidently wanted.
Luego entraron algunos vecinos.
Mi silla era necesaria.
I took leave.
Me despedí.
I passed up the street, looking as I went at all the houses to the right hand and to the left; but I could discover no pretext, nor see an inducement to enter any.
Recorrí la calle mirando a derecha e izquierda cuantas casas encontraba, pero sin hallar pretexto para entrar en ninguna.
I rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to a little distance and returning again, for an hour or more.
Vagué por el pueblo más de una hora.
Much exhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, I turned aside into a lane and sat down under the hedge.
Ere many minutes had elapsed, I was again on my feet, however, and again searching something--a resource, or at least an informant.
Exhausta, experimentando la imperiosa necesidad de comer, me senté al borde de un sendero y allí permanecí largo rato.
A pretty little house stood at the top of the lane, with a garden before it, exquisitely neat and brilliantly blooming.
I stopped at it.
Luego me levanté y me dirigí hacia una linda casita, con un jardín delante, que se hallaba al final del camino.
What business had I to approach the white door or touch the glittering knocker?
In what way could it possibly be the interest of the inhabitants of that dwelling to serve me?
¿Para qué me aproximaba a aquella blanca puerta, ni qué interés habían de tener sus habitantes en servirme?
Yet I drew near and knocked.
Sin embargo, llamé.
A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young woman opened the door.
Una mujer joven, de agradable apariencia, muy limpia, me abrió.
In such a voice as might be expected from a hopeless heart and fainting frame--a voice wretchedly low and faltering--I asked if a servant was wanted here?
Con la voz que puede suponerse en una persona desfallecida y desesperada le pregunté si necesitaban por casualidad una sirviente.
"No," said she; "we do not keep a servant."
-No -dijo-; no la necesitamos.
"Can you tell me where I could get employment of any kind?"
I continued.
-¿Sabe si me sería posible encontrar alguna clase de trabajo aquí -volví a preguntar-.
"I am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place.
Soy forastera, no conozco a nadie.
I want some work: no matter what."
Necesito trabajar, sea en lo que fuere.
But it was not her business to think for me, or to seek a place for me: besides, in her eyes, how doubtful must have appeared my character, position, tale.
Pero ella no tenía por qué ocuparse de mí, ni buscarme un empleo, ni a sus ojos podía aparecer mi relato, situación y carácter sino como muy dudosos.
She shook her head, she "was sorry she could give me no information," and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but it shut me out.
Movió la cabeza, dijo que no podía informarme y cerró la puerta blanca.
Con toda cortesía, pero la cerró.
If she had held it open a little longer, I believe I should have begged a piece of bread; for I was now brought low.
Si la hubiese tenido abierta un instante más, creo que le habría pedido un poco de pan, porque me sentía desfallecida.
I could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no prospect of aid was visible.
¿A qué volver al sórdido villorrio, donde ninguna perspectiva de ayuda se divisaba?

I should have longed rather to deviate to a wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer inviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature's cravings, instinct kept me roaming round abodes where there was a chance of food.

Hubiera sido mejor dirigirme a un bosquecillo cercano, que se mostraba ante mis ojos brindándome un apetecible refugio, pero me hallaba tan débil, tan extenuada, que rondaba por instinto en torno a los sitios donde existía alguna posibilidad de hallar alimento.
Solitude would be no solitude--rest no rest--while the vulture, hunger, thus sank beak and talons in my side.
Imposible buscar la soledad mientras el buitre del hambre me clavaba tan cruelmente sus garras.
I drew near houses; I left them, and came back again, and again I wandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim to ask--no right to expect interest in my isolated lot.
Me aproximé a las casas, me alejé de ellas, volví a aproximarme de nuevo, y de nuevo me alejé, comprendiendo que no tenía derecho alguno a pedir nada ni a que nadie se interesase por mí.
Meantime, the afternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and starving dog.
La tarde avanzaba mientras yo erraba de aquel modo, como un perro extraviado y hambriento.
In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before me: I hastened towards it.
Al cruzar un prado divisé ante mí la torre de la iglesia y me dirigí hacia ella.
Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a garden, stood a well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was the parsonage.
Cerca del cementerio, en medio de un jardín, había una agradable casita, que no dudé que sería la del párroco.
I remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where they have no friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the clergyman for introduction and aid.
It is the clergyman's function to help--at least with advice--those who wished to help themselves.
Recordé que los forasteros que llegan a un lugar donde no conocen a nadie, acuden a veces a los párrocos para pedir su ayuda.
I seemed to have something like a right to seek counsel here.
Y la misión de un sacerdote es socorrer, al menos con su consejo, a los que soliciten su auxilio.
Renewing then my courage, and gathering my feeble remains of strength, I pushed on.
I reached the house, and knocked at the kitchen-door.
Reuniendo, pues, todo mi valor y mis débiles fuerzas, llegué a la casa y llamé a la puerta de la cocina.
An old woman opened: I asked was this the parsonage?
"Yes."
Abrió una anciana.
Le pregunté por el párroco.
"Was the clergyman in?"
"No."
-No está -dijo.
"Would he be in soon?"
-¿Volverá pronto?
"No, he was gone from home."
-No.
"To a distance?"
"Not so far--happen three mile.
He had been called away by the sudden death of his father: he was at Marsh End now, and would very likely stay there a fortnight longer."
Está a tres millas de aquí, en Marsh End, adonde le han llamado por haber muerto su padre súbitamente.
Lo probable es que pase allá quince días.
"Was there any lady of the house?"
-¿Hay alguna señora en la casa?
"Nay, there was naught but her, and she was housekeeper;" and of her, reader, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was sinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.
Contestó que no había nadie sino ella, y a ella, lector, no fui capaz de pedirle lo que necesitaba.
Otra vez, pues, comencé a errar.
Once more I took off my handkerchief--once more I thought of the cakes of bread in the little shop.
Me quité el pañuelo que llevaba al cuello.
Había vuelto a pensar en los panecillos de la tiendecita.
Oh, for but a crust! for but one mouthful to allay the pang of famine!
¡Oh, qué terrible tormento es el hambre!

Instinctively I turned my face again to the village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others were there besides the woman I ventured the request--"Would she give me a roll for this handkerchief?"
De nuevo me dirigí a la aldea, de nuevo entré en la tienda y, aunque había otras personas, dije a la tendera que si quería darme un panecillo a cambio de aquel pañuelo.
She looked at me with evident suspicion: "Nay, she never sold stuff i' that way."
Me miró con evidentes sospechas. -No; nunca hago tratos de esa clase.
Almost desperate, I asked for half a cake; she again refused.
Casi desesperada, le rogué que me diese siquiera medio panecillo.
"How could she tell where I had got the handkerchief?" she said.
Se negó también.
¿Qué sabía dónde había cogido yo el pañuelo?, insinuó.
"Would she take my gloves?"
-¿Quiere mis guantes a cambio?
"No! what could she do with them?"
-No.
¿Qué voy a hacer con ellos?
Reader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details.
No es agradable insistir en estos detalles.

Some say there is enjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I can scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral degradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a recollection ever to be willingly dwelt on.
Según algunas personas, complace evocar los recuerdos penosos, pero a mí hoy me es insoportable revivir los tiempos que relato.
Aquel rebajamiento moral, unido al sufrimiento físico, fue demasiado doloroso para mí.
I blamed none of those who repulsed me.
No censuro a ninguno de los que se negaron entonces a ayudarme.
I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not be helped: an ordinary beggar is frequently an object of suspicion; a well-dressed beggar inevitably so.
Si un pordiosero vulgar suele inspirar sospechas, un pordiosero bien vestido las inspira siempre.
To be sure, what I begged was employment; but whose business was it to provide me with employment?
Verdad es que lo que yo pedía era trabajo, pero ¿cómo iban a preocuparse de tal cosa personas que me veían por primera vez?
Not, certainly, that of persons who saw me then for the first time, and who knew nothing about my character.
And as to the woman who would not take my handkerchief in exchange for her bread, why, she was right, if the offer appeared to her sinister or the exchange unprofitable.
La mujer que no quiso cambiar un panecillo por mi pañuelo de seda tenía derecho a hacerlo si el cambio le parecía ventajoso o la oferta extraña.
Let me condense now.
I am sick of the subject.
A little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which the farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese.
Poco antes de oscurecer pasé ante una granja.
El granjero, a la puerta, estaba cenando pan y queso.
I stopped and said-- "Will you give me a piece of bread? for I am very hungry."
Me detuve y le dije: -¿Quiere darme un poco de pan?
Estoy hambrienta.
He cast on me a glance of surprise; but without answering, he cut a thick slice from his loaf, and gave it to me.
Me miró asombrado y, sin contestar, cortó una delgada rebanada de pan y me la tendió.
I imagine he did not think I was a beggar, but only an eccentric sort of lady, who had taken a fancy to his brown loaf.
No creo que me considerase una pordiosera, sino más bien una señora extravagante, que sentía el capricho de probar su pan moreno.
As soon as I was out of sight of his house, I sat down and ate it.
En cuanto estuve a alguna distancia, me senté y comí el pan.
I could not hope to get a lodging under a roof, and sought it in the wood I have before alluded to.
No teniendo esperanza de dormir bajo techado, pensé que debía dirigirme al bosque a que antes aludí.

But my night was wretched, my rest broken: the ground was damp, the air cold: besides, intruders passed near me more than once, and I had again and again to change my quarters; no sense of safety or tranquillity befriended me.
Pero mi descanso fue frecuentemente interrumpido.
El suelo era duro, el aire frío y a menudo pasaban intrusos cerca de mí, y tenía que cambiar de sitio.
Towards morning it rained; the whole of the following day was wet.
Hacia la mañana empezó a llover y durante todo el día hubo mucha humedad.
Do not ask me, reader, to give a minute account of that day; as before, I sought work; as before, I was repulsed; as before, I starved; but once did food pass my lips.
No me pidas, lector, un relato minucioso de aquella jornada.
Como la anterior, anduve buscando trabajo, y como la anterior fui rechazada siempre.
At the door of a cottage I saw a little girl about to throw a mess of cold porridge into a pig trough.
"Will you give me that?"
Como la anterior, me sentí extenuada, y como la anterior pude comer algo.
Pasando a la puerta de una casita, vi a una niña echando restos de potaje frío en una gamella de las que se usan para los cerdos.
I asked.
Le dije: -¿Quieres darme eso?
She stared at me.
"Mother!" she exclaimed, "there is a woman wants me to give her these porridge."
-¡Madre! -gritó la niña-.
¡Aquí hay una mujer que quiere el potaje!
"Well lass," replied a voice within, "give it her if she's a beggar.
-Si es una mendiga, dáselo -contestó una voz desde dentro-.
T' pig doesn't want it."
El cerdo está harto.
The girl emptied the stiffened mould into my hand, and I devoured it ravenously.
La niña me entregó el recipiente y devoré su contenido con ansia.
As the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path, which I had been pursuing an hour or more.
Al caer del húmedo crepúsculo me detuve al borde de un sendero por el que caminaba sin objeto hacía más de una hora.
"My strength is quite failing me," I said in a soliloquy.
«Me faltan las fuerzas -monologué- y no podré seguir mucho más adelante.
"I feel I cannot go much farther.
¿Cómo pasar la noche?
Shall I be an outcast again this night?
While the rain descends so, must I lay my head on the cold, drenched ground?
¿Con la cabeza sobre el duro suelo mientras la lluvia me cala?, no obstante, no puedo hacer otra cosa, porque nadie me daría hospitalidad.
I fear I cannot do otherwise: for who will receive me?
But it will be very dreadful, with this feeling of hunger, faintness, chill, and this sense of desolation--this total prostration of hope.
Pero es de temer, dada mi postración, mi abatimiento y mi desesperanza, que me muera esta noche.
In all likelihood, though, I should die before morning.
And why cannot I reconcile myself to the prospect of death?
Después de todo, ¿por qué no hacerme a la idea de morir?
Why do I struggle to retain a valueless life?
¿Por qué esforzarse en prolongar una vida inútil?
¡Más no!
Because I know, or believe, Mr. Rochester is living: and then, to die of want and cold is a fate to which nature cannot submit passively.
¡Debo vivir, porque Edward vive o creo que vive!
No debo dejarme morir de hambre y de frío.
Oh, Providence! sustain me a little longer!
Aid!--direct me!"
¡Oh, Dios mío, ayúdame, ayúdame un poco más!»
My glazed eye wandered over the dim and misty landscape.
Mis ojos contemplaron el sombrío y brumoso paisaje.
I saw I had strayed far from the village: it was quite out of sight.
Estaba lejos de la aldea y ésta no se distinguía ya.
The very cultivation surrounding it had disappeared.
Los campos cultivados de sus cercanías habían desaparecido.

I had, by cross-ways and by- paths, once more drawn near the tract of moorland; and now, only a few fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which they were scarcely reclaimed, lay between me and the dusky hill.
A lo largo de atajos y senderos había llegado otra vez a las cercanías de la zona pantanosa y en mi torno sólo se divisaban míseros prados, casi tan silvestres y áridos como el páramo mismo.
"Well, I would rather die yonder than in a street or on a frequented road," I reflected.
«Mejor sería morir ahí que en una calle o en un camino frecuentado -pensé-.

"And far better that crows and ravens--if any ravens there be in these regions--should pick my flesh from my bones, than that they should be prisoned in a workhouse coffin and moulder in a pauper's grave."
Prefiero que los cuervos, si los hay en la comarca, devoren mis restos, que no que éstos desciendan, en un ataúd de caridad, al fondo de la fosa común.»
To the hill, then, I turned.
I reached it.
Me hallaba a la sazón en pleno páramo.
It remained now only to find a hollow where I could lie down, and feel at least hidden, if not secure.
But all the surface of the waste looked level.
Los musgos y juncos que crecían en las ciénagas se distinguían por su color verde del oscuro de los matorrales que cubrían los lugares donde el suelo formaba una superficie sólida.
It showed no variation but of tint: green, where rush and moss overgrew the marshes; black, where the dry soil bore only heath.
Dark as it was getting, I could still see these changes, though but as mere alternations of light and shade; for colour had faded with the daylight.
A mis ojos aquella gradación de matices se presentaba sólo en forma de luces y sombras, ya que el día se había desvanecido.
My eye still roved over the sullen swell and along the moor-edge, vanishing amidst the wildest scenery, when at one dim point, far in among the marshes and the ridges, a light sprang up.
Oteando el desolado paisaje me pareció ver brillar una luz a lo lejos.
"That is an _ignis fatuus_," was my first thought; and I expected it would soon vanish.
La juzgué un fuego fatuo y creí que se desvanecería en seguida.
It burnt on, however, quite steadily, neither receding nor advancing.
Más la luz no se movía.
"Is it, then, a bonfire just kindled?"
«¿Será una hoguera?», me pregunté.
I questioned.
I watched to see whether it would spread: but no; as it did not diminish, so it did not enlarge.
"It may be a candle in a house," I then conjectured; "but if so, I can never reach it.
It is much too far away: and were it within a yard of me, what would it avail?
I should but knock at the door to have it shut in my face."

Pero no aumentaba ni disminuía de tamaño, por lo que deduje que podría ser la luz de una casa, aunque tan lejana que no habría podido alcanzarla, ni me hubiera servido de nada llamar a su puerta, puesto que seguramente me la hubieran cerrado, como las demás.
And I sank down where I stood, and hid my face against the ground.
Me tendí en el mismo lugar en que me hallaba, rostro a tierra.
I lay still a while: the night-wind swept over the hill and over me, and died moaning in the distance; the rain fell fast, wetting me afresh to the skin.
El aire de la noche soplaba sobre mí y se perdía a lo lejos.
A poco empezó a llover y el agua me caló hasta los huesos.
Could I but have stiffened to the still frost--the friendly numbness of death--it might have pelted on; I should not have felt it; but my yet living flesh shuddered at its chilling influence.
I rose ere long.
Me incorporé.
The light was yet there, shining dim but constant through the rain.
La luz continuaba brillando, mortecina, pero constante, a través de la lluvia.
I tried to walk again: I dragged my exhausted limbs slowly towards it.
Comencé a andar, con fatigados pies, en aquella dirección.
It led me aslant over the hill, through a wide bog, which would have been impassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the height of summer.
Hube de atravesar un cenagal que hubiera sido impracticable en invierno.
Here I fell twice; but as often I rose and rallied my faculties.
Dos veces caí, pero ambas volví a levantarme y a caminar hacia aquella luz, última esperanza mía.
This light was my forlorn hope: I must gain it.
Having crossed the marsh, I saw a trace of white over the moor.
Cruzada la ciénaga, distinguí una faja blanca que atravesaba el páramo.
Me acerqué: era un camino.

I approached it; it was a road or a track: it led straight up to the light, which now beamed from a sort of knoll, amidst a clump of trees--firs, apparently, from what I could distinguish of the character of their forms and foliage through the gloom.
La luz brillaba, al parecer, en una especie de otero entre pinos, que se entreveían confusamente entre las tinieblas.
My star vanished as I drew near: some obstacle had intervened between me and it.
Mi estrella se desvaneció al acercarme.
Sin duda se había interpuesto entre ella y yo algún obstáculo.
I put out my hand to feel the dark mass before me: I discriminated the rough stones of a low wall--above it, something like palisades, and within, a high and prickly hedge.
Extendí la mano y toqué un muro bajo y tras él un alto seto.
I groped on.
Again a whitish object gleamed before me: it was a gate--a wicket; it moved on its hinges as I touched it.
On each side stood a sable bush-holly or yew.
Lo seguí, hasta dar con un postigo, que giró sobre sus goznes al empujarlo.
Entering the gate and passing the shrubs, the silhouette of a house rose to view, black, low, and rather long; but the guiding light shone nowhere.
Pasado el postigo, la silueta de una casa se elevó ante mí.
Era baja, oscura y bastante grande.
All was obscurity.
Al presente no se veía en ella luz alguna.
Were the inmates retired to rest?
I feared it must be so.
¿Se habrían acostado sus moradores?

In seeking the door, I turned an angle: there shot out the friendly gleam again, from the lozenged panes of a very small latticed window, within a foot of the ground, made still smaller by the growth of ivy or some other creeping plant, whose leaves clustered thick over the portion of the house wall in which it was set.

Buscando la puerta, doblé un ángulo del edificio y volví a distinguir la anhelada luz brotando de una ventanita enrejada, pequeña y que lo parecía más aún porque la ocultaba en parte la hiedra que revestía el muro de aquella parte de la casa.
The aperture was so screened and narrow, that curtain or shutter had been deemed unnecessary; and when I stooped down and put aside the spray of foliage shooting over it, I could see all within.
Las ventanas no tenían cortina y, a través de sus cristales, pude ver el interior.
I could see clearly a room with a sanded floor, clean scoured; a dresser of walnut, with pewter plates ranged in rows, reflecting the redness and radiance of a glowing peat-fire.

Era una estancia muy limpia, de suelo de tierra apisonada, con un aparador de nogal sobre el que había colocadas varias filas de platos de peltre, en los que se reflejaba el resplandor de un buen fuego de turba.
I could see a clock, a white deal table, some chairs.
Vi un reloj, una mesa blanca, varias sillas...
The candle, whose ray had been my beacon, burnt on the table; and by its light an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but scrupulously clean, like all about her, was knitting a stocking.
La vela que fuera mi guía en la oscuridad se hallaba sobre la mesa y a su luz una mujer, tosca, pero tan limpia como cuanto la rodeaba, hacía calceta.
I noticed these objects cursorily only--in them there was nothing extraordinary.
Todo aquello no tenía nada de extraordinario.
A group of more interest appeared near the hearth, sitting still amidst the rosy peace and warmth suffusing it.

Two young, graceful women--ladies in every point--sat, one in a low rocking-chair, the other on a lower stool; both wore deep mourning of crape and bombazeen, which sombre garb singularly set off very fair necks and faces: a large old pointer dog rested its massive head on the knee of one girl--in the lap of the other was cushioned a black cat.
Pero junto al fuego había algo más: dos jóvenes, evidentemente dos señoritas, vestidas de luto, sentadas, una en una mecedora baja y otra en un taburete.
Un gran perro de caza apoyaba su maciza cabeza en las rodillas de una de las muchachas y un gato negro dormía en el regazo de la otra.
A strange place was this humble kitchen for such occupants!
Who were they?
¡Extraño lugar era aquella humilde cocina para las dos exquisitas jóvenes que la ocupaban!
They could not be the daughters of the elderly person at the table; for she looked like a rustic, and they were all delicacy and cultivation.
Con toda certeza, no eran hijas de la mujer sentada a la mesa, porque tenían tanto de delicadas y distinguidas como ella de rústica.
I had nowhere seen such faces as theirs: and yet, as I gazed on them, I seemed intimate with every lineament.
Jamás había visto rostros como los de aquellas mujeres.
I cannot call them handsome--they were too pale and grave for the word: as they each bent over a book, they looked thoughtful almost to severity.
No cabe llamarlas hermosas, porque eran demasiado graves, pálidas y pensativas para aplicarles tal adjetivo.

A stand between them supported a second candle and two great volumes, to which they frequently referred, comparing them, seemingly, with the smaller books they held in their hands, like people consulting a dictionary to aid them in the task of translation.

Cada una tenía en la mano un tomito y en una mesa entre las dos había otra vela y dos gruesos volúmenes, que de vez en cuando consultaban, comparándolo con el texto de sus libros respectivos, como se hace cuando se traduce.

This scene was as silent as if all the figures had been shadows and the firelit apartment a picture: so hushed was it, I could hear the cinders fall from the grate, the clock tick in its obscure corner; and I even fancied I could distinguish the click-click of the woman's knitting-needles.

Todo transcurría en tan hondo silencio como si aquellos seres fueran sombras y el conjunto un cuadro, hasta el punto de que yo podía percibir el chisporroteo de la lumbre, el tictac del reloj y el choque de las agujas con que la mujer hacía calceta.
When, therefore, a voice broke the strange stillness at last, it was audible enough to me.
Al fin una voz rompió el silencio:
"Listen, Diana," said one of the absorbed students; "Franz and old Daniel are together in the night-time, and Franz is telling a dream from which he has awakened in terror--listen!"
-Escucha, Diana -dijo una de las absortas lectoras-.
Franz y el viejo Daniel se hallaban juntos esta noche y Franz está contando un sueño del que ha despertado aterrorizado.
And in a low voice she read something, of which not one word was intelligible to me; for it was in an unknown tongue--neither French nor Latin.
Oye...
Y leyó, en voz baja, algo ininteligible para mí: ni francés ni latín.
Whether it were Greek or German I could not tell.
Si era griego, alemán u otro idioma, imposible saberlo.
"That is strong," she said, when she had finished: "I relish it."
-Es muy enérgico -dijo al terminar-.
Me gusta mucho.
The other girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister, repeated, while she gazed at the fire, a line of what had been read.
La otra muchacha, mirando al fuego, repitió una línea de las que le habían sido leídas.
At a later day, I knew the language and the book; therefore, I will here quote the line: though, when I first heard it, it was only like a stroke on sounding brass to me--conveying no meaning:--
Más tarde supe de qué libro se trataba.
Citaré, pues, lo que ella repitió, aunque entonces me fue del todo incomprensible:
"'Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die Sternen Nacht.'
-Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie di Sternen Nacht.
Good! good!" she exclaimed, while her dark and deep eye sparkled.
¡Muy bien! -exclamó, abriendo mucho sus oscuros y profundos ojos-.
"There you have a dim and mighty archangel fitly set before you!
¡Cuánto me gusta!
The line is worth a hundred pages of fustian.
Una sola línea de éstas vale por cien páginas de prosa rebuscada.
'Ich wage die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.'
Ich wäge die Gedanken in der Schale meines Zornes un die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms...
I like it!"
Both were again silent.
Ambas callaron de nuevo.
"Is there ony country where they talk i' that way?" asked the old woman, looking up from her knitting.
-¿Existe algún país donde hablen de ese modo? -les preguntó la anciana.
"Yes, Hannah--a far larger country than England, where they talk in no other way."
-Sí, Hannah: un país mayor que Inglaterra.
"Well, for sure case, I knawn't how they can understand t' one t'other: and if either o' ye went there, ye could tell what they said, I guess?"
-¡No sé cómo pueden entenderse!
Si viniera aquí uno de los que hablan así, ¿le entenderían ustedes?
"We could probably tell something of what they said, but not all--for we are not as clever as you think us, Hannah.
-Algo de lo que dijera, sí, pero todo no, porque no somos lo inteligentes que usted cree, Hannah.
