We don't speak German, and we cannot read it without a dictionary to help us."
No hablamos alemán ni somos capaces de leerlo sin ayuda del diccionario.
"And what good does it do you?"
-¿Y para qué sirve estudiar eso?
"We mean to teach it some time--or at least the elements, as they say; and then we shall get more money than we do now."
-Nos proponemos aprenderlo mejor y entonces podremos ganar más dinero del que ganamos ahora.
"Varry like: but give ower studying; ye've done enough for to-night."
-Eso está bien.
Pero déjense ya de estudiar.
Basta por hoy.
"I think we have: at least I'm tired.
-Sí.
Yo estoy fatigada.
Mary, are you?"
¿Y tú, Mary?
"Mortally: after all, it's tough work fagging away at a language with no master but a lexicon."
-Mucho.
Es muy trabajoso aprender sin profesor, sólo con el diccionario.
"It is, especially such a language as this crabbed but glorious Deutsch.
-Y sobre todo un lenguaje como este admirable alemán...
I wonder when St. John will come home."
Oye, ¿cómo no habrá vuelto John todavía?
-No tardará.
"Surely he will not be long now: it is just ten (looking at a little gold watch she drew from her girdle).
Son las diez en punto-dijo la interpelada, mirando su relojito de oro-.
Y está lloviendo.
It rains fast, Hannah: will you have the goodness to look at the fire in the parlour?"
Hannah, ¿quiere tener la bondad de mirar cómo está el fuego del salón?
The woman rose: she opened a door, through which I dimly saw a passage: soon I heard her stir a fire in an inner room; she presently came back.
La mujer abrió una puerta, desapareció por un pasillo, la sentí atizar la lumbre.
Luego reapareció.
"Ah, childer!" said she, "it fair troubles me to go into yond' room now: it looks so lonesome wi' the chair empty and set back in a corner."
-¡Ay, niñas -dijo al volver-, qué pena me da entrar en ese cuarto y ver aquel sillón vacío!
She wiped her eyes with her apron: the two girls, grave before, looked sad now.
Se secó los ojos con el delantal.
Las dos muchachas se entristecieron.
"But he is in a better place," continued Hannah: "we shouldn't wish him here again.
-¡Pero ahora está en otro mundo mejor! -continuó Hannah-.
Más vale que se encuentre allí.
And then, nobody need to have a quieter death nor he had."
¡Todos quisiéramos morir tan serenamente como él!
"You say he never mentioned us?" inquired one of the ladies.
-¿No le habló de nosotros antes de fallecer? -inquirió una de las jóvenes.
"He hadn't time, bairn: he was gone in a minute, was your father.
He had been a bit ailing like the day before, but naught to signify; and when Mr. St. John asked if he would like either o' ye to be sent for, he fair laughed at him.
-No tuvo tiempo.
Su pobre padre se había sentido un poco mal el día antes, pero no le dio importancia, y cuando el señorito John le preguntó si quería que enviase a buscar a una de ustedes, se puso a reír.
Al día siguiente -hoy hace quince- volvió a sentir dolor de cabeza.

He began again with a bit of a heaviness in his head the next day--that is, a fortnight sin'--and he went to sleep and niver wakened: he wor a'most stark when your brother went into t' chamber and fand him.
Se durmió y no despertó más.
Cuando el hermano de ustedes entró en la habitación, le encontró ya rígido.
Ah, childer! that's t' last o' t' old stock--for ye and Mr. St. John is like of different soart to them 'at's gone; for all your mother wor mich i' your way, and a'most as book-learned.
She wor the pictur' o' ye, Mary: Diana is more like your father."

La vieja sirvienta, en el dialecto de la región, se extendió en consideraciones familiares, asegurando que Mary era el vivo retrato de su difunta madre y Diana más parecida a su padre, cosa que para mí resultaba incomprensible, pues las dos muchachas me parecían casi idénticas.
I thought them so similar I could not tell where the old servant (for such I now concluded her to be) saw the difference.
Both were fair complexioned and slenderly made; both possessed faces full of distinction and intelligence.
Ambas eran esbeltas y bellas, ambas distinguidas, ambas tenían aspecto de muy inteligentes.

One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker than the other, and there was a difference in their style of wearing it; Mary's pale brown locks were parted and braided smooth: Diana's duskier tresses covered her neck with thick curls.
Cierto que el cabello de una era algo más oscuro que el de la otra y que se lo peinaban de modo diferente: Mary, liso y con rayas; Diana, con tirabuzones.
The clock struck ten.
El reloj dio las diez.
"Ye'll want your supper, I am sure," observed Hannah; "and so will Mr. St. John when he comes in."
-Supongo -observó Hannah- que en cuanto venga su hermano desearán cenar.
And she proceeded to prepare the meal.
Y comenzó a preparar la cena.
The ladies rose; they seemed about to withdraw to the parlour.
Las muchachas se fueron, probablemente al salón.
Till this moment, I had been so intent on watching them, their appearance and conversation had excited in me so keen an interest, I had half-forgotten my own wretched position: now it recurred to me.
More desolate, more desperate than ever, it seemed from contrast.
Hasta entonces yo había estado tan atenta a observarlas, y tanto me habían interesado, que incluso me olvidé de mí misma.
Pero ahora me acordé de mí, y mi situación, por el contraste, se me presentó más desolada y desesperada que nunca.

And how impossible did it appear to touch the inmates of this house with concern on my behalf; to make them believe in the truth of my wants and woes--to induce them to vouchsafe a rest for my wanderings!
Imposible impresionar a los moradores de la casa con el relato de lo que me sucedía; no me creerían, no me concederían albergue...
As I groped out the door, and knocked at it hesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera.
Así pensaba mientras, vacilante, llamaba a la puerta.
Hannah opened.
Hannah abrió.
"What do you want?" she inquired, in a voice of surprise, as she surveyed me by the light of the candle she held.
-¿Qué desea? -inquirió, sorprendida, examinándome a la luz de la bujía que llevaba en la mano.
"May I speak to your mistresses?"
I said.
-¿Puedo hablar a una de las señoritas? -pregunté.
"You had better tell me what you have to say to them.
-Mejor será que me diga a mí lo que fuera a decirles a ellas.
Where do you come from?"
"I am a stranger."
-Soy forastera...
"What is your business here at this hour?"
-¿Y qué hace por aquí a estas horas?
"I want a night's shelter in an out-house or anywhere, and a morsel of bread to eat."
-Quisiera que me dieran albergue por esta noche, en el pajar o donde sea, y un poco de pan.
Distrust, the very feeling I dreaded, appeared in Hannah's face.
En el rostro de Hannah se pintó la expresión de contrariedad que yo temía y aguardaba.
"I'll give you a piece of bread," she said, after a pause; "but we can't take in a vagrant to lodge.
It isn't likely."
-Le daré pan-dijo, tras una pausa-, pero albergue no es posible.
"Do let me speak to your mistresses."
-Déjeme hablar con sus señoritas.
"No, not I. What can they do for you?
-No.
¿Qué van ellas a remediarle?
You should not be roving about now; it looks very ill."
¡Y le aconsejo que no vagabundee por acá!
"But where shall I go if you drive me away?
-¿Y qué voy a hacer si me hecha usted?
What shall I do?"
¿Qué haré?
"Oh, I'll warrant you know where to go and what to do.
-¡Ya sabe usted muy bien adónde ir y qué hacer!
Mind you don't do wrong, that's all.
Here is a penny; now go--"
¡Ea, tome un penique y váyase!
"A penny cannot feed me, and I have no strength to go farther.
-¿Para qué quiero un penique?
¡Si no tengo ni fuerzas para moverme!
Don't shut the door:--oh, don't, for God's sake!"
¡No cierre, no cierre, por amor de Dios!
"I must; the rain is driving in--"
-Tengo que cerrar.
Está entrando la lluvia.
"Tell the young ladies.
Let me see them--"
-Hable a las señoritas, presénteme a ellas.
"Indeed, I will not.
-No quiero.
You are not what you ought to be, or you wouldn't make such a noise.
No es usted una mujer como debe.
No alborote.
Move off."
Váyase.
"But I must die if I am turned away."
-¡Me moriré si me quedo esta noche al aire libre!
"Not you.
-No.
I'm fear'd you have some ill plans agate, that bring you about folk's houses at this time o' night.
Seguramente la mandan a usted algunos salteadores, para averiguar el modo de robar la casa.
If you've any followers--housebreakers or such like--anywhere near, you may tell them we are not by ourselves in the house; we have a gentleman, and dogs, and guns."
Pero ya puede decirles que aquí hay un hombre, perros y escopetas.
Here the honest but inflexible servant clapped the door to and bolted it within.
Y la honrada, pero inflexible sirvienta, cerró la puerta.
This was the climax.
A pang of exquisite suffering--a throe of true despair--rent and heaved my heart.
Un sufrimiento inmenso, una desesperación infinita colmaron mi corazón.
Worn out, indeed, I was; not another step could I stir.
No pude dar un solo paso.
I sank on the wet doorstep: I groaned--I wrung my hands--I wept in utter anguish.
Me senté en el peldaño de la puerta, con los pies sobre el suelo mojado, junté las manos y lloré con angustia.
Oh, this spectre of death!
Oh, this last hour, approaching in such horror!
¡Oh, el espectro de la muerte, la visión de la última hora que se aproxima con todos sus horrores!
Alas, this isolation--this banishment from my kind!
Más, al fin, pude recuperar mi presencia de ánimo.
Not only the anchor of hope, but the footing of fortitude was gone--at least for a moment; but the last I soon endeavoured to regain.
"I can but die," I said, "and I believe in God.
-Después de todo, bien puedo morir -dije-.
Let me try to wait His will in silence."
Creo en Dios y aguardaré resignada que se cumpla su voluntad.
These words I not only thought, but uttered; and thrusting back all my misery into my heart, I made an effort to compel it to remain there--dumb and still.
No sólo había pensado aquellas palabras, sino que mis labios las habían pronunciado en alta voz.
"All men must die," said a voice quite close at hand; "but all are not condemned to meet a lingering and premature doom, such as yours would be if you perished here of want."
-Todos hemos de morir -murmuró una voz muy próxima a mí-, pero no todos están condenados a perecer prematuramente de necesidad, como podría haberle sucedido a usted al pie de esta puerta.
"Who or what speaks?"
I asked, terrified at the unexpected sound, and incapable now of deriving from any occurrence a hope of aid.
-¿Quién o qué es lo que me habla así? -exclamé, aterrorizada.
No contaba ya con la posibilidad alguna de ayuda de nadie.
A form was near--what form, the pitch-dark night and my enfeebled vision prevented me from distinguishing.
Junto a mí había una figura que mis sentidos debilitados y la oscuridad de la noche no me permitían distinguir bien.
With a loud long knock, the new-comer appealed to the door.
El recién llegado llamó fuertemente a la puerta.
"Is it you, Mr. St. John?" cried Hannah.
-¿Es usted, señorito John? -preguntó Hannah.
"Yes--yes; open quickly."
-Sí.
Abra pronto.
"Well, how wet and cold you must be, such a wild night as it is!
-¡Debe usted llegar calado y muerto de frío!
¡Hay que ver la noche que hace!
Come in--your sisters are quite uneasy about you, and I believe there are bad folks about.
Entre; sus hermanas están preocupadas por usted y deben rondar malas gentes por los contornos.
There has been a beggar-woman--I declare she is not gone yet!--laid down there.
Ha estado una mendiga que...
¡Ah, si no se ha ido aún!
Get up! for shame!
Move off, I say!"
¡Lárguese!
"Hush, Hannah!
-¡Chist, Hannah!
I have a word to say to the woman.
Tengo que hablarla.
You have done your duty in excluding, now let me do mine in admitting her.
Usted ha cumplido su deber echándola y yo cumplo con el mío admitiéndola.
I was near, and listened to both you and her.
Yo estaba cerca de ustedes y las he oído hablar.
I think this is a peculiar case--I must at least examine into it.
Me parece que éste es un caso especial.
Young woman, rise, and pass before me into the house."
Joven: levántese y entre.
With difficulty I obeyed him.
Le obedecí, no sin dificultad.
Presently I stood within that clean, bright kitchen--on the very hearth--trembling, sickening; conscious of an aspect in the last degree ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten.
Me hallé en la agradable cocina, junto al fuego, bien consciente del maltratado y lamentable aspecto que debía presentar.
The two ladies, their brother, Mr. St. John, the old servant, were all gazing at me.
Las dos jóvenes, su hermano y la criada me contemplaban con atención.
"St. John, who is it?"
I heard one ask.
-¿Quién es, John? -oí preguntar a una de las hermanas.
"I cannot tell: I found her at the door," was the reply.
-No sé.
La he hallado a la puerta. -Está muy pálida-dijo Hannah.
"She does look white," said Hannah.
-Pálida como la muerte.
"As white as clay or death," was responded.
Sentadla.
"She will fall: let her sit."
Va a caerse si no.
And indeed my head swam: I dropped, but a chair received me.
Y, en efecto, se me iba la cabeza, y hubiera caído a no habérseme ofrecido oportunamente una silla.
I still possessed my senses, though just now I could not speak.
Aún conservaba el sentido, pero no podía hablar.
"Perhaps a little water would restore her.
Hannah, fetch some.
-Quizá le siente bien un poco de agua.
But she is worn to nothing.
Tráigala, Hannah.
How very thin, and how very bloodless!"
¡Qué delgada y qué lívida está!
"A mere spectre!"
-Parece un espectro.
"Is she ill, or only famished?"
-¿Estará enferma o famélica tan sólo?
"Famished, I think.
-Creo que sólo famélica.
Hannah, is that milk?
Give it me, and a piece of bread."
Hannah: deme pan y leche.
Diana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and the fire as she bent over me) broke some bread, dipped it in milk, and put it to my lips.
Diana -la reconocí por sus largos tirabuzones al inclinarse sobre mí- partió un trozo de pan, lo mojó en leche y me lo puso en los labios.
Her face was near mine: I saw there was pity in it, and I felt sympathy in her hurried breathing.
En su rostro, muy próximo al mío, leí simpatía y compasión.
In her simple words, too, the same balm-like emotion spoke: "Try to eat."
En las palabras que me dirigió había una emoción afectuosa: -Pruebe a comer.
"Yes--try," repeated Mary gently; and Mary's hand removed my sodden bonnet and lifted my head.
-Sí, pruebe -repitió Mary, mientras me quitaba el gorrito.
I tasted what they offered me: feebly at first, eagerly soon.
Y probé, en efecto, lo que me ofrecían.
Primero con timidez, luego con ansia.
"Not too much at first--restrain her," said the brother; "she has had enough."
-No le deis mucho de primera intención -indicó su hermano-.
Por ahora es bastante.
And he withdrew the cup of milk and the plate of bread.
Y retiró la taza de leche y el plato de pan.
"A little more, St. John--look at the avidity in her eyes."
-Un poco más, John, por favor.
¿No ves el hambre que tiene?
"No more at present, sister.
-No, hermana, ahora no.
Try if she can speak now--ask her her name."
Si puede hablar, preguntadla su nombre.
I felt I could speak, and I answered--"My name is Jane Elliott."
-Jane Elliott -contesté.
Anxious as ever to avoid discovery, I had before resolved to assume an _alias_.
Había resuelto usar un nombre supuesto para evitar que me descubriesen.
"And where do you live?
Where are your friends?"
-¿Dónde vive usted?
I was silent.
Callé.
"Can we send for any one you know?"
-¿Podemos enviar a buscar a sus parientes?
I shook my head.
Denegué con la cabeza.
"What account can you give of yourself?"
-¿Qué puede decirnos de sí misma?
Somehow, now that I had once crossed the threshold of this house, and once was brought face to face with its owners, I felt no longer outcast, vagrant, and disowned by the wide world.
I dared to put off the mendicant--to resume my natural manner and character.
Desde que había cruzado el umbral de aquella casa y me sentía entre mis semejantes volvía a ser la de siempre.
I began once more to know myself; and when Mr. St. John demanded an account--which at present I was far too weak to render--I said after a brief pause--
Dejaba de obrar como una mendiga y recuperaba mi carácter natural.
Incapaz de detallar mi situación, porque me sentía muy débil, repuse:
"Sir, I can give you no details to-night."
-No me siento con fuerzas para explicarme por esta noche.
"But what, then," said he, "do you expect me to do for you?"
-Y entonces, ¿qué desea usted de mí?
"Nothing," I replied.
My strength sufficed for but short answers.
Diana took the word--
Diana tomó la palabra:
"Do you mean," she asked, "that we have now given you what aid you require? and that we may dismiss you to the moor and the rainy night?"
-¡No supondrá usted que creemos haberla prestado toda la ayuda que necesita y que vamos a dejarla marchar en esta noche de lluvia!
I looked at her.
La miré.
She had, I thought, a remarkable countenance, instinct both with power and goodness.
En su rostro se pintaban, a la vez, bondad y la energía.
I took sudden courage.
Answering her compassionate gaze with a smile, I said-
Me animé y repuse con una sonrisa.
-"I will trust you.
-Deseo decirles la verdad sobre mí.
If I were a masterless and stray dog, I know that you would not turn me from your hearth to-night: as it is, I really have no fear.
Estoy segura de que, aunque fuera un perro perdido, no tendría usted valor para echarme fuera en una noche como ésta.
No lo temo, pues.
Do with me and for me as you like; but excuse me from much discourse--my breath is short--I feel a spasm when I speak."
Hagan lo que quieran conmigo, pero les ruego que no me fuercen a hablar mucho hoy, porque me falta el aliento.
All three surveyed me, and all three were silent.
Los tres me miraron en silencio.
-Hannah -dijo John, al fin-.
"Hannah," said Mr. St. John, at last, "let her sit there at present, and ask her no questions; in ten minutes more, give her the remainder of that milk and bread.
Déjela ahí sentada y no le pregunte nada por ahora.
De aquí a diez minutos dele el resto del pan y la leche.
Mary and Diana, let us go into the parlour and talk the matter over."
Nosotros vamos al salón para hablar de esto.
They withdrew.
Se fueron.
Very soon one of the ladies returned--I could not tell which.
Una de las jóvenes volvió al poco rato.
No sé cuál de las dos.
A kind of pleasant stupor was stealing over me as I sat by the genial fire.
Una especie de agradable entumecimiento me poseía mientras me hallaba sentada junto al magnífico fuego.
In an undertone she gave some directions to Hannah.
La muchacha, en voz baja, dio instrucciones a Hannah.
Ere long, with the servant's aid, I contrived to mount a staircase; my dripping clothes were removed; soon a warm, dry bed received me.
Ésta me ayudó a subir una escalera, me despojé de mis ropas empapadas y un lecho seco y cálido me acogió.
I thanked God--experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of grateful joy--and slept.
Di gracias a Dios, y me dormí con la impresión de que un rayo de luz disipaba las tinieblas de mi desventura.
CHAPTER XXIX
XXIX
The recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very dim in my mind.
El recuerdo de lo que sucedió durante los tres días y tres noches siguientes permanece muy oscuro en mi memoria.
I can recall some sensations felt in that interval; but few thoughts framed, and no actions performed.
Apenas me acuerdo de nada, porque nada hacía, ni en casi nada pensaba.
I knew I was in a small room and in a narrow bed.
Sé que estaba en un cuarto pequeño y en una cama estrecha.
To that bed I seemed to have grown; I lay on it motionless as a stone; and to have torn me from it would have been almost to kill me.
I took no note of the lapse of time--of the change from morning to noon, from noon to evening.
Permanecía en ella inmóvil como una piedra, sin poderme volver siquiera y sin apenas reparar en el transcurso del tiempo.

I observed when any one entered or left the apartment: I could even tell who they were; I could understand what was said when the speaker stood near to me; but I could not answer; to open my lips or move my limbs was equally impossible.
Notaba que entraban y salían personas en la alcoba, podía decir quiénes eran y oía lo que me hablaban, pero no podía contestarles, porque me era imposible abrir los labios ni mover los miembros.
Hannah, the servant, was my most frequent visitor.
Her coming disturbed me.
Hannah, la criada, era quien me visitaba con más frecuencia.
I had a feeling that she wished me away: that she did not understand me or my circumstances; that she was prejudiced against me.
Su presencia me disgustaba comprendiendo que ella habría preferido verme marchar y que sentía prevención contra mí.
Diana and Mary appeared in the chamber once or twice a day.
Diana y Mary entraban en la alcoba una o dos veces al día.
They would whisper sentences of this sort at my bedside--
A veces les oía comentar:
"It is very well we took her in."
-Hicimos bien en acogerla.
"Yes; she would certainly have been found dead at the door in the morning had she been left out all night.
-Sí, porque de lo contrario hubiese aparecido muerta en el umbral al día siguiente.
I wonder what she has gone through?"
¿Qué le habrá sucedido?
"Strange hardships, I imagine--poor, emaciated, pallid wanderer?"
-Azares de la vida, supongo...
¡Pobrecita! -No parece una persona ineducada.
"She is not an uneducated person, I should think, by her manner of speaking; her accent was quite pure; and the clothes she took off, though splashed and wet, were little worn and fine."
Habla con corrección y las ropas que se quitó eran bastante finas.
"She has a peculiar face; fleshless and haggard as it is, I rather like it; and when in good health and animated, I can fancy her physiognomy would be agreeable."
-Su cara es agradable, a pesar de lo demacrada que está.
Imagino que, sana y animada, debe tener un aspecto muy agradable.
Never once in their dialogues did I hear a syllable of regret at the hospitality they had extended to me, or of suspicion of, or aversion to, myself.
Nunca les oí lamentar la hospitalidad que me concedían ni expresar hacia mí sospecha alguna.
I was comforted.
Aquello me consolaba.
Mr. St. John came but once: he looked at me, and said my state of lethargy was the result of reaction from excessive and protracted fatigue.
John apareció sólo una vez, me examinó y dijo que mi estado era la consecuencia natural de una excesiva fatiga.
He pronounced it needless to send for a doctor: nature, he was sure, would manage best, left to herself.
He said every nerve had been overstrained in some way, and the whole system must sleep torpid a while.
There was no disease.
He imagined my recovery would be rapid enough when once commenced.
Juzgó innecesario llamar al médico, asegurando que la naturaleza obraría por sí misma; que había sufrido un fuerte trastorno nervioso y que en cuanto reaccionase me repondría muy de prisa.

These opinions he delivered in a few words, in a quiet, low voice; and added, after a pause, in the tone of a man little accustomed to expansive comment, "Rather an unusual physiognomy; certainly, not indicative of vulgarity or degradation."
Habló en términos concisos, añadiendo, tras una pausa, con tono de hombre poco acostumbrado a expansiones verbales: -Su semblante es poco vulgar y por cierto no el de un ser degradado.
"Far otherwise," responded Diana.
-Nada de eso -dijo Diana-.
"To speak truth, St. John, my heart rather warms to the poor little soul.
I wish we may be able to benefit her permanently."
A decir verdad, John, quisiera que pudiésemos favorecerla de un modo más eficiente.
"That is hardly likely," was the reply.
-Eso quizá sea difícil -repuso él-.
"You will find she is some young lady who has had a misunderstanding with her friends, and has probably injudiciously left them.
Probablemente averiguaremos que es una joven que ha tenido alguna riña con sus parientes e irreflexivamente les ha abandonado.
We may, perhaps, succeed in restoring her to them, if she is not obstinate: but I trace lines of force in her face which make me sceptical of her tractability."
He stood considering me some minutes; then added, "She looks sensible, but not at all handsome."
Tal vez consigamos hacerla volver con ellos, si no es muy obstinada.
Mas por la expresión de su rostro me parece que no debe de tener nada de dócil -y agregó, tras contemplarme unos minutos-: Debe de ser inteligente, pero no tiene nada de guapa.
"She is so ill, St. John."
-Está enferma, John.
"Ill or well, she would always be plain.
-Enferma o no, no debe de ser guapa nunca.
The grace and harmony of beauty are quite wanting in those features."
La gracia y la belleza me parecen ausentes de sus facciones.
On the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise in bed, and turn.
Al tercer día me sentí mejor y al cuarto pude hablar, moverme y hasta sentarme en la cama.
Hannah had brought me some gruel and dry toast, about, as I supposed, the dinner-hour.
I had eaten with relish: the food was good--void of the feverish flavour which had hitherto poisoned what I had swallowed.
Hannah me trajo, a la hora de comer, una sopa y unas tostadas, que paladeé con deleite.
When she left me, I felt comparatively strong and revived: ere long satiety of repose and desire for action stirred me.
Cuando se fue me sentí relativamente vigorosa, harta de descanso y necesitada de acción.
I wished to rise; but what could I put on?
Hubiese querido levantarme, pero ¿cómo vestirme?
Only my damp and bemired apparel; in which I had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh.
Mis ropas debían de estar sucias y arrugadas como consecuencia de las noches al raso.
I felt ashamed to appear before my benefactors so clad.
I was spared the humiliation.
Miré en torno mío.
On a chair by the bedside were all my own things, clean and dry.
Todas mis prendas, lavadas y secas, estaban en una silla.
My black silk frock hung against the wall.
The traces of the bog were removed from it; the creases left by the wet smoothed out: it was quite decent.
Mi vestido de seda negra colgaba de la pared.
My very shoes and stockings were purified and rendered presentable.
Mis medias y mis zapatos estaban limpios.
There were the means of washing in the room, and a comb and brush to smooth my hair.
En la habitación había lavabo y un peine.
After a weary process, and resting every five minutes, I succeeded in dressing myself.

My clothes hung loose on me; for I was much wasted, but I covered deficiencies with a shawl, and once more, clean and respectable looking--no speck of the dirt, no trace of the disorder I so hated, and which seemed so to degrade me, left--I crept down a stone staircase with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow low passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.

Me arreglé rápidamente, me vestí, me cubrí con un chal y, ya recobrado mi aspecto correcto y desaparecida toda traza del desorden que tanto aborrecía y tan rebajada me hacía sentirme, bajé, apoyándome en el pasamanos, una escalera de piedra, y me encontré en la cocina.
It was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous fire.
Sentíase un fuerte aroma a pan caliente y ardía en el hogar un espléndido fuego.
Hannah was baking.
Hannah estaba amasando.
Prejudices, it is well known, are most difficult to eradicate from the heart whose soil has never been loosened or fertilised by education: they grow there, firm as weeds among stones.
Como es notorio, los prejuicios son más difíciles de desarraigar en las naturalezas no cultivadas, en las que se afincan como el musgo entre las piedras.
Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first: latterly she had begun to relent a little; and when she saw me come in tidy and well-dressed, she even smiled.
Hannah, desde el principio, había obrado fría y secamente conmigo.
Después había amainado un tanto su antipatía.
Y ahora, al verme arreglada y bien vestida, incluso me sonrió.
"What, you have got up!" she said.
-¡Vaya, ya está usted mejor! -dijo-.
"You are better, then.
Siéntese junto al fuego, si quiere.
You may sit you down in my chair on the hearthstone, if you will."
Señalaba la mecedora.
Me acomodé en ella.
She pointed to the rocking-chair: I took it.
De vez en cuando me examinaba a hurtadillas.
She bustled about, examining me every now and then with the corner of her eye.
Turning to me, as she took some loaves from the oven, she asked bluntly--
De repente, me preguntó:
"Did you ever go a-begging afore you came here?"
-Antes de estar aquí, ¿pedía limosna?

I was indignant for a moment; but remembering that anger was out of the question, and that I had indeed appeared as a beggar to her, I answered quietly, but still not without a certain marked firmness--
Me indigné, pero comprendiendo que toda actitud estaba completamente fuera de lugar, ya que, en efecto, había aparecido ante ella como una pordiosera, repuse con firmeza, sin alterarme:
"You are mistaken in supposing me a beggar.
-Se engaña suponiéndome una mendiga.
I am no beggar; any more than yourself or your young ladies."
No lo soy más que lo pueda ser usted o una de sus señoritas.
After a pause she said, "I dunnut understand that: you've like no house, nor no brass, I guess?"
-No lo comprendo -dijo, después de una pausa-, porque me parece que no tiene usted casa ni parneses.
"The want of house or brass (by which I suppose you mean money) does not make a beggar in your sense of the word."
-El carecer de casa y de dinero, que es lo que supongo que quiere indicar diciendo parneses, no hacen a una persona ser una mendiga en el sentido que da usted a la palabra.
"Are you book-learned?" she inquired presently.
-¿Sabe usted leer? -preguntó.
"Yes, very."
-Sí.
"But you've never been to a boarding-school?"
-¿Y cómo, no habiendo estado en la escuela?
"I was at a boarding-school eight years."
-He estado en la escuela ocho años.
She opened her eyes wide.
Abrió los ojos desmesuradamente.
"Whatever cannot ye keep yourself for, then?"
-Y entonces, ¿cómo no gana usted para vivir?
"I have kept myself; and, I trust, shall keep myself again.
-He ganado para vivir y volveré a ganar de nuevo.
What are you going to do with these gooseberries?"
I inquired, as she brought out a basket of the fruit.
¿Qué va a hacer usted con estas uvas?
"Mak' 'em into pies."
-Pastelillos.
"Give them to me and I'll pick them."
-Iré escogiendo las uvas, si quiere. -No.
"Nay; I dunnut want ye to do nought."
No me hace falta que me ayuden. -Vamos, déjeme.
"But I must do something.
Let me have them."
No voy a estar sin hacer nada.
She consented; and she even brought me a clean towel to spread over my dress, "lest," as she said, "I should mucky it."
Consintió al fin y me puso un paño de cocina sobre el vestido para que no me lo ensuciase, según dijo.
"Ye've not been used to sarvant's wark, I see by your hands," she remarked.
-Ya veo -comentó mientras yo trabajaba- que no está acostumbrada a faenas de éstas.
"Happen ye've been a dressmaker?"
Acaso haya sido usted modista.
"No, you are wrong.
-No.
And now, never mind what I have been: don't trouble your head further about me; but tell me the name of the house where we are."
Pero eso no importa.
Dígame, ¿cómo se llama esta casa?
"Some calls it Marsh End, and some calls it Moor House."
-Unos la llaman Marsh End y otros Moor House.
"And the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?"
-¿Y el señor que vive aquí se llama Mr.
Rivers?
"Nay; he doesn't live here: he is only staying a while.
-No vive aquí; está de temporada.
When he is at home, he is in his own parish at Morton."
Es párroco de Morton.
"That village a few miles off?
-¿Esa aldea a pocas millas de distancia?
"Aye."
-Sí.
"And what is he?"
"He is a parson."
I remembered the answer of the old housekeeper at the parsonage, when I had asked to see the clergyman.
Me acordé de la respuesta que el ama de llaves de la rectoral de aquel pueblo me diera, y dije:
"This, then, was his father's residence?"
-Entonces, ¿era ésta la casa de su padre?
"Aye; old Mr. Rivers lived here, and his father, and grandfather, and gurt (great) grandfather afore him."
-Sí: aquí vivió el anciano Rivers, y su abuelo y su tatarabuelo...
"The name, then, of that gentleman, is Mr. St. John Rivers?"
-¿Así que ese señor se llama John Rivers?
"Aye; St. John is like his kirstened name."
-Sí.
"And his sisters are called Diana and Mary Rivers?"
-¿Y sus hermanas Diana y Mary Rivers?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"Their father is dead?"
-¿Y su padre ha muerto? -De apoplejía.
"Dead three weeks sin' of a stroke."
Hace tres semanas.
"They have no mother?"
-¿No tienen madre?
"The mistress has been dead this mony a year."
-Murió hace mucho.
"Have you lived with the family long?"
-¿Lleva usted tiempo con la familia?
"I've lived here thirty year.
-Treinta años.
I nursed them all three."
He criado a los tres muchachos.
"That proves you must have been an honest and faithful servant.
I will say so much for you, though you have had the incivility to call me a beggar."
-Eso prueba que es usted una servidora leal y honrada, lo que me complace saber, aunque haya tenido la descortesía de llamarme pordiosera.
She again regarded me with a surprised stare.
Me miró con asombro.
"I believe," she said, "I was quite mista'en in my thoughts of you: but there is so mony cheats goes about, you mun forgie me."
-Ya veo -dijo- que me equivocaba en mi juicio, pero hay tantos bribones por los contornos, que...
En fin, perdone.
"And though," I continued, rather severely, "you wished to turn me from the door, on a night when you should not have shut out a dog."
-Y a pesar -continué, con aumentada severidad de que usted quería echarme fuera una noche en que no se hubiera debido negar refugio ni a un perro.
"Well, it was hard: but what can a body do?
-¿Qué iba a hacer?
I thought more o' th' childer nor of mysel: poor things!
No era por mí, sino por las pobres niñas.
They've like nobody to tak' care on 'em but me.
I'm like to look sharpish."
Si no me preocupo de ellas, ¿quién va a preocuparse?
I maintained a grave silence for some minutes.
Guardé profundo silencio durante algunos minutos.
"You munnut think too hardly of me," she again remarked.
-No debe juzgarme mal -dijo Hannah.

"But I do think hardly of you," I said; "and I'll tell you why--not so much because you refused to give me shelter, or regarded me as an impostor, as because you just now made it a species of reproach that I had no 'brass' and no house.
-La juzgo mal -repuse-, no tanto porque aquella noche me negase cobijo, sino por el reproche que me ha dirigido de que no tengo casa ni parneses.
Some of the best people that ever lived have been as destitute as I am; and if you are a Christian, you ought not to consider poverty a crime."
Si es usted cristiana, no debe considerar la pobreza como un crimen. -Ya sé que no debo -repuso-.
"No more I ought," said she: "Mr. St. John tells me so too; and I see I wor wrang--but I've clear a different notion on you now to what I had.
El señorito John me lo dice a menudo.
Ahora, además, ya la considero a usted de otro modo.
You look a raight down dacent little crater."
Hice mal.
"That will do--I forgive you now.
Shake hands."
-Bien: todo olvidado.
She put her floury and horny hand into mine; another and heartier smile illumined her rough face, and from that moment we were friends.
Deme la mano.
Puso sus rugosos y bastos dedos en los míos, sonrió y desde entonces fuimos amigas.
Hannah was evidently fond of talking.
A Hannah le gustaba mucho la charla.
While I picked the fruit, and she made the paste for the pies, she proceeded to give me sundry details about her deceased master and mistress, and "the childer," as she called the young people.
Mientras yo escogía la fruta y ella amasaba la harina para los pastelillos me dio amplios detalles sobre sus difuntos señores y sobre los niños, como llamaba a los jóvenes.
Según sus informes, el viejo Mr.
Old Mr. Rivers, she said, was a plain man enough, but a gentleman, and of as ancient a family as could be found.
Rivers pertenecía a una antigua familia y era todo un caballero, aunque muy llano en su trato.

Marsh End had belonged to the Rivers ever since it was a house: and it was, she affirmed, "aboon two hundred year old--for all it looked but a small, humble place, naught to compare wi' Mr. Oliver's grand hall down i' Morton Vale.
Marsh End pertenecía a los Rivers desde que se construyera, más de doscientos años atrás.

But she could remember Bill Oliver's father a journeyman needlemaker; and th' Rivers wor gentry i' th' owd days o' th' Henrys, as onybody might see by looking into th' registers i' Morton Church vestry."
Still, she allowed, "the owd maister was like other folk--naught mich out o' t' common way: stark mad o' shooting, and farming, and sich like."

Y aunque fuese una casa muy modesta comparada con la magnífica residencia de los Oliver, en el valle de Morton, ella recordaba bien la época en que el padre de Bill Oliver trabajaba como jornalero en una fábrica de agujas, mientras que los Rivers eran hidalgos desde los tiempos del rey Enrique, como constaba en los archivos de la parroquia de Morton.
Sin embargo, a Mr.
The mistress was different.
Rivers, hombre muy sencillo, le gustaba cazar, ocuparse en la labranza «y todo eso».
She was a great reader, and studied a deal; and the "bairns" had taken after her.
La señora había sido diferente.
Leía mucho, estudiaba mucho y sus hijos habían «salido a ella».
There was nothing like them in these parts, nor ever had been; they had liked learning, all three, almost from the time they could speak; and they had always been "of a mak' of their own."
En la comarca no existía quien les igualase.

Mr. St. John, when he grew up, would go to college and be a parson; and the girls, as soon as they left school, would seek places as governesses: for they had told her their father had some years ago lost a great deal of money by a man he had trusted turning bankrupt; and as he was now not rich enough to give them fortunes, they must provide for themselves.

El señorito John, al salir del colegio, se ordenó de sacerdote, y las muchachas, al dejar la escuela, se colocaron como institutrices, porque su padre había perdido, años atrás, mucho dinero en una quiebra y ellas tenían que ganarse la vida.
Les gustaba mucho aquel sitio, y aunque solían vivir en Londres y otras grandes ciudades, afirmaban que ninguna les complacía tanto como Moor House.

They had lived very little at home for a long while, and were only come now to stay a few weeks on account of their father's death; but they did so like Marsh End and Morton, and all these moors and hills about.
Se encontraban allí ahora pasando unas semanas con motivo de la muerte de su padre.
They had been in London, and many other grand towns; but they always said there was no place like home; and then they were so agreeable with each other--never fell out nor "threaped."
She did not know where there was such a family for being united.
Según Hannah, los tres miembros supervivientes de la familia vivían en una unión admirable entre sí.
Having finished my task of gooseberry picking, I asked where the two ladies and their brother were now.
Una vez terminada mi tarea con las uvas, pregunté dónde se hallaban los tres hermanos en aquel momento.
"Gone over to Morton for a walk; but they would be back in half-an-hour to tea."
-Se han acercado a Morton dando un paseo, pero volverán de aquí a media hora, para el té.
They returned within the time Hannah had allotted them: they entered by the kitchen door.
Regresaron, en efecto, cuando ella dijo, entrando por la puerta de la cocina.
John, al verme, se inclinó y siguió adelante.
Las jóvenes se entretuvieron conmigo.

Mr. St. John, when he saw me, merely bowed and passed through; the two ladies stopped: Mary, in a few words, kindly and calmly expressed the pleasure she felt in seeing me well enough to be able to come down; Diana took my hand: she shook her head at me.
Mary, en pocas palabras, me expresó el agrado que le causaba verme restablecida.
Diana me tomó la mano y movió la cabeza.
"You should have waited for my leave to descend," she said.
"You still look very pale--and so thin!
-Debía de haber esperado que fuese yo para ayudarla a bajar ¡Qué pálida y qué delgada se ha quedado usted, pobrecita!
Poor child!--poor girl!"
Diana had a voice toned, to my ear, like the cooing of a dove.
La voz de Diana sonaba en mi oído tan dulce como el arrullo de una paloma.
She possessed eyes whose gaze I delighted to encounter.
Me encantaba la mirada de sus ojos, la expresión de su faz.
Her whole face seemed to me full of charm.
Mary's countenance was equally intelligent--her features equally pretty; but her expression was more reserved, and her manners, though gentle, more distant.
Mary, de aspecto igualmente inteligente, de rostro igualmente bello, era más reservada, menos expansiva, aunque muy amable.
Diana looked and spoke with a certain authority: she had a will, evidently.
Diana hablaba y miraba con cierta autoridad.
Evidentemente, era una mujer voluntariosa.
It was my nature to feel pleasure in yielding to an authority supported like hers, and to bend, where my conscience and self-respect permitted, to an active will.
Y estaba en mi carácter aceptar con gusto una autoridad tan suave como la suya y plegarme, hasta donde mi dignidad me lo permitiese, a una voluntad más enérgica que la mía.
"And what business have you here?" she continued.
-¿Por qué está aquí? -preguntó-.
"It is not your place.
Éste no es el sitio adecuado para usted:
Mary and I sit in the kitchen sometimes, because at home we like to be free, even to license--but you are a visitor, and must go into the parlour."
Mary y yo nos sentamos a veces junto al fogón, pero nosotras estamos en casa y tenemos derecho a no andar con cumplidos.
Pero usted es una visitante y debe estar en el salón.
"I am very well here."
-Me encuentro muy bien aquí.
"Not at all, with Hannah bustling about and covering you with flour."
-No lo creo.
Hannah está amasando y llenándola de harina.
"Besides, the fire is too hot for you," interposed Mary.
-Y el fuego es demasiado fuerte para usted -agregó Mary.
"To be sure," added her sister.
-Claro --concluyó su hermana-.
"Come, you must be obedient."
And still holding my hand she made me rise, and led me into the inner room.
Vamos, sea obediente. -Y tomándome de la mano me llevó al salón.

"Sit there," she said, placing me on the sofa, "while we take our things off and get the tea ready; it is another privilege we exercise in our little moorland home--to prepare our own meals when we are so inclined, or when Hannah is baking, brewing, washing, or ironing."
-Siéntese ahí -dijo, colocándome en un sofá-.
Nosotras vamos a hervir el té, porque uno de los privilegios que nos permitimos en nuestra casa es preparar nosotras mismas las cosas cuando nos apetece o bien cuando Hannah está muy ocupada.
She closed the door, leaving me solus with Mr. St. John, who sat opposite, a book or newspaper in his hand.
Y cerró la puerta, dejándome sola con John Rivers que, en el extremo opuesto del salón, leía no sé si un periódico o un libro.
I examined first, the parlour, and then its occupant.
Examiné primero el aposento y luego a su ocupante.
The parlour was rather a small room, very plainly furnished, yet comfortable, because clean and neat.
La estancia era pequeña y modesta, pero cuidada y limpia.
The old-fashioned chairs were very bright, and the walnut-wood table was like a looking-glass.
Las sillas, de antañón estilo, eran muy cómodas y la mesa de nogal brillaba como un espejo.
A few strange, antique portraits of the men and women of other days decorated the stained walls; a cupboard with glass doors contained some books and an ancient set of china.
Viejos retratos de hombres y mujeres de otros días decoraban las paredes.
Una alacena de puertas de cristal contenía varios libros y un antiguo juego de porcelana.

There was no superfluous ornament in the room--not one modern piece of furniture, save a brace of workboxes and a lady's desk in rosewood, which stood on a side-table: everything--including the carpet and curtains--looked at once well worn and well saved.
No había un solo adorno superfluo, ni un solo mueble moderno, excepto dos costureros y un escritorio de señora, de palisandro.
Todo lo más, incluso cortinajos y alfombras, parecía tan viejo como bien conservado.
Mr. St. John--sitting as still as one of the dusty pictures on the walls, keeping his eyes fixed on the page he perused, and his lips mutely sealed--was easy enough to examine.
John Rivers, inmóvil cual uno de los retratos que pendían de los muros, fijos los ojos en la página que leía, fue para mí fácil objeto de examen.
Had he been a statue instead of a man, he could not have been easier.
Una estatua no lo hubiera sido más.

He was young--perhaps from twenty- eight to thirty--tall, slender; his face riveted the eye; it was like a Greek face, very pure in outline: quite a straight, classic nose; quite an Athenian mouth and chin.
Era joven -unos veintiocho o treinta años-, alto y delgado.
Todos los rasgos de su rostro eran de una pureza griega: el corte de su cara, la nariz, la barbilla y la boca.
It is seldom, indeed, an English face comes so near the antique models as did his.
Rara vez se encuentra en semblantes ingleses tal parecido a los modelos clásicos.
He might well be a little shocked at the irregularity of my lineaments, his own being so harmonious.
No me extrañó que le hubiese impresionado la irregularidad de mis facciones, siendo las suyas tan armoniosas.
His eyes were large and blue, with brown lashes; his high forehead, colourless as ivory, was partially streaked over by careless locks of fair hair.
Tenía los ojos grandes y azules, con oscuras pestañas, y su cabello rubio, cuidadosamente peinado, coronaba una ancha frente pálida como el marfil.
This is a gentle delineation, is it not, reader?
¿Verdad, lector, que este retrato que hago es atractivo?
Yet he whom it describes scarcely impressed one with the idea of a gentle, a yielding, an impressible, or even of a placid nature.
Sin embargo, apenas da una idea del sereno, imperturbable y plácido aspecto de John Rivers.
Quiescent as he now sat, there was something about his nostril, his mouth, his brow, which, to my perceptions, indicated elements within either restless, or hard, or eager.
Y con todo, mientras le contemplaba, en ciertos casi imperceptibles movimientos de su boca, de sus cejas, de sus manos, parecíame apreciar elementos interiores de vehemencia, pasión y energía.
He did not speak to me one word, nor even direct to me one glance, till his sisters returned.
No me habló ni me dirigió una sola mirada hasta que sus hermanas volvieron.
Diana, as she passed in and out, in the course of preparing tea, brought me a little cake, baked on the top of the oven.
Diana me ofreció un bollito calentado al horno.
"Eat that now," she said: "you must be hungry.
Hannah says you have had nothing but some gruel since breakfast."
-Cómalo -dijo-, Hannah me ha contado que desde la mañana no ha tomado usted más que una sopa.
I did not refuse it, for my appetite was awakened and keen.
No me negué, porque sentía apetito.
Mr. Rivers now closed his book, approached the table, and, as he took a seat, fixed his blue pictorial-looking eyes full on me.
There was an unceremonious directness, a searching, decided steadfastness in his gaze now, which told that intention, and not diffidence, had hitherto kept it averted from the stranger.

Rivers cerró su libro, se acercó a la mesa, se sentó y clavó sus azules ojos en los míos con una naturalidad que me hizo comprender que no me había hablado hasta entonces adrede, no por timidez o desconfianza.
"You are very hungry," he said.
-Tiene usted hambre -dijo.
"I am, sir."
-Sí -repuse.
It is my way--it always was my way, by instinct--ever to meet the brief with brevity, the direct with plainness.
Está en mi modo de ser el contestar con claridad y sin ambages a las preguntas.
"It is well for you that a low fever has forced you to abstain for the last three days: there would have been danger in yielding to the cravings of your appetite at first.
-Ha convenido que la fiebre de estos días pasados no le haya permitido comer, porque hubiera sido peligroso calmar su apetito de repente.
Now you may eat, though still not immoderately."
Ahora, en cambio, puede comer ya lo que guste, aunque todavía con moderación.
"I trust I shall not eat long at your expense, sir," was my very clumsily- contrived, unpolished answer.
-Espero no comer mucho tiempo a costa de usted-contesté, casi sin darme cuenta de lo grosero de la respuesta.
"No," he said coolly: "when you have indicated to us the residence of your friends, we can write to them, and you may be restored to home."
-Eso creo -dijo él, fríamente-, porque, una vez que nos dé la dirección de su familia, escribiremos para que vengan a buscarla.
"That, I must plainly tell you, is out of my power to do; being absolutely without home and friends."
-Eso es imposible, porque no tengo casa ni familia.
The three looked at me, but not distrustfully; I felt there was no suspicion in their glances: there was more of curiosity.
Los tres me miraron, no con desconfianza, sino con curiosidad.
I speak particularly of the young ladies.
St. John's eyes, though clear enough in a literal sense, in a figurative one were difficult to fathom.
Me refiero más bien a las jóvenes, ya que los ojos de John Rivers, claros en el sentido literal de la palabra, resultaban muy oscuros en el sentido de que era imposible desentrañar lo que pensaba.

He seemed to use them rather as instruments to search other people's thoughts, than as agents to reveal his own: the which combination of keenness and reserve was considerably more calculated to embarrass than to encourage.
Parecía emplearlos más bien para averiguar los pensamientos de los demás que para reflejar los suyos.
"Do you mean to say," he asked, "that you are completely isolated from every connection?"
-¿Quiere usted decir -preguntó- que carece en absoluto de parientes?
"I do.
-Ése es el caso.
Not a tie links me to any living thing: not a claim do I possess to admittance under any roof in England."
No tengo derecho a ser admitida bajo techo alguno de Inglaterra.
"A most singular position at your age!"
-¡Extraña situación para su edad!
Here I saw his glance directed to my hands, which were folded on the table before me.
Sus ojos buscaron mis manos, que yo tenía apoyadas en la mesa.
I wondered what he sought there: his words soon explained the quest.
Sus palabras me aclararon lo que trataba de saber.
"You have never been married?
You are a spinster?"
-¿Es usted soltera?
Diana laughed.
Diana rió.
"Why, she can't be above seventeen or eighteen years old, St. John," said she.
-¡Por Dios, John!
¡Si no debe tener más que diecisiete o dieciocho años!
"I am near nineteen: but I am not married.
-Tengo diecinueve -dije-.
No."
No, no estoy casada.
I felt a burning glow mount to my face; for bitter and agitating recollections were awakened by the allusion to marriage.
Amargos y estremecedores recuerdos me agitaron al pronunciar esta frase.
Todos notaron mi turbación.
They all saw the embarrassment and the emotion.

Diana and Mary relieved me by turning their eyes elsewhere than to my crimsoned visage; but the colder and sterner brother continued to gaze, till the trouble he had excited forced out tears as well as colour.
Diana y Mary, discretamente, separaron sus miradas de mi ruborizado rostro, pero su hermano continuó contemplándome de tal modo, que acabé sintiendo afluir las lágrimas a mis ojos.
"Where did you last reside?" he now asked.
-¿Dónde vivía usted últimamente? -preguntó.
"You are too inquisitive, St. John," murmured Mary in a low voice; but he leaned over the table and required an answer by a second firm and piercing look.
-No seas así, John -murmuró Mary en voz baja, sin que por ello dejara él de seguir insistiendo, a través de su penetrante mirada.
"The name of the place where, and of the person with whom I lived, is my secret," I replied concisely.
-Dónde y con quién vivía, deseo mantenerlo en secreto -dije concisamente.
"Which, if you like, you have, in my opinion, a right to keep, both from St. John and every other questioner," remarked Diana.
-Tiene derecho a hacerlo así, con John y con quien sea -observó Diana.
"Yet if I know nothing about you or your history, I cannot help you," he said.
"And you need help, do you not?"
-Si no sé nada de usted, no podré ayudarla -repuso él-, y creo que necesita usted ayuda.

"I need it, and I seek it so far, sir, that some true philanthropist will put me in the way of getting work which I can do, and the remuneration for which will keep me, if but in the barest necessaries of life."
-La necesito y la deseo -dije-, y sería muy humanitario quien me buscara trabajo en lo que fuera y pagado como fuera, con tal que me permitiera ganar lo indispensable para vivir.
"I know not whether I am a true philanthropist; yet I am willing to aid you to the utmost of my power in a purpose so honest.
-Por mi parte, no sé si soy humanitario o no, pero deseo ayudarla en un propósito tan honrado.
First, then, tell me what you have been accustomed to do, and what you _can_ do."
Para ello, necesito saber lo que usted sabe hacer y a qué está acostumbrada.
I had now swallowed my tea.
Bebí mi té.
I was mightily refreshed by the beverage; as much so as a giant with wine: it gave new tone to my unstrung nerves, and enabled me to address this penetrating young judge steadily.
El brebaje me reconfortó como a un gigante pudiera reconfortarle una azumbre de vino, tonificó mis nervios y me puso en condiciones de contestar como debía a las preguntas de aquel inquisitivo joven.

"Mr. Rivers," I said, turning to him, and looking at him, as he looked at me, openly and without diffidence, "you and your sisters have done me a great service--the greatest man can do his fellow-being; you have rescued me, by your noble hospitality, from death.
-Mr.

Rivers -le dije, mirándole sinceramente y sin desconfianza, como él a mí-, usted y sus hermanas me han prestado una gran servicio, el mayor que puede prestarse, librándome de la muerte con su generosa hospitalidad.
This benefit conferred gives you an unlimited claim on my gratitude, and a claim, to a certain extent, on my confidence.
Este servicio les da derecho a mi gratitud ilimitada y, hasta cierto punto, a mis confidencias.
I will tell you as much of the history of the wanderer you have harboured, as I can tell without compromising my own peace of mind--my own security, moral and physical, and that of others.
Les diré cuanto pueda de mi historia, cuanto no perturbe la tranquilidad de mi alma, ni mi propia seguridad o la de otros.
"I am an orphan, the daughter of a clergyman.
Soy huérfana, hija de un sacerdote.
My parents died before I could know them.
Mis padres murieron antes de que los conociera.
I was brought up a dependant; educated in a charitable institution.
Fui educada en una institución de beneficencia.

I will even tell you the name of the establishment, where I passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher--Lowood Orphan Asylum, ---shire: you will have heard of it, Mr. Rivers?--the Rev. Robert Brocklehurst is the treasurer."
El nombre del establecimiento donde he pasado seis años como discípula y dos como profesora, es Orfanato de Lowood, el cual tenía por tesorero al reverendo padre Robert Brocklehurst...
"I have heard of Mr. Brocklehurst, and I have seen the school."
-He oído hablar de él y conozco Lowood.
"I left Lowood nearly a year since to become a private governess.
-Hace un año abandoné el colegio, empleándome como institutriz en una casa particular.
I obtained a good situation, and was happy.
El puesto era bueno y me sentía dichosa en él.
This place I was obliged to leave four days before I came here.
Cuatro días antes de llegar aquí tuve que dejar el empleo.
The reason of my departure I cannot and ought not to explain: it would be useless, dangerous, and would sound incredible.
No puedo ni debo decir por qué.
Sería inútil, arriesgado e increíble.
No blame attached to me: I am as free from culpability as any one of you three.
No me fui por culpa mía: tanta culpa tengo yo de lo sucedido como puedan tener ustedes.
Miserable I am, and must be for a time; for the catastrophe which drove me from a house I had found a paradise was of a strange and direful nature.
La catástrofe que me ha hecho salir de aquella casa es de un género extraordinario.

I observed but two points in planning my departure--speed, secrecy: to secure these, I had to leave behind me everything I possessed except a small parcel; which, in my hurry and trouble of mind, I forgot to take out of the coach that brought me to Whitcross.
Hube de partir con premura y en secreto, dejando allí casi todo cuanto tenía, excepto un paquete que, en mi prisa, olvidé en la diligencia de que me apeé en Whitcross.
To this neighbourhood, then, I came, quite destitute.
Llegué a este país falta de todo.

I slept two nights in the open air, and wandered about two days without crossing a threshold: but twice in that space of time did I taste food; and it was when brought by hunger, exhaustion, and despair almost to the last gasp, that you, Mr. Rivers, forbade me to perish of want at your door, and took me under the shelter of your roof.
Dos noches seguidas dormí al aire libre y sólo dos veces en este tiempo pude comer algo.
Estaba a punto de morir de hambre y de fatiga cuando usted, Mr.
Rivers, me ofreció un refugio bajo su techo.

I know all your sisters have done for me since--for I have not been insensible during my seeming torpor--and I owe to their spontaneous, genuine, genial compassion as large a debt as to your evangelical charity."
Sé cuanto sus hermanas han hecho por mí desde entonces -porque, a pesar de mi sopor, oía y veía- y he apreciado en cuanto valen su inmensa y espontánea compasión y la caridad cristiana de usted.
"Don't make her talk any more now, St. John," said Diana, as I paused; "she is evidently not yet fit for excitement.
-No la hagas hablar más.
John -dijo Diana-.
Come to the sofa and sit down now, Miss Elliott."
Está excitada aún.
Siéntese aquí, Miss Elliott.
I gave an involuntary half start at hearing the _alias_: I had forgotten my new name.
Me sobresalté al escuchar aquel falso nombre, que casi había olvidado ya.
Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape, noticed it at once.
John Rivers, a cuya penetración no escapaba nada, observó:
"You said your name was Jane Elliott?" he observed.
-¿No ha dicho que se llama Jane Elliott?
"I did say so; and it is the name by which I think it expedient to be called at present, but it is not my real name, and when I hear it, it sounds strange to me."
-Lo dije, y por ese nombre pienso hacerme llamar por ahora, pero no es el mío verdadero y, cuando lo oigo, me suena muy raro.
"Your real name you will not give?"
-¿Por qué no nos dice su nombre real?
"No: I fear discovery above all things; and whatever disclosure would lead to it, I avoid."
-Porque temo que se produzcan complicaciones que deseo impedir.
"You are quite right, I am sure," said Diana.
-Seguramente acierta -dijo Diana-.
"Now do, brother, let her be at peace a while."
Déjala un poco tranquila, hermano.
But when St. John had mused a few moments he recommenced as imperturbably and with as much acumen as ever.
Pero John Rivers comenzó a hablar al poco rato, presionándome tanto como antes.

"You would not like to be long dependent on our hospitality--you would wish, I see, to dispense as soon as may be with my sisters' compassion, and, above all, with my _charity_ (I am quite sensible of the distinction drawn, nor do I resent it--it is just): you desire to be independent of us?"

-Creo que desea usted librarse de nuestra hospitalidad, dejar de depender de la compasión de mis hermanas y de mi caridad cristiana (he notado la distinción y no me ofendo por ello) y vivir con independencia, cuanto antes, ¿no?
"I do: I have already said so.
-Sí, sí lo deseo.

Show me how to work, or how to seek work: that is all I now ask; then let me go, if it be but to the meanest cottage; but till then, allow me to stay here: I dread another essay of the horrors of homeless destitution."
Le ruego que me busque trabajo, aunque sea el más humilde en la más humilde cabaña.
Pero hasta entonces, le ruego me permita estar aquí y no me condene a los horrores de no tener donde refugiarme.
"Indeed you _shall_ stay here," said Diana, putting her white hand on my head.
-Se quedará -aseguró Diana, acariciando con su blanca mano mi cabeza.
"You _shall_," repeated Mary, in the tone of undemonstrative sincerity which seemed natural to her.
-Se quedará -repitió Mary, con el sosegado tono que parecía serle tan peculiar.

"My sisters, you see, have a pleasure in keeping you," said Mr. St. John, "as they would have a pleasure in keeping and cherishing a half-frozen bird, some wintry wind might have driven through their casement.
-Mis hermanas -dijo Rivers- tienen interés por usted, como lo tendrían por un pajarillo medio helado que encontraran en su ventana un día de invierno.
I feel more inclination to put you in the way of keeping yourself, and shall endeavour to do so; but observe, my sphere is narrow.
Yo preferiría, desde luego, buscarle el medio de que se valiera por sí misma, pero mi esfera de acción es reducida.
I am but the incumbent of a poor country parish: my aid must be of the humblest sort.
No soy más que un párroco de una pobre feligresía campesina y mi ayuda ha de ser forzosamente muy pequeña.
And if you are inclined to despise the day of small things, seek some more efficient succour than such as I can offer."
Le conviene más buscar una ayuda más eficaz que la mía, porque yo bien poca cosa podré encontrarle.

"She has already said that she is willing to do anything honest she can do," answered Diana for me; "and you know, St. John, she has no choice of helpers: she is forced to put up with such crusty people as you."
-Ya te ha dicho -repuso Diana- que está dispuesta a trabajar en cualquier cosa honrada que le sea posible, y bien ves que no tiene muchos favorecedores entre quienes escoger.
Así que tendrá que quedarse con uno tan gruñón como tú.
"I will be a dressmaker; I will be a plain-workwoman; I will be a servant, a nurse-girl, if I can be no better," I answered.
-Estoy dispuesta a trabajar de lo que sea: modista, criada, niñera, si no encuentro algo mejor-dije.
"Right," said Mr. St. John, quite coolly.
-Bien -repuso John Rivers, con frialdad-.
"If such is your spirit, I promise to aid you, in my own time and way."
Si se conforma con eso, prometo ayudarla, a su tiempo y a mi modo.
He now resumed the book with which he had been occupied before tea.
Volvió a coger el libro que leía antes.
I soon withdrew, for I had talked as much, and sat up as long, as my present strength would permit.
Yo me retiré pronto, porque había hablado y permanecido levantada el máximo que mis fuerzas me permitían.
CHAPTER XXX
XXX
The more I knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better I liked them.
Cuanto más iba conociendo a los habitantes de Moor House, más les apreciaba.
In a few days I had so far recovered my health that I could sit up all day, and walk out sometimes.
I could join with Diana and Mary in all their occupations; converse with them as much as they wished, and aid them when and where they would allow me.
A los pocos días había recobrado mi salud, podía hablar con Diana y Mary cuanto querían y ayudarlas como y cuando les parecía bien.
There was a reviving pleasure in this intercourse, of a kind now tasted by me for the first time--the pleasure arising from perfect congeniality of tastes, sentiments, and principles.
Había para mí un placer en aquella especie de resurrección: el de convivir con gentes que congeniaban conmigo en gustos, sentimientos y principios.
I liked to read what they liked to read: what they enjoyed, delighted me; what they approved, I reverenced.
Me gustaban las lecturas que a ellas, disfrutaba con lo que ellas disfrutaban, reverenciaba las cosas que aprobaban ellas.
They loved their sequestered home.

I, too, in the grey, small, antique structure, with its low roof, its latticed casements, its mouldering walls, its avenue of aged firs--all grown aslant under the stress of mountain winds; its garden, dark with yew and holly--and where no flowers but of the hardiest species would bloom--found a charm both potent and permanent.

Ellas amaban su casa y yo, en aquel edificio de antigua arquitectura-con su techo bajo, sus ventanas enrejadas, su avenida de pinos añosos, su jardín, con sus plantas de tejo y acebo, donde sólo florecían las más silvestres flores- encontraba un encanto constante y profundo.

They clung to the purple moors behind and around their dwelling--to the hollow vale into which the pebbly bridle-path leading from their gate descended, and which wound between fern-banks first, and then amongst a few of the wildest little pasture-fields that ever bordered a wilderness of heath, or gave sustenance to a flock of grey moorland sheep, with their little mossy- faced lambs:--they clung to this scene, I say, with a perfect enthusiasm of attachment.

Compartía su afecto hacia los rojizos páramos que rodeaban la residencia, hacia el profundo valle al que conducía el sendero que arrancaba de la verja, y que, serpenteando entre los helechos, alcanzaba los silvestres prados del fondo, donde pastaban rebaños de ovejas y corderitos.
I could comprehend the feeling, and share both its strength and truth.
I saw the fascination of the locality.

I felt the consecration of its loneliness: my eye feasted on the outline of swell and sweep--on the wild colouring communicated to ridge and dell by moss, by heath-bell, by flower-sprinkled turf, by brilliant bracken, and mellow granite crag.

Yo comprendía sus sentimientos, experimentaba el atractivo del solitario lugar, amaba aquellas laderas y cañadas cubiertas de musgo, campánulas y otras florecillas silvestres, y sembradas, aquí y allá, de rocas.
These details were just to me what they were to them--so many pure and sweet sources of pleasure.
Tales detalles eran para mí, como para ellas, manantial de puros placeres.

The strong blast and the soft breeze; the rough and the halcyon day; the hours of sunrise and sunset; the moonlight and the clouded night, developed for me, in these regions, the same attraction as for them--wound round my faculties the same spell that entranced theirs.
El viento huracanado y la dulce brisa, los días desapacibles y los serenos, el alba y el crepúsculo, las noches sombrías y las noches de luna, me producían a mí las mismas sensaciones que a ellas.
Indoors we agreed equally well.
Dentro de la casa también nos entendíamos en todo.
They were both more accomplished and better read than I was; but with eagerness I followed in the path of knowledge they had trodden before me.
Ambas habían leído mucho y sabían más que yo, pero yo las seguía con facilidad en el camino que ellas recorrieran antes.
I devoured the books they lent me: then it was full satisfaction to discuss with them in the evening what I had perused during the day.
Devoraba los libros que me dejaban y comentaba con entusiasmo por las noches lo que había leído durante el día.
Thought fitted thought; opinion met opinion: we coincided, in short, perfectly.
En opiniones y pensamientos coincidíamos de un modo absoluto.
If in our trio there was a superior and a leader, it was Diana.
Si en nuestro trío había alguna superior a las demás, era Diana.
Physically, she far excelled me: she was handsome; she was vigorous.
Físicamente, valía más que yo: era hermosa y fuerte y poseía un dinamismo que excitaba mi asombro.
In her animal spirits there was an affluence of life and certainty of flow, such as excited my wonder, while it baffled my comprehension.
Yo podía hablar algo sobre un asunto, pero en cuanto agotaba mi primer ímpetu de elocuencia, me sentía cansada y sin saber qué decir.

I could talk a while when the evening commenced, but the first gush of vivacity and fluency gone, I was fain to sit on a stool at Diana's feet, to rest my head on her knee, and listen alternately to her and Mary, while they sounded thoroughly the topic on which I had but touched.
Entonces me sentaba en un escabel, apoyaba la cabeza en las rodillas de Diana y oía alternativamente, a ella y a Mary, profundizar y glosar el tema que yo apenas había desflorado.
Diana offered to teach me German.
Diana me ofreció enseñarme el alemán.
I liked to learn of her: I saw the part of instructress pleased and suited her; that of scholar pleased and suited me no less.
Me gustaba aprender con ella, y a ella no le placía menos instruirme.
Our natures dovetailed: mutual affection--of the strongest kind--was the result.
El resultado de aquella afinidad de nuestros temperamentos fue el afecto que se desarrolló entre nosotras.
They discovered I could draw: their pencils and colour-boxes were immediately at my service.
Descubrieron que yo sabía pintar e inmediatamente pusieron a mi disposición sus calas y útiles de dibujo.
My skill, greater in this one point than theirs, surprised and charmed them.
Les sorprendió y encantó encontrar que siquiera en un aspecto las superaba.
Mary would sit and watch me by the hour together: then she would take lessons; and a docile, intelligent, assiduous pupil she made.
Mary se sentaba a mi lado para verme trabajar y tomar lecciones, y se convirtió en una discípula inteligente, asidua y dócil.
Thus occupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks like days.
Así ocupadas y entretenidas, los días pasaban como minutos y las semanas como días.
As to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and rapidly between me and his sisters did not extend to him.
La intimidad que tan rápida y naturalmente brotó entre las jóvenes y yo, no se extendió a su hermano.

One reason of the distance yet observed between us was, that he was comparatively seldom at home: a large proportion of his time appeared devoted to visiting the sick and poor among the scattered population of his parish.
Una de las razones de ello era que él estaba en casa relativamente poco, ya que solía dedicar su tiempo a visitar a sus feligreses pobres y enfermos.

No weather seemed to hinder him in these pastoral excursions: rain or fair, he would, when his hours of morning study were over, take his hat, and, followed by his father's old pointer, Carlo, go out on his mission of love or duty--I scarcely know in which light he regarded it.
Lloviese o hiciera viento, una vez pasadas las horas que dedicaba al estudio, tomaba el sombrero y seguido de Carlo, el viejo perro de caza, salía a cumplir su misión.
Yo ignoraba si ésta le era agradable o si simplemente la consideraba como un deber.
Sometimes, when the day was very unfavourable, his sisters would expostulate.
He would then say, with a peculiar smile, more solemn than cheerful--
Cuando el tiempo era muy malo, sus hermanas insistían para que no saliera, pero él contestaba con una sonrisa más solemne que amable:
"And if I let a gust of wind or a sprinkling of rain turn me aside from these easy tasks, what preparation would such sloth be for the future I propose to myself?"
-Si el viento o la lluvia me detuviesen en el cumplimiento de mi labor, ¿cómo podría prepararme a la tarea que he resuelto realizar en el porvenir?
Diana and Mary's general answer to this question was a sigh, and some minutes of apparently mournful meditation.
Diana y Mary contestaban con un suspiro y quedaban pensativas.
But besides his frequent absences, there was another barrier to friendship with him: he seemed of a reserved, an abstracted, and even of a brooding nature.
A más de sus frecuentes ausencias, el carácter reservado y concentrado de John Rivers elevaba en torno suyo una barrera que impedía la amistad con él.

Zealous in his ministerial labours, blameless in his life and habits, he yet did not appear to enjoy that mental serenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every sincere Christian and practical philanthropist.

Celoso de su ministerio, impecable en su vida y costumbres, no parecía gozar, sin embargo, de la interior satisfacción, de la serenidad espiritual que debe ser característica de todo cristiano sincero y todo filántropo práctico.

Often, of an evening, when he sat at the window, his desk and papers before him, he would cease reading or writing, rest his chin on his hand, and deliver himself up to I know not what course of thought; but that it was perturbed and exciting might be seen in the frequent flash and changeful dilation of his eye.

A veces, por las tardes, al sentarse junto a la ventana, con sus papeles ante sí, dejaba de escribir o de leer y se entregaba a no sé qué clase de pensamientos, que evidentemente, le excitaban y le perturbaban, como se podía apreciar por la expresión de sus ojos.
I think, moreover, that Nature was not to him that treasury of delight it was to his sisters.
La naturaleza, además, parecía no ofrecer tanto encanto para él como para sus hermanas.

He expressed once, and but once in my hearing, a strong sense of the rugged charm of the hills, and an inborn affection for the dark roof and hoary walls he called his home; but there was more of gloom than pleasure in the tone and words in which the sentiment was manifested; and never did he seem to roam the moors for the sake of their soothing silence--never seek out or dwell upon the thousand peaceful delights they could yield.
Una vez habló ante mí del afecto que experimentaba hacia su hogar y hacia aquellas colinas que lo rodeaban, pero más que contento, creí adivinar una sombra de tristeza en sus palabras.
Incommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an opportunity of gauging his mind.
Era tan poco comunicativo, que, no me resultaba fácil apreciar la magnitud o estrechez de su inteligencia.
I first got an idea of its calibre when I heard him preach in his own church at Morton.
La primera idea real que tuve de ella fue cuando le oí predicar en la iglesia de Morton.
I wish I could describe that sermon: but it is past my power.
Describir aquel sermón escapa a mi capacidad.
I cannot even render faithfully the effect it produced on me.
Imposible expresar fielmente el efecto que me produjo.

It began calm--and indeed, as far as delivery and pitch of voice went, it was calm to the end: an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal breathed soon in the distinct accents, and prompted the nervous language.
Empezó a hablar con calma y su voz poderosa y sus conceptos enérgicos, contenidos, comprimidos, condensados, resultaban de una fuerza infinita.
This grew to force--compressed, condensed, controlled.
El corazón quedaba traspasado y la mente atónita ante las palabras del predicador.
The heart was thrilled, the mind astonished, by the power of the preacher: neither were softened.
No había en ellas blandura, ni abundaban los consuelos.

Throughout there was a strange bitterness; an absence of consolatory gentleness; stern allusions to Calvinistic doctrines--election, predestination, reprobation--were frequent; and each reference to these points sounded like a sentence pronounced for doom.

Sentíase en ellas más bien una amargura extraña, percibíanse frecuentes alusiones a las doctrinas calvinistas -elección, predestinación, reprobación- y cada una de aquellas frases sonaba en su boca como una sentencia inapelable.

When he had done, instead of feeling better, calmer, more enlightened by his discourse, I experienced an inexpressible sadness; for it seemed to me--I know not whether equally so to others--that the eloquence to which I had been listening had sprung from a depth where lay turbid dregs of disappointment--where moved troubling impulses of insatiate yearnings and disquieting aspirations.

Cuando concluyó el sermón, yo, más que calmada y alentada, me sentí triste, con una indefinible tristeza, porque me parecía -no sé si los demás experimentarían lo mismo- que bajo la elocuencia del predicador se ocultaban insatisfechos anhelos y fracasadas aspiraciones.

I was sure St. John Rivers--pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was--had not yet found that peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found it, I thought, than had I with my concealed and racking regrets for my broken idol and lost elysium--regrets to which I have latterly avoided referring, but which possessed me and tyrannised over me ruthlessly.

Estaba segura de que John Rivers -por puro, honrado y celoso que fuerano había encontrado la paz de Dios, no la había encontrado más que yo, con mis ocultos recuerdos de mi paraíso perdido y mi ídolo destrozado, que me atormentaban amargamente.
Meantime a month was gone.
Pasó un mes.

Diana and Mary were soon to leave Moor House, and return to the far different life and scene which awaited them, as governesses in a large, fashionable, south-of-England city, where each held a situation in families by whose wealthy and haughty members they were regarded only as humble dependants, and who neither knew nor sought out their innate excellences, and appreciated only their acquired accomplishments as they appreciated the skill of their cook or the taste of their waiting-woman.

Diana y Mary iban a dejar en breve Moor House para dirigirse a la gran ciudad meridional en que ejercían como institutrices en casas de acaudaladas familias que no reparaban en ellas sino para considerarlas humildes servidoras, sin apreciar lo que valían más de lo que pudieran apreciar la habilidad de su cocinera o la disposición de sus criadas.
Mr. St. John had said nothing to me yet about the employment he had promised to obtain for me; yet it became urgent that I should have a vocation of some kind.
John no me había hablado nada del trabajo que yo le pidiera y que ya me urgía.

One morning, being left alone with him a few minutes in the parlour, I ventured to approach the window-recess--which his table, chair, and desk consecrated as a kind of study--and I was going to speak, though not very well knowing in what words to frame my inquiry--for it is at all times difficult to break the ice of reserve glassing over such natures as his--when he saved me the trouble by being the first to commence a dialogue.

Una mañana, estando a solas con él en el salón, me aventuré a acercarme al rincón de la ventana en que su mesa, su tintero y sus libros habían improvisado un pequeño despacho y, aunque no sabía cómo empezar, porque es difícil romper el hielo cuando se trata de naturalezas tan reservadas como la suya, tuve la fortuna de que él me ayudara, comenzando el diálogo.
Looking up as I drew near--"You have a question to ask of me?" he said.
-Quiere preguntarme algo, ¿no? -me dijo.
"Yes; I wish to know whether you have heard of any service I can offer myself to undertake?"
-Sí; quisiera saber si ha encontrado un trabajo en que pudiese ocuparme.

"I found or devised something for you three weeks ago; but as you seemed both useful and happy here--as my sisters had evidently become attached to you, and your society gave them unusual pleasure--I deemed it inexpedient to break in on your mutual comfort till their approaching departure from Marsh End should render yours necessary."
-Hace tres semanas lo encontré, pero como veía que estaba usted a gusto con mis hermanas y ellas con usted, me pareció mejor aplazarlo hasta que la marcha de ellas hiciera forzosa la suya.
"And they will go in three days now?"
I said.
-Se van de aquí a tres días, ¿verdad?
