"Yes; and when they go, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton: Hannah will accompany me; and this old house will be shut up."
-Sí, y cuando se vayan yo regresaré a Morton, llevándome a Hannah, y cerraremos esta vieja casa.
I waited a few moments, expecting he would go on with the subject first broached: but he seemed to have entered another train of reflection: his look denoted abstraction from me and my business.
Esperé que se explicase, pero él parecía abstraído en sus propios pensamientos y ajeno a mis asuntos.
I was obliged to recall him to a theme which was of necessity one of close and anxious interest to me.
Le recordé el tema, porque la cosa era para mí de un interés que no admitía demora.
"What is the employment you had in view, Mr. Rivers?
-¿Y de qué empleo se trata, Mr.
Rivers?
I hope this delay will not have increased the difficulty of securing it."
Confío en que las semanas transcurridas no dificulten...
"Oh, no; since it is an employment which depends only on me to give, and you to accept."
-No, ya que depende únicamente de mí concederlo y de usted aceptarlo.
He again paused: there seemed a reluctance to continue.
Se detuvo, como si le desagradase continuar.
I grew impatient: a restless movement or two, and an eager and exacting glance fastened on his face, conveyed the feeling to him as effectually as words could have done, and with less trouble.
Mi impaciencia crecía.
Algún movimiento que hice, alguna mirada que le dirigí fueron lo bastante elocuentes para hacerle continuar.
"You need be in no hurry to hear," he said: "let me frankly tell you, I have nothing eligible or profitable to suggest.
-No tenga prisa -dijo- Ante todo, permítame decirle francamente que no he hallado nada adecuado para usted.
Before I explain, recall, if you please, my notice, clearly given, that if I helped you, it must be as the blind man would help the lame.
Ya le advertí que mi ayuda no sería mayor que la que un ciego puede prestar a un lisiado.

I am poor; for I find that, when I have paid my father's debts, all the patrimony remaining to me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind, and the patch of moorish soil, with the yew-trees and holly-bushes in front.
Soy pobre: después de pagar las deudas de mi padre, no me quedará sino esta vieja granja, esa hilera de pinos que ve ahí y ese jardín con plantas de tejo y acebo que rodea la casa.

I am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole descendants of the race, two earn the dependant's crust among strangers, and the third considers himself an alien from his native country--not only for life, but in death.
Soy humilde.
La raza de los Rivers es antigua, pero de sus últimos tres descendientes, dos han de servir a desconocidos y el tercero se considera extraño en su propio país para vida y para muerte.

Yes, and deems, and is bound to deem, himself honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day when the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his shoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest members he is one, shall give the word, 'Rise, follow Me!'"

Para muerte, porque no volverá a su patria, ya que tomará la cruz de la separación cuando el jefe de la Iglesia militante de que él es uno de los más humildes miembros, pronuncie la palabra: «¡Sígueme!»
St. John said these words as he pronounced his sermons, with a quiet, deep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of glance.
John pronunció aquellas palabras con la mirada radiante y con la voz profunda y serena con que predicaba.
He resumed--

"And since I am myself poor and obscure, I can offer you but a service of poverty and obscurity. _You_ may even think it degrading--for I see now your habits have been what the world calls refined: your tastes lean to the ideal, and your society has at least been amongst the educated; but _I_ consider that no service degrades which can better our race.
-Siendo, pues, pobre y humilde, no puedo ofrecer a usted trabajos que no sean humildes y pobres.
Usted quizá se considere rebajada, porque me doy cuenta de que tiene los hábitos que el mundo llama refinados, y que ha tratado con gentes educadas.
Mas yo opino que no es degradante trabajo alguno que tienda a hacer mejores a los hombres.
I hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the Christian labourer's task of tillage is appointed him--the scantier the meed his toil brings--the higher the honour.
Cuanto más duro es el suelo que el cristiano ara, mayor es el honor que consigue.
His, under such circumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of the Gospel were the Apostles--their captain was Jesus, the Redeemer, Himself."
Así lo hicieron los Apóstoles, capitaneados por Jesús, el Redentor...
"Well?"
I said, as he again paused--"proceed."
-Continúe -dije viendo que se interrumpía.
He looked at me before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to read my face, as if its features and lines were characters on a page.
Me miró con detenimiento, como si mis facciones fueran líneas de una página y quisiera leer en ellas.
The conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in his succeeding observations.
Las conclusiones que obtuvo fueron parcialmente expuestas en las siguientes palabras:

"I believe you will accept the post I offer you," said he, "and hold it for a while: not permanently, though: any more than I could permanently keep the narrow and narrowing--the tranquil, hidden office of English country incumbent; for in your nature is an alloy as detrimental to repose as that in mine, though of a different kind."
-Creo que aceptará usted lo que voy a ofrecerle -dijo-, pero no de modo permanente, no quizá por más tiempo que el que yo continúe siendo cura de esta pacífica parroquia de la campiña inglesa.
El carácter de usted es tan inquieto como el mío, aunque en otro sentido.
"Do explain," I urged, when he halted once more.
-Explíquese -pedí cuando él se interrumpió una vez más.
"I will; and you shall hear how poor the proposal is,--how trivial--how cramping.
-Lo haré, y verá cuán pobre es mi oferta.
I shall not stay long at Morton, now that my father is dead, and that I am my own master.
Ahora que mi padre ha muerto y soy señor de mí mismo, no estaré mucho tiempo en Morton.
I shall leave the place probably in the course of a twelve-month; but while I do stay, I will exert myself to the utmost for its improvement.
Probablemente me iré antes de un año.
Pero mientras esté aquí, debo preocuparme de mis feligreses.
Morton, when I came to it two years ago, had no school: the children of the poor were excluded from every hope of progress.
Morton, cuando me encargué de la parroquia hace dos años, carecía de escuela, y los hijos de los pobres no tenían posibilidad alguna de instruirse.
I established one for boys: I mean now to open a second school for girls.
Establecí una escuela para muchachos y ahora voy a abrir otra para niñas.
I have hired a building for the purpose, with a cottage of two rooms attached to it for the mistress's house.
He alquilado una casa a ese propósito, con un pabellón contiguo, de dos habitaciones, para vivienda de la maestra.

Her salary will be thirty pounds a year: her house is already furnished, very simply, but sufficiently, by the kindness of a lady, Miss Oliver; the only daughter of the sole rich man in my parish--Mr.
Oliver, the proprietor of a needle- factory and iron-foundry in the valley.

Ganará usted treinta libras al año y la casa estará amueblada, aunque muy modestamente, gracias a la munificencia de Miss Oliver, única hija del solo hombre adinerado que hay en mi parroquia: Oliver, el dueño de la fábrica de agujas y la fundición de hierro que hay en el valle.

The same lady pays for the education and clothing of an orphan from the workhouse, on condition that she shall aid the mistress in such menial offices connected with her own house and the school as her occupation of teaching will prevent her having time to discharge in person.
La misma señorita paga la educación y vestido de una huérfana a condición de que ayude a la maestra en los trabajos domésticos que ella no podría hacer sin detrimento de su cargo de profesora.
Will you be this mistress?"
¿Le conviene este empleo?

He put the question rather hurriedly; he seemed half to expect an indignant, or at least a disdainful rejection of the offer: not knowing all my thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, he could not tell in what light the lot would appear to me.
Había hablado como si esperase de mi parte una indignada repulsa, ignoraba mis verdaderos sentimientos y pensamientos, aunque adivinase alguno.

In truth it was humble--but then it was sheltered, and I wanted a safe asylum: it was plodding--but then, compared with that of a governess in a rich house, it was independent; and the fear of servitude with strangers entered my soul like iron: it was not ignoble--not unworthy--not mentally degrading, I made my decision.
En verdad, el cargo, aunque humilde, tenía sobre el de institutriz de una casa la ventaja de la independencia, ya que me hería más profundamente que el sentimiento de dependencia respecto a terceros.
No era un empleo innoble, ni degradante, ni indigno.
Me resolví.
"I thank you for the proposal, Mr. Rivers, and I accept it with all my heart."
-Le doy gracias por su oferta, Mr.
Rivers, y la acepto de todo corazón.
"But you comprehend me?" he said.
-¿Ha comprendido bien? -insistió-.
"It is a village school: your scholars will be only poor girls--cottagers' children--at the best, farmers' daughters.
Es una escuela de aldea; sus discípulas serán niñas pobres, hijas de labradores en el caso mejor.
Knitting, sewing, reading, writing, ciphering, will be all you will have to teach.
No tiene usted que enseñar sino a leer, escribir, contar, coser y hacer calceta.
What will you do with your accomplishments?
Nada adecuado a sus conocimientos, a sus inclinaciones...
What, with the largest portion of your mind--sentiments--tastes?"
¿Qué hará con ellos?
"Save them till they are wanted.
They will keep."
-Guardarlos hasta que haya ocasión de aplicarlos.
"You know what you undertake, then?"
-¿Sabe usted de lo que se encarga?
"I do."
-Sí.
He now smiled: and not a bitter or a sad smile, but one well pleased and deeply gratified.
Sonrió, pero no con amargura, sino satisfecho.
"And when will you commence the exercise of your function?"
"I will go to my house to-morrow, and open the school, if you like, next week."
-Si le parece, iré a la casa mañana y abriré la escuela la semana próxima.
"Very well: so be it."
-Muy bien.
He rose and walked through the room.
Standing still, he again looked at me.
Se levantó y comenzó a pasear por la sala.
He shook his head.
Movió la cabeza.
"What do you disapprove of, Mr. Rivers?"
I asked.
"You will not stay at Morton long: no, no!"
-Usted no estará mucho en Morton, no.
"Why?
-¿Por qué?
What is your reason for saying so?"
¿qué motivos tiene para creerlo?
"I read it in your eye; it is not of that description which promises the maintenance of an even tenor in life."
-Leo en sus ojos que no soportará largo tiempo tal género de vida.
"I am not ambitious."
-No tengo ambición.
He started at the word "ambitious."
Se sobresaltó al oírme.
He repeated, "No.
Repitió:
What made you think of ambition?
-¿Quién habla de ambición?
Who is ambitious?
I know I am: but how did you find it out?"
Ya sé que la tengo, pero ¿cómo lo sabe usted?
"I was speaking of myself."
-Hablaba de mí.
"Well, if you are not ambitious, you are--" He paused.
-Bien; no es ambiciosa, pero es... -y se interrumpió.
"What?"
-¿Qué soy?
"I was going to say, impassioned: but perhaps you would have misunderstood the word, and been displeased.
-Iba a decir apasionada, pero temo que dé usted un sentido equívoco a la palabra.
I mean, that human affections and sympathies have a most powerful hold on you.
Quiero decir que los afectos y simpatías humanas influyen mucho sobre usted.

I am sure you cannot long be content to pass your leisure in solitude, and to devote your working hours to a monotonous labour wholly void of stimulus: any more than I can be content," he added, with emphasis, "to live here buried in morass, pent in with mountains--my nature, that God gave me, contravened; my faculties, heaven-bestowed, paralysed--made useless.
Estoy cierto de que no será capaz de pasar su vida en una tarea tan monótona, tan falta de estímulo.
¿Quién puede vivir encerrada entre pantanos y montañas, sin emplear las facultades que nos ha dado Dios...?
You hear now how I contradict myself.
I, who preached contentment with a humble lot, and justified the vocation even of hewers of wood and drawers of water in God's service--I, His ordained minister, almost rave in my restlessness.
Contestará que me contradigo, yo que aconsejo a los fieles conformarse con su suerte, aun a los leñadores, aun a los aguadores, pensando que todo es servicio de Dios...
Well, propensities and principles must be reconciled by some means."
En fin: cabe conciliar las inclinaciones con los principios.
He left the room.
Salió del aposento.
In this brief hour I had learnt more of him than in the whole previous month: yet still he puzzled me.
En aquel breve rato yo había sabido más de su carácter que en todo el mes precedente.
No obstante, seguía sintiéndome desconcertada respecto a su modo de ser.
Diana and Mary Rivers became more sad and silent as the day approached for leaving their brother and their home.
Diana y Mary Rivers se entristecían y poníanse más taciturnas a medida que llegaba el momento de abandonar a su hermano y su casa.
They both tried to appear as usual; but the sorrow they had to struggle against was one that could not be entirely conquered or concealed.
Trataban de aparecer como de costumbre, pero no podían disimular el esfuerzo que les costaba.
Diana intimated that this would be a different parting from any they had ever yet known.
It would probably, as far as St. John was concerned, be a parting for years: it might be a parting for life.
Diana entendía que aquella separación iba a ser diferente a otras anteriores, ya que acaso no volvieran a ver a John en muchos años o quizá nunca.
"He will sacrifice all to his long-framed resolves," she said: "natural affection and feelings more potent still.
-Todo lo sacrificará a sus propósitos -me dijo-, incluso los mayores afectos.
St. John looks quiet, Jane; but he hides a fever in his vitals.
John parece tranquilo, Jane, pero en su interior es un hombre ardiente.

You would think him gentle, yet in some things he is inexorable as death; and the worst of it is, my conscience will hardly permit me to dissuade him from his severe decision: certainly, I cannot for a moment blame him for it.
Aunque se muestra amable y dúctil, en ciertas cosas es inflexible como la muerte.
Y lo peor de todo es que no me atrevo a disuadirle, ni menos a censurarle, porque sus intenciones son elevadas, nobles y cristianas, aunque me desgarren el corazón.
It is right, noble, Christian: yet it breaks my heart!"
And the tears gushed to her fine eyes.
Mary bent her head low over her work.
Mary inclinó la cabeza sobre la costura.
"We are now without father: we shall soon be without home and brother," she murmured.
-Ya no tenemos padre -dijo- y pronto no tendremos casi ni hermano.

At that moment a little accident supervened, which seemed decreed by fate purposely to prove the truth of the adage, that "misfortunes never come singly," and to add to their distresses the vexing one of the slip between the cup and the lip.

En aquel momento sobrevino un incidente de aquellos que prueban la verdad del adagio de que las desgracias nunca vienen solas y que demuestran que siempre queda algo más que libar en la copa de la amargura, John entró leyendo una carta.
St. John passed the window reading a letter.
He entered.
-Parece que desaprueba usted algo -dije.
"Our uncle John is dead," said he.
-El tío John ha muerto -dijo.
Both the sisters seemed struck: not shocked or appalled; the tidings appeared in their eyes rather momentous than afflicting.
Las hermanas parecieron impresionarse, pero sin quedar afectadas, como si se tratase de algo más inesperado que aflictivo.
"Dead?" repeated Diana.
-¿Muerto? -repitió Diana.
"Yes."
She riveted a searching gaze on her brother's face.
Dirigió una mirada a su hermano.
"And what then?" she demanded, in a low voice.
-¿Y entonces, John? -preguntó, en voz baja.
"What then, Die?" he replied, maintaining a marble immobility of feature.
-Entonces, ¿qué? -dijo él con el rostro impasible como el mármol-.
"What then?
Why--nothing.
Entonces, nada...
Read."
Lee.
He threw the letter into her lap.
Le echó la carta en la falda.
She glanced over it, and handed it to Mary.
Mary perused it in silence, and returned it to her brother.
Diana la leyó en silencio y se la pasó a Mary, quien después de leerla, la devolvió a su hermano.
All three looked at each other, and all three smiled--a dreary, pensive smile enough.
Los tres se miraron y los tres sonrieron, pensativos.
"Amen!
-Amén.
We can yet live," said Diana at last.
No vamos a morirnos por eso - dijo Diana.
"At any rate, it makes us no worse off than we were before," remarked Mary.
-Después de todo, hemos quedado como estábamos antes -observó Mary.
"Only it forces rather strongly on the mind the picture of what _might have been_," said Mr. Rivers, "and contrasts it somewhat too vividly with what _is_."
-Unicamente ocurre que resulta fuerte el contraste de lo que podía haber sido con lo que es -comentó John Rivers.
He folded the letter, locked it in his desk, and again went out.
Colocó la carta en el escritorio y salió.
For some minutes no one spoke.
Diana then turned to me.
Tras algunos minutos de silencio, Diana se volvió a mí.

"Jane, you will wonder at us and our mysteries," she said, "and think us hard-hearted beings not to be more moved at the death of so near a relation as an uncle; but we have never seen him or known him.
-Te asombrarán estos misterios, Jane, y nos considerarás insensibles viendo cómo acogemos la muerte de un tío -dijo-.
Pero no le hemos visto nunca.
He was my mother's brother.
Era hermano de mi madre.
My father and he quarrelled long ago.
Mi padre y él riñeron hace mucho.
It was by his advice that my father risked most of his property in the speculation that ruined him.
Por consejo suyo, mi padre había invertido la mitad de sus bienes en una especulación que le arruinó.
Mutual recrimination passed between them: they parted in anger, and were never reconciled.
Hubo recriminaciones mutuas, se separaron disgustados y no volvieron a verse.
My uncle engaged afterwards in more prosperous undertakings: it appears he realised a fortune of twenty thousand pounds.
Mi tío tuvo suerte después en sus negocios y parece que ganó veinte mil libras.
He was never married, and had no near kindred but ourselves and one other person, not more closely related than we.
No se casó nunca, ni tenía más parientes que nosotros y otro, no más cercano.

My father always cherished the idea that he would atone for his error by leaving his possessions to us; that letter informs us that he has bequeathed every penny to the other relation, with the exception of thirty guineas, to be divided between St. John, Diana, and Mary Rivers, for the purchase of three mourning rings.
Mi padre esperaba que el tío nos dejase sus bienes, pero esta carta nos informa de que los ha dejado íntegros a ese otro pariente, excepto treinta guineas que nos lega a los tres para lutos.
He had a right, of course, to do as he pleased: and yet a momentary damp is cast on the spirits by the receipt of such news.
Desde luego, tenía perfecto derecho a hacer lo que quisiera, pero siempre impresiona un poco recibir noticias de éstas.
Mary and I would have esteemed ourselves rich with a thousand pounds each; and to St. John such a sum would have been valuable, for the good it would have enabled him to do."
Mary y yo nos habríamos considerado ricas con mil libras cada una y John hubiera sido feliz con análoga cantidad, porque hubiera podido hacer mucho bien con ella.
This explanation given, the subject was dropped, and no further reference made to it by either Mr. Rivers or his sisters.
Tras esta explicación, pasamos a otro tema y no se insistió más en aquél.
The next day I left Marsh End for Morton.
The day after, Diana and Mary quitted it for distant B-.
Al día siguiente me instalé en Morton, y al otro Diana y María partieron para B...
In a week, Mr. Rivers and Hannah repaired to the parsonage: and so the old grange was abandoned.
Una semana después, John Rivers y Hannah se presentaron en la rectora y la vieja granja quedó abandonada.
CHAPTER XXXI
XXXI

My home, then, when I at last find a home,--is a cottage; a little room with whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, containing four painted chairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard, with two or three plates and dishes, and a set of tea-things in delf.
Mi casa -al fin había encontrado una casa- era un pabelloncito con las paredes encaladas y el suelo de arena apisonada.
Contenía cuatro sillas y una mesa, un reloj, un aparadorcito con dos o tres platos y tazas y un servicio de té.

Above, a chamber of the same dimensions as the kitchen, with a deal bedstead and chest of drawers; small, yet too large to be filled with my scanty wardrobe: though the kindness of my gentle and generous friends has increased that, by a modest stock of such things as are necessary.

En el piso alto había una alcoba de las mismas dimensiones que la cocina, con un lecho y una pequeña cómoda, sobrada para mi escaso guardarropa, aunque éste hubiera sido incrementado con algunas cosas regaladas por mis generosas amigas.
It is evening.
Era de noche.
I have dismissed, with the fee of an orange, the little orphan who serves me as a handmaid.
Había despedido, dándole una naranja, a la huerfanita que me servía de doncella.
I am sitting alone on the hearth.
Me hallaba sentada junto al fuego.
This morning, the village school opened.
I had twenty scholars.
La escuela de la aldea se había abierto aquella mañana, con veinte discípulas.
But three of the number can read: none write or cipher.
Sólo tres de ellas sabían leer y ninguna escribir ni contar.
Several knit, and a few sew a little.
Algunas sabían hacer calceta y unas pocas coser.
They speak with the broadest accent of the district.
Hablaban con el rudo acento de la región.
At present, they and I have a difficulty in understanding each other's language.
Experimentaba algún trabajo en comprenderlas.
Some of them are unmannered, rough, intractable, as well as ignorant; but others are docile, have a wish to learn, and evince a disposition that pleases me.
Algunas eran toscas e intratables como ignorantes, pero otras eran dóciles y amigas de aprender y manifestaban buen temperamento.

I must not forget that these coarsely-clad little peasants are of flesh and blood as good as the scions of gentlest genealogy; and that the germs of native excellence, refinement, intelligence, kind feeling, are as likely to exist in their hearts as in those of the best-born.

No olvidaba que aquellas burdas aldeanas eran tan de carne y hueso y de tan buena sangre como las hijas de las gentes más distinguidas, y que los gérmenes de lo buenos sentimientos, el refinamiento y las nobles inclinaciones existían igual en su corazón que en el de los nacidos en privilegiadas cunas.
My duty will be to develop these germs: surely I shall find some happiness in discharging that office.
Mi deber era desarrollar aquellos y seguramente no me sería ingrato cumplir tal oficio.
Much enjoyment I do not expect in the life opening before me: yet it will, doubtless, if I regulate my mind, and exert my powers as I ought, yield me enough to live on from day to day.
Con todo, no cabía esperar grandes satisfacciones en la vida que se me presentaba.
Was I very gleeful, settled, content, during the hours I passed in yonder bare, humble schoolroom this morning and afternoon?
¿Me sentía contenta, alegre durante las horas que pasé en aquella clase, desnuda y humilde?
Not to deceive myself, I must reply--No: I felt desolate to a degree.
Si había de ser sincera conmigo misma, debía contestar que no.
I felt--yes, idiot that I am--I felt degraded.
I doubted I had taken a step which sank instead of raising me in the scale of social existence.
I was weakly dismayed at the ignorance, the poverty, the coarseness of all I heard and saw round me.

Me sentía muy sola y además -¡necia de mí!- me consideraba degradada, preguntándome si no había bajado un escalón, en vez de subirlo, en la escala de la vida social, al caer entre la ignorancia, la pobreza y la tosquedad que me rodeaban, pero hube de reconocer, al fin, que mis opiniones eran erróneas y que en realidad había ascendido un peldaño.
But let me not hate and despise myself too much for these feelings; I know them to be wrong--that is a great step gained; I shall strive to overcome them.
To-morrow, I trust, I shall get the better of them partially; and in a few weeks, perhaps, they will be quite subdued.
In a few months, it is possible, the happiness of seeing progress, and a change for the better in my scholars may substitute gratification for disgust.
Acaso, pasado algún tiempo, la satisfacción de ver progresar a mis discípulas, la alegría de verlas mejorar, sustituyesen mi disgusto por una sincera congratulación.

Meantime, let me ask myself one question--Which is better?--To have surrendered to temptation; listened to passion; made no painful effort--no struggle;--but to have sunk down in the silken snare; fallen asleep on the flowers covering it; wakened in a southern clime, amongst the luxuries of a pleasure villa: to have been now living in France, Mr. Rochester's mistress; delirious with his love half my time--for he would--oh, yes, he would have loved me well for a while.

La cuestión era ésta: ¿qué valía más, rendirme a la tentación, escuchar la voz de las pasiones, dejarme caer en una trampa de seda, dormirme sobre las flores que la cubrían, despertarme en un clima meridional, en una villa lujosa, vivir en Francia como amante de Rochester, delirar de amor -porque él me amaba, sí, como nadie más volvería a amarme, ya que el homenaje amoroso se rinde sólo a la belleza y a la gracia, y ningún otro hombre que él podría sentirse orgulloso de mí, que carecía de tales encantos- o...?
He _did_ love me--no one will ever love me so again.
Pero ¿qué decía?
I shall never more know the sweet homage given to beauty, youth, and grace--for never to any one else shall I seem to possess these charms.
He was fond and proud of me--it is what no man besides will ever be.--But where am I wandering, and what am I saying, and above all, feeling?

Whether is it better, I ask, to be a slave in a fool's paradise at Marseilles--fevered with delusive bliss one hour--suffocating with the bitterest tears of remorse and shame the next--or to be a village-schoolmistress, free and honest, in a breezy mountain nook in the healthy heart of England?

¿Cabía comparar la ignominia de ser esclava favorita de un loco paraíso, en el Sur, y gozar una hora de fiebre amorosa para despertar a la realidad anegada en lágrimas de remordimiento, con ser maestra de aldea, honrada y libre, en un rincón de las montañas de Inglaterra?
Yes; I feel now that I was right when I adhered to principle and law, and scorned and crushed the insane promptings of a frenzied moment.
Sí: yo había hecho bien siguiendo los principios establecidos por la ley y apartando de mi paso las tentaciones.
God directed me to a correct choice: I thank His providence for the guidance!
Dios me había llevado por el mejor camino y le di fervorosamente las gracias.

Having brought my eventide musings to this point, I rose, went to my door, and looked at the sunset of the harvest-day, and at the quiet fields before my cottage, which, with the school, was distant half a mile from the village.
Al llegar a este punto de mis pensamientos me levanté, me asomé a la ventana y miré los campos silenciosos bajo el crepúsculo.
La aldea distaba una media milla.
The birds were singing their last strains-- "The air was mild, the dew was balm."
Los pájaros cantaban y el aire era sereno y el rocío fragante...
While I looked, I thought myself happy, and was surprised to find myself ere long weeping--and why?
Me consideré feliz y me asombró notar que estaba llorando.
¿Por qué?

For the doom which had reft me from adhesion to my master: for him I was no more to see; for the desperate grief and fatal fury--consequences of my departure--which might now, perhaps, be dragging him from the path of right, too far to leave hope of ultimate restoration thither.
Porque no volvería a ver más a mi amado y, más aún, porque acaso la furia y el dolor en que le sumiera mi partida le separaran del camino recto, le quitaran su última esperanza de salvación.

At this thought, I turned my face aside from the lovely sky of eve and lonely vale of Morton--I say _lonely_, for in that bend of it visible to me there was no building apparent save the church and the parsonage, half-hid in trees, and, quite at the extremity, the roof of Vale Hall, where the rich Mr. Oliver and his daughter lived.

Al imaginar esto, aparté la vista del bello cielo y del solitario valle de Morton -solitario porque sólo se veían en él la iglesia y la rectoral, medio ocultas entre árboles, y, muy lejos, los tejados de Pale Hall, donde vivían el rico fabricante Oliver y su hija rubia- y apoyé la cabeza en el alféizar de la ventana.
I hid my eyes, and leant my head against the stone frame of my door; but soon a slight noise near the wicket which shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it made me look up.
El ruido del postigo que separaba mi jardincillo de la pradera que ante él se extendía, me hizo alzar la cabeza.

A dog--old Carlo, Mr. Rivers' pointer, as I saw in a moment--was pushing the gate with his nose, and St. John himself leant upon it with folded arms; his brow knit, his gaze, grave almost to displeasure, fixed on me.
Un perro, el viejo Carlo, según pude ver, empujaba la cancela con el hocico, y John Rivers la abría en aquel momento.
Su entrecejo arrugado, su mirada grave, le daban un aspecto casi hostil.
I asked him to come in.
Le invité a pasar.
"No, I cannot stay; I have only brought you a little parcel my sisters left for you.
I think it contains a colour-box, pencils, and paper."
-No; no puedo detenerme.
Sólo venía a darle unas cosas que dejaron mis hermanas para usted: una caja de colores, papel y lápices.
I approached to take it: a welcome gift it was.
He examined my face, I thought, with austerity, as I came near: the traces of tears were doubtless very visible upon it.
Recogí el agradable don y, al acercarme, él examinó mi rostro, donde debió apreciar huellas de lágrimas.
"Have you found your first day's work harder than you expected?" he asked.
-¿Ha encontrado su primer día de trabajo más ingrato de lo que creía?
"Oh, no!
-Al contrario.
On the contrary, I think in time I shall get on with my scholars very well."
Creo que, con el tiempo, acabaré llevándome muy bien con mis alumnas.
"But perhaps your accommodations--your cottage--your furniture--have disappointed your expectations?
-Acaso la casa, el mobiliario, le hayan parecido peores de lo que esperaba.
They are, in truth, scanty enough; but--" I interrupted--
Reconozco que son muy modestos, pero...
"My cottage is clean and weather-proof; my furniture sufficient and commodious.
-La casa es limpia y sin humedad y los muebles son suficientes y cómodos -interrumpí-.
All I see has made me thankful, not despondent.
Todo me ha agradado.

I am not absolutely such a fool and sensualist as to regret the absence of a carpet, a sofa, and silver plate; besides, five weeks ago I had nothing--I was an outcast, a beggar, a vagrant; now I have acquaintance, a home, a business.
No soy una necia sibarita como para echar de menos alfombras, tapicerías, un sofá y cubiertos de plata.
Además, hace cinco semanas yo no tenía nada: era una mendiga, una vagabunda, sin hogar y sin trabajo.
I wonder at the goodness of God; the generosity of my friends; the bounty of my lot.
I do not repine."
Estoy maravillada de la bondad de Dios y de la generosidad de mis amigos, y me siento contenta de mi suerte.
"But you feel solitude an oppression?
-¿No se encuentra demasiado sola?
The little house there behind you is dark and empty."
La casa, así, le parecerá oscura y vacía...
"I have hardly had time yet to enjoy a sense of tranquillity, much less to grow impatient under one of loneliness."
-Casi no he tenido tiempo de darme cuenta... -Bien.
"Very well; I hope you feel the content you express: at any rate, your good sense will tell you that it is too soon yet to yield to the vacillating fears of Lot's wife.
Confío en que experimente de verdad el contento que expresa y le aconsejo que ponga todo su buen sentido en no imitar a la mujer de Lot.

What you had left before I saw you, of course I do not know; but I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation which would incline you to look back: pursue your present career steadily, for some months at least."
No sé lo que ha dejado usted tras de sí, pero debe desechar toda tentación de mirar atrás y perseverar en su ocupación actual, al menos por algunos meses.
"It is what I mean to do," I answered.
-Eso me propongo hacer.
St. John continued--
John Rivers continuó:
"It is hard work to control the workings of inclination and turn the bent of nature; but that it may be done, I know from experience.
-Es muy duro contrariar las inclinaciones naturales, pero sé por experiencia que cabe hacerlo.
En cierto sentido, Dios nos ha dejado en libertad de escoger nuestro destino.

God has given us, in a measure, the power to make our own fate; and when our energies seem to demand a sustenance they cannot get--when our will strains after a path we may not follow--we need neither starve from inanition, nor stand still in despair: we have but to seek another nourishment for the mind, as strong as the forbidden food it longed to taste--and perhaps purer; and to hew out for the adventurous foot a road as direct and broad as the one Fortune has blocked up against us, if rougher than it.
Si alguna vez nuestras energías son impotentes para seguir el camino que deseamos, no debemos desesperar.

Busquemos otro desahogo a nuestra alma, otro placer para nuestro corazón, tan intensos -y acaso más puros- que los que nos son vedados y, si no podemos seguir el sendero que la Fortuna nos cierra, emprendamos otro, aunque sea más escabroso.
"A year ago I was myself intensely miserable, because I thought I had made a mistake in entering the ministry: its uniform duties wearied me to death.
»Hace un año, yo me sentía muy desventurado, pensando que había cometido un error al hacerme sacerdote.
Me creía llamado a una vida activa.

I burnt for the more active life of the world--for the more exciting toils of a literary career--for the destiny of an artist, author, orator; anything rather than that of a priest: yes, the heart of a politician, of a soldier, of a votary of glory, a lover of renown, a luster after power, beat under my curate's surplice.

Bajo mi sobrepelliz latía un corazón anheloso de algo más enérgico, más dinámico; la carrera de un literato, de un artista, de un autor, de un orador, de un político, de un guerrero, de un amante de la fama, de un codicioso del poder...
I considered; my life was so wretched, it must be changed, or I must die.
Medité: mi vida tenía que cambiar de ruta, porque si no me sería imposible soportarla.

After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke and relief fell: my cramped existence all at once spread out to a plain without bounds--my powers heard a call from heaven to rise, gather their full strength, spread their wings, and mount beyond ken.
Tras una temporada de luchas conmigo mismo, de tinieblas en torno, se hizo la luz para mí.
Ante mi estrecha existencia se abrían panoramas sin límites.
Podía ejercitar todas mis facultades, remontarme tan alto como lo permitieran mis alas.

God had an errand for me; to bear which afar, to deliver it well, skill and strength, courage and eloquence, the best qualifications of soldier, statesman, and orator, were all needed: for these all centre in the good missionary.
Dios tenía algo para mí: algo en que poder desplegar esfuerzo, valor, elocuencia, las cualidades necesarias al soldado, al estadista, al orador.
Porque todo ello se necesita para ser un buen misionero.
"A missionary I resolved to be.
»Resolví hacerme misionero.
From that moment my state of mind changed; the fetters dissolved and dropped from every faculty, leaving nothing of bondage but its galling soreness--which time only can heal.
Desde entonces mi estado de ánimo cambió.
Las cadenas que oprimían mi espíritu desaparecieron, sin dejarme otro recuerdo que el de las llagas producidas, que sólo el tiempo puede cicatrizar.

My father, indeed, imposed the determination, but since his death, I have not a legitimate obstacle to contend with; some affairs settled, a successor for Morton provided, an entanglement or two of the feelings broken through or cut asunder--a last conflict with human weakness, in which I know I shall overcome, because I have vowed that I _will_ overcome--and I leave Europe for the East."
Mi padre contrariaba mi decisión, pero desde su muerte ningún obstáculo se opone a que yo cumpla lo que me propongo.

Una vez que deje arreglados algunos asuntos y se designe sucesor mío en la parroquia, una vez que venza algunas debilidades sentimentales que me retienen aún, pero que sé que acabaré venciendo, porque debo vencerlas, embarcaré para Oriente.»
He said this, in his peculiar, subdued, yet emphatic voice; looking, when he had ceased speaking, not at me, but at the setting sun, at which I looked too.
Habló con su voz peculiar, reprimida y enfática, y cuando hubo callado miró al sol que se ponía, y que yo miraba también.
Both he and I had our backs towards the path leading up the field to the wicket.
Mientras hablábamos habíamos comenzado a caminar por el sendero que, partiendo de mi verja, atravesaba el campo.

We had heard no step on that grass-grown track; the water running in the vale was the one lulling sound of the hour and scene; we might well then start when a gay voice, sweet as a silver bell, exclaimed--
Ningún paso resonaba en aquel camino tapizado de hierbecillas, y sólo se sentía el rumor del arroyo en el valle.
Nos sobresaltó, pues, escuchar el sonido de una voz alegre, dulce, como una campanilla de plata, que decía:
"Good evening, Mr. Rivers.
-Buenas tardes, Mr.
And good evening, old Carlo.
Rivers, ¡Hola, Carlo!
Su perro reconoce a los amigos antes que usted.
Your dog is quicker to recognise his friends than you are, sir; he pricked his ears and wagged his tail when I was at the bottom of the field, and you have your back towards me now."
Aún estaba yo en el extremo del prado, y ya él aguzaba las orejas y agitaba la cola.
En cambio usted todavía continúa de espaldas a mí.
It was true.
Era cierto.

Though Mr. Rivers had started at the first of those musical accents, as if a thunderbolt had split a cloud over his head, he stood yet, at the close of the sentence, in the same attitude in which the speaker had surprised him--his arm resting on the gate, his face directed towards the west.

Rivers se había estremecido al escuchar aquella voz, como si un tremendo trueno hubiese estallado sobre su cabeza, y al terminar de hablar el nuevo interlocutor, permaneció en la misma actitud en que éste le había sorprendido.
He turned at last, with measured deliberation.
Se volvió, al fin, con deliberada lentitud.
A vision, as it seemed to me, had risen at his side.
Una aparición, o tal se me antojó, se hallaba a su lado.

There appeared, within three feet of him, a form clad in pure white--a youthful, graceful form: full, yet fine in contour; and when, after bending to caress Carlo, it lifted up its head, and threw back a long veil, there bloomed under his glance a face of perfect beauty.
Vestía completamente de blanco, era juvenil y graciosa.
Al inclinarse para acariciar al perro, separó un velo que cubría su cara y mostró una faz de la más perfecta belleza.

Perfect beauty is a strong expression; but I do not retrace or qualify it: as sweet features as ever the temperate clime of Albion moulded; as pure hues of rose and lily as ever her humid gales and vapoury skies generated and screened, justified, in this instance, the term.

Las más dulces facciones que el clima templado de Albión haya modelado jamás, la más bella combinación de rosas y lirios que hayan hecho brotar de un rostro femenino la brisa y el brumoso cielo ingleses, justifican mi afirmación.
Ningún encanto faltaba, ningún defecto era perceptible.

No charm was wanting, no defect was perceptible; the young girl had regular and delicate lineaments; eyes shaped and coloured as we see them in lovely pictures, large, and dark, and full; the long and shadowy eyelash which encircles a fine eye with so soft a fascination; the pencilled brow which gives such clearness; the white smooth forehead, which adds such repose to the livelier beauties of tint and ray; the cheek oval, fresh, and smooth; the lips, fresh too, ruddy, healthy, sweetly formed; the even and gleaming teeth without flaw; the small dimpled chin; the ornament of rich, plenteous tresses--all advantages, in short, which, combined, realise the ideal of beauty, were fully hers.
La joven tenía los rasgos delicados y tan brillantes, profundos y oscuros los ojos como los que se ven en algunos cuadros de grandes maestros.

Eran largas y sombreadas sus pestañas, finas las cejas, blanca y suave la frente, lozanas y ovaladas las mejillas, frescos, saludables, suavemente cincelados los labios, relucientes los dientes, menuda la barbilla.
I wondered, as I looked at this fair creature: I admired her with my whole heart.
Al ver aquella bellísima criatura, la admiré con todo mi corazón.
Nature had surely formed her in a partial mood; and, forgetting her usual stinted step-mother dole of gifts, had endowed this, her darling, with a grand-dame's bounty.
La naturaleza, al modelarla, no le había negado ni uno de sus dones.
What did St. John Rivers think of this earthly angel?
¿Qué pensaba John Rivers de aquel ángel terrenal?
I naturally asked myself that question as I saw him turn to her and look at her; and, as naturally, I sought the answer to the inquiry in his countenance.
Esto me pregunté al verle volver el rostro y mirarla, y busqué la respuesta en su expresión.
He had already withdrawn his eye from the Peri, and was looking at a humble tuft of daisies which grew by the wicket.
Pero él, casi al momento, retiró su mirada de la joven y la posó en las humildes margaritas que crecían junto al sendero.
"A lovely evening, but late for you to be out alone," he said, as he crushed the snowy heads of the closed flowers with his foot.
-Hace una buena tarde, pero es ya una hora muy avanzada para que ande sola por aquí -dijo, al fin, mientras aplastaba las margaritas con el pie.
"Oh, I only came home from S-" (she mentioned the name of a large town some twenty miles distant) "this afternoon.
-He vuelto hoy de S... -y mencionó el nombre de una ciudad situada a veinte millas de distancia-;
Papa told me you had opened your school, and that the new mistress was come; and so I put on my bonnet after tea, and ran up the valley to see her: this is she?" pointing to me.
papá me ha dicho que usted ha abierto la escuela y que la maestra está ya en ella, y en cuanto tomé el té me puse el sombrero y salí para verla.
¿Es esta señorita? -añadió, señalándome.
"It is," said St. John.
-Sí -dijo John.
"Do you think you shall like Morton?" she asked of me, with a direct and naive simplicity of tone and manner, pleasing, if child-like.
-¿Le gusta Morton? -me preguntó ella con una simplicidad de tono y maneras casi infantiles.
"I hope I shall.
I have many inducements to do so."
-Creo que llegará a gustarme.
"Did you find your scholars as attentive as you expected?"
-¿Son aplicadas sus alumnas?
"Quite."
-Sí.
"Do you like your house?"
-¿Le gusta su casa?
"Very much."
-Mucho.
"Have I furnished it nicely?"
-¿Y los muebles?
"Very nicely, indeed."
-También.
"And made a good choice of an attendant for you in Alice Wood?"
-¿He acertado escogiendo a Alice Wood para servirla?
"You have indeed.
-Ha acertado usted.
She is teachable and handy."
Es afable y trabajadora dije a la joven, de cuya identidad ya no dudaba.
(This then, I thought, is Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of fortune, as well as in those of nature!
Era la hija del acaudalado Oliver, y tan rica, por tanto, de dones de belleza como de fortuna.
What happy combination of the planets presided over her birth, I wonder?)
¿Qué feliz combinación de planetas habría presidido su nacimiento?
"I shall come up and help you to teach sometimes," she added.
-Iré alguna vez a ayudarla -me dijo-.
"It will be a change for me to visit you now and then; and I like a change.
Siempre será un cambio para mí visitarla de vez en cuando, y me gusta mucho cambiar.
Mr. Rivers, I have been _so_ gay during my stay at S-.
Me he divertido mucho en S....
Mr.
Rivers.
Last night, or rather this morning, I was dancing till two o'clock.
La última noche estuve bailando hasta las dos de la madrugada.
The ---th regiment are stationed there since the riots; and the officers are the most agreeable men in the world: they put all our young knife-grinders and scissor merchants to shame."
Hay allí un regimiento de guarnición y sus oficiales son amabilísimos.
Dejan tamañitos a todos nuestros jóvenes fabricantes de cuchillos y comerciantes de ferretería.
It seemed to me that Mr. St. John's under lip protruded, and his upper lip curled a moment.
Los labios de John Rivers se contrajeron al escucharla.
His mouth certainly looked a good deal compressed, and the lower part of his face unusually stern and square, as the laughing girl gave him this information.
He lifted his gaze, too, from the daisies, and turned it on her.
An unsmiling, a searching, a meaning gaze it was.
Separando la mirada de las margaritas, la volvió hacia la joven de un modo escrutador y severo.
She answered it with a second laugh, and laughter well became her youth, her roses, her dimples, her bright eyes.
Ella correspondió con una sonrisa, que armonizaba muy bien con su juventud, con las rosas de sus mejillas y con la luz de sus ojos.
As he stood, mute and grave, she again fell to caressing Carlo.
Mientras él permanecía mudo y grave, ella volvió a acariciar al perro diciendo:
"Poor Carlo loves me," said she. "_He_ is not stern and distant to his friends; and if he could speak, he would not be silent."
-¡Cuánto me quiere el pobre Carlo!
No es un ser frío y ajeno a sus amigos y, si supiese hablar, no permanecería mudo cuando le hablan.
As she patted the dog's head, bending with native grace before his young and austere master, I saw a glow rise to that master's face.
Mientras se inclinaba para acariciar la cabeza del animal, vi encenderse una llama en el rostro austero de Rivers.
I saw his solemn eye melt with sudden fire, and flicker with resistless emotion.
Sus ojos graves se llenaron de una emocionada luz.
Flushed and kindled thus, he looked nearly as beautiful for a man as she for a woman.
Así, sonrojado, brillante la mirada, parecía tan hermoso hombre como ella mujer.
His chest heaved once, as if his large heart, weary of despotic constriction, had expanded, despite the will, and made a vigorous bound for the attainment of liberty.
Su pecho se dilató, como si su gran corazón tratase de expandirse en él.
But he curbed it, I think, as a resolute rider would curb a rearing steed.
He responded neither by word nor movement to the gentle advances made him.
Pero dominó sus impresiones, tal un jinete experto domina un potro fogoso, y no respondió con una palabra ni con un ademán.
"Papa says you never come to see us now," continued Miss Oliver, looking up.
"You are quite a stranger at Vale Hall.
-Papá -continuaba la joven- dice que ya no va usted a vernos nunca.
He is alone this evening, and not very well: will you return with me and visit him?"
Él se encuentra esta noche solo y algo indispuesto.
¿Por qué no viene conmigo, para visitarle?
"It is not a seasonable hour to intrude on Mr. Oliver," answered St. John.
-No es hora de visitar a nadie-dijo Rivers.
"Not a seasonable hour!
But I declare it is.
-Cuando yo se lo digo, es que sí.
It is just the hour when papa most wants company: when the works are closed and he has no business to occupy him.
Precisamente es la hora conveniente para papá, porque ya están cerrados los talleres y no tiene que ocuparse en negocios.
Now, Mr. Rivers, _do_ come.
Venga, Mr.
Rivers.
Why are you so very shy, and so very sombre?"
¿Cómo está usted tan sombrío?
She filled up the hiatus his silence left by a reply of her own.
-y como sólo la contestase el silencio, exclamó de pronto-:
"I forgot!" she exclaimed, shaking her beautiful curled head, as if shocked at herself.
"I am so giddy and thoughtless! _Do_ excuse me.
Perdone; no recordaba que no tiene usted motivos para sentirse alegre.
It had slipped my memory that you have good reasons to be indisposed for joining in my chatter.
Diana and Mary have left you, and Moor House is shut up, and you are so lonely.
Diana y Mary acaban de abandonarlo, Moor House está cerrada y usted se encuentra solo.
I am sure I pity you.
Do come and see papa."
¡Ande, venga a ver a papá!
"Not to-night, Miss Rosamond, not to-night."
-Esta noche, no, Miss Rosamond.
Mr. St. John spoke almost like an automaton: himself only knew the effort it cost him thus to refuse.
Rivers hablaba como un autómata.
Sólo él podía saber el esfuerzo que aquella negativa le exigiera.
"Well, if you are so obstinate, I will leave you; for I dare not stay any longer: the dew begins to fall.
-¡Qué obstinado es usted!...
Ya no puedo detenerme más: comienza a caer el rocío.
Good evening!"
Buenas noches.
She held out her hand.
He just touched it.
"Good evening!" he repeated, in a voice low and hollow as an echo.
-Buenas noches -dijo Rivers en voz baja y casi como un eco.
She turned, but in a moment returned.
Ella echó a andar, pero se volvió en seguida.
"Are you well?" she asked.
-¿Se encuentra bien? -preguntó.
Well might she put the question: his face was blanched as her gown.
Y no le faltaba razón para interrogarlo, porque la faz del joven estaba tan blanca como el vestido de la muchacha.
"Quite well," he enunciated; and, with a bow, he left the gate.
-Muy bien-repuso él.
E, inclinándose, se apartó de la verja.
She went one way; he another.
Cada uno se alejó por un camino distinto.
She turned twice to gaze after him as she tripped fairy-like down the field; he, as he strode firmly across, never turned at all.
Ella, vaporosa entre los campos como una aparición maravillosa, se volvió dos veces para mirarle.
El, ninguna.
This spectacle of another's suffering and sacrifice rapt my thoughts from exclusive meditation on my own.
El espectáculo del dolor y el sacrificio de otro, ahuyentó el pensamiento de los míos personales.
Diana Rivers had designated her brother "inexorable as death."
Diana Rivers había calificado a su hermano de «inflexible como la muerte».
She had not exaggerated.
Y no exageraba.
CHAPTER XXXII
XXXII
I continued the labours of the village-school as actively and faithfully as I could.
Proseguí mis tareas en la escuela de la aldea tan activa y entusiasta como pude.
It was truly hard work at first.
El trabajo fue duro al principio.
Some time elapsed before, with all my efforts, I could comprehend my scholars and their nature.
Pasó tiempo, pese a mis esfuerzos, antes de que pudiera comprender a mis alumnas y su modo de ser.
Wholly untaught, with faculties quite torpid, they seemed to me hopelessly dull; and, at first sight, all dull alike: but I soon found I was mistaken.
Me parecía imposible desembotar sus facultades y, además, al primer golpe de vista, todas se me figuraron iguales en su rusticidad y en sus aptitudes.
There was a difference amongst them as amongst the educated; and when I got to know them, and they me, this difference rapidly developed itself.
Pronto comprendí que estaba equivocada y que entre ellas había tanta diferencia de una a otra como la que hay entre seres educados.
Their amazement at me, my language, my rules, and ways, once subsided, I found some of these heavy-looking, gaping rustics wake up into sharp-witted girls enough.

Many showed themselves obliging, and amiable too; and I discovered amongst them not a few examples of natural politeness, and innate self-respect, as well as of excellent capacity, that won both my goodwill and my admiration.

Una vez que comenzamos a comprendernos mutuamente, descubrí en muchas de ellas cierta amabilidad natural, cierto. innato sentido del respeto propio y una capacidad innata que granjearon mi admiración y mi buena voluntad.
These soon took a pleasure in doing their work well, in keeping their persons neat, in learning their tasks regularly, in acquiring quiet and orderly manners.
Las muchachas se interesaron en seguida en cumplir bien sus tareas, en adquirir hábitos de limpieza, puntualidad y urbanidad.
La rapidez de los progresos de algunas era sorprendente.
The rapidity of their progress, in some instances, was even surprising; and an honest and happy pride I took in it: besides, I began personally to like some of the best girls; and they liked me.
Y ello me imbuía un modesto orgullo.
Acabé estimando a algunas de las mejores de mis discípulas, y ellas me correspondían.
I had amongst my scholars several farmers' daughters: young women grown, almost.
Tenía entre las alumnas varias hijas de granjeros, ya casi mujeres.
These could already read, write, and sew; and to them I taught the elements of grammar, geography, history, and the finer kinds of needlework.
Como sabían leer, escribir y coser algo, pude enseñarles rudimentos de gramática, geografía, historia y labores.
I found estimable characters amongst them--characters desirous of information and disposed for improvement--with whom I passed many a pleasant evening hour in their own homes.
A veces pasaba agradables horas en las casas de algunas de las que se mostraban más ávidas de instruirse y progresar.
Their parents then (the farmer and his wife) loaded me with attentions.
En tales casos, los granjeros, sus padres, me colmaban de atenciones.

There was an enjoyment in accepting their simple kindness, and in repaying it by a consideration--a scrupulous regard to their feelings--to which they were not, perhaps, at all times accustomed, and which both charmed and benefited them; because, while it elevated them in their own eyes, it made them emulous to merit the deferential treatment they received.
Experimentaba una alegría aceptándolas y retribuyéndolas con consideración y respeto escrupuloso hacia sus sentimientos, a lo que quizá no estuvieran acostumbrados.
Ello les encantaba y beneficiaba, porque, sintiéndose elevados ante sus propios ojos, procuraban merecer el trato diferente que yo gustosamente les daba.
I felt I became a favourite in the neighbourhood.
Me convertí en favorita de la aldea.
Whenever I went out, I heard on all sides cordial salutations, and was welcomed with friendly smiles.
Cuando salía, acogíanme por doquiera cordiales saludos y amistosas sonrisas.
To live amidst general regard, though it be but the regard of working people, is like "sitting in sunshine, calm and sweet;" serene inward feelings bud and bloom under the ray.
Vivir entre el respeto general, aunque sea entre humildes trabajadores, es como estar «sentados bajo un sol dulce y benigno».

At this period of my life, my heart far oftener swelled with thankfulness than sank with dejection: and yet, reader, to tell you all, in the midst of this calm, this useful existence--after a day passed in honourable exertion amongst my scholars, an evening spent in drawing or reading contentedly alone--I used to rush into strange dreams at night:
En aquel período de mi vida mi corazón solía estar más animado que abatido.
Y con todo, lector, en medio de mi existencia tranquila y laboriosa, tras un día pasado en la escuela y una velada transcurrida leyendo en apacible soledad, cuando me dormía soñaba extraños sueños,

dreams many-coloured, agitated, full of the ideal, the stirring, the stormy--dreams where, amidst unusual scenes, charged with adventure, with agitating risk and romantic chance, I still again and again met Mr. Rochester, always at some exciting crisis; and then the sense of being in his arms, hearing his voice, meeting his eye, touching his hand and cheek, loving him, being loved by him--the hope of passing a lifetime at his side, would be renewed, with all its first force and fire.
Then I awoke.
coloridos, agitados, llenos de ideal, de aventura y de novelescas probabilidades.

Muchas veces imaginaba hallarme con Rochester, me sentía en sus brazos, oía su voz, veía su mirada, tocaba su rostro y sus manos, y entonces la esperanza y el deseo de pasar la vida a su lado se renovaban en todo su prístino vigor.
Then I recalled where I was, and how situated.
Then I rose up on my curtainless bed, trembling and quivering; and then the still, dark night witnessed the convulsion of despair, and heard the burst of passion.d
Al despertar recordaba dónde estaba y cómo vivía, me estremecía de dolor y la noche oscura asistía a mis convulsiones de desesperación y al crepitar de la llama de mis pasiones.
By nine o'clock the next morning I was punctually opening the school; tranquil, settled, prepared for the steady duties of the day.
A las nueve de la mañana siguiente, abría con puntualidad la escuela y me preparaba para los cotidianos deberes.
Rosamond Oliver kept her word in coming to visit me.
Rosamond Oliver cumplió su palabra de visitarme.
Her call at the school was generally made in the course of her morning ride.
She would canter up to the door on her pony, followed by a mounted livery servant.
Solía ir a la escuela durante su paseo matinal a caballo, seguida por un servidor montado.

Anything more exquisite than her appearance, in her purple habit, with her Amazon's cap of black velvet placed gracefully above the long curls that kissed her cheek and floated to her shoulders, can scarcely be imagined: and it was thus she would enter the rustic building, and glide through the dazzled ranks of the village children.

Imposible imaginar nada más exquisito que el aspecto que tenía con su vestido rojo y su sombrero de amazona graciosamente colocado sobre sus largos rizos que besaban sus mejillas y flotaban sobre sus hombros.
Solía llegar a la hora en que Mr.
She generally came at the hour when Mr. Rivers was engaged in giving his daily catechising lesson.
Rivers daba la diaria lección de doctrina cristiana.
Keenly, I fear, did the eye of the visitress pierce the young pastor's heart.
Yo comprendía que los ojos de la visitante desgarraban el corazón del joven pastor.

A sort of instinct seemed to warn him of her entrance, even when he did not see it; and when he was looking quite away from the door, if she appeared at it, his cheek would glow, and his marble-seeming features, though they refused to relax, changed indescribably, and in their very quiescence became expressive of a repressed fervour, stronger than working muscle or darting glance could indicate.

Dijérase que un instinto secreto anunciase a Rivers la llegada de la muchacha, porque, aunque fingía no verla, antes de que cruzase el umbral, la sangre se agolpaba en sus mejillas, sus marmóreas facciones se transformaban y su serenidad aparente demostraba una impresión mayor que cuanto hubieran exteriorizado los más vivos ademanes o miradas.
Of course, she knew her power: indeed, he did not, because he could not, conceal it from her.
Ella sabía el efecto que le causaba.
In spite of his Christian stoicism, when she went up and addressed him, and smiled gaily, encouragingly, even fondly in his face, his hand would tremble and his eye burn.
Pese a su cristiano estoicismo, Rivers, cuando Rosamond le miraba y le sonreía, no podía contener el temblar de sus manos y el fulgor de sus ojos.
He seemed to say, with his sad and resolute look, if he did not say it with his lips, "I love you, and I know you prefer me.
Parecía decirla, con su mirada, triste y resuelta a la vez: «La amo y sé que usted me aprecia.
It is not despair of success that keeps me dumb.
No dejo de dirigirme a usted por temor al fracaso.
If I offered my heart, I believe you would accept it.
Creo que si le ofreciera mi corazón, usted lo aceptaría.
But that heart is already laid on a sacred altar: the fire is arranged round it.
It will soon be no more than a sacrifice consumed."
Pero mi corazón está destinado a arder en un ara sagrada y en breve el sacrificio se habrá consumado.»

And then she would pout like a disappointed child; a pensive cloud would soften her radiant vivacity; she would withdraw her hand hastily from his, and turn in transient petulance from his aspect, at once so heroic and so martyr-like.
En tales ocasiones ella se ponía pensativa como una niña disgustada.
Una nube velaba su radiante vivacidad; separaba con premura la mano de la de él y volvía la mirada.

St. John, no doubt, would have given the world to follow, recall, retain her, when she thus left him; but he would not give one chance of heaven, nor relinquish, for the elysium of her love, one hope of the true, eternal Paradise.
Estoy segura de que Rivers hubiera dado un mundo por retenerla cuando se apartaba de él así, pero no, en cambio, una probabilidad de alcanzar el cielo.
No hubiera cambiado por el amor de aquella mujer su esperanza de alcanzar el verdadero paraíso.
Besides, he could not bind all that he had in his nature--the rover, the aspirant, the poet, the priest--in the limits of a single passion.
Ni le era posible concentrar en los límites de un solo amor sus ansias de ambicioso, de poeta, de sacerdote.
He could not--he would not--renounce his wild field of mission warfare for the parlours and the peace of Vale Hall.
No quería, ni debía, sacrificar su tarea de misionero a una vida reposada en los salones de Pale Hall.
I learnt so much from himself in an inroad I once, despite his reserve, had the daring to make on his confidence.
Aprendí mucho en el ejemplo de aquel hombre, una vez que, a pesar de su reserva, logré penetrar algo en su confianza.
Miss Oliver already honoured me with frequent visits to my cottage.
Miss Oliver honraba mi casita con visitas frecuentes.
I had learnt her whole character, which was without mystery or disguise: she was coquettish but not heartless; exacting, but not worthlessly selfish.
Yo conocía bien su carácter, en el que no había ciertamente disfraz ni misterio.
She had been indulged from her birth, but was not absolutely spoilt.
Era coqueta, pero no le faltaba corazón, y absorbente, pero no egoísta.

She was hasty, but good-humoured; vain (she could not help it, when every glance in the glass showed her such a flush of loveliness), but not affected; liberal-handed; innocent of the pride of wealth; ingenuous; sufficiently intelligent; gay, lively, and unthinking: she was very charming, in short, even to a cool observer of her own sex like me; but she was not profoundly interesting or thoroughly impressive.
Era caprichosa, pero tenía buen carácter; frívola, mas no afectada; generosa, nada orgullosa de su situación económica, ingenua, bastante inteligente, despreocupada y alegre.
Era encantadora, en resumen, aun para un observador imparcial y de su propio sexo, como yo, pero no profundamente interesado.
A very different sort of mind was hers from that, for instance, of the sisters of St. John.
Un tipo muy diferente, en fin, de las hermanas de Rivers.

Still, I liked her almost as I liked my pupil Adele; except that, for a child whom we have watched over and taught, a closer affection is engendered than we can give an equally attractive adult acquaintance.
Yo experimentaba por ella un afecto muy semejante al que sintiera por Adèle con la natural diferencia de ser ésta una niña y aquélla una adulta.
She had taken an amiable caprice to me.
Ella sentía por mí un amable capricho.
She said I was like Mr. Rivers, only, certainly, she allowed, "not one-tenth so handsome, though I was a nice neat little soul enough, but he was an angel."
Decía que yo era como Rivers (aunque estoy segura de que en el fondo pensaba que no tan bella y que, aunque limpia de alma, no podía compararme con él, a quien debía considerar como un ángel).
I was, however, good, clever, composed, and firm, like him.
I was a _lusus naturae_, she affirmed, as a village schoolmistress: she was sure my previous history, if known, would make a delightful romance.
Agregaba que yo, como maestra de escuela de aldea, era un lussus naturae y que estaba segura de que mi vida anterior debía de constituir una sugestiva novela.

One evening, while, with her usual child-like activity, and thoughtless yet not offensive inquisitiveness, she was rummaging the cupboard and the table-drawer of my little kitchen, she discovered first two French books, a volume of Schiller, a German grammar and dictionary, and then my drawing-materials and some sketches, including a pencil-head of a pretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars, and sundry views from nature, taken in the Vale of Morton and on the surrounding moors.

Una noche en que, con su curiosidad infantil, aunque no molesta, se dedicaba a revolver el aparador de mi cocina, encontró una gramática y un diccionario alemanes, dos libros franceses y una obra de Schiller, así como mis útiles de dibujo, un apunte de la cabecita de una de mis alumnas y algunos paisajes del valle de Morton y de los pantanos.
She was first transfixed with surprise, and then electrified with delight.
Quedó atónita de sorpresa y placer.
"Had I done these pictures?
¿Había hecho yo aquellos dibujos?
Did I know French and German?
¿Sabía francés y alemán?
What a love--what a miracle I was!
¡Qué encanto!
I drew better than her master in the first school in S-.
¡Yo podía ser maestra de la mejor escuela de S...!
Would I sketch a portrait of her, to show to papa?"
¿Querría hacer un retrato de ella, para enseñarlo a papá?
"With pleasure," I replied; and I felt a thrill of artist-delight at the idea of copying from so perfect and radiant a model.
Respondí que con mucho gusto, experimentando, en efecto, el placer que todo artista sentiría en copiar un modelo tan perfecto y radiante.
She had then on a dark-blue silk dress; her arms and her neck were bare; her only ornament was her chestnut tresses, which waved over her shoulders with all the wild grace of natural curls.
Vestía la joven un traje de seda azul oscuro, llevaba desnudos los brazos y el cuello, y no ostentaba otro adorno que el natural de sus tirabuzones castaños cayendo sobre los hombros.
I took a sheet of fine card-board, and drew a careful outline.
I promised myself the pleasure of colouring it; and, as it was getting late then, I told her she must come and sit another day.
Tomé cuidadosamente un apunte, que me prometí colorear, y le dije que, como era tarde, debía volver a posar otro día.
De tal modo debió de hablar de mí a su padre, que éste la acompañó al día siguiente.

She made such a report of me to her father, that Mr. Oliver himself accompanied her next evening--a tall, massive-featured, middle-aged, and grey-headed man, at whose side his lovely daughter looked like a bright flower near a hoary turret.
Era un hombre alto, de cara cuadrada, maduro, de cabello gris.
Su hija parecía, a su lado, una flor junto a una vieja torre.
He appeared a taciturn, and perhaps a proud personage; but he was very kind to me.
Aunque tenía aspecto orgulloso y taciturno, estuvo muy amable conmigo.
The sketch of Rosamond's portrait pleased him highly: he said I must make a finished picture of it.
El bosquejo del retrato de Rosamond le gustó mucho y dijo que era preciso que lo completara.
He insisted, too, on my coming the next day to spend the evening at Vale Hall.
Me rogó también insistentemente que fuese a pasar la velada del día siguiente en Pale Hall.
I went.
Acudí.
I found it a large, handsome residence, showing abundant evidences of wealth in the proprietor.
La casa, amplia y hermosa, denotaba la riqueza de su propietario.
Rosamond was full of glee and pleasure all the time I stayed.
Rosamond estuvo muy alegre y sin padre muy afable.

Her father was affable; and when he entered into conversation with me after tea, he expressed in strong terms his approbation of what I had done in Morton school, and said he only feared, from what he saw and heard, I was too good for the place, and would soon quit it for one more suitable.
Después del té me dijo que se hallaba muy satisfecho de mi labor en la escuela y que sólo temía que yo la abandonase pronto, ya que mis aptitudes no eran apropiadas a aquel modesto empleo.
"Indeed," cried Rosamond, "she is clever enough to be a governess in a high family, papa."
-¡Claro! -exclamó Rosamond-.
Podría ser muy bien institutriz de una familia distinguida.
I thought I would far rather be where I am than in any high family in the land.
Yo pensaba que estaba más a gusto así que con la familia más distinguida del planeta.
Mr. Oliver spoke of Mr. Rivers--of the Rivers family--with great respect.
Mr.
Oliver habló con gran respeto de los Rivers.

He said it was a very old name in that neighbourhood; that the ancestors of the house were wealthy; that all Morton had once belonged to them; that even now he considered the representative of that house might, if he liked, make an alliance with the best.
Dijo que era la casa más antigua de la comarca, que antiguamente les había pertenecido todo Morton y que, aun ahora, el representante de aquella noble familia podría hacer un matrimonio excelente.
He accounted it a pity that so fine and talented a young man should have formed the design of going out as a missionary; it was quite throwing a valuable life away.
Se lamentó de que un hombre de tanto talento como el joven hubiese decidido hacerse misionero.
It appeared, then, that her father would throw no obstacle in the way of Rosamond's union with St. John.
Mr. Oliver evidently regarded the young clergyman's good birth, old name, and sacred profession as sufficient compensation for the want of fortune.

Entendí que el padre de Rosamond no hubiera dificultado su unión con John considerando sin duda que el nombre ilustre, la familia distinguida y la respetable profesión de Rivers compensaban su falta de fortuna.
It was the 5th of November, and a holiday.
El 5 de noviembre era fiesta.
My little servant, after helping me to clean my house, was gone, well satisfied with the fee of a penny for her aid.
Mi criadita, después de ayudarme a limpiar la casa, se había ido, encantada con el penique con que la obsequié.
All about me was spotless and bright--scoured floor, polished grate, and well-rubbed chairs.
Todo estaba limpio y brillante: la vajilla, el suelo, las sillas bien barnizadas.
I had also made myself neat, and had now the afternoon before me to spend as I would.
Tenía ante mí la tarde para emplearla como quisiera.
The translation of a few pages of German occupied an hour; then I got my palette and pencils, and fell to the more soothing, because easier occupation, of completing Rosamond Oliver's miniature.
Pasé una hora traduciendo alemán.
Luego cogí mis pinceles y mi paleta y comencé a dar los últimos toques al retrato de Rosamond Oliver.

The head was finished already: there was but the background to tint and the drapery to shade off; a touch of carmine, too, to add to the ripe lips--a soft curl here and there to the tresses--a deeper tinge to the shadow of the lash under the azured eyelid.
Apenas faltaba nada: algún toque de carmín que añadir a los labios, algún rizo que añadir a los tirabuzones, un ligero sombreado bajo los ojos...
I was absorbed in the execution of these nice details, when, after one rapid tap, my door unclosed, admitting St. John Rivers.
Estaba abstraída en estos detalles cuando oí un golpe en la puerta entornada y entró seguidamente John Rivers.
"I am come to see how you are spending your holiday," he said.
-Vengo a ver cómo pasa usted la fiesta --dijo-.
"Not, I hope, in thought?
Espero que no en pensar cosas tristes.
No, that is well: while you draw you will not feel lonely.
¡Ah, está pintando!
Muy bien.
You see, I mistrust you still, though you have borne up wonderfully so far.
Le traía un libro para entretenerse.

I have brought you a book for evening solace," and he laid on the table a new publication--a poem: one of those genuine productions so often vouchsafed to the fortunate public of those days--the golden age of modern literature.
Y puso sobre la mesa un poema recientemente publicado, una de aquellas excelentes producciones que se ofrecían al público en aquella época, la edad de oro de la literatura inglesa moderna.
Alas! the readers of our era are less favoured.
¡Nuestra época no es, en ese sentido, tan afortunada!
But courage!
I will not pause either to accuse or repine.
No nos desalentemos, sin embargo.
I know poetry is not dead, nor genius lost; nor has Mammon gained power over either, to bind or slay: they will both assert their existence, their presence, their liberty and strength again one day.
Sé que la poesía no ha muerto ni el genio se ha perdido, que Mammon no los ha esclavizado.
Así, pues, un día u otro demostrarán su existencia, presencia y libertad.
Powerful angels, safe in heaven! they smile when sordid souls triumph, and feeble ones weep over their destruction.
Como potentes ángeles, se han refugiado en el cielo, y sonríen ante el triunfo de las almas sórdidas y de las lágrimas de las débiles.
Poetry destroyed?
Genius banished?
No; no está la poesía destruida ni desvanecido el genio.
No!
Mediocrity, no: do not let envy prompt you to the thought.
No cantes victoria, ¡oh, mediocridad!
No; they not only live, but reign and redeem: and without their divine influence spread everywhere, you would be in hell--the hell of your own meanness.
No sólo aquellos divinos influjos existen, sino que reinan y sin ellos tú misma estarías en el infierno... en el de tu insignificancia.
While I was eagerly glancing at the bright pages of "Marmion" (for "Marmion" it was), St. John stooped to examine my drawing.
Mientras examinaba el libro, John Rivers contemplaba el retrato.
His tall figure sprang erect again with a start: he said nothing.
Luego se irguió, en silencio.
I looked up at him: he shunned my eye.

I knew his thoughts well, and could read his heart plainly; at the moment I felt calmer and cooler than he: I had then temporarily the advantage of him, and I conceived an inclination to do him some good, if I could.
Le miré: leía en sus ojos y en su corazón como en un libro abierto y me sentía más tranquila y más fría que él.
"With all his firmness and self-control," thought I, "he tasks himself too far: locks every feeling and pang within--expresses, confesses, imparts nothing.
Viéndome de momento más fuerte que Rivers, resolví hacerle el bien que me fuera posible,
I am sure it would benefit him to talk a little about this sweet Rosamond, whom he thinks he ought not to marry: I will make him talk."
segura de que nada le sería más grato que hablar un poco de aquella dulce Rosamond con la que no pensaba casarse, a pesar de su amor...
I said first, "Take a chair, Mr. Rivers."
-Siéntese -le dije.
But he answered, as he always did, that he could not stay.
Contestó, como siempre, que no le era posible detenerse.
"Very well," I responded, mentally, "stand if you like; but you shall not go just yet, I am determined: solitude is at least as bad for you as it is for me.
Resolví que, sentado o de pie, me oiría, ya que la soledad no era más conveniente para él que para mí.
I'll try if I cannot discover the secret spring of your confidence, and find an aperture in that marble breast through which I can shed one drop of the balm of sympathy."
Pensaba que, de no poder llegar hasta la fuente de su confianza, al menos descubriría en su pecho de mármol una grieta a través de la cual poder deslizar el bálsamo de mi simpatía.
"Is this portrait like?"
I asked bluntly.
-¿Le gusta este retrato? -pregunté de pronto.
"Like!
Like whom?
-¿Gustarme el qué?
I did not observe it closely."
No me he fijado bien.
"You did, Mr. Rivers."
-Sí se ha fijado.
He almost started at my sudden and strange abruptness: he looked at me astonished.
Me contempló atónito, sorprendido de mi brusquedad.
"Oh, that is nothing yet," I muttered within.
"I don't mean to be baffled by a little stiffness on your part; I'm prepared to go to considerable lengths."
I continued, "You observed it closely and distinctly; but I have no objection to your looking at it again," and I rose and placed it in his hand.
Pero yo continué, impertérrita: -Lo ha mirado detenidamente, pero no sé por qué no ha de verlo mejor -y diciendo así, se lo entregué.
"A well-executed picture," he said; "very soft, clear colouring; very graceful and correct drawing."
-Es un excelente retrato, muy suave de color y muy dibujado.
"Yes, yes; I know all that.
-Ya, ya...
But what of the resemblance?
Who is it like?"
Pero, ¿de quién es?
Mastering some hesitation, he answered, "Miss Oliver, I presume."
Dominando un titubeo, respondió: -Presumo que de Miss Oliver.
"Of course.
-Sí.
And now, sir, to reward you for the accurate guess, I will promise to paint you a careful and faithful duplicate of this very picture, provided you admit that the gift would be acceptable to you.
Ahora bien, si desea y lo acepta, le ofrezco una copia fiel del retrato.
I don't wish to throw away my time and trouble on an offering you would deem worthless."
He continued to gaze at the picture: the longer he looked, the firmer he held it, the more he seemed to covet it.
Siguió examinándolo y murmuró:
"It is like!" he murmured; "the eye is well managed: the colour, light, expression, are perfect.
-¡Es admirable!
Los ojos, su expresión, su color, son perfectos...
It smiles!"
Se la ve sonreír...
"Would it comfort, or would it wound you to have a similar painting?
-¿Le agradaría o le disgustaría tener una copia?
Tell me that.

When you are at Madagascar, or at the Cape, or in India, would it be a consolation to have that memento in your possession? or would the sight of it bring recollections calculated to enervate and distress?"
Cuando se encuentre usted en Madagascar, en la India, o en El Cairo, ¿sería para usted un consuelo este retrato o más bien un motivo de recuerdos tristes?
He now furtively raised his eyes: he glanced at me, irresolute, disturbed: he again surveyed the picture.
Me miró indeciso y volvió a examinar la pintura.
"That I should like to have it is certain: whether it would be judicious or wise is another question."
-Me agradaría tenerlo -respondió-.
Que sea prudente o no, es otra cosa.

Since I had ascertained that Rosamond really preferred him, and that her father was not likely to oppose the match, I--less exalted in my views than St. John--had been strongly disposed in my own heart to advocate their union.
Desde que comprobara que Rosamond quería a Rivers y su padre no se oponía a un matrimonio, había deseado abogar porque se realizara.

It seemed to me that, should he become the possessor of Mr. Oliver's large fortune, he might do as much good with it as if he went and laid his genius out to wither, and his strength to waste, under a tropical sun.
Parecía que, si entraba John Rivers en posesión de la gran fortuna de Mr.
Oliver, podría hacer más beneficios a sus semejantes que los que efectuara ejerciendo de misionero bajo el sol de los trópicos.
