With this persuasion I now answered--
Por ello, le dije:
"As far as I can see, it would be wiser and more judicious if you were to take to yourself the original at once."
-A mi entender, lo más razonable sería tener, mejor que el retrato, el modelo.
By this time he had sat down: he had laid the picture on the table before him, and with his brow supported on both hands, hung fondly over it.
Él se había sentado, colocando el retrato sobre la mesa y la contemplaba en éxtasis, con la cabeza entre las manos.
I discerned he was now neither angry nor shocked at my audacity.
Noté que no le ofendía mi audacia.
I saw even that to be thus frankly addressed on a subject he had deemed unapproachable--to hear it thus freely handled--was beginning to be felt by him as a new pleasure--an unhoped-for relief.
Hasta observé que aquel modo brusco de tratar el asunto le placía y le aliviaba.
Reserved people often really need the frank discussion of their sentiments and griefs more than the expansive.
Las personas reservadas necesitan a veces que se hable de sus sentimientos y angustias más que las expansivas.
The sternest-seeming stoic is human after all; and to "burst" with boldness and good-will into "the silent sea" of their souls is often to confer on them the first of obligations.
El más estoico es, al fin, un ser humano.
"She likes you, I am sure," said I, as I stood behind his chair, "and her father respects you.
-Estoy segura de que usted la quiere -dije-.
Y el padre de ella le estima mucho a usted.
Moreover, she is a sweet girl--rather thoughtless; but you would have sufficient thought for both yourself and her.
Además, es una muchacha encantadora y si no posee una gran mentalidad, usted tiene bastante para los dos.
You ought to marry her."
Debe casarse con ella.
"_Does_ she like me?" he asked.
-¿Acaso me quiere ella a mí? -repuso.
"Certainly; better than she likes any one else.
-Más que a nadie.
She talks of you continually: there is no subject she enjoys so much or touches upon so often."
Nada le complace tanto como hablar de usted y lo hace continuamente.
"It is very pleasant to hear this," he said--"very: go on for another quarter of an hour."
-Eso es muy agradable de oír...
And he actually took out his watch and laid it upon the table to measure the time.
Estaré otro cuarto de hora -añadió, poniendo el reloj sobre la mesa para calcular el tiempo.
"But where is the use of going on," I asked, "when you are probably preparing some iron blow of contradiction, or forging a fresh chain to fetter your heart?"
-¿Para qué?
¿Para preparar entre tanto una violenta contradicción y forjar una cadena más que aprisione los impulsos de su corazón?
"Don't imagine such hard things.
-Vaya, no imagine esas cosas terribles...

Fancy me yielding and melting, as I am doing: human love rising like a freshly opened fountain in my mind and overflowing with sweet inundation all the field I have so carefully and with such labour prepared--so assiduously sown with the seeds of good intentions, of self-denying plans.

Imagine más bien, y acertará, que la posibilidad de un amor humano fluye en mi mente como una riada que inunda el campo que con tanto cuidado y trabajo preparé, que hace llover sobre él un suave veneno.

And now it is deluged with a nectarous flood--the young germs swamped--delicious poison cankering them: now I see myself stretched on an ottoman in the drawing-room at Vale Hall at my bride Rosamond Oliver's feet: she is talking to me with her sweet voice--gazing down on me with those eyes your skilful hand has copied so well--smiling at me with these coral lips.

Me veo a mí mismo sentado en una butaca en el salón de Pale Hall, con Rosamond a mis pies, hablándome con su dulce voz, sonriéndome con esos labios de coral que la diestra mano de usted ha copiado tan bien.
She is mine--I am hers--this present life and passing world suffice to me.
Es mía, soy suyo, esta vida y este mundo me bastan.
¡Chist!
Hush! say nothing--my heart is full of delight--my senses are entranced--let the time I marked pass in peace."
No diga nada: mi corazón está lleno de satisfacción y enervados mis sentidos.
Deje pasar en paz el tiempo marcado.
I humoured him: the watch ticked on: he breathed fast and low: I stood silent.
Sonaba el tictac del reloj.
Rivers respiraba fuertemente; yo callaba.
Amidst this hush the quartet sped; he replaced the watch, laid the picture down, rose, and stood on the hearth.
Pasado el cuarto de hora, se incorporó, guardó el reloj y dejó de mirar la pintura.
"Now," said he, "that little space was given to delirium and delusion.
-Estos minutos -dijo- han sido consagrados al delirio y a la ilusión.
I rested my temples on the breast of temptation, and put my neck voluntarily under her yoke of flowers.
I tasted her cup.
He ofrecido mi cerviz voluntariamente al florido yugo de las tentaciones, me he dejado cubrir las sienes con sus guirnaldas y he apurado su copa.
The pillow was burning: there is an asp in the garland: the wine has a bitter taste: her promises are hollow--her offers false: I see and know all this."
Ahora veo ya y siento que su vino es hiel, sus promesas falsas y sus guirnaldas espinas.
I gazed at him in wonder.
Volvió a mirarme y continuó:

"It is strange," pursued he, "that while I love Rosamond Oliver so wildly--with all the intensity, indeed, of a first passion, the object of which is exquisitely beautiful, graceful, fascinating--I experience at the same time a calm, unwarped consciousness that she would not make me a good wife; that she is not the partner suited to me; that I should discover this within a year after marriage; and that to twelve months' rapture would succeed a lifetime of regret.
This I know."

-Aunque haya amado a Rosamond Oliver tan intensamente como la amo, y reconociendo lo bella, exquisita y graciosa que es, jamás he dejado de comprender que no será una esposa apropiada para mí, que no sería la compañera que necesito.
Me consta que a un año de éxtasis, sucedería toda una vida de lamentar esa unión.
"Strange indeed!"
I could not help ejaculating.
-¡Qué extraño! -no pude por menos de exclamar.

"While something in me," he went on, "is acutely sensible to her charms, something else is as deeply impressed with her defects: they are such that she could sympathise in nothing I aspired to--co-operate in nothing I undertook.
-Hay algo en mí -dijo Rivers- inmensamente sensible a sus encantos y otra parte que nota fuertemente sus defectos.
Sé que ella no compartiría ninguna de mis aspiraciones ni colaboraría en ninguna de mis iniciativas.
Rosamond a sufferer, a labourer, a female apostle?
Rosamond a missionary's wife?
¿Cree posible que Rosamond se convirtiera en una mujer abnegada, laboriosa, paciente, en la esposa de un misionero?
No!"
¡No!
"But you need not be a missionary.
-Pero no está usted obligado a ser misionero.
You might relinquish that scheme."
Renuncie a ello.
"Relinquish!
What! my vocation?
-¿Renunciar a mi vocación?
My great work?
My foundation laid on earth for a mansion in heaven?
¿Destruir los cimientos terrenos de mi morada celestial?

My hopes of being numbered in the band who have merged all ambitions in the glorious one of bettering their race--of carrying knowledge into the realms of ignorance--of substituting peace for war--freedom for bondage--religion for superstition--the hope of heaven for the fear of hell?
¿Sustituir la sabiduría por la ignorancia, la paz por la guerra, la libertad por la esclavitud, la religión por la superstición, la esperanza del cielo por el amor del infierno?
Must I relinquish that?
It is dearer than the blood in my veins.
¿Renunciar a cuanto me es más querido que la sangre de mis venas?
It is what I have to look forward to, and to live for."
No; debo vivir para ello y mirar hacia delante.
After a considerable pause, I said--"And Miss Oliver?
Are her disappointment and sorrow of no interest to you?"
-Y el disgusto que experimente Miss Oliver, ¿le es indiferente? -pregunté, tras larga pausa.
"Miss Oliver is ever surrounded by suitors and flatterers: in less than a month, my image will be effaced from her heart.
She will forget me; and will marry, probably, some one who will make her far happier than I should do."
-Rosamond está siempre rodeada, de hombres que la cortejan y antes de un mes se habrá olvidado de mí y se casara, probablemente, con alguien que la hará más feliz de lo que yo la haría.
"You speak coolly enough; but you suffer in the conflict.
You are wasting away."
-Usted habla con calma, pero sufre.
"No.
-No.
If I get a little thin, it is with anxiety about my prospects, yet unsettled--my departure, continually procrastinated.
Lo único que me disgusta es el alargamiento de mi marcha.

Only this morning, I received intelligence that the successor, whose arrival I have been so long expecting, cannot be ready to replace me for three months to come yet; and perhaps the three months may extend to six."
Esta mañana me he informado de que el párroco que me sustituye no llegará hasta dentro de tres meses, acaso de seis.
"You tremble and become flushed whenever Miss Oliver enters the schoolroom."
-Usted se estremece y se sonroja cuando ella entra en la escuela.
Again the surprised expression crossed his face.
Otra vez una expresión de asombro se pintó en su faz.
He had not imagined that a woman would dare to speak so to a man.
No imaginaba que una mujer osase hablar así a un hombre.
For me, I felt at home in this sort of discourse.
En cuanto a mí, navegaba en mis propias aguas.

I could never rest in communication with strong, discreet, and refined minds, whether male or female, till I had passed the outworks of conventional reserve, and crossed the threshold of confidence, and won a place by their heart's very hearthstone.
Nunca me sentía a gusto en el trato de cualquiera, hombre o mujer, hasta que penetraba en el umbral de su confianza, traspasando los límites de la reserva convencional.
"You are original," said he, "and not timid.
-Es usted original y nada tímida -dijo-.
There is something brave in your spirit, as well as penetrating in your eye; but allow me to assure you that you partially misinterpret my emotions.
Su espíritu es atrevido y sus ojos perspicaces, pero le aseguro que en parte interpreta mal mis emociones.
You think them more profound and potent than they are.
Me considera más profundo y más inteligente de lo que soy.
You give me a larger allowance of sympathy than I have a just claim to.
Me concede más simpatía de la que merezco.
When I colour, and when I shade before Miss Oliver, I do not pity myself.
I scorn the weakness.
I know it is ignoble: a mere fever of the flesh: not, I declare, the convulsion of the soul. _That_ is just as fixed as a rock, firm set in the depths of a restless sea.
Si se me enciende la cara cuando veo a Rosamond no es, como supone usted, por un impulso del alma, sino por una vergonzosa debilidad de la carne.
Know me to be what I am--a cold hard man."
Pero espiritualmente me conozco: soy un hombre frío y duro como una roca.
I smiled incredulously.
Sonreí, incrédula.
"You have taken my confidence by storm," he continued, "and now it is much at your service.
-Ha tomado usted por asalto mi intimidad -siguió- y no le ocultaré mi carácter.
I am simply, in my original state--stripped of that blood-bleached robe with which Christianity covers human deformity--a cold, hard, ambitious man.
Prescindiendo de las vestiduras externas y convencionales con que cubrimos las deformidades humanas, en el fondo no soy más que un hombre duro, frío y ambicioso.
Natural affection only, of all the sentiments, has permanent power over me.
Reason, and not feeling, is my guide; my ambition is unlimited: my desire to rise higher, to do more than others, insatiable.
No me guía el sentimiento, sino la razón; mi ambición es ilimitada; deseo elevarme más que nadie.
I honour endurance, perseverance, industry, talent; because these are the means by which men achieve great ends and mount to lofty eminence.
Si alabo la perseverancia, la laboriosidad y el talento, es porque son los medios de que pueden servirse los hombres para alcanzar vastos fines.
I watch your career with interest, because I consider you a specimen of a diligent, orderly, energetic woman: not because I deeply compassionate what you have gone through, or what you still suffer."
Y si yo me ocupo de usted, es porque la considero un modelo de mujer diligente, enérgica y disciplinada, no porque me compadezca de lo que usted ha sufrido o le falte por sufrir.
"You would describe yourself as a mere pagan philosopher," I said.
-Se pinta usted como un filósofo pagano -dije.
"No.
There is this difference between me and deistic philosophers: I believe; and I believe the Gospel.
-Hay una diferencia entre mí y esos filósofos, y es que creo en el Evangelio.
You missed your epithet.
I am not a pagan, but a Christian philosopher--a follower of the sect of Jesus.
No soy un filósofo pagano, sino cristiano, un discípulo de Jesús, que acepta sus benignas y piadosas doctrinas.
As His disciple I adopt His pure, His merciful, His benignant doctrines.
I advocate them: I am sworn to spread them.
Las profeso y he jurado propagarlas.
Won in youth to religion, she has cultivated my original qualities thus:
La religión me ha ganado a su causa y ha convertido los gérmenes de afecto instintivo que hubiera en mí, en el árbol amplio de la filantropía cristiana.
--From the minute germ, natural affection, she has developed the overshadowing tree, philanthropy.
From the wild stringy root of human uprightness, she has reared a due sense of the Divine justice.
Of the ambition to win power and renown for my wretched self, she has formed the ambition to spread my Master's kingdom; to achieve victories for the standard of the cross.
La ambición de obtener poder y fama personal la he transformado en ambición de extender el reinado del Maestro y conseguir victorias para el estandarte de la cruz.
So much has religion done for me; turning the original materials to the best account; pruning and training nature.
But she could not eradicate nature: nor will it be eradicated 'till this mortal shall put on immortality.'"
Así, pues, la religión ha modificado en buen sentido mis inclinaciones, pero no ha podido transformar mi naturaleza, ni la cambiará «hasta que este mortal, inmortal sea...».
Having said this, he took his hat, which lay on the table beside my palette.
Once more he looked at the portrait.
Y tras esta cita, tomó el sombrero de la mesa y, al hacerlo, miró otra vez el retrato.
"She _is_ lovely," he murmured.
-¡Es encantadora! -murmuró-.
"She is well named the Rose of the World, indeed!"
Bien lo dice su nombre: es la rosa del mundo.
"And may I not paint one like it for you?"
-¿Quiere una copia del retrato? -Cui bono?
"_Cui bono_?
No.
No."
He drew over the picture the sheet of thin paper on which I was accustomed to rest my hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from being sullied.
Colocó sobre el dibujo la hoja de papel transparente en que yo solía apoyar la mano mientras pintaba, para no ensuciar la cartulina.
What he suddenly saw on this blank paper, it was impossible for me to tell; but something had caught his eye.
Lo que pudiese ver en aquel papel fue entonces un misterio para mí, pero en algo debió de reparar su mirada.

He took it up with a snatch; he looked at the edge; then shot a glance at me, inexpressibly peculiar, and quite incomprehensible: a glance that seemed to take and make note of every point in my shape, face, and dress; for it traversed all, quick, keen as lightning.
Lo cogió rápidamente, examinó sus bordes y me miró de un modo extraño e incomprensible, como si tratara de examinar hasta el detalle más mínimo de mi aspecto, mi rostro y mi vestido.
His lips parted, as if to speak: but he checked the coming sentence, whatever it was.
Sus labios se entreabrieron, como si fuese a hablar, pero nada dijo.
"What is the matter?"
I asked.
-¿Qué pasa? -pregunté.
"Nothing in the world," was the reply; and, replacing the paper, I saw him dexterously tear a narrow slip from the margin.
-Nada --contestó.
Y antes de volver a dejar el papel en su sitio cortó rápidamente una estrecha tira de su borde y la guardó en el guante.
It disappeared in his glove; and, with one hasty nod and "good-afternoon," he vanished.
Luego inclinó la cabeza y desapareció murmurando: -Buenas tardes.
"Well!"
I exclaimed, using an expression of the district, "that caps the globe, however!"
-¡Si lo entiendo, que me maten! -exclamé usando una locución local muy corriente.
I, in my turn, scrutinised the paper; but saw nothing on it save a few dingy stains of paint where I had tried the tint in my pencil.
Examiné el papel, pero nada vi de raro, salvo unas ligeras manchas de pintura.
I pondered the mystery a minute or two; but finding it insolvable, and being certain it could not be of much moment, I dismissed, and soon forgot it.
Medité en aquel misterio un par de minutos y, estimándolo insoluble y seguramente secundario, dejé de pensar en él.
CHAPTER XXXIII
XXXIII
When Mr. St. John went, it was beginning to snow; the whirling storm continued all night.
Cuando se fue Rivers comenzaba a nevar, y siguió nevando toda la noche.
The next day a keen wind brought fresh and blinding falls; by twilight the valley was drifted up and almost impassable.
Al oscurecer del día siguiente el valle estaba casi intransitable.

I had closed my shutter, laid a mat to the door to prevent the snow from blowing in under it, trimmed my fire, and after sitting nearly an hour on the hearth listening to the muffled fury of the tempest, I lit a candle, took down "Marmion," and beginning--
Cerré, apliqué una esterilla a la puerta para que la nieve, al derretirse, no entrase por debajo, encendí una vela y comencé a leer el libro de Marmion que me trajera Rivers:

"Day set on Norham's castled steep, And Tweed's fair river broad and deep, And Cheviot's mountains lone; The massive towers, the donjon keep, The flanking walls that round them sweep, In yellow lustre shone"--
Laderas del castillo de Norham, ancho y profundo río Tweed, solitarias montañas de Cheviot...
Macizos murallones, que flanquean las torres que protegen el dintel reluciendo, amarillas, bajo el sol...
I soon forgot storm in music.
La bella melodía de los versos me hizo olvidar en breve la áspera tormenta.
I heard a noise: the wind, I thought, shook the door.
Oí repentinamente un ruido en la puerta.
No; it was St. John Rivers, who, lifting the latch, came in out of the frozen hurricane--the howling darkness--and stood before me: the cloak that covered his tall figure all white as a glacier.

Creí que fuera el batir del viento pero era John Rivers, que surgiendo bajo el helado huracán de entre las profundas tinieblas, aparecía ante mí, cubierta su alta figura de un abrigo todo blanco de nieve, como un glaciar.
I was almost in consternation, so little had I expected any guest from the blocked-up vale that night.
Me alarmé, ya que no esperaba visita alguna en semejante noche.
"Any ill news?"
I demanded.
"Has anything happened?"
-¿Pasa algo? -pregunté.
"No.
-No.
How very easily alarmed you are!" he answered, removing his cloak and hanging it up against the door, towards which he again coolly pushed the mat which his entrance had deranged.
He stamped the snow from his boots.
¡Con qué facilidad se asusta! -dijo, mientras se quitaba el gabán y lo colgaba de la puerta, tras la que volvió a poner la esterilla, en la que se limpió las botas llenas de nieve.
"I shall sully the purity of your floor," said he, "but you must excuse me for once."
Then he approached the fire.
-Dispense que ensucie la limpieza de su pavimento -exclamó, agregando, mientras se acercaba al fuego-:
"I have had hard work to get here, I assure you," he observed, as he warmed his hands over the flame.
Le aseguro que me ha costado trabajo llegar.d
"One drift took me up to the waist; happily the snow is quite soft yet."
He caído en un hoyo y la nieve me alcanzaba hasta la cintura.
Por fortuna no se había helado aún.
"But why are you come?"
I could not forbear saying.
-¿Por qué ha venido? -no pude menos de interrogarle.
"Rather an inhospitable question to put to a visitor; but since you ask it, I answer simply to have a little talk with you; I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms.
-¡Qué pregunta tan poco acogedora!
No obstante, le diré que he venido para hablar con usted un poco, ya que me siento fatigado de mis libros silenciosos y mis habitaciones vacías.
Besides, since yesterday I have experienced the excitement of a person to whom a tale has been half-told, and who is impatient to hear the sequel."
Además, experimento desde ayer el interés de la persona a quien cuentan una historia y la dejan a la mitad.
He sat down.
Se sentó.
I recalled his singular conduct of yesterday, and really I began to fear his wits were touched.
Recordando su singular conducta del día anterior, empecé a temer que Rivers no estuviera bien de la cabeza.
Pero si estaba loco, lo estaba con una locura harto fría y serena.

If he were insane, however, his was a very cool and collected insanity: I had never seen that handsome-featured face of his look more like chiselled marble than it did just now, as he put aside his snow-wet hair from his forehead and let the firelight shine free on his pale brow and cheek as pale, where it grieved me to discover the hollow trace of care or sorrow now so plainly graved.
Nunca me parecieron de una calma tan marmórea sus facciones como hoy, mientras se separaba de la frente el cabello húmedo de nieve.
Con todo, la preocupación se pintaba claramente en su rostro iluminado por la llama del hogar.
I waited, expecting he would say something I could at least comprehend; but his hand was now at his chin, his finger on his lip: he was thinking.
Esperé que hablara.
Había apoyado la barbilla en la mano, mantenía un dedo sobre los labios y parecía pensativo.
It struck me that his hand looked wasted like his face.
Aquella mano me pareció tan pálida y demacrada como ahora lo estaba su rostro.
A perhaps uncalled-for gush of pity came over my heart: I was moved to say--
Sentí pena de él y dije:
"I wish Diana or Mary would come and live with you: it is too bad that you should be quite alone; and you are recklessly rash about your own health."
-Me gustaría que Diana o Mary viniesen a vivir con usted.
Está muy solo y temo por su salud.
"Not at all," said he: "I care for myself when necessary.
I am well now.
-Ya me cuido yo; estoy muy bien -repuso-.
What do you see amiss in me?"
¿Qué ve usted de mal en mí?
This was said with a careless, abstracted indifference, which showed that my solicitude was, at least in his opinion, wholly superfluous.
Habló distraídamente, con indiferencia, como si no necesitara para nada mi solicitud.
I was silenced.
Guardé silencio.

He still slowly moved his finger over his upper lip, and still his eye dwelt dreamily on the glowing grate; thinking it urgent to say something, I asked him presently if he felt any cold draught from the door, which was behind him.
Separó al fin su dedo de los labios, pero sus ojos contemplaban aún, fijos y estáticos, el fuego.
Por decir algo, le pregunté si no le molestaba el frío que se deslizaba por las rendijas de la puerta.
"No, no!" he responded shortly and somewhat testily.
-No, no -respondió, casi ásperamente.
«Bien -pensé-.
"Well," I reflected, "if you won't talk, you may be still; I'll let you alone now, and return to my book."
Puesto que no quieres hablar, allá tú.
Yo vuelvo a mi libro.»
So I snuffed the candle and resumed the perusal of "Marmion."
Despabilé la bujía y me sumí en la lectura de Marmion.

He soon stirred; my eye was instantly drawn to his movements; he only took out a morocco pocket-book, thence produced a letter, which he read in silence, folded it, put it back, relapsed into meditation.
Él, al cabo, sacó una cartera de piel y de ella una carta, que examinó en silencio, volviendo luego a hundirse en sus reflexiones.
It was vain to try to read with such an inscrutable fixture before me; nor could I, in impatience, consent to be dumb; he might rebuff me if he liked, but talk I would.
Leer en aquellas condiciones me resultaba insoportable.
Resolví hablarle, a riesgo de que me contestase con la misma brusquedad.
"Have you heard from Diana and Mary lately?"
-¿Le han vuelto a escribir sus hermanas?
"Not since the letter I showed you a week ago."
-Desde la carta que le enseñé la semana pasada, no.
"There has not been any change made about your own arrangements?
-¿Han experimentado algún cambio sus asuntos?
You will not be summoned to leave England sooner than you expected?"
¿Podrá partir antes de lo que contaba?
"I fear not, indeed: such chance is too good to befall me."
-Me temo que no.
Sería demasiada suerte.
Baffled so far, I changed my ground.
I bethought myself to talk about the school and my scholars.
No viendo posibilidad de charla por aquel lado, opté por hablar de la escuela.
"Mary Garrett's mother is better, and Mary came back to the school this morning, and I shall have four new girls next week from the Foundry Close--they would have come to-day but for the snow."
-La madre de Mary Garret está mejor y Mary ha venido hoy a la escuela.
La semana próxima asistirán cuatro niñas más de la Inclusa.
"Indeed!"
-Ya.
"Mr. Oliver pays for two."
-Mr.
Oliver paga los gastos de dos.
"Does he?"
-¿Sí?
"He means to give the whole school a treat at Christmas."
-Se propone hacer un regalo a la escuela por Navidad.
"I know."
-Lo sé.
"Was it your suggestion?"
-¿Se lo aconsejó usted?
"No."
-No.
"Whose, then?"
-¿Entonces, quién?
"His daughter's, I think."
-Supongo que su hija.
"It is like her: she is so good-natured."
-Probablemente: es muy buena.
"Yes."
-Sí.
Again came the blank of a pause: the clock struck eight strokes.
Se produjo otra pausa.
It aroused him; he uncrossed his legs, sat erect, turned to me.
Él, al fin, se volvió hacia mí.
"Leave your book a moment, and come a little nearer the fire," he said.
-Deje su libro un momento y acérquese más al fuego -dijo.
Wondering, and of my wonder finding no end, I complied.
Le obedecí, asombrada.

"Half-an-hour ago," he pursued, "I spoke of my impatience to hear the sequel of a tale: on reflection, I find the matter will be better managed by my assuming the narrator's part, and converting you into a listener.
-Hace media hora -explicó- que pienso en la continuación de la historia de ayer y he llegado a concluir que es mejor que yo la cuente y usted la escuche.
Before commencing, it is but fair to warn you that the story will sound somewhat hackneyed in your ears; but stale details often regain a degree of freshness when they pass through new lips.
Antes de empezar, debo advertirla que la historia le va a sonar a cosa conocida, pero con todo, siempre adquieren alguna novedad los detalles cuando son pronunciados por otra boca.
For the rest, whether trite or novel, it is short.
Por lo demás, el relato es breve.

"Twenty years ago, a poor curate--never mind his name at this moment--fell in love with a rich man's daughter; she fell in love with him, and married him, against the advice of all her friends, who consequently disowned her immediately after the wedding.
»Hace veinte años, un pobre sacerdote-su nombre no hace al caso por el momento- se enamoró de la hija de un hombre adinerado.
Ella le correspondió y se casó con él, contra la voluntad de su familia, que rompió sus relaciones con los recién casados.
Before two years passed, the rash pair were both dead, and laid quietly side by side under one slab.
Antes de dos años, los dos habían muerto y reposan en paz bajo la misma lápida.
(I have seen their grave; it formed part of the pavement of a huge churchyard surrounding the grim, soot-black old cathedral of an overgrown manufacturing town in ---shire.)
Yo he visto su tumba, en el inmenso cementerio adosado a la sombría y antigua catedral de una ciudad industrial, en el condado de...
They left a daughter, which, at its very birth, Charity received in her lap--cold as that of the snow-drift I almost stuck fast in to-night.
Dejaron una hija, a quien, a poco de nacer, la caridad acogió en su regazo frío, como el hoyo lleno de nieve en el que he caído esta noche.
Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations; it was reared by an aunt-in- law, called (I come to names now) Mrs. Reed of Gateshead.
La persona que la recogió era una tía suya: Mrs.
Reed, de Gateshead.
You start--did you hear a noise?
A propósito: ¿no oye usted un ruido?
I daresay it is only a rat scrambling along the rafters of the adjoining schoolroom: it was a barn before I had it repaired and altered, and barns are generally haunted by rats.
Debe ser un ratón, seguramente en el edificio de la escuela.
Antes de alquilarlo para escuela era un granero, y en los graneros suelen abundar los ratones...
--To proceed.
Pero continuemos: Mrs.

Mrs. Reed kept the orphan ten years: whether it was happy or not with her, I cannot say, never having been told; but at the end of that time she transferred it to a place you know--being no other than Lowood School, where you so long resided yourself.
Reed tuvo a la huérfana en su casa diez años, y si la niña fue feliz o no es cosa que, no habiéndome sido dicha, no puedo concretar.
Al fin, dicha señora la envió a un colegio, que no era otro que Lowood, donde usted ha vivido.

It seems her career there was very honourable: from a pupil, she became a teacher, like yourself--really it strikes me there are parallel points in her history and yours-- she left it to be a governess: there, again, your fates were analogous; she undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr. Rochester."
Su carrera fue lucida, ya que pasó de alumna a profesora..., y por cierto que noto semejanza entre su historia y la de usted...
Como usted, se empleó después de institutriz, encargándose de la educación de una niña, protegida de un tal Mr.
Rochester...
"Mr. Rivers!"
-¡Mr.
I interrupted.
Rivers! -interrumpí.
"I can guess your feelings," he said, "but restrain them for a while: I have nearly finished; hear me to the end.
-Adivino sus sentimientos -repuso-, pero le ruego que me oiga hasta el fin.

Of Mr. Rochester's character I know nothing, but the one fact that he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl, and that at the very altar she discovered he had a wife yet alive, though a lunatic.
Nada sé del carácter de ese Mr.
Rochester; sólo me consta que propuso a la joven unirse con él en matrimonio legal, aunque vivía su mujer, que estaba demente.

What his subsequent conduct and proposals were is a matter of pure conjecture; but when an event transpired which rendered inquiry after the governess necessary, it was discovered she was gone--no one could tell when, where, or how.
Cuáles fueran sus ulteriores propósitos, es asunto que se presta a discusión.
Lo único evidente es que, habiéndose precisado tener noticias de la muchacha, resultó que ésta había desaparecido sin saberse cómo.
She had left Thornfield Hall in the night; every research after her course had been vain: the country had been scoured far and wide; no vestige of information could be gathered respecting her.
Abandonó Thornfield Hall una noche y todas las pesquisas hechas en la comarca para encontrarla han resultado inútiles.

Yet that she should be found is become a matter of serious urgency: advertisements have been put in all the papers; I myself have received a letter from one Mr. Briggs, a solicitor, communicating the details I have just imparted.
Sin embargo, urge que aparezca, y al efecto se han publicado anuncios en todos los periódicos.
Yo mismo he recibido una carta de un procurador llamado Briggs comunicándome los detalles que acabo de participarle.
Is it not an odd tale?"
¿No le parece una historia interesante?
"Just tell me this," said I, "and since you know so much, you surely can tell it me--what of Mr. Rochester?
-Puesto que conoce tales detalles -contesté-, podrá decirme uno más.
How and where is he?
¿Qué es de Mr.
Rochester?
What is he doing?
¿Qué hace?
Is he well?"
¿Está bien?
"I am ignorant of all concerning Mr. Rochester: the letter never mentions him but to narrate the fraudulent and illegal attempt I have adverted to.
-Ignoro cuanto se refiere a ese caballero, ya que la carta no le menciona más que para citar el ilegal propósito que le he referido.
You should rather ask the name of the governess--the nature of the event which requires her appearance."
Más vale que pregunte usted el nombre de la institutriz y el motivo que requiere su aparición.
"Did no one go to Thornfield Hall, then?
-Pero ¿no han ido a Thornfield Hall?
Did no one see Mr. Rochester?"
¿No han visto a Mr.
Rochester?
"I suppose not."
-Creo que no.
"But they wrote to him?"
-¿Y entonces...?
"Of course."
"And what did he say?
Who has his letters?"
-Mr.
"Mr. Briggs intimates that the answer to his application was not from Mr. Rochester, but from a lady: it is signed 'Alice Fairfax.'"
Briggs dice que la contestación a su carta dirigida a Thornfield no la envió Mr.
Rochester, sino una señora llamada Alice Fairfax.
Me sentí desmayar.
I felt cold and dismayed: my worst fears then were probably true: he had in all probability left England and rushed in reckless desperation to some former haunt on the Continent.
Mis peores temores se habían confirmado.
Seguramente él había abandonado Inglaterra y erraba a la sazón por el continente.
And what opiate for his severe sufferings--what object for his strong passions--had he sought there?
¿Y qué bálsamo buscaría para sus sufrimientos, qué objeto encontraría en que desahogar sus pasiones?
I dared not answer the question.
No me atreví a darme la respuesta.
Oh, my poor master--once almost my husband--whom I had often called "my dear Edward!"
¡Pobre amado mío, aquél a quien casi llegara a estar unida, aquél a quien llamara una vez «mi querido Edward»!
"He must have been a bad man," observed Mr. Rivers.
-Ese Rochester debe de ser un mal hombre -comentó Rivers.
"You don't know him--don't pronounce an opinion upon him," I said, with warmth.
-No le conoce usted.
No puede juzgarle -contesté con calor.
"Very well," he answered quietly: "and indeed my head is otherwise occupied than with him: I have my tale to finish.
-Bien -repuso serenamente-.
Tengo otras cosas en qué pensar antes que en él...
Since you won't ask the governess's name, I must tell it of my own accord.
Debo concluir mi historia.
Stay!
I have it here--it is always more satisfactory to see important points written down, fairly committed to black and white."
Y, puesto que no me pregunta el nombre de la institutriz, yo lo diré, y no de palabra, porque siempre son mejores las cosas por escrito.

And the pocket-book was again deliberately produced, opened, sought through; from one of its compartments was extracted a shabby slip of paper, hastily torn off: I recognised in its texture and its stains of ultra-marine, and lake, and vermillion, the ravished margin of the portrait-cover.

Volvió a sacar la cartera y de una de sus divisiones extrajo una delgada tira de papel, en la que reconocí, por sus manchas de azul ultramar, ocre y bermellón, el borde de la hoja que Rivers cortara en mi casa el día antes.
He got up, held it close to my eyes: and I read, traced in Indian ink, in my own handwriting, the words "JANE EYRE"--the work doubtless of some moment of abstraction.
Y en él, escrito en tinta china, de mi puño y letra, se leía Jane Eyre, mi propio nombre, que yo había escrito allí en un momento de distracción, sin duda.

"Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre:" he said, "the advertisements demanded a Jane Eyre: I knew a Jane Elliott.--I confess I had my suspicions, but it was only yesterday afternoon they were at once resolved into certainty.
-Briggs me habla de una Jane Eyre -siguió Rivers-, anuncios hablan de una Jane Eyre y yo conozco a una Jane Elliott.
Confieso que tenía algunas sospechas, pero sólo ayer tuve la certidumbre.
You own the name and renounce the _alias_?"
¿Qué?
¿Renuncia usted a ese nombre supuesto?
"Yes--yes; but where is Mr. Briggs?
-Sí, sí, pero ¿dónde está Briggs?
He perhaps knows more of Mr. Rochester than you do."
Él sabrá de Rochester más cosas que usted.
"Briggs is in London.
I should doubt his knowing anything at all about Mr. Rochester; it is not in Mr. Rochester he is interested.
-Briggs está en Londres y dudo que sepa nada de Rochester, porque no es en él quien está interesado.
Meantime, you forget essential points in pursuing trifles: you do not inquire why Mr. Briggs sought after you--what he wanted with you."
Y veo que olvida usted los motivos que Briggs tiene en hallarla...
"Well, what did he want?"
-¿Qué quiere de mí?
"Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property, and that you are now rich--merely that--nothing more."
-Sólo advertirla que su tío Eyre, que vivía en Madera, ha muerto, que ha legado a usted todos sus bienes y... ya nada más.
-¿Sus bienes?
"I!--rich?"
¿A mí?
¿Conque soy rica?
"Yes, you, rich--quite an heiress."
-Sí.
Silence succeeded.
-Siguió un silencio.
"You must prove your identity of course," resumed St. John presently: "a step which will offer no difficulties; you can then enter on immediate possession.
-Ahora es preciso que pruebe usted su identidad -concluyó John Rivers-.
Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and the necessary documents."
Los bienes están invertidos en títulos públicos de Inglaterra.
Briggs tiene el testamento y la documentación necesaria.
Here was a new card turned up!
He aquí que mi suerte experimentaba un nuevo cambio.
It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted in a moment from indigence to wealth--a very fine thing; but not a matter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once.
Es una agradable cosa, lector, pasar en un momento de la indigencia a la opulencia, pero, sin embargo, al recibir la noticia, no hay por qué saltar, gritar y enloquecer de alegría.

And then there are other chances in life far more thrilling and rapture-giving: _this_ is solid, an affair of the actual world, nothing ideal about it: all its associations are solid and sober, and its manifestations are the same.
La riqueza es un hecho concreto, práctico, desprovisto de aspectos ideales y, por tanto, la alegría que se experimenta alcanzándola debe ser del mismo género.

One does not jump, and spring, and shout hurrah! at hearing one has got a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to ponder business; on a base of steady satisfaction rise certain grave cares, and we contain ourselves, and brood over our bliss with a solemn brow.
Besides, the words Legacy, Bequest, go side by side with the words, Death, Funeral.
Además, las expresiones herencia y testamento están íntimamente ligadas a las de funeral y muerte.
My uncle I had heard was dead--my only relative; ever since being made aware of his existence, I had cherished the hope of one day seeing him: now, I never should.
Mi tío había muerto y yo que, desde que conocí su existencia, había acariciado la esperanza de verle algún día, debía renunciar a ello.
And then this money came only to me: not to me and a rejoicing family, but to my isolated self.
Luego aquel dinero era sólo para mí, no para una familia venturosa y alegre.
It was a grand boon doubtless; and independence would be glorious--yes, I felt that--that thought swelled my heart.
En fin: de todos modos era una gran suerte, yo podía alcanzar mi independencia, y este pensamiento me ensanchó el corazón.
"You unbend your forehead at last," said Mr. Rivers.
"I thought Medusa had looked at you, and that you were turning to stone.
-Parece que se ha convertido usted en piedra -dijo Rivers-.
Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth?"
Vamos, ¿no pregunta cuánto hereda?
"How much am I worth?"
-Bien: ¿cuánto heredo?
"Oh, a trifle!
-¡Una bagatela!
Nothing of course to speak of--twenty thousand pounds, I think they say--but what is that?"
No merece la pena hablar de ello...
Veinte mil libras.
"Twenty thousand pounds?"
-¿Veinte mil libras?
Here was a new stunner--I had been calculating on four or five thousand.
Quedé atónita.
Había contado con cuatro o cinco mil.
This news actually took my breath for a moment: Mr. St. John, whom I had never heard laugh before, laughed now.
Se me cortó la respiración.
Rivers, a quien nunca viera reír, no pudo reprimir la risa esta vez.
"Well," said he, "if you had committed a murder, and I had told you your crime was discovered, you could scarcely look more aghast."
-Si hubiese cometido usted un crimen y la dijese que había sido descubierta, no quedaría más petrificada...
"It is a large sum--don't you think there is a mistake?"
-¡Es mucho!
¿No será un error?
"No mistake at all."
"Perhaps you have read the figures wrong--it may be two thousand!"
¿No serán dos mil y por equivocación en las cifras...?
"It is written in letters, not figures,--twenty thousand."
-Nada de cifras.
Está escrito en letras.
Son veinte mil.
I again felt rather like an individual of but average gastronomical powers sitting down to feast alone at a table spread with provisions for a hundred.
Sentí la impresión que podría experimentar un gastrónomo solo ante una mesa servida para un centenar.
Mr. Rivers rose now and put his cloak on.
Rivers se levantó y se puso el gabán.
"If it were not such a very wild night," he said, "I would send Hannah down to keep you company: you look too desperately miserable to be left alone.
-Si no hiciera tan mala noche -dijo- le enviaría a Hannah a acompañarla, porque parece usted sentirse hoy desgraciadísima...
But Hannah, poor woman! could not stride the drifts so well as I: her legs are not quite so long: so I must e'en leave you to your sorrows.
Pero la pobre Hannah no puede saltar los hoyos llenos de nieve tan bien como yo.
Así que tengo que abandonarla a su pena.
Good-night."
Buenas noches.
He was lifting the latch: a sudden thought occurred to me.
Un súbito pensamiento acudió a mi mente.
"Stop one minute!"
I cried.
-Espere un momento -rogué.
"Well?"
-¿Qué?
"It puzzles me to know why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me; or how he knew you, or could fancy that you, living in such an out-of-the-way place, had the power to aid in my discovery."
-Me asombra que Briggs escribiese a usted sobre esto.
¿Cómo le conoce ni cómo podía figurarse que usted, en un lugar tan apartado, podría cooperar a encontrarme?
"Oh!
I am a clergyman," he said; "and the clergy are often appealed to about odd matters."
-Soy sacerdote -dijo-, y con frecuencia se apela a los sacerdotes en los más raros asuntos.
Again the latch rattled.
Y empuñó el picaporte.
"No; that does not satisfy me!"
-No me convence -repuse.
I exclaimed: and indeed there was something in the hasty and unexplanatory reply which, instead of allaying, piqued my curiosity more than ever.
Había, en efecto, en su ambigua contestación algo que excitaba mi curiosidad en grado sumo.
"It is a very strange piece of business," I added; "I must know more about it."
Añadí-: Es algo tan extraño, que deseo que me lo aclare.
"Another time."
-Otro día. -No.
"No; to-night!--to-night!" and as he turned from the door, I placed myself between it and him.
¡Hoy, hoy!
Y me interpuse entre él y la puerta.
He looked rather embarrassed.
Pareció turbarse.
"You certainly shall not go till you have told me all," I said.
-No se irá hasta que me lo diga -aseguré.
"I would rather not just now."
"You shall!--you must!"
"I would rather Diana or Mary informed you."
-Preferiría que la informaran Mary o Diana.
Of course these objections wrought my eagerness to a climax: gratified it must be, and that without delay; and I told him so.
Tales objeciones no hacían más que estimular mi curiosidad.
Era preciso satisfacerla, y se lo dije:
"But I apprised you that I was a hard man," said he, "difficult to persuade."
-Ya le he manifestado que soy un hombre duro, impersuadible -objetó.
"And I am a hard woman,--impossible to put off."
-Y yo una mujer durísima.
"And then," he pursued, "I am cold: no fervour infects me."
-Y frío... -siguió diciendo.
"Whereas I am hot, and fire dissolves ice.
-El fuego deshace el hielo -alegué-, y yo soy ardiente.
The blaze there has thawed all the snow from your cloak; by the same token, it has streamed on to my floor, and made it like a trampled street.
La prueba está en que la nieve que cubría su abrigo se ha fundido al calor, convirtiendo mi cocina en un lago.
As you hope ever to be forgiven, Mr. Rivers, the high crime and misdemeanour of spoiling a sanded kitchen, tell me what I wish to know."
Y, si quiere usted que le perdone el horrible crimen de inundar mi cocina, es preciso que me diga lo que deseo.
"Well, then," he said, "I yield; if not to your earnestness, to your perseverance: as stone is worn by continual dropping.
-Me rindo -dijo-, no a su ardor, sino a su perseverancia, capaz de agujerear la roca, como una gota de agua.
Besides, you must know some day,--as well now as later.
Aparte de eso, más pronto o más tarde había de saberlo...
Your name is Jane Eyre?"
¿Usted se llama Jane Eyre?
"Of course: that was all settled before."
-Desde luego.
"You are not, perhaps, aware that I am your namesake?--that I was christened St. John Eyre Rivers?"
-En ese caso...
¿No sabe usted que mi nombre es John Eyre Rivers?
"No, indeed!
-¡No lo sabía!
I remember now seeing the letter E. comprised in your initials written in books you have at different times lent me; but I never asked for what name it stood.
Recuerdo ahora haber visto su nombre, con la E en abreviatura, escrito en los libros que me ha dejado algunas veces, pero nunca se me ocurrió pensar que...
But what then?
Surely--"
Pero entonces...
I stopped: I could not trust myself to entertain, much less to express, the thought that rushed upon me--that embodied itself,--that, in a second, stood out a strong, solid probability.

Circumstances knit themselves, fitted themselves, shot into order: the chain that had been lying hitherto a formless lump of links was drawn out straight,--every ring was perfect, the connection complete.
Me interrumpí.
No acertaba a expresar el pensamiento que se me ocurría y que, sin embargo, representaba una evidente probabilidad, ya que formaba el resultado lógico de una cadena de circunstancias concurrentes.
I knew, by instinct, how the matter stood, before St. John had said another word; but I cannot expect the reader to have the same intuitive perception, so I must repeat his explanation.
Por si el lector no acierta, reproduciré las explicaciones de Rivers:
"My mother's name was Eyre; she had two brothers; one a clergyman, who married Miss Jane Reed, of Gateshead; the other, John Eyre, Esq., merchant, late of Funchal, Madeira.
-Mi madre se apellidaba Eyre y tenía dos hermanos: uno, sacerdote, casó con Jane Reed, de Gateshead; el otro, John Eyre, era comerciante en Funchal, en Madera.

Mr. Briggs, being Mr. Eyre's solicitor, wrote to us last August to inform us of our uncle's death, and to say that he had left his property to his brother the clergyman's orphan daughter, overlooking us, in consequence of a quarrel, never forgiven, between him and my father.

Briggs, abogado de Eyre, nos escribió en agosto informándonos de la muerte de nuestro tío y de que había dejado sus bienes a la huérfana de su hermano el sacerdote, prescindiendo de nosotros, como consecuencia de su ruptura con mi padre.
He wrote again a few weeks since, to intimate that the heiress was lost, and asking if we knew anything of her.
Nos escribió semanas después anunciando que la heredera había desaparecido y preguntándome si sabía algo de ella.
A name casually written on a slip of paper has enabled me to find her out.
Un nombre escrito por casualidad al borde de un papel me ha permitido encontrarla.
You know the rest."
Lo demás es inútil que lo diga, porque ya lo sabe usted.
Again he was going, but I set my back against the door.
Y trató de salir, pero yo me apoyé contra la puerta.
"Do let me speak," I said; "let me have one moment to draw breath and reflect."
-Antes de hablarle -dije- déjeme reflexionar un momento
I paused--he stood before me, hat in hand, looking composed enough.
-y tras una pausa agregué-:
I resumed--
"Your mother was my father's sister?"
Su madre era hermana de mi padre, ¿no?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"My aunt, consequently?"
-¿Y, por tanto, tía mía?
He bowed.
Asintió.
"My uncle John was your uncle John?
You, Diana, and Mary are his sister's children, as I am his brother's child?"
-Mi tío John era tío de usted, y usted, Diana y Mary, hijos de su hermana, como yo hija de su hermano.
"Undeniably."
-Innegablemente.
"You three, then, are my cousins; half our blood on each side flows from the same source?"
-¿De modo que los tres son mis primos?
"We are cousins; yes."
-Lo somos, en efecto.
I surveyed him.
Le miré.

It seemed I had found a brother: one I could be proud of,--one I could love; and two sisters, whose qualities were such, that, when I knew them but as mere strangers, they had inspired me with genuine affection and admiration.
Parecíame haber hallado un hermano -y un hermano del que me sentía orgullosa-, y dos hermanas cuyas cualidades, aun considerándolas extrañas a mí, habían despertado mi admiración y mi afecto.

The two girls, on whom, kneeling down on the wet ground, and looking through the low, latticed window of Moor House kitchen, I had gazed with so bitter a mixture of interest and despair, were my near kinswomen; and the young and stately gentleman who had found me almost dying at his threshold was my blood relation.
Glorious discovery to a lonely wretch!
Aquellas dos jóvenes que, desesperada, contemplara una noche de lluvia a través de la enrejada ventanita de la cocina de Moor House eran mis parientes, como lo era aquel joven que se hallaba ante mí.
¡Oh, qué delicioso descubrimiento para quien sufría el dolor de su soledad!
This was wealth indeed!--wealth to the heart!--a mine of pure, genial affections.
This was a blessing, bright, vivid, and exhilarating;--not like the ponderous gift of gold: rich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight.
¡Ésta sí que era riqueza, auténtica riqueza, riqueza del corazón, susceptible de producir la alegría y el entusiasmo, al contrario de la riqueza metálica!
I now clapped my hands in sudden joy--my pulse bounded, my veins thrilled.
Junté las manos, en un impulso de alegría.
Mi pulso latía aceleradamente.
"Oh, I am glad!--I am glad!"
I exclaimed.
-¡Qué contenta estoy! -exclamé.
St. John smiled.
John sonrió.
"Did I not say you neglected essential points to pursue trifles?" he asked.
-¿No le decía que descuidaba usted lo esencial?
"You were serious when I told you you had got a fortune; and now, for a matter of no moment, you are excited."
Se puso seria cuando le dije que poseía una fortuna y ahora se emociona por una cosa de tan poca importancia.
"What can you mean?
-¿De poca importancia?
It may be of no moment to you; you have sisters and don't care for a cousin; but I had nobody; and now three relations,--or two, if you don't choose to be counted,--are born into my world full-grown.

Quizá para usted que, teniendo dos hermanas, no necesita una prima, pero no para mí, que me encuentro de improviso con tres parientes... o al menos con dos, si usted no quiere contarse en el número...
I say again, I am glad!"
¡Qué contenta estoy, sí!

I walked fast through the room: I stopped, half suffocated with the thoughts that rose faster than I could receive, comprehend, settle them:--thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere long.
Comencé a pasear a través de la habitación y luego me detuve, medio sofocada por los pensamientos que invadían mi mente.
I looked at the blank wall: it seemed a sky thick with ascending stars,--every one lit me to a purpose or delight.
Yo podía corresponder a los beneficios de los que salvaron mi vida.
Those who had saved my life, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly, I could now benefit.
Eran dependientes: yo podía independizarles; estaban separados: podía reunirlos.
They were under a yoke,--I could free them: they were scattered,--I could reunite them: the independence, the affluence which was mine, might be theirs too.
Lo que era mío, debía ser de ellos también.
Were we not four?
Puesto que éramos cuatro, las veinte mil libras debían ser repartidas.
Twenty thousand pounds shared equally would be five thousand each, justice--enough and to spare: justice would be done,--mutual happiness secured.
Con cinco mil cada uno, todos teníamos la vida de sobra asegurada, todos seríamos felices y se cumpliría un acto de justicia.
Now the wealth did not weigh on me: now it was not a mere bequest of coin,--it was a legacy of life, hope, enjoyment.
Ahora la riqueza no era ya un peso para mí.
Implicaba, al contrario, vida, felicidad, esperanza...
How I looked while these ideas were taking my spirit by storm, I cannot tell; but I perceived soon that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind me, and was gently attempting to make me sit down on it.
No sé cómo miraría a Rivers mientras pensaba en estas cosas; sólo sé que me ofreció una silla y me aconsejó que me serenase.
He also advised me to be composed; I scorned the insinuation of helplessness and distraction, shook off his hand, and began to walk about again.
"Write to Diana and Mary to-morrow," I said, "and tell them to come home directly.
-Escriba mañana a Diana y a Mary y dígales que vuelvan a casa.
Diana said they would both consider themselves rich with a thousand pounds, so with five thousand they will do very well."
Si se consideraban ricas con mil libras, hay que creer que con cinco mil cada una se considerarán dichosas -exclamé.
"Tell me where I can get you a glass of water," said St. John; "you must really make an effort to tranquillise your feelings."
-Dígame dónde puedo encontrar un vaso de agua para usted, porque necesita calmarse -repuso John.
"Nonsense! and what sort of an effect will the bequest have on you?
-¡Nada de eso!
Y dígame: ¿qué hará usted?
Will it keep you in England, induce you to marry Miss Oliver, and settle down like an ordinary mortal?"
¿Se quedará en Inglaterra, pedirá la mano de Rosamond y hará una vida corriente, como...?
"You wander: your head becomes confused.
-Desvaría usted.
I have been too abrupt in communicating the news; it has excited you beyond your strength."
Le he comunicado las noticias tan bruscamente, que no me extraña...
-Me hace perder la paciencia.
"Mr. Rivers! you quite put me out of patience: I am rational enough; it is you who misunderstand, or rather who affect to misunderstand."
Estoy en mi plena razón.
Es usted quien no entiende o no quiere entender.
"Perhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I should comprehend better."
-Quizá la comprendiese si se explicara mejor.
"Explain!
What is there to explain?
-¿Qué falta hacen explicaciones?
You cannot fail to see that twenty thousand pounds, the sum in question, divided equally between the nephew and three nieces of our uncle, will give five thousand to each?
Puesto que son veinte mil libras, deben dividirse a partes iguales entre los cuatro sobrinos de nuestro tío.
What I want is, that you should write to your sisters and tell them of the fortune that has accrued to them."
Escriba a Mary y a Diana diciéndoles la fortuna que han heredado...
"To you, you mean."
-Que ha heredado usted.
"I have intimated my view of the case: I am incapable of taking any other.
-Ya le he dicho lo que pienso y no cambiaré.
I am not brutally selfish, blindly unjust, or fiendishly ungrateful.
No soy una egoísta ni una desagradecida.
Besides, I am resolved I will have a home and connections.
Además, quiero tener una casa y una familia.
I like Moor House, and I will live at Moor House; I like Diana and Mary, and I will attach myself for life to Diana and Mary.
Me gusta Moor House y viviré en Moor House, y quiero a Diana y a Mary y viviré con ellas.
Poseer cinco mil libras me agrada y me conviene.
It would please and benefit me to have five thousand pounds; it would torment and oppress me to have twenty thousand; which, moreover, could never be mine in justice, though it might in law.
Poseer veinte mil, me abrumaría.
Y no serían mías en justicia, aunque lo fueran según la ley.
I abandon to you, then, what is absolutely superfluous to me.
Les cedo lo que es superfluo para mí.
Let there be no opposition, and no discussion about it; let us agree amongst each other, and decide the point at once."
No rehúse ni me lo discuta.
Póngase de acuerdo conmigo sobre ello ahora mismo.
"This is acting on first impulses; you must take days to consider such a matter, ere your word can be regarded as valid."
-Habla usted siguiendo el primer impulso.
Tómese días para pensarlo, antes de comprometer su palabra.
"Oh! if all you doubt is my sincerity, I am easy: you see the justice of the case?"
-Aunque dude de mi sinceridad, ¿no comprende que lo que digo es justo?
"I _do_ see a certain justice; but it is contrary to all custom.
-Es justo hasta cierto punto, pero no es lo que se acostumbra a hacer.
Besides, the entire fortune is your right: my uncle gained it by his own efforts; he was free to leave it to whom he would: he left it to you.
Tiene usted derecho a toda la fortuna.
Mi tío la ganó con su trabajo y podía legarla a quien quisiera.
After all, justice permits you to keep it: you may, with a clear conscience, consider it absolutely your own."
Puede usted, en conciencia, quedarse con todo.
"With me," said I, "it is fully as much a matter of feeling as of conscience: I must indulge my feelings; I so seldom have had an opportunity of doing so.
-Para mí -dije- el sentimiento es tan importante como la conciencia.
Y ya que puedo pocas veces seguir mis sentimientos, deseo seguirlos ahora que se me ofrece la oportunidad.

Were you to argue, object, and annoy me for a year, I could not forego the delicious pleasure of which I have caught a glimpse--that of repaying, in part, a mighty obligation, and winning to myself lifelong friends."
Cuanto pudiera usted argumentar, aunque me hablase un año seguido, no destruirá el placer que me proporciona el pagar una deuda moral y conseguir amigos para toda mi vida.

"You think so now," rejoined St. John, "because you do not know what it is to possess, nor consequently to enjoy wealth: you cannot form a notion of the importance twenty thousand pounds would give you; of the place it would enable you to take in society; of the prospects it would open to you: you cannot--"
-Habla usted así -objetó John- porque no sabe lo que es la riqueza ni los goces que proporciona.
No comprende bien lo que son veinte mil libras, el puesto que le darán en sociedad, las perspectivas que...
"And you," I interrupted, "cannot at all imagine the craving I have for fraternal and sisterly love.
-Y usted -interrumpí- no comprende bien lo que es conseguir un cariño fraternal.
I never had a home, I never had brothers or sisters; I must and will have them now: you are not reluctant to admit me and own me, are you?"
Yo no he tenido casa nunca, nunca hermanos ni hermanas.
Quiero tenerlos ahora ¿Me rechaza?
"Jane, I will be your brother--my sisters will be your sisters--without stipulating for this sacrifice of your just rights."
-Jane: yo seré su hermano y Diana y Mary sus hermanas sin necesidad de sacrificio pecuniario alguno.
"Brother?
-¿Hermanos?
Yes; at the distance of a thousand leagues!
Sisters?
¿A mil leguas de distancia de mí?
Yes; slaving amongst strangers!
I, wealthy--gorged with gold I never earned and do not merit!
¿Y hermanas esclavas en casas ajenas?
You, penniless!
Famous equality and fraternisation!
¿Yo rica, con una riqueza que no he ganado ni merecido, y ustedes pobres?
Close union!
Intimate attachment!"
¡Vaya una fraternidad y vaya una unión!
"But, Jane, your aspirations after family ties and domestic happiness may be realised otherwise than by the means you contemplate: you may marry."
-Sus deseos de tener una familia pueden realizarse cuando se case.
"Nonsense, again!
-¡Tontería!
Marry!
I don't want to marry, and never shall marry."
No quiero casarme y no me casaré nunca.
"That is saying too much: such hazardous affirmations are a proof of the excitement under which you labour."
-Eso es mucho decir, y sólo prueba lo muy excitada que está.
"It is not saying too much: I know what I feel, and how averse are my inclinations to the bare thought of marriage.
-No es mucho decir.
Sé lo que siento y lo poco inclinada que me encuentro al matrimonio.
No one would take me for love; and I will not be regarded in the light of a mere money speculation.
Nadie se enamorará de mí, y si alguien se casara conmigo sería por mi dinero.
And I do not want a stranger--unsympathising, alien, different from me; I want my kindred: those with whom I have full fellow- feeling.
Y no deseo a mi lado un ser ajeno a mi alma.
Quiero convivir con aquellos que comparten mis sentimientos.
Say again you will be my brother: when you uttered the words I was satisfied, happy; repeat them, if you can, repeat them sincerely."
Dígame otra vez que es mi hermano; dígalo, si puede, con sinceridad y me sentiré feliz.
"I think I can.
-Puedo.
I know I have always loved my own sisters; and I know on what my affection for them is grounded,--respect for their worth and admiration of their talents.
Sé que si he querido a mis hermanas ha sido porque estimo sus virtudes y admiro sus méritos.

You too have principle and mind: your tastes and habits resemble Diana's and Mary's; your presence is always agreeable to me; in your conversation I have already for some time found a salutary solace.
Usted es inteligente y virtuosa, tiene los mismos gustos que Diana y Mary, su presencia y su conversación me son agradables.
I feel I can easily and naturally make room in my heart for you, as my third and youngest sister."
Creo que puedo reservar un sitio para usted en mi corazón, como una hermana mía.
"Thank you: that contents me for to-night.
-Gracias.
Eso me basta por hoy.
Now you had better go; for if you stay longer, you will perhaps irritate me afresh by some mistrustful scruple."
Y ahora vale más que se vaya, John, porque si se queda tal vez me haga enfadar otra vez con sus escrúpulos.
"And the school, Miss Eyre?
¿Y la escuela, Jane?
It must now be shut up, I suppose?"
¿Habrá que cerrarla?
"No.
I will retain my post of mistress till you get a substitute."
-Seguiré en el cargo hasta que se encuentre una sustituta.
He smiled approbation: we shook hands, and he took leave.
Sonrió, aprobatorio.
Nos estrechamos la mano y se fue.
I need not narrate in detail the further struggles I had, and arguments I used, to get matters regarding the legacy settled as I wished.
No es preciso detallar los ulteriores esfuerzos y argumentos que empleé para convencer a mis primos.

My task was a very hard one; but, as I was absolutely resolved--as my cousins saw at length that my mind was really and immutably fixed on making a just division of the property--as they must in their own hearts have felt the equity of the intention; and must, besides, have been innately conscious that in my place they would have done precisely what I wished to do--they yielded at length so far as to consent to put the affair to arbitration.
Mi tarea fue difícil, pero como estaba absolutamente resuelta a imponer mi voluntad y ellos comprendieron la sinceridad con que lo hacía, acordaron finalmente someter el asunto a arbitraje.
The judges chosen were Mr. Oliver and an able lawyer: both coincided in my opinion: I carried my point.
Los árbitros fueron Mr.
Oliver y un inteligente abogado, que coincidieron con mi opinión.
The instruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and I, each became possessed of a competency.
Los documentos transmisorios fueron legalizados, y John, Diana y Mary entraron en posesión de sus partes respectivas.
CHAPTER XXXIV
XXXIV
It was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of general holiday approached.
Todo quedó arreglado poco antes de las fiestas de Navidad.
I now closed Morton school, taking care that the parting should not be barren on my side.
Abandoné la escuela después de procurar que me sustituyera alguien que no hiciese estériles mis esfuerzos en pro de las alumnas.
Good fortune opens the hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we have largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual ebullition of the sensations.
I had long felt with pleasure that many of my rustic scholars liked me, and when we parted, that consciousness was confirmed: they manifested their affection plainly and strongly.
La mayoría de ellas, según parecía, me apreciaban, y mi partida lo puso de manifiesto.

Deep was my gratification to find I had really a place in their unsophisticated hearts: I promised them that never a week should pass in future that I did not visit them, and give them an hour's teaching in their school.

Me sentí profundamente emocionada por el lugar que me habían concedido en sus inocentes corazones y les prometí que, en el porvenir, las visitaría todas las semanas y daría una hora de clase en la escuela.

Mr. Rivers came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty girls, file out before me, and locked the door, I stood with the key in my hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some half-dozen of my best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and well-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British peasantry.

And that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British peasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of any in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and Bauerinnen; and the best of them seemed to me ignorant, coarse, and besotted, compared with my Morton girls.

John Rivers llegó cuando yo, después de haberme despedido de las sesenta muchachas alineadas ante mí, cambiaba nuevos adioses con las mejores de mis discípulas: media docena de muchachas recatadas, modestas e instruidas como no se encontrarían fácilmente en el resto de Inglaterra ni en toda Europa.
"Do you consider you have got your reward for a season of exertion?" asked Mr. Rivers, when they were gone.
"Does not the consciousness of having done some real good in your day and generation give pleasure?"
-¿No sientes -dijo John cuando todas hubieron salido- la satisfacción de haber hecho con esas muchachas algo en beneficio de tus semejantes?
"Doubtless."
-Sin duda.
"And you have only toiled a few months!
Would not a life devoted to the task of regenerating your race be well spent?"
-Pues si eso ha sido así en pocos meses, ¿no crees que la tarea de dedicar toda la vida a la regeneración humana es hermosa?
"Yes," I said; "but I could not go on for ever so: I want to enjoy my own faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people.
-Sí -dije-, pero yo no puedo dedicarme sólo al bien de los demás.
I must enjoy them now; don't recall either my mind or body to the school; I am out of it and disposed for full holiday."
Deseo gozar de mi propia vida también.
He looked grave.
"What now?
What sudden eagerness is this you evince?
What are you going to do?"
-¿Y qué vas a hacer ahora? -me preguntó gravemente.
"To be active: as active as I can.
-Trabajar en lo que está a mi alcance.
And first I must beg you to set Hannah at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on you."
Deseo que busques a alguien que sustituya a Hannah para que ésta me acompañe.
"Do you want her?"
-¿A dónde?
"Yes, to go with me to Moor House.
-A Moor House.
Diana and Mary will be at home in a week, and I want to have everything in order against their arrival."
Diana y Mary llegarán de aquí a una semana y quiero tenerlo todo arreglado para cuando vengan.
"I understand.
-Comprendo.
I thought you were for flying off on some excursion.
Creí que pensabas hacer algún viaje.
It is better so: Hannah shall go with you."
Sí, vale más que vaya Hannah contigo.
"Tell her to be ready by to-morrow then; and here is the schoolroom key: I will give you the key of my cottage in the morning."
-Bien; pues dile que esté lista para mañana.
Toma la llave de la escuela.
He took it.
La de casa mañana te la daré.

"You give it up very gleefully," said he; "I don't quite understand your light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what employment you propose to yourself as a substitute for the one you are relinquishing.
-Quisiera saber -me dijo, mientras tomaba la llave- qué ocupación vas a realizar en lugar de la que dejas.
What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have you now?"
¿Qué proyectos, qué ambiciones tienes ahora?

"My first aim will be to _clean down_ (do you comprehend the full force of the expression?)--to _clean down_ Moor House from chamber to cellar; my next to rub it up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of cloths, till it glitters again; my third, to arrange every chair, table, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision; afterwards I shall go near to ruin you in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room; and lastly, the two days preceding that on which your sisters are expected will be devoted by Hannah and me to such a beating of eggs, sorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christmas cakes, chopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other culinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the uninitiated like you.

-Primero, limpiar Moor House de arriba abajo; segundo, encerarla y pulirla cuanto pueda; tercero, colocar todas las mesas, sillas y demás muebles con un orden y precisión matemáticos; cuarto, arruinarme comprando carbón y leña para que en cada cuarto haya un fuego excelente; quinto, dedicar a Hannah, dos días antes de que lleguen Diana y Mary, a batir tantos huevos, amasar tantas empanadas y preparar tantos bollos de Pascua, que no hay palabras en el diccionario para darle idea de la solemnidad de los ritos culinarios a que me entregaré.

My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an absolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next Thursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome when they come."
En resumen: mi ambición consiste en que todo esté listo el próximo jueves para otorgar a mis primas una acogida que constituya el ideal de las acogidas familiares.
St. John smiled slightly: still he was dissatisfied.
John sonrió.
No parecía del todo satisfecho.
"It is all very well for the present," said he; "but seriously, I trust that when the first flush of vivacity is over, you will look a little higher than domestic endearments and household joys."
-Eso está muy bien por el momento -dijo-, pero hablando seriamente, creo que después mirarás un poco más alto y no te limitarás a ocuparte de esas cuestiones domésticas.
"The best things the world has!"
-¡Son lo más agradable del mundo! -repuse.
I interrupted.
-No, Jane:
"No, Jane, no: this world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt to make it so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful."
este mundo no es lugar de placeres, ni hay por qué intentar convertirlo en tal; como no hay tampoco que entregarse a la molicie.
"I mean, on the contrary, to be busy."
-Al contrario; voy a entregarme a la actividad.

"Jane, I excuse you for the present: two months' grace I allow you for the full enjoyment of your new position, and for pleasing yourself with this late-found charm of relationship; but _then_, I hope you will begin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and the selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence.
-Por ahora está bien, Jane.
Admito que están bien dos meses para gozar el encanto de tu nueva situación y del cariño de tus nuevos parientes.
I hope your energies will then once more trouble you with their strength."
Pero después supongo que Moor House y Morton, y la compañía de mis hermanas, y la calma egoísta y la comodidad no te parecerán suficientes.
I looked at him with surprise.
Le miré con sorpresa.
"St. John," I said, "I think you are almost wicked to talk so.
-John -dije-: ¿cómo puedes hablar así?
I am disposed to be as content as a queen, and you try to stir me up to restlessness!
Me sentiré tan satisfecha como una reina.
To what end?"
¿En qué cosa mejor puedo pensar?
"To the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to your keeping; and of which He will surely one day demand a strict account.
-En aprovechar la inteligencia que Dios te ha concedido y de que, si no la ejercitas como debes, te pedirá algún día estrecha cuenta.
Jane, I shall watch you closely and anxiously--I warn you of that.
Te observo con mucho interés, Jane,
And try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which you throw yourself into commonplace home pleasures.
y extraño el desmesurado interés que pones en los placeres vulgares del hogar.
Don't cling so tenaciously to ties of the flesh; save your constancy and ardour for an adequate cause; forbear to waste them on trite transient objects.
No te aferres tan tenazmente a las debilidades materiales.
Reserva tu constancia y tu vehemencia para empresas más elevadas...
Do you hear, Jane?"
¿Entiendes, Jane?
"Yes; just as if you were speaking Greek.
-Tanto como si me hablaras en griego.
I feel I have adequate cause to be happy, and I _will_ be happy.
Para mí ser feliz es una empresa bastante elevada.
Y lo seré.
Goodbye!"
¡Adiós!

Happy at Moor House I was, and hard I worked; and so did Hannah: she was charmed to see how jovial I could be amidst the bustle of a house turned topsy-turvy--how I could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook.

Y lo fui, en efecto, en Moor House, y trabajé de firme, con asombro de Hannah, admirada de la jovialidad con que me desenvolvía en el ajetreo de aquellos arreglos, de la energía con que pulía, limpiaba y cocinaba.
And really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was delightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had made.
Era delicioso, un par de días después, ver cómo iba resurgiendo el orden del caos que nosotras mismas habíamos producido.

I had previously taken a journey to S--- to purchase some new furniture: my cousins having given me _carte blanche_ to effect what alterations I pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that purpose.
Hice antes un viaje a S... para comprar algunos muebles, fin al que habíamos asignado algún dinero y para lo que mis primas me habían dado carta blanca.

The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms I left much as they were: for I knew Diana and Mary would derive more pleasure from seeing again the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the spectacle of the smartest innovations.
Still some novelty was necessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it to be invested.

La salita y los dormitorios fueron dejados como estaban, porque comprendí que a Diana y a Mary les placería hallarse en su ambiente acostumbrado, pero en cambio, una alcoba libre y un salón que no se usaba fueron decorados con bellos cortinajes y alfombras nuevas, con adornos de bronce cuidadosamente elegidos.

Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement of some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze, new coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables, answered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring.
En las demás alcobas instalé tocadores y espejos nuevos.
Los muebles comprados eran de caoba y las alfombras y cortinas de color carmesí oscuro.
A spare parlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and crimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the stairs.
When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model of bright modest snugness within, as it was, at this season, a specimen of wintry waste and desert dreariness without.
Todo terminado, juzgué que Moor House era el modelo perfecto de una casa modesta bien acomodada por dentro, como era el tipo de la desolación invernal por fuera en aquella época del año.
The eventful Thursday at length came.
Llegó, al fin, el anhelado jueves.
They were expected about dark, and ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in perfect trim; Hannah and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.
Esperábamos a las jóvenes al oscurecer.
Las chimeneas estaban encendidas, la cocina preparada.
Hannah y yo vestidas, y todo a punto.
St. John arrived first.
John fue el primero en llegar.

I had entreated him to keep quite clear of the house till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the commotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within its walls sufficed to scare him to estrangement.
Yo había procurado que no acudiese durante los preparativos, para no darle una impresión desagradable con el espectáculo de la casa revuelta.
He found me in the kitchen, watching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking.
Me encontró en la cocina vigilando la operación de amasar pastas para el té.
Approaching the hearth, he asked, "If I was at last satisfied with housemaid's work?"
I answered by inviting him to accompany me on a general inspection of the result of my labours.
Me preguntó si estaba satisfecha de mis tareas domésticas y le contesté invitándole a inspeccionar el resultado de mis tareas.
With some difficulty, I got him to make the tour of the house.
No sin dificultad, le convencí de que me acompañase.

He just looked in at the doors I opened; and when he had wandered upstairs and downstairs, he said I must have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have effected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a syllable did he utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of his abode.

Luego que hubimos recorrido toda la casa y subido y bajado escaleras, comentó que debía haberme tomado mucha molestia para llevar a la práctica aquellos cambios en tan poco tiempo, pero no añadió ni una sílaba que indicase que le placía el nuevo aspecto de la residencia.
This silence damped me.
I thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed some old associations he valued.
Me disgustó aquel silencio, pensando que acaso le hubiera contrariado que se alterase el aspecto de la casa paterna.
I inquired whether this was the case: no doubt in a somewhat crest-fallen tone.
Le pregunté si era así.
"Not at all; he had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously respected every association: he feared, indeed, I must have bestowed more thought on the matter than it was worth.
-Nada de eso.
Ya he observado el cuidado que has tenido en respetar cuanto pudiese significar un recuerdo.
How many minutes, for instance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very room?--By-the-bye, could I tell him where such a book was?"
¿Cuántos minutos has dedicado a pensar en el arreglo de esa habitación?
Y ¿puedes decirme dónde está colocado...?
Me mencionó el título de un libro.
I showed him the volume on the shelf: he took it down, and withdrawing to his accustomed window recess, he began to read it.
Se lo mostré, lo cogió y, retirándose a su acostumbrado rincón, junto a la ventana, comenzó a leer.
Now, I did not like this, reader.
Aquello me desagradó.
St. John was a good man; but I began to feel he had spoken truth of himself when he said he was hard and cold.
John, lector, era un hombre bueno, pero yo comenzaba a pensar que había dicho la verdad cuando él mismo afirmara que era frío y duro.
The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for him--its peaceful enjoyments no charm.
La vida no presentaba atractivos para él.
Literally, he lived only to aspire--after what was good and great, certainly; but still he would never rest, nor approve of others resting round him.
No vivía más que para sus elevadas aspiraciones, y además desaprobaba que no se compartiesen.
