I went out and approached him as he stood leaning over the little gate; I spoke to the point at once.
Me acerqué a él, que estaba junto a la verja, y le hablé:
"St. John, I am unhappy because you are still angry with me.
-John: siento mucho que estés disgustado conmigo todavía.
Let us be friends."
Quedemos amigos.
"I hope we are friends," was the unmoved reply; while he still watched the rising of the moon, which he had been contemplating as I approached.
-Creo que lo somos -repuso, con frialdad.
Y siguió contemplando la luna, que se alzaba en el horizonte, como lo hiciera hasta aquel momento.
"No, St. John, we are not friends as we were.
-No, John, no lo somos como debíamos.
Ya lo sabes.
You know that."
-¿No lo somos?
"Are we not?
¡Qué raro!
That is wrong.
For my part, I wish you no ill and all good."
Por mi parte, deseo tu bien y no tu mal.

"I believe you, St. John; for I am sure you are incapable of wishing any one ill; but, as I am your kinswoman, I should desire somewhat more of affection than that sort of general philanthropy you extend to mere strangers."
-Lo creo, porque no te considero capaz de desear mal a nadie, pero quisiera para mí una amistad más honda que esa afección general que haces extensiva a todos.
"Of course," he said.
"Your wish is reasonable, and I am far from regarding you as a stranger."
-Tu deseo es razonable -repuso- y disto mucho de considérate como una extraña.
This, spoken in a cool, tranquil tone, was mortifying and baffling enough.
Lo dijo con tan helado tono, que me sentí mortificada.
Had I attended to the suggestions of pride and ire, I should immediately have left him; but something worked within me more strongly than those feelings could.
A seguir los impulsos de mi orgullo y mi cólera, me hubiese separado de él inmediatamente, pero algo en mi interior me lo impidió.
I deeply venerated my cousin's talent and principle.
Yo admiraba los principios y la inteligencia de mi primo.
His friendship was of value to me: to lose it tried me severely.
Me disgustaba perder su amistad, que apreciaba en mucho.
I would not so soon relinquish the attempt to reconquer it.
No debía, pues, abandonar tan pronto el propósito de recobrarla.
"Must we part in this way, St. John?
-¿Vamos a separarnos así, John?
And when you go to India, will you leave me so, without a kinder word than you have yet spoken?"
¿Te separarías de mí, cuando vayas a la India, sin una palabra más amable que la de ahora?
He now turned quite from the moon and faced me.
"When I go to India, Jane, will I leave you!
-¿Separarnos cuando vaya a la India?
What! do you not go to India?"
¿No vas a acompañarme?
"You said I could not unless I married you."
-Tú mismo has dicho que no, a menos que nos casemos.
"And you will not marry me!
You adhere to that resolution?"
-¿Y persistes en no casarte conmigo?
Reader, do you know, as I do, what terror those cold people can put into the ice of their questions?
¿Has notado, lector, la impresión de horror que producen las heladas preguntas de las personas de carácter frío?
How much of the fall of the avalanche is in their anger? of the breaking up of the frozen sea in their displeasure?
Hay en ellas algo análogo al desprendimiento de un alud, a la rotura de un mar helado.
"No.
St. John, I will not marry you.
-No, John, no me casaré contigo.
I adhere to my resolution."
Persisto en mi resolución.
The avalanche had shaken and slid a little forward, but it did not yet crash down.
"Once more, why this refusal?" he asked.
-Vuelvo a preguntarte, no puedo evitarlo, que por qué rehúsas -dijo.
"Formerly," I answered, "because you did not love me; now, I reply, because you almost hate me.
-Antes -repuse- te dije que porque no me amabas; ahora añado que porque me odias.
If I were to marry you, you would kill me.
Si me casara contigo, me matarías.
You are killing me now."
Ya me estás matando ahora.
His lips and cheeks turned white--quite white.
Sus labios y sus mejillas se pusieron blancos como la cera.
"_I should kill you_--_I am killing you_?
-¿Que te mataría y te estoy matando?
Your words are such as ought not to be used: violent, unfeminine, and untrue.
Tus palabras son injustas y violentas, delatan un lamentable estado de ánimo, merecen severa censura y son inexcusables.
They betray an unfortunate state of mind: they merit severe reproof: they would seem inexcusable, but that it is the duty of man to forgive his fellow even until seventy-and-seven times."
Pero el hombre debe perdonar a su prójimo hasta setenta veces siete.
I had finished the business now.
Todo había terminado.
While earnestly wishing to erase from his mind the trace of my former offence, I had stamped on that tenacious surface another and far deeper impression, I had burnt it in.
Al tratar de borrar en aquel obstinado espíritu las huellas de la ofensa anterior, no había conseguido más que grabarlas a fuego.
"Now you will indeed hate me," I said.
-Desde ahora me odiarás -dije-.
"It is useless to attempt to conciliate you: I see I have made an eternal enemy of you."
Todo intento de reconciliación es inútil.
Ya veo que me consideras una enemiga mortal.
A fresh wrong did these words inflict: the worse, because they touched on the truth.
Aquello fue aún peor, porque era verdad.
That bloodless lip quivered to a temporary spasm.
I knew the steely ire I had whetted.
I was heart-wrung.
Vi contraerse sus labios y comprendí que había estimulado todavía más su ira.
"You utterly misinterpret my words," I said, at once seizing his hand: "I have no intention to grieve or pain you--indeed, I have not."
-Interpretas mal mis palabras -me apresuré a agregar, cogiéndole la mano-.
No he querido ofenderte.
Most bitterly he smiled--most decidedly he withdrew his hand from mine.
Sonrió con amargura y retiró su mano de la mía.
"And now you recall your promise, and will not go to India at all, I presume?" said he, after a considerable pause.
Tras una larga pausa, preguntó: -¿De modo que retiras tu promesa y no me acompañas a la India?
"Yes, I will, as your assistant," I answered.
-Sí, si lo deseas, como tu colaboradora -repuse.
A very long silence succeeded.
Siguió un prolongado silencio.
What struggle there was in him between Nature and Grace in this interval, I cannot tell: only singular gleams scintillated in his eyes, and strange shadows passed over his face.
No sé lo que pasaba en el alma de John.
Singulares luces se encendían en sus ojos y extrañas sombras oscurecían su semblante.
He spoke at last.
"I before proved to you the absurdity of a single woman of your age proposing to accompany abroad a single man of mine.
-Ya te he demostrado lo absurdo de que una mujer de tu edad acompañe a un hombre de la mía.
I proved it to you in such terms as, I should have thought, would have prevented your ever again alluding to the plan.
Te lo probé de tal forma, que no creí que volvieras a aludir a ello.
That you have done so, I regret--for your sake."
Lamento por ti lo que haces.
I interrupted him.
Le interrumpí.
Anything like a tangible reproach gave me courage at once.
El reproche que apreciaba en su voz me daba ánimos.
"Keep to common sense, St. John: you are verging on nonsense.
-No digas tonterías, John.
You pretend to be shocked by what I have said.
You are not really shocked: for, with your superior mind, you cannot be either so dull or so conceited as to misunderstand my meaning.
Pareces mostrarte asombrado de lo que te he dicho y en realidad no lo estás.
No es posible que tu inteligencia no comprenda lo que quiero decirte.
I say again, I will be your curate, if you like, but never your wife."
Estoy dispuesta a ser tu auxiliar, pero no tu mujer.
Again he turned lividly pale; but, as before, controlled his passion perfectly.
He answered emphatically but calmly--
Volvió a palidecer, pero como antes, supo contenerse y respondió con énfasis:
"A female curate, who is not my wife, would never suit me.
-Un auxiliar de tu sexo, no siendo mi mujer, no me acompañará nunca.
With me, then, it seems, you cannot go: but if you are sincere in your offer, I will, while in town, speak to a married missionary, whose wife needs a coadjutor.
Conmigo, pues, no puedes ir.
Pero si quieres, hablaré a un misionero casado cuya mujer necesita una ayudante.
Your own fortune will make you independent of the Society's aid; and thus you may still be spared the dishonour of breaking your promise and deserting the band you engaged to join."
Gracias a tus bienes puedes ser independiente de la sociedad, y así evitarás la deshonra de faltar a tu promesa y desertar de la bandera en que te has alistado.
Now I never had, as the reader knows, either given any formal promise or entered into any engagement; and this language was all much too hard and much too despotic for the occasion.
Como sabe el lector, yo no había dado promesa alguna en firme ni alistándome bajo ninguna bandera.
Tal lenguaje, en tal ocasión, me pareció harto violento y despótico.
I replied--
Repliqué:
"There is no dishonour, no breach of promise, no desertion in the case.
-No hay deshonra alguna, ni falta a promesa de ningún género, ni deserción de ninguna clase.
I am not under the slightest obligation to go to India, especially with strangers.
No tengo obligación de ir a la India, y menos con personas extrañas.
With you I would have ventured much, because I admire, confide in, and, as a sister, I love you; but I am convinced that, go when and with whom I would, I should not live long in that climate."
Podría haberme aventurado contigo a hacerlo, porque te admiro, confío en ti y te quiero como un hermano.
Además, estoy segura de que, fuese con quien fuera, no viviría mucho en aquel clima.
"Ah! you are afraid of yourself," he said, curling his lip.
-¡Ah, temes por tu vida! -dijo apretando los labios.
"I am.
-Sí.
God did not give me my life to throw away; and to do as you wish me would, I begin to think, be almost equivalent to committing suicide.
Dios no me la dio para suicidarme y sospecho que si hiciera lo que deseas, casi equivaldría -a un suicidio.
Y, finalmente, antes de irme de Inglaterra quisiera estar segura de que soy más útil en otro lugar que aquí.
Moreover, before I definitively resolve on quitting England, I will know for certain whether I cannot be of greater use by remaining in it than by leaving it."
Es inútil entrar en explicaciones, pero hay un extremo que me ha hecho sufrir lo bastante para que desee cerciorarme de lo que existe-respecto a él antes de partir de Inglaterra.
"What do you mean?"
"It would be fruitless to attempt to explain; but there is a point on which I have long endured painful doubt, and I can go nowhere till by some means that doubt is removed."
"I know where your heart turns and to what it clings.
-Sé a lo que te refieres.
The interest you cherish is lawless and unconsecrated.
Te interesas por una cosa ilegal y reprobable.
Long since you ought to have crushed it: now you should blush to allude to it.
Hace tiempo que debías haberla olvidado.
You think of Mr. Rochester?"
¿Te refieres a Rochester?
It was true.
I confessed it by silence.
Mi silencio confirmó su suposición.
"Are you going to seek Mr. Rochester?"
"I must find out what is become of him."
-Necesito saber lo que ha sido de él.
"It remains for me, then," he said, "to remember you in my prayers, and to entreat God for you, in all earnestness, that you may not indeed become a castaway.
-Entonces -dijo- sólo me queda rogar a Dios por ti para que no te apartes del sendero de la virtud.
I had thought I recognised in you one of the chosen.
Creí haber hallado en ti a una de las elegidas.
But God sees not as man sees: _His_ will be done--"
Pero Dios ve más lejos que nosotros, mortales.
Hágase su voluntad.
He opened the gate, passed through it, and strayed away down the glen.
He was soon out of sight.
Abrió la verja, salió, se dirigió hacia el valle y se perdió de vista.
On re-entering the parlour, I found Diana standing at the window, looking very thoughtful.
Al entrar en el salón hallé a Diana mirando por la ventana, muy pensativa.
Diana was a great deal taller than I: she put her hand on my shoulder, and, stooping, examined my face.
Puso la mano en mi hombro -era mucho más alta que yo- y examinó mi semblante.
"Jane," she said, "you are always agitated and pale now.
-Jane -dijo-: estás pálida y agitada.
I am sure there is something the matter.
Estoy segura de que pasa algo.
Tell me what business St. John and you have on hands.
Dime lo que tenéis entre manos John y tú.
I have watched you this half hour from the window; you must forgive my being such a spy, but for a long time I have fancied I hardly know what.
He pasado media hora mirándoos por la ventana.
Perdona, pero hace tiempo que imagino no sé qué...
St. John is a strange being--" She paused--I did not speak: soon she resumed--
¡John es tan raro!
Se detuvo y como yo no dijera nada, continuó:
"That brother of mine cherishes peculiar views of some sort respecting you, I am sure: he has long distinguished you by a notice and interest he never showed to any one else--to what end?
-Mi hermano debe de tener proyectos especiales respecto a ti, estoy segura.
Te ha concedido una atención que nunca concede a nadie.
¿Qué es?
I wish he loved you--does he, Jane?"
Si estuviera enamorado de ti, me alegraría.
¿Es eso, Jane?
I put her cool hand to my hot forehead; "No, Die, not one whit."
-No es eso, Diana -repuse, poniendo su fresca mano sobre mi frente ardorosa.
"Then why does he follow you so with his eyes, and get you so frequently alone with him, and keep you so continually at his side?
-Entonces, ¿por qué se pasa la vida mirándote y paseando a solas contigo?
Mary and I had both concluded he wished you to marry him."
Mary y yo suponíamos que iba a proponerte...
"He does--he has asked me to be his wife."
-En efecto; me ha pedido que fuera su mujer.
Diana clapped her hands.
"That is just what we hoped and thought!
-¡Lo que suponía! -exclamó Diana, juntando las manos-.
And you will marry him, Jane, won't you?
¿Te casarás con él, Jane?
And then he will stay in England."
¡Así se quedará en Inglaterra!
"Far from that, Diana; his sole idea in proposing to me is to procure a fitting fellow-labourer in his Indian toils."
-No, Diana.
Casándose conmigo, lo haría para llevar a la India una colaboradora eficaz.
"What!
-¡Cómo!
He wishes you to go to India?"
¿Pretende que le acompañes a la India?
"Yes."
-Sí.
"Madness!" she exclaimed.
-¡Está loco!
"You would not live three months there, I am certain.
No vivirías allí ni tres meses.
No lo hagas.
You never shall go: you have not consented, have you, Jane?"
No consientas.
¿Qué le has dicho, Jane?
"I have refused to marry him--"
-Me he negado a casarme con él.
"And have consequently displeased him?" she suggested.
-¿Se ha disgustado?
"Deeply: he will never forgive me, I fear: yet I offered to accompany him as his sister."
-Sí; no me lo perdonará nunca, aunque le he ofrecido acompañarle como pudiera hacerlo una hermana.
"It was frantic folly to do so, Jane.
-Sería una locura.
Think of the task you undertook--one of incessant fatigue, where fatigue kills even the strong, and you are weak.
La tarea es fatigosa y tú débil.
John pide imposibles, y no dejaría de exigírtelos allí.

St. John--you know him--would urge you to impossibilities: with him there would be no permission to rest during the hot hours; and unfortunately, I have noticed, whatever he exacts, you force yourself to perform.
Desgraciadamente, según he notado, eres incapaz de negarte a nada que él te pida.
I am astonished you found courage to refuse his hand.
Me maravilla que hayas tenido valor para rehusar.
You do not love him then, Jane?"
¿No le quieres, Jane?
"Not as a husband."
-Para marido, no.
"Yet he is a handsome fellow."
-Es un buen mozo, sin embargo.
"And I am so plain, you see, Die.
-Y yo soy fea, ya lo ves.
We should never suit."
No haríamos buena pareja.
"Plain!
-¿Fea?
You?
¡Al contrario!
Not at all.
You are much too pretty, as well as too good, to be grilled alive in Calcutta."
Eres muy bonita, demasiado para encerrarte en Calculta.
And again she earnestly conjured me to give up all thoughts of going out with her brother.
E insistió en que desechase todo pensamiento de acompañar a su hermano.
"I must indeed," I said; "for when just now I repeated the offer of serving him for a deacon, he expressed himself shocked at my want of decency.
-Así será -dije-, porque cuando le he expresado mi deseo de servirle de auxiliar ha manifestado su disgusto por lo que considera una falta de decoro.
He seemed to think I had committed an impropriety in proposing to accompany him unmarried: as if I had not from the first hoped to find in him a brother, and habitually regarded him as such."
Cree que le propongo una cosa incorrecta ofreciéndome a seguirle sin casarnos.
¡Como si yo no le hubiese considerado siempre como un hermano!
"What makes you say he does not love you, Jane?"
-¿Por qué dices que no te quiere?
"You should hear himself on the subject.
-Me gustaría que él mismo te lo explicara.
He has again and again explained that it is not himself, but his office he wishes to mate.
Asegura que no desea una compañera para su satisfacción, sino para el servicios de la obra a que se consagra.
He has told me I am formed for labour--not for love: which is true, no doubt.
Afirma que yo estoy hecha para la labor y no para el amor, lo que sin duda es verdad.
But, in my opinion, if I am not formed for love, it follows that I am not formed for marriage.
Pero en mi opinión, si no estoy hecha para el amor, no lo estoy tampoco para el matrimonio.
Would it not be strange, Die, to be chained for life to a man who regarded one but as a useful tool?"
¿No sería una extravagancia, Diana, encadenarse de por vida a un hombre que sólo la considera a una como un instrumento útil?
"Insupportable--unnatural--out of the question!"
-Sería insoportable, absurdo, fuera de lugar.

"And then," I continued, "though I have only sisterly affection for him now, yet, if forced to be his wife, I can imagine the possibility of conceiving an inevitable, strange, torturing kind of love for him, because he is so talented; and there is often a certain heroic grandeur in his look, manner, and conversation.

-No obstante -continué-, si me casara con él admito la posibilidad de amarle de un modo especial y torturador, porque es' inteligente y a veces en su aspecto, maneras y palabras hay cierta grandeza heroica.
In that case, my lot would become unspeakably wretched.
Y en tal caso, yo sería indeciblemente desdichada.
He would not want me to love him; and if I showed the feeling, he would make me sensible that it was a superfluity, unrequired by him, unbecoming in me.
No desea que le ame y si le demostrara algún sentimiento, me diría que era una cosa superflua, innecesaria para él e inoportuna en mí.
I know he would."
Me consta.
"And yet St. John is a good man," said Diana.
-¡Y el caso es que John es bueno! -dijo Diana.
"He is a good and a great man; but he forgets, pitilessly, the feelings and claims of little people, in pursuing his own large views.
-Bueno y elevado, pero indiferente a los derechos y los sentimientos de las gentes pequeñas cuando se trata de alcanzar sus vastas miras.
It is better, therefore, for the insignificant to keep out of his way, lest, in his progress, he should trample them down.
Pero los insignificantes, es mejor no mezclarnos en su camino...
Here he comes!
Mira: ahí viene.
I will leave you, Diana."
Te dejo, Diana.
And I hastened upstairs as I saw him entering the garden.
Y subí las escaleras mientras él entraba en el jardín.
But I was forced to meet him again at supper.
Hube de verle durante la cena.
During that meal he appeared just as composed as usual.
Él se mostró tan sereno como de costumbre.
I had thought he would hardly speak to me, and I was certain he had given up the pursuit of his matrimonial scheme: the sequel showed I was mistaken on both points.
Yo temía que me hablase con aspereza o que insistiera en sus proyectos.
Me equivoqué en ambas suposiciones.
He addressed me precisely in his ordinary manner, or what had, of late, been his ordinary manner--one scrupulously polite.
Me habló con la cortesía de costumbre.
No doubt he had invoked the help of the Holy Spirit to subdue the anger I had roused in him, and now believed he had forgiven me once more.
Sin duda había invocado la ayuda divina para dominar el disgusto que yo le causara y me había perdonado una vez más.
For the evening reading before prayers, he selected the twenty-first chapter of Revelation.
Al leer las plegarias de la noche, eligió el capítulo veintiuno de la Revelación.

It was at all times pleasant to listen while from his lips fell the words of the Bible: never did his fine voice sound at once so sweet and full--never did his manner become so impressive in its noble simplicity, as when he delivered the oracles of God:
Era muy agradable escucharle.

Jamás su voz resultaba más armoniosa que cuando brotaban de sus labios las frases de la Biblia, jamás sus modales eran tan impresionantes en su noble simplicidad como cuando hacía escuchar los oráculos de Dios.

and to-night that voice took a more solemn tone--that manner a more thrilling meaning--as he sat in the midst of his household circle (the May moon shining in through the uncurtained window, and rendering almost unnecessary the light of the candle on the table): as he sat there, bending over the great old Bible, and described from its page the vision of the new heaven and the new earth--told how God would come to dwell with men, how He would wipe away all tears from their eyes, and promised that there should be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, nor any more pain, because the former things were passed away.

Nunca su voz sonó más solemne que aquella noche en que, en el salón de su casa, mientras la luz de una clara luna de mayo penetraba a través de los visillos de la ventana, él, inclinado sobre la vieja Biblia, leía las promesas de Dios a los hombres, ofreciendo enjugar todas sus lágrimas, evitarles para siempre la muerte, el mal y el dolor.
The succeeding words thrilled me strangely as he spoke them: especially as I felt, by the slight, indescribable alteration in sound, that in uttering them, his eye had turned on me.
Las palabras siguientes me impresionaron, tanto por su contenido como por la casi imperceptible alteración de la voz de John y porque observé que, al leer, sus ojos se volvían hacia mí:
"He that overcometh shall inherit all things; and I will be his God, and he shall be my son.
«...y el incrédulo irá al lago de fuego y azufre, que es la segunda muerte...».
But," was slowly, distinctly read, "the fearful, the unbelieving, &c., shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone, which is the second death."
Henceforward, I knew what fate St. John feared for me.
Comprendí que tal era la suerte futura que John me suponía reservada.
A calm, subdued triumph, blent with a longing earnestness, marked his enunciation of the last glorious verses of that chapter.

The reader believed his name was already written in the Lamb's book of life, and he yearned after the hour which should admit him to the city to which the kings of the earth bring their glory and honour; which has no need of sun or moon to shine in it, because the glory of God lightens it, and the Lamb is the light thereof.
In the prayer following the chapter, all his energy gathered--all his stern zeal woke: he was in deep earnest, wrestling with God, and resolved on a conquest.

He supplicated strength for the weak-hearted; guidance for wanderers from the fold: a return, even at the eleventh hour, for those whom the temptations of the world and the flesh were luring from the narrow path.
He asked, he urged, he claimed the boon of a brand snatched from the burning.
Earnestness is ever deeply solemn: first, as I listened to that prayer, I wondered at his; then, when it continued and rose, I was touched by it, and at last awed.
He felt the greatness and goodness of his purpose so sincerely: others who heard him plead for it, could not but feel it too.
The prayer over, we took leave of him: he was to go at a very early hour in the morning.
Terminada la plegaria, nos despedimos de él, que debía partir muy temprano de mañana.
Diana and Mary having kissed him, left the room--in compliance, I think, with a whispered hint from him: I tendered my hand, and wished him a pleasant journey.
Diana y Mary, una vez que le hubieron besado, salieron del aposento.
Yo le tendí la mano y le deseé un feliz viaje.
"Thank you, Jane.
-Gracias, Jane -repuso-.
As I said, I shall return from Cambridge in a fortnight: that space, then, is yet left you for reflection.
Volveré de Cambridge dentro de quince días.
Te doy ese tiempo para que reflexiones.
If I listened to human pride, I should say no more to you of marriage with me; but I listen to my duty, and keep steadily in view my first aim--to do all things to the glory of God.
Si atendiese la voz del orgullo humano, no insistiría en que te casaras conmigo, pero sólo oigo la de mi deber, que me manda hacer todas las cosas para gloria de Dios.
My Master was long-suffering: so will I be.
Mi Maestro soportó mucho; también yo lo soportaré.
I cannot give you up to perdition as a vessel of wrath: repent--resolve, while there is yet time.
Quiero darte, mientras pueda ser, una última posibilidad de salvación.
Remember, we are bid to work while it is day--warned that 'the night cometh when no man shall work.'
Te ofrezco la posibilidad de elegir entre lo mejor y lo peor.
Remember the fate of Dives, who had his good things in this life.
God give you strength to choose that better part which shall not be taken from you!"
He laid his hand on my head as he uttered the last words.
Y mientras hablaba, puso la mano sobre mi cabeza.

He had spoken earnestly, mildly: his look was not, indeed, that of a lover beholding his mistress, but it was that of a pastor recalling his wandering sheep--or better, of a guardian angel watching the soul for which he is responsible.
No ofrecía, ciertamente, el aspecto de un enamorado acariciando a su amada, sino de un pastor guiando a una oveja descarriada o de un ángel de la guarda custodiando el alma que está a su cargo.
All men of talent, whether they be men of feeling or not; whether they be zealots, or aspirants, or despots--provided only they be sincere--have their sublime moments, when they subdue and rule.
Todo hombre de talento, posea sentimientos o no, sea déspota, ambicioso o lo que fuere, siempre que lo sea con sinceridad, tiene momentos sublimes.
I felt veneration for St. John--veneration so strong that its impetus thrust me at once to the point I had so long shunned.
I was tempted to cease struggling with him--to rush down the torrent of his will into the gulf of his existence, and there lose my own.
Experimenté admiración hacia John y por un momento me sentí tentada a dejar de resistirle, a dejarme arrastrar por el torrente de su voluntad hacia la corriente de su existencia y mezclarme con ella.
I was almost as hard beset by him now as I had been once before, in a different way, by another.
Estaba procediendo con él casi tan duramente como, en distinto sentido, procediera antes con otro.
I was a fool both times.
Ambas veces obraba neciamente.
To have yielded then would have been an error of principle; to have yielded now would have been an error of judgment.
Antes había cometido un error de principios y ahora cometía un error de apreciación.
So I think at this hour, when I look back to the crisis through the quiet medium of time: I was unconscious of folly at the instant.
Así pensaba yo en aquel momento, pero ahora, pasado el tiempo, reconozco que cuando obré como una necia fue en aquel momento precisamente.
I stood motionless under my hierophant's touch.
Permanecí inmóvil bajo su contacto.
My refusals were forgotten--my fears overcome--my wrestlings paralysed.
Olvidé mis negativas, mis temores.
The Impossible--_i.e._, my marriage with St. John--was fast becoming the Possible.
Lo imposible -mi casamiento con John- comenzó a parecerme posible.
All was changing utterly with a sudden sweep.
Todo había cambiado de pronto:

Religion called--Angels beckoned--God commanded--life rolled together like a scroll--death's gates opening, showed eternity beyond: it seemed, that for safety and bliss there, all here might be sacrificed in a second.
la religión me llamaba, los ángeles me conducían, Dios me daba una orden.
Ante mí parecía disiparse la vida, abrirse las puertas de la muerte y mostrarme más allá la eternidad.
The dim room was full of visions.
¡E iba a sacrificarlo todo, en el corto tiempo de un segundo, a la felicidad terrenal!
El cuarto me parecía lleno de extrañas visiones.
"Could you decide now?" asked the missionary.
-¿Te decides ahora? -preguntó, con gentileza, atrayéndome suavemente hacia sí.
The inquiry was put in gentle tones: he drew me to him as gently.
¡Oh, qué fuerza había en su amabilidad!
Oh, that gentleness! how far more potent is it than force!
Yo podría resistir a John airado, pero amable era irresistible para mí.
I could resist St. John's wrath: I grew pliant as a reed under his kindness.
Yet I knew all the time, if I yielded now, I should not the less be made to repent, some day, of my former rebellion.
His nature was not changed by one hour of solemn prayer: it was only elevated.
"I could decide if I were but certain," I answered: "were I but convinced that it is God's will I should marry you, I could vow to marry you here and now--come afterwards what would!"
-Me decidiría -repuse- si estuviera segura de que es voluntad divina que me case contigo.
Entonces lo haría ahora mismo, pasara después lo que pasase.
"My prayers are heard!" ejaculated St. John.
-¡Mis oraciones han sido escuchadas! -exclamó John.

He pressed his hand firmer on my head, as if he claimed me: he surrounded me with his arm, _almost_ as if he loved me (I say _almost_--I knew the difference--for I had felt what it was to be loved; but, like him, I had now put love out of the question, and thought only of duty).
I contended with my inward dimness of vision, before which clouds yet rolled.
Oprimió mi cabeza con su mano, como si me reclamase, y su brazo ciñó mi cintura, casi como si me amara.
Y digo casi, porque bien sabía yo, al hacerlo, no pensaba en el amor y sí sólo en el deber.
I sincerely, deeply, fervently longed to do what was right; and only that.
"Show me, show me the path!"
I entreated of Heaven.
En cuanto a mí, sentíame sinceramente inclinada a realizar lo que ya consideraba acertado, a seguir el camino que me condujera al cielo.
I was excited more than I had ever been; and whether what followed was the effect of excitement the reader shall judge.
Estaba más excitada que lo estuviera nunca.
El lector juzgará si lo que siguió fue o no efecto de mi excitación.
All the house was still; for I believe all, except St. John and myself, were now retired to rest.
La casa estaba en silencio, porque todos, menos John y yo, debían de haberse acostado.
The one candle was dying out: the room was full of moonlight.
La bujía se había extinguido y la luz de la luna inundaba la estancia.
My heart beat fast and thick: I heard its throb.
Yo oía los apresurados latidos de mi propio corazón.
Suddenly it stood still to an inexpressible feeling that thrilled it through, and passed at once to my head and extremities.
Súbitamente, experimenté una sensación extraña, que hizo temblar mi cuerpo de pies a cabeza.

The feeling was not like an electric shock, but it was quite as sharp, as strange, as startling: it acted on my senses as if their utmost activity hitherto had been but torpor, from which they were now summoned and forced to wake.
No fue precisamente como una descarga eléctrica, sino algo agudo, extraño, estimulante, que despertó mis sentidos cual si hasta entonces hubiesen permanecido aletargados.
They rose expectant: eye and ear waited while the flesh quivered on my bones.
Permanecí con ojos y oídos atentos, sintiendo un temblor que penetraba mi carne hasta la médula.
"What have you heard?
-¡Jane!
What do you see?" asked St. John.
¿Qué has visto, qué has oído? -preguntó John.
I saw nothing, but I heard a voice somewhere cry--
Yo no veía nada, pero percibí claramente una voz que murmuraba:
"Jane!
Jane!
-¡Jane, Jane, Jane!
Jane!"--nothing more.
No oí más.
"O God! what is it?"
-¡Oh, Dios mío!
I gasped.
¿Qué es esto? -balbucí.
I might have said, "Where is it?" for it did not seem in the room--nor in the house--nor in the garden; it did not come out of the air--nor from under the earth--nor from overhead.
En vez de qué, debía haber preguntado dónde, porque ciertamente no sonaba ni en el cuarto, ni encima de mí.
I had heard it--where, or whence, for ever impossible to know!
Y sin embargo era una voz, una voz inconfundible, una voz adorada, la voz de Edward Fairfax Rochester, hablando con una expresión de agonía y dolor infinitos, penetrantes, urgentes.
And it was the voice of a human being--a known, loved, well-remembered voice--that of Edward Fairfax Rochester; and it spoke in pain and woe, wildly, eerily, urgently.
"I am coming!"
I cried.
-¡Voy! -grité-.
"Wait for me!
¡Espérame!
Oh, I will come!"
¡Voy, voy!
I flew to the door and looked into the passage: it was dark.
Corría a la puerta y miré el pasillo: estaba en sombras.
I ran out into the garden: it was void.
Salí al jardín: estaba vacío.
"Where are you?"
I exclaimed.
-¿Dónde estás? -exclamé.
The hills beyond Marsh Glen sent the answer faintly back--"Where are you?"
Las montañas devolvieron el eco de mi pregunta y oí repetir: ¿Dónde estás?
I listened.
The wind sighed low in the firs: all was moorland loneliness and midnight hush.
El viento silbaba entre los pinos y todo era en torno soledad y silencio.
"Down superstition!"
I commented, as that spectre rose up black by the black yew at the gate.
«¡Silencio, superstición! -dije para mí-.
"This is not thy deception, nor thy witchcraft: it is the work of nature.
Aquí no hay engaño, no hay brujería, no hay milagro.
She was roused, and did--no miracle--but her best."
Es el instinto lo que obra en mí.»
I broke from St. John, who had followed, and would have detained me.
Me separé de John, que me había seguido y trataba de detenerme.
It was _my_ time to assume ascendency. _My_ powers were in play and in force.
Aquel era el momento de que yo reaccionara.
Mis facultades estaban en tensión.
I told him to forbear question or remark; I desired him to leave me: I must and would be alone.
Le prohibí que me preguntase nada y agregué que deseaba que me dejase sola.
He obeyed at once.
Obedeció.
Where there is energy to command well enough, obedience never fails.
Cuando se tiene energía para ordenar nunca se es desobedecido.
I mounted to my chamber; locked myself in; fell on my knees; and prayed in my way--a different way to St. John's, but effective in its own fashion.
Subí a mi alcoba, caí de rodillas y oré a mi modo, muy diferente del de mi primo, pero no por ello menos ferviente.
I seemed to penetrate very near a Mighty Spirit; and my soul rushed out in gratitude at His feet.
Me parecía que un poderoso espíritu me penetraba y, agradecida, me postré a sus pies.
I rose from the thanksgiving--took a resolve--and lay down, unscared, enlightened--eager but for the daylight.
Me incorporé, con una resolución adoptada, y me acosté, esperando el siguiente día.
CHAPTER XXXVI
XXXVI
The daylight came.
Llegó el día y me levanté.
I rose at dawn.
I busied myself for an hour or two with arranging my things in my chamber, drawers, and wardrobe, in the order wherein I should wish to leave them during a brief absence.
Empleé un par de horas en ordenar las cosas de mi cuarto tal como deseaba dejarlas durante la breve ausencia que iba a realizar.
Meantime, I heard St. John quit his room.
Sentí a John salir de su alcoba y pararse ante la mía.
He stopped at my door: I feared he would knock--no, but a slip of paper was passed under the door.
Temí que llamara, pero se limitó a deslizar un papel bajo la puerta.
I took it up.
It bore these words--
Lo cogí y leí estas palabras:
"You left me too suddenly last night.
Had you stayed but a little longer, you would have laid your hand on the Christian's cross and the angel's crown.
«Me dejaste ayer de repente, antes de haber tomado en definitiva la decisión de empuñar la cruz cristiana y ceñirte la corona de los ángeles.
I shall expect your clear decision when I return this day fortnight.
Espero tu determinación final cuando vuelva, dentro de quince días.
Meantime, watch and pray that you enter not into temptation: the spirit, I trust, is willing, but the flesh, I see, is weak.
Rogaré para que no caigas en la tentación.
Tu alma es fuerte, pero tu carne es débil.
I shall pray for you hourly.
Sí; no dejaré de rogar por ti.
--Yours, ST.
JOHN."
Tuyo, John. »
"My spirit," I answered mentally, "is willing to do what is right; and my flesh, I hope, is strong enough to accomplish the will of Heaven, when once that will is distinctly known to me.
«Mi alma -respondí mentalmente- es bastante fuerte para hacer lo que debo y confío en que mi carne lo sea bastante para cumplir la voluntad divina una vez que me parezca evidente.
At any rate, it shall be strong enough to search--inquire--to grope an outlet from this cloud of doubt, and find the open day of certainty."
Y confío, en fin, en que bastarán una y otra para disipar las nubes en que estoy envuelta y distinguir, al cabo, la luz del sol.»
It was the first of June; yet the morning was overcast and chilly: rain beat fast on my casement.
Estábamos a primeros de junio, pero la mañana era desapacible y fría.
La lluvia azotaba mi ventana.
I heard the front-door open, and St. John pass out.
Looking through the window, I saw him traverse the garden.
A través de los cristales vi a John atravesar el jardín.
He took the way over the misty moors in the direction of Whitcross--there he would meet the coach.
Se dirigió por los brumosos campos hacia Whitcross, donde tomaría la diligencia.
"In a few more hours I shall succeed you in that track, cousin," thought I: "I too have a coach to meet at Whitcross.
I too have some to see and ask after in England, before I depart for ever."
»Dentro de pocas horas seguiré por ese camino, primo -pensé-.
Como tú tomaré una diligencia y veré si me queda algo que hacer en Inglaterra antes de abandonarla para siempre.»
It wanted yet two hours of breakfast-time.
Faltaban dos horas para el desayuno.
I filled the interval in walking softly about my room, and pondering the visitation which had given my plans their present bent.
En el intervalo paseé por mi alcoba, recordando la sensación que experimentara la noche antes, la voz que oyera...
I recalled that inward sensation I had experienced: for I could recall it, with all its unspeakable strangeness.
I recalled the voice I had heard; again I questioned whence it came, as vainly as before: it seemed in _me_--not in the external world.
¿Dónde había sonado?
En mí, sin duda, no en lo que me rodeaba.
I asked was it a mere nervous impression--a delusion?
I could not conceive or believe: it was more like an inspiration.
¿Había sido una mera ilusión?

The wondrous shock of feeling had come like the earthquake which shook the foundations of Paul and Silas's prison; it had opened the doors of the soul's cell and loosed its bands--it had wakened it out of its sleep, whence it sprang trembling, listening, aghast; then vibrated thrice a cry on my startled ear, and in my quaking heart and through my spirit, which neither feared nor shook, but exulted as if in joy over the success of one effort it had been privileged to make, independent of the cumbrous body.
Sobrevino en mí como el terremoto que conmoviera los cimientos de la prisión de Pablo y Silas, abriendo las puertas de la celda en que yacía mi alma y despertándola de su letargo.
"Ere many days," I said, as I terminated my musings, "I will know something of him whose voice seemed last night to summon me.
Letters have proved of no avail--personal inquiry shall replace them."
«Puesto que por carta -medité, resumiendo mis pensamientos- no puedo saber nada de aquel cuya voz creí oír anoche, una gestión personal me permitirá averiguarlo.»
At breakfast I announced to Diana and Mary that I was going a journey, and should be absent at least four days.
Mientras desayunábamos, anuncié a Diana y Mary que iba a hacer un viaje y estaría ausente lo menos cuatro días.
"Alone, Jane?" they asked.
-¿Vas sola, Jane? -Sí.
"Yes; it was to see or hear news of a friend about whom I had for some time been uneasy."
Quiero tener noticias de un amigo de quien no sé nada hace tiempo.

They might have said, as I have no doubt they thought, that they had believed me to be without any friends save them: for, indeed, I had often said so; but, with their true natural delicacy, they abstained from comment, except that Diana asked me if I was sure I was well enough to travel.
I looked very pale, she observed.
Podían haberme preguntado qué amigo era, ya que yo solía afirmar que no tenía otros que ellas, pero con su innata delicadeza se abstuvieron de preguntarme nada.
Diana me preguntó si me encontraba en condiciones de viajar, ya que le parecía verme muy pálida.
I replied, that nothing ailed me save anxiety of mind, which I hoped soon to alleviate.
Contesté que nada tenía, sino inquietud, y que esperaba calmarla con aquel viaje.
It was easy to make my further arrangements; for I was troubled with no inquiries--no surmises.

Having once explained to them that I could not now be explicit about my plans, they kindly and wisely acquiesced in the silence with which I pursued them, according to me the privilege of free action I should under similar circumstances have accorded them.

Observando que no deseaba por el momento entrar en detalles sobre mis planes, guardaron un discreto y amable silencio, dejándome en la libertad de acción en que, en caso análogo, yo les hubiera dejado a ellas.
I left Moor House at three o'clock p.m., and soon after four I stood at the foot of the sign-post of Whitcross, waiting the arrival of the coach which was to take me to distant Thornfield.
Salí de Moor House a las tres de la tarde y hacia las cuatro me hallaba en Whitcross, esperando la diligencia que debía llevarme al distante Thornfield.
Amidst the silence of those solitary roads and desert hills, I heard it approach from a great distance.
En el silencio profundo de los caminos desiertos y las solitarias montañas, oí acercarse al coche cuando aún estaba muy lejos.
It was the same vehicle whence, a year ago, I had alighted one summer evening on this very spot--how desolate, and hopeless, and objectless!
It stopped as I beckoned.
Era el vehículo que, un año atrás, me dejara en aquel mismo lugar en plena desolación y desesperanza.
I entered--not now obliged to part with my whole fortune as the price of its accommodation.
Esta vez no tenía que entregar toda mi fortuna como precio del pasaje.
Once more on the road to Thornfield, I felt like the messenger-pigeon flying home.
Hice seña de que la diligencia parara, se detuvo y, una vez en marcha, me pareció ser la paloma mensajera que vuela del palomar.
It was a journey of six-and-thirty hours.
El viaje duró treinta y seis horas.

I had set out from Whitcross on a Tuesday afternoon, and early on the succeeding Thursday morning the coach stopped to water the horses at a wayside inn, situated in the midst of scenery whose green hedges and large fields and low pastoral hills (how mild of feature and verdant of hue compared with the stern North- Midland moors of Morton!) met my eye like the lineaments of a once familiar face.

Salí de Whitcross la tarde de un martes y en la mañana del jueves el coche se detuvo, para que bebiesen los caballos, ante una posada en medio de campos verdes e idílicas colinas que contrastaban con el áspero escenario de las montañas norteñas que acababa de abandonar.
Yes, I knew the character of this landscape: I was sure we were near my bourne.
Reconocí el aspecto de aquel paisaje, como si viese un rostro conocido.
"How far is Thornfield Hall from here?"
I asked of the ostler.
-¿Está Thornfield muy lejos de aquí? -pregunté al posadero.
"Just two miles, ma'am, across the fields."
-Dos millas a campo traviesa, señorita.
"My journey is closed," I thought to myself.
«El viaje ha concluido», pensé.

I got out of the coach, gave a box I had into the ostler's charge, to be kept till I called for it; paid my fare; satisfied the coachman, and was going: the brightening day gleamed on the sign of the inn, and I read in gilt letters, "The Rochester Arms."
Me apeé, dejé mi equipaje en la posada, anunciando que volvería a buscarlo, pagué el pasaje, gratifiqué al cochero y el carruaje partió.
El sol arrancaba destellos de la muestra de la posada, en cuyas doradas letras leí: A las armas de Rochester.
My heart leapt up: I was already on my master's very lands.
Mi corazón latió con premura.
Me hallaba ya en los dominios de mi amado.

It fell again: the thought struck it:-- "Your master himself may be beyond the British Channel, for aught you know: and then, if he is at Thornfield Hall, towards which you hasten, who besides him is there?
Luego un pensamiento amargo me invadió: «Acaso él hubiese cruzado el canal de la Mancha, acaso no estuviese en Thornfield, acaso valiera más pedir informes al posadero.»
His lunatic wife: and you have nothing to do with him: you dare not speak to him or seek his presence.
You have lost your labour--you had better go no farther," urged the monitor.
"Ask information of the people at the inn; they can give you all you seek: they can solve your doubts at once.
Go up to that man, and inquire if Mr. Rochester be at home."
The suggestion was sensible, and yet I could not force myself to act on it.
I so dreaded a reply that would crush me with despair.
To prolong doubt was to prolong hope.
Temía, sin embargo, alguna mala noticia y no me resolvía a preguntar, ya que prolongar la duda era prolongar la esperanza.
I might yet once more see the Hall under the ray of her star.

There was the stile before me--the very fields through which I had hurried, blind, deaf, distracted with a revengeful fury tracking and scourging me, on the morning I fled from Thornfield: ere I well knew what course I had resolved to take, I was in the midst of them.
Ante mí se extendían los campos que cruzara el día de mi fuga.
How fast I walked!
How I ran sometimes!
How I looked forward to catch the first view of the well-known woods!
With what feelings I welcomed single trees I knew, and familiar glimpses of meadow and hill between them!
Los recorrí de prisa, contemplando el familiar panorama, los bosques, los árboles, las praderas y las colinas.
Remonté, al fin, la ladera.
At last the woods rose; the rookery clustered dark; a loud cawing broke the morning stillness.
Sobre mi cabeza volaban las cornejas.
Un graznido quebró el silencio de la mañana.
Strange delight inspired me: on I hastened.
Another field crossed--a lane threaded--and there were the courtyard walls--the back offices: the house itself, the rookery still hid.
Crucé un prado, seguí un sendero y me hallé ante las tapias del patio.
Aún no podía distinguir la casa.

"My first view of it shall be in front," I determined, "where its bold battlements will strike the eye nobly at once, and where I can single out my master's very window: perhaps he will be standing at it--he rises early: perhaps he is now walking in the orchard, or on the pavement in front.
«Quiero verla por su fachada -pensé-, contemplar el espectáculo de sus almenares, la ventana de mi amado.
Acaso esté asomado a ella -¡madruga tanto!- o bien pasee ante la puerta o por el huerto.
Could I but see him!--but a moment!
¡Oh, deseo verle, un instante siquiera!
Surely, in that case, I should not be so mad as to run to him?
¿Seré tan loca que corra hacia él?
I cannot tell--I am not certain.
No puedo asegurarlo, no sé...
And if I did--what then?
¿Y si él -¡bendito sea!corre hacia mí?
God bless him!
¡Ah!
What then?
Who would be hurt by my once more tasting the life his glance can give me?
I rave: perhaps at this moment he is watching the sun rise over the Pyrenees, or on the tideless sea of the south."
¿Quién sabe si a estas horas está contemplando la salida del sol en los Pirineos o sobre los tranquilos mares del Mediodía...?»
I had coasted along the lower wall of the orchard--turned its angle: there was a gate just there, opening into the meadow, between two stone pillars crowned by stone balls.
Di la vuelta a la tapia del huerto.
Allí había un portillo que permitía entrar desde la pradera, entre dos pilares coronados por bolas de piedra.
From behind one pillar I could peep round quietly at the full front of the mansion.
Ocultándome tras uno de los pilares podía observar la casa sin ser vista.
I advanced my head with precaution, desirous to ascertain if any bedroom window-blinds were yet drawn up: battlements, windows, long front--all from this sheltered station were at my command.
Adelanté la cabeza con cautela, para comprobar si las ventanas de algún dormitorio estaban abiertas ya.
Todo - fachada, ventanas, almenas-, quedaba desde allí al alcance de mis ojos.
The crows sailing overhead perhaps watched me while I took this survey.
I wonder what they thought.
They must have considered I was very careful and timid at first, and that gradually I grew very bold and reckless.
Si las cornejas que volaban sobre mi cabeza me hubieran examinado, habríanme visto hacer mis observaciones, primero recelosa y tímida, más tarde atrevida, al fin despreocupada.
A peep, and then a long stare; and then a departure from my niche and a straying out into the meadow; and a sudden stop full in front of the great mansion, and a protracted, hardy gaze towards it.
"What affectation of diffidence was this at first?" they might have demanded; "what stupid regardlessness now?"
Y seguramente hubieran pensado: «¡Qué afectada desconfianza primero y qué necia confianza ahora!»
Hear an illustration, reader.
Esto, lector, tiene su explicación.
La ilustraré con un ejemplo:
A lover finds his mistress asleep on a mossy bank; he wishes to catch a glimpse of her fair face without waking her.
Un enamorado divisa a su amante dormida en el césped y desea contemplarla de cerca sin interrumpir su sueño.
He steals softly over the grass, careful to make no sound; he pauses--fancying she has stirred: he withdraws: not for worlds would he be seen.
Avanza, cauteloso; se para creyendo que ella se mueve; se retira, temiendo que la vea...

All is still: he again advances: he bends above her; a light veil rests on her features: he lifts it, bends lower; now his eyes anticipate the vision of beauty--warm, and blooming, and lovely, in rest.
Pero todo está tranquilo y entonces vuelve a avanzar.
Se inclina sobre ella lentamente, gozando de antemano con la visión de la belleza que va a admirar.
How hurried was their first glance!
But how they fix!
How he starts!
How he suddenly and vehemently clasps in both arms the form he dared not, a moment since, touch with his finger!
Y de pronto se sobresalta, se precipita, sujeta fuertemente entre sus brazos a la que un momento antes no osaba tocar con un dedo.
How he calls aloud a name, and drops his burden, and gazes on it wildly!
Pronuncia su nombre a gritos, la mira con desesperación.
He thus grasps and cries, and gazes, because he no longer fears to waken by any sound he can utter--by any movement he can make.
¡Porque ella no puede contestarle!
He thought his love slept sweetly: he finds she is stone dead.
El enamorado había creído dormida a su amada y la encuentra fría e inmóvil como una piedra.
I looked with timorous joy towards a stately house: I saw a blackened ruin.
Yo buscaba con temerosa alegría una majestuosa casa y encontraba una calcinada ruina.
No need to cower behind a gate-post, indeed!--to peep up at chamber lattices, fearing life was astir behind them!
No need to listen for doors opening--to fancy steps on the pavement or the gravel-walk!
Era innecesario ocultarme tras una columna, lanzar ojeadas a las ventanas, escuchar ruidos de puertas o de pasos en la explanada.
The lawn, the grounds were trodden and waste: the portal yawned void.
The front was, as I had once seen it in a dream, but a well-like wall, very high and very fragile-looking, perforated with paneless windows: no roof, no battlements, no chimneys--all had crashed in.
Porque la explanada estaba desierta y la fachada era, como ya la viera una vez en sueños, una sola pared, alta y frágil, agujereada por ventanas sin cristales, tras las que no quedaba nada.
No había techo, ni almenas, ni chimeneas.
Todo se hallaba destruido.
And there was the silence of death about it: the solitude of a lonesome wild.
En torno reinaba un silencio de muerte, una soledad de desierto.
No wonder that letters addressed to people here had never received an answer: as well despatch epistles to a vault in a church aisle.
Ya no extrañaba que mis cartas no obtuviesen respuesta, porque era como escribir a los quietos moradores de una tumba.
The grim blackness of the stones told by what fate the Hall had fallen--by conflagration: but how kindled?
Las ennegrecidas piedras del edificio decían cómo éste se había derrumbado: por un incendio.
Pero ¿cómo?
What story belonged to this disaster?
¿Cuál era la historia de aquella catástrofe?
What loss, besides mortar and marble and wood-work had followed upon it?
¿Qué pérdidas, además de las piedras, mármoles y maderas habían acontecido?
Had life been wrecked as well as property?
¿Había muerto alguno?
If so, whose?
¿Y quién?
Dreadful question: there was no one here to answer it--not even dumb sign, mute token.
Terrible pregunta a que no me cabía contestar...
In wandering round the shattered walls and through the devastated interior, I gathered evidence that the calamity was not of late occurrence.

Winter snows, I thought, had drifted through that void arch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the drenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherished vegetation: grass and weed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters.

Rondando en torno a los derribados muros, comprobé que el siniestro debía haber sucedido tiempo atrás, porque entre las ruinas brotaba ya una vegetación silvestre: hierbas y musgos que crecían entre las piedras y las vigas partidas.
And oh! where meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck?
¿Dónde estaba el desgraciado propietario de aquella ruina?
In what land?
Under what auspices?
¿En qué tierras y en qué estado se encontraba?
My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower near the gates, and I asked, "Is he with Damer de Rochester, sharing the shelter of his narrow marble house?"
Mis ojos se dirigieron hacia la no lejana iglesia y me pregunté si no yacería, con el antiguo Damer de Rochester, en su angosta morada de mármol.
Some answer must be had to these questions.
I could find it nowhere but at the inn, and thither, ere long, I returned.
Era preciso obtener respuesta a mis preguntas.
The host himself brought my breakfast into the parlour.
I requested him to shut the door and sit down: I had some questions to ask him.
Volví a la posada y cuando el posadero me trajo el desayuno le rogué que se sentase, cerrara y contestase a un asunto sobre el que deseaba interrogarle.
But when he complied, I scarcely knew how to begin; such horror had I of the possible answers.
And yet the spectacle of desolation I had just left prepared me in a measure for a tale of misery.
The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged man.
Pero casi no sabía cómo empezar, temiendo las contestaciones que iba a oír, a pesar de que la desolación de Thornfield me preparaba para los más funestos relatos.
"You know Thornfield Hall, of course?"
I managed to say at last.
-¿Conoce usted Thornfield Hall? -pregunté, al fin, al hostelero, hombre ya maduro, de buena apariencia.
"Yes, ma'am; I lived there once."
-Sí, señorita.
He vivido allí.
"Did you?"
Not in my time, I thought: you are a stranger to me.
-¿Sí? -y pensaba que ello no había sucedido en mi época, porque me era desconocido.
"I was the late Mr. Rochester's butler," he added.
-Fui el mayordomo del difunto Mr.
Rochester -añadió.
The late!
¡El difunto!
I seem to have received, with full force, the blow I had been trying to evade.
Al fin había recibido el golpe que tanto temía.
"The late!"
I gasped.
"Is he dead?"
-¿Ha muerto? -balbucí.
"I mean the present gentleman, Mr. Edward's father," he explained.
-Quiero decir el padre del actual Mr.
Rochester -exclamó.
I breathed again: my blood resumed its flow.
Respiré.
Estaba segura de que mi Edward vivía gracias a aquel breve, «el actual Mr.
Fully assured by these words that Mr. Edward--_my_ Mr. Rochester (God bless him, wherever he was!)--was at least alive: was, in short, "the present gentleman."
Rochester».
Puesto que él vivía, aún podría escuchar lo más terrible con tranquilidad relativa.
Gladdening words!
It seemed I could hear all that was to come--whatever the disclosures might be--with comparative tranquillity.
Since he was not in the grave, I could bear, I thought, to learn that he was at the Antipodes.
Ya que no estaba en la tumba, oiría con tranquilidad decir incluso que se hallaba en las antípodas.
"Is Mr. Rochester living at Thornfield Hall now?"
-¿Reside ahora Mr.
Rochester en Thornfield?
I asked, knowing, of course, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the direct question as to where he really was.
-pregunté, conociendo de antemano la respuesta, pero deseosa de aplazar lo posible las noticias que me dieran.
"No, ma'am--oh, no!
-No, señorita.
No one is living there.
Nadie vive allí.
I suppose you are a stranger in these parts, or you would have heard what happened last autumn,--Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: it was burnt down just about harvest-time.
Supongo que es usted forastera, puesto que no sabe lo que ocurrió el pasado otoño.
Thornfield Hall está en ruinas; fue destruido por un incendio.
A dreadful calamity! such an immense quantity of valuable property destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved.
¡Un desastre, porque apenas pudo salvarse nada!
The fire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from Millcote, the building was one mass of flame.
El incendio estalló de noche y antes de que llegasen las bombas de Millcote la casa era ya un inmenso brasero.
It was a terrible spectacle: I witnessed it myself."
"At dead of night!"
Fue un horrible espectáculo, se lo aseguró. -¡De noche! -murmuré.
I muttered.
Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality at Thornfield.
Era la hora en que sucedían todas las calamidades en Thornfield.
"Was it known how it originated?"
I demanded.
Añadí: -¿Se sabe cómo se produjo el incendio?
"They guessed, ma'am: they guessed.
-Se supone, señorita.
Indeed, I should say it was ascertained beyond a doubt.
O mejor dicho, se sabe con certeza.
You are not perhaps aware," he continued, edging his chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, "that there was a lady--a--a lunatic, kept in the house?"
Acaso ignora usted -prosiguió, acercando su silla a la mesa y hablando en voz baja- que en la casa había encerrada una señora que estaba... loca.
"I have heard something of it."
-Oí decir algo de eso.
"She was kept in very close confinement, ma'am: people even for some years was not absolutely certain of her existence.
No one saw her: they only knew by rumour that such a person was at the Hall; and who or what she was it was difficult to conjecture.
-La guardaban con riguroso secreto, así que durante muchos años la gente no estaba segura de que esa señora existiera, aunque se rumoreaba que sí.
Desde luego, no se sabía quién era.
They said Mr. Edward had brought her from abroad, and some believed she had been his mistress.
Se decía que Mr.
Edward la había traído del extranjero y se suponía que era su querida.
But a queer thing happened a year since--a very queer thing."
Pero hace un año sucedió una cosa extraña, muy extraña.
I feared now to hear my own story.
I endeavoured to recall him to the main fact.
Temiendo que me contase mi propia historia, insistí en lo principal:
"And this lady?"
-¿Y esa señora?
"This lady, ma'am," he answered, "turned out to be Mr. Rochester's wife!
-¡Esa señora resultó ser la esposa de Mr.
The discovery was brought about in the strangest way.
Rochester!
Se supo de un modo muy raro.
There was a young lady, a governess at the Hall, that Mr. Rochester fell in--"
Había en la casa una joven institutriz, y Mr.
Rochester...
"But the fire," I suggested.
-Bien, pero ¿y el incendio?
-Ahora, ahora.
"I'm coming to that, ma'am--that Mr. Edward fell in love with.
Mr.
Rochester se enamoró de ella.
The servants say they never saw anybody so much in love as he was: he was after her continually.
Los criados dicen que nunca han visto a nadie tan enamorado como él.
They used to watch him--servants will, you know, ma'am--and he set store on her past everything: for all, nobody but him thought her so very handsome.
Lo observaban, claro...
¡Ya sabe usted lo que es la servidumbre!
She was a little small thing, they say, almost like a child.
Ella era muy jovencita, casi una niña.
I never saw her myself; but I've heard Leah, the house-maid, tell of her.
Leah liked her well enough.
No la he visto nunca, pero Leah, que la apreciaba, me ha hablado con frecuencia de ella.
Mr.
Mr. Rochester was about forty, and this governess not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen of his age fall in love with girls, they are often like as if they were bewitched.
Rochester tenía unos cuarenta años y esa señorita menos de veinte, y cuando caballeros de esa edad se enamoran de muchachas, casi se atontan...
Well, he would marry her."
En fin; él quiso casarse con la joven...
"You shall tell me this part of the story another time," I said; "but now I have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire.
-Esa parte de la historia cuéntemela luego -dije-.
Ahora tengo especiales razones para enterarme de lo del incendio.
Was it suspected that this lunatic, Mrs. Rochester, had any hand in it?"
¿Se supone que la loca intervino en él?
"You've hit it, ma'am: it's quite certain that it was her, and nobody but her, that set it going.
-Es seguro, señorita, que ella y no otra persona fue quien lo causó.

She had a woman to take care of her called Mrs. Poole--an able woman in her line, and very trustworthy, but for one fault--a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons--she _kept a private bottle of gin by her_, and now and then took a drop over-much.
Tenía una mujer que la custodiaba, Grace Poole, una persona muy buena y muy escrupulosa.
Pero tenía un defecto común a niñeras y sirvientas de esa clase, y es que guardaba en su cuarto una botella de ginebra y apuraba frecuentes tragos.

It is excusable, for she had a hard life of it: but still it was dangerous; for when Mrs. Poole was fast asleep after the gin and water, the mad lady, who was as cunning as a witch, would take the keys out of her pocket, let herself out of her chamber, and go roaming about the house, doing any wild mischief that came into her head.

Es comprensible, porque llevaba una vida poco agradable y tenía que consolarse de algún modo, pero el caso es que, cuando Grace se dormía después de beber su ginebra con agua, la señora loca, que era astuta como una bruja, le sacaba las llaves del bolsillo y erraba por la casa haciendo todo el mal que se le venía a la cabeza.
They say she had nearly burnt her husband in his bed once: but I don't know about that.
Se dice que una noche incendió la cama de su marido, pero de eso no sé nada a punto fijo.

However, on this night, she set fire first to the hangings of the room next her own, and then she got down to a lower storey, and made her way to the chamber that had been the governess's--(she was like as if she knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at her)--and she kindled the bed there; but there was nobody sleeping in it, fortunately.

En fin, para acabar: una noche prendió fuego a los tapices del cuarto contiguo al suyo, y luego bajó al de la institutriz que estaba afortunadamente, vacío, porque la joven se había ido dos meses antes.
Mr.

The governess had run away two months before; and for all Mr. Rochester sought her as if she had been the most precious thing he had in the world, he never could hear a word of her; and he grew savage--quite savage on his disappointment: he never was a wild man, but he got dangerous after he lost her.
He would be alone, too.
Rochester la había buscado como si fuese la cosa más preciosa del mundo, pero no supo nada de ella.
Desde entonces, el disgusto le hizo huraño, casi salvaje.
Envió a Mrs.
He sent Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to her friends at a distance; but he did it handsomely, for he settled an annuity on her for life: and she deserved it--she was a very good woman.
Fairfax, su ama de llaves, con su familia, aunque portándose bien con ella, porque le señaló una pensión fija.
La Fairfax era muy buena mujer.
Miss Adele, a ward he had, was put to school.
Adèle, una niña que Mr.
Edward había recogido, fue enviada al colegio.
He broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and shut himself up like a hermit at the Hall."
Rompió toda relación con sus amigos y quedó en la sala como un ermitaño.
"What! did he not leave England?"
-¿No se fue de Inglaterra?
"Leave England?
-¡Bendito sea Dios!
No.
Bless you, no!
No salía de casa, excepto por las noches.

He would not cross the door-stones of the house, except at night, when he walked just like a ghost about the grounds and in the orchard as if he had lost his senses--which it is my opinion he had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener gentleman than he was before that midge of a governess crossed him, you never saw, ma'am.
Entonces erraba por el huerto como un alma en pena.
Parecía loco, y mi corazón es que lo estaba, porque nunca había sido así antes de que esa mosquita muerta la institutriz se cruzara en su camino.
He was not a man given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and he was not so very handsome; but he had a courage and a will of his own, if ever man had.
No bebía ni jugaba y, aunque no era un hombre gallardo, era tan cabal como el primero.
Yo le he tratado de niño.
I knew him from a boy, you see: and for my part, I have often wished that Miss Eyre had been sunk in the sea before she came to Thornfield Hall."
¡Figúrese si le conozco!
¡Ojalá esa Miss Eyre se hubiese ahogado en el mar antes de venir a Thornfield! -¿Estaba en casa Mr.
"Then Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?"
Rochester cuando se declaró el incendio?

"Yes, indeed was he; and he went up to the attics when all was burning above and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them down himself, and went back to get his mad wife out of her cell.
-Sí, estaba.
Subió en seguida al piso alto para despertar a los criados, y luego fue a sacar a la loca de su celda.

And then they called out to him that she was on the roof, where she was standing, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till they could hear her a mile off: I saw her and heard her with my own eyes.
Pero ella se hallaba en el tejado, en pie, agitando los brazos y gritando de un modo que se la oía en una milla a la redonda.
She was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see it streaming against the flames as she stood.
Yo mismo la vi y la oí.
Era una mujer corpulenta, de cabello negro, que flotaba iluminado por las llamas.
I witnessed, and several more witnessed, Mr. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the roof; we heard him call 'Bertha!'
Yo vi, y los demás vieron, a Mr.
Rochester subir al tejado y gritar: «¡Bertha!»
We saw him approach her; and then, ma'am, she yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute she lay smashed on the pavement."
Entonces ella dio un salto y se estrelló contra el suelo.
"Dead?"
-¿Murió?
"Dead!
-Murió.
Ay, dead as the stones on which her brains and blood were scattered."
Se rompió la cabeza contra las piedras de la explanada.
"Good God!"
-¡Dios mío!
"You may well say so, ma'am: it was frightful!"
He shuddered.
-Fue horrible, señorita.
"And afterwards?"
I urged.
-Y después, ¿qué pasó?
"Well, ma'am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are only some bits of walls standing now."
Después, señorita, la casa ardió hasta los cimientos, y no han quedado en pie más que algunos lienzos de pared.
"Were any other lives lost?"
-¿Hubo alguna víctima más?
"No--perhaps it would have been better if there had."
-No; pero hubiera valido más que la hubiese.
"What do you mean?"
-¿Por qué?
-¡Pobre Mr.
"Poor Mr. Edward!" he ejaculated, "I little thought ever to have seen it!
Edward! -exclamó el posadero-.
¡Quién me hubiera dicho que había de verle así!
Some say it was a just judgment on him for keeping his first marriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while he had one living: but I pity him, for my part."
Hay quien afirma que ha sido un justo castigo por mantener secreto su matrimonio y tratar de casarse con otra cuando su primera mujer vivía, pero yo le compadezco.
"You said he was alive?"
I exclaimed.
-Pero ¿vive? -insistí.
"Yes, yes: he is alive; but many think he had better be dead."
-Vive ¡Más le hubiera valido perder la vida!
"Why?
How?"
My blood was again running cold.
"Where is he?"
I demanded.
"Is he in England?"
-¿Qué le pasa?
¿Está en Inglaterra?
"Ay--ay--he's in England; he can't get out of England, I fancy--he's a fixture now."
-Está, está, y no creo que en el estado en que se halla pueda ir a sitio alguno.
What agony was this!
¡Qué tortura!
And the man seemed resolved to protract it.
¡Y aquel hombre parecía dispuesto a prolongarla!
"He is stone-blind," he said at last.
-Está ciego -dijo, al fin-.
"Yes, he is stone-blind, is Mr. Edward."
¡Ciego, el pobre Mr.
Edward!
I had dreaded worse.
I had dreaded he was mad.
Yo había temido algo peor aún: que estuviera loco.
I summoned strength to ask what had caused this calamity.
Haciendo un esfuerzo pude preguntar a mi interlocutor cómo había sucedido aquella desgracia.
"It was all his own courage, and a body may say, his kindness, in a way, ma'am: he wouldn't leave the house till every one else was out before him.
-Mr.
Rochester era valeroso; no quiso salir hasta que todos lo hubieran hecho.
As he came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs. Rochester had flung herself from the battlements, there was a great crash--all fell.
Cuando, después de la muerte de su esposa, bajaba la escalera, después que los demás, el edificio se derrumbó.
Se extrajo a Mr.

He was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly hurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him partly; but one eye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the surgeon, had to amputate it directly.
Rochester de las ruinas, vivo, pero mal herido.
Una viga había caído de modo que le protegió en parte.
The other eye inflamed: he lost the sight of that also.
Sin embargo, había perdido un ojo y tenía una mano tan estropeada que Mr.
Carter, el médico, hubo de amputársela inmediatamente.
He is now helpless, indeed--blind and a cripple."
Acabó perdiendo también la vista del otro ojo sano.
Así que ahora está ciego e inválido.
"Where is he?
-¿Dónde vive?
Where does he now live?"
"At Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm he has, about thirty miles off: quite a desolate spot."
-En Ferndean, una casa de campo que posee a treinta millas de aquí.
Un sitio desolado, solitario.
"Who is with him?"
-¿Quién le acompaña?
"Old John and his wife: he would have none else.
-El anciano John y su mujer.
Mr.
He is quite broken down, they say."
Edward está completamente aniquilado, según ellos dicen.
"Have you any sort of conveyance?"
-¿Tiene usted algún medio de transporte?
"We have a chaise, ma'am, a very handsome chaise."
-Sí, señora; una excelente silla de posta.
"Let it be got ready instantly; and if your post-boy can drive me to Ferndean before dark this day, I'll pay both you and him twice the hire you usually demand."
-Mande engancharla en seguida y si su cochero puede llevarme a Ferndean antes de que anochezca, les pagaré, a él y a usted, el doble de la tarifa habitual.
CHAPTER XXXVII
XXXVII
The manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity, moderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.
Ferndean era un edificio antiguo, de regular tamaño y sin pretensiones arquitectónicas, situado en el fondo de un bosque.
I had heard of it before.
Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and sometimes went there.
Rochester hablaba con frecuencia de aquella casa y la visitaba a veces.
His father had purchased the estate for the sake of the game covers.
Su padre la había dedicado a albergue de caza.
He would have let the house, but could find no tenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site.
Hubiese querido alquilarla, pero la insalubridad de su situación lo impedía.
Ferndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception of some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the squire when he went there in the season to shoot.
Por tanto, Ferndean permanecía deshabitada y desamueblada, con excepción de dos o tres habitaciones, utilizadas por su dueño cuando iba a cazar.
To this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the characteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating rain.
Llegué allí al caer de una tarde de cielo plomizo, viento frío y lluvia penetrante y continua.
The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise and driver with the double remuneration I had promised.
Recorrí a pie la última milla, después de despedir coche y cochero con la doble remuneración ofrecida.
Even when within a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing of it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it.
Aunque muy próxima a la casa, no la distinguía aún, tan espeso y sombrío era el bosque que la rodeaba.
Iron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and passing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of close-ranked trees.
Atravesando una verja entre dos columnas de granito, me encontré bajo la oscura bóveda que formaba el ramaje.
There was a grass-grown track descending the forest aisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches.
Un camino cubierto de hierba penetraba en el bosque entre intrincadas zarzas, bajo las apretadas ramas de los árboles.
I followed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on and on, it would far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was visible.
Lo seguí, esperando alcanzar pronto mi objetivo, pero a pesar de que avanzaba incesantemente, no veía por lado alguno señales de casa.
I thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way.
Temí haber tomado una dirección equivocada o haberme extraviado.
The darkness of natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me.
La oscuridad y la soledad del lugar me impresionaban.
I looked round in search of another road.
Miré en torno, en demanda de otro camino; no había ninguno.
There was none: all was interwoven stem, columnar trunk, dense summer foliage--no opening anywhere.
Sólo se distinguían gruesos troncos, espesos follajes y ningún claro.

I proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little; presently I beheld a railing, then the house--scarce, by this dim light, distinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying walls.
Continué.
Al fin el bosque se hizo menos denso y hallé una empalizada y tras ella la casa, apenas visible entre los árboles, tan cubiertos de verdín y humedad estaban sus ruinosos muros.
Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a space of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a semicircle.
Pasando un portillo me encontré en un espacio abierto, rodeado en semicírculo por el bosque.
There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad gravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of the forest.
No había flores ni césped; sólo un sendero enarenado rodeado de musgo.
The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the windows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one step led up to it.
Las ventanas de la casa eran enrejadas y angostas, y la fachada, estrecha y mezquina.
The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms had said, "quite a desolate spot."
Como me dijera el posadero, Ferndean era un desolado lugar.
It was as still as a church on a week-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound audible in its vicinage.
Reinaba el silencio, como en una iglesia inglesa un día no festivo.
El único rumor que se sentía era el de la lluvia.
"Can there be life here?"
I asked.
«¿Es posible viva alguien aquí?», me pregunté.
Yes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement--that narrow front-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the grange.
Sí; vivía alguien.
La puerta se abrió lentamente y una figura apareció sobre la escalera de acceso.
It opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the step; a man without a hat: he stretched forth his hand as if to feel whether it rained.
Extendió la mano como para comprobar si llovía.
Dusk as it was, I had recognised him--it was my master, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no other.
A pesar de la oscuridad, le reconocí.
Era mi amado Edward Fairfax Rochester en persona.
I stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him--to examine him, myself unseen, and alas! to him invisible.
Detuve mis pasos, contuve la respiración y le contemplé, ya que él, ¡ay!, no podía contemplarme.
It was a sudden meeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain.
En aquel encuentro el entusiasmo quedaba reprimido por la pena.
I had no difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from hasty advance.
No me fue difícil ahogar la exclamación que acudía a mi garganta, ni paralizar mi impulso de lanzarme hacia Edward.

His form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: his port was still erect, his hair was still raven black; nor were his features altered or sunk: not in one year's space, by any sorrow, could his athletic strength be quelled or his vigorous prime blighted.
Su figura tenía el porte erguido de siempre, su cabello seguía siendo negro y sus facciones no estaban nada alteradas por el transcurso de un año de penas, gracias a su constitución vigorosa.
But in his countenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding--that reminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous to approach in his sullen woe.
Y, sin embargo, se apreciaba un cambio en él.
The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes cruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.
Una fiera mutilada, un águila enjaulada a la que se hubiesen arrancado los ojos podrían dar una idea de la apariencia de aquel Sansón ciego.
And, reader, do you think I feared him in his blind ferocity?--if you do, you little know me.
Mas si imaginas, lector, que sentí temor de él, me conoces poco.
A soft hope blest with my sorrow that soon I should dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so sternly sealed beneath it: but not yet.
No; yo experimentaba la dulce esperanza de depositar un beso en aquella frente de roca y en aquellos labios ásperamente cerrados.
I would not accost him yet.
Pero no quería abordarle aún.
He descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards the grass-plat.
Descendió un escalón y avanzó, lento, hacia el sendero.
Where was his daring stride now?
Then he paused, as if he knew not which way to turn.
